DOC.HEAD: Car Bomb in Colombia Kills 16, Wounds At Least 73
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with four grafs to UPDATE with TV program saying police have evidence Pablo Escobar ordered the attack. Picks up 4th pvs, `National police...'
DOC.TEXT: A car bomb exploded on a busy highway in Medellin as a police anti-drug patrol was passing Wednesday, killing 16 people and wounding at least 73, authorities said. Ten vehicles and surrounding buildings were badly damaged, officials reported from that northern city, home of the notorious Medellin drug cartel. No one claimed responsibility, but drug traffickers have been killing police officers in Medellin in retaliation for the government's anti-drug campaign. In Bogota, the news program TV Hoy reported late Wednesday that according to senior police sources, the attack was ordered by Medellin cartel leader Pablo Escobar. The TV program quoted police as saying without elaborating that they had irrefutible evidence of Escobar's involvement. National police declared a state of alert late Wednesday. A communique by the Bogota headquarters said more attacks might be planned. Eight police and eight civilians were killed in the attack Wednesday, said Carlos Palacios, a spokesman for the government in the southern Medellin suburb of Itagui. The police officers attacked belonged to an elite unit charged with battling terrorism by drug traffickers and leftist guerrillas. The force has received training in Colombia from U.S. and British security personnel in recent months. There were conflicting reports of wounded. Radio reports placed the number at 109 while the police spokesman reported 73. The police spokesman, who refused to identify himself, said 60 civilians and 13 police officers were injured. Palacios said many of the wounded were in critical condition. He said children were among the victims. The bomb, packing 220 pounds of dynamite, targeted a police patrol traveling on the highway leading to Itagui, a Medellin police spokesman said. The police revised the amount of dynamite down from their initial report of 440 pounds. The chief of Medellin's fire department, Carlos Correa, said in a radio interview by the RCN network that the blast wrecked nine other vehicles along with the truck carrying police to their posts. The attack on a busy highway came as thousands of Colombians were driving out of the city to begin Holy Week vacations. Radio reports said the blast left a 7-foot-deep hole in the highway. ``Everyone here felt the blast,'' Palacios said in a radio interview from the Itagui municipal government offices near the site of the bombing. He said the blast ``caused the earth and nearby buildings to shake.'' In the port of Cartagena, President Virgilio Barco said he was ``sorry to receive such bad news.'' His brief comment was broadcast by RCN. Before Wednesday, gunmen working for the Medellin cartel had killed 19 police officers and a soldier in less than two weeks in Medellin, Colombia's second most populous city with 2 million residents. Authorities say the drug chiefs have offered to pay $4,300 for each police officer killed in the city, hub of Colombia's cocaine trade. The cartel claims that members detained by police in Medellin have been tortured and killed, a charge the government denies. On April 5, police defused a 1,650-pound dynamite bomb packed in a truck and abandoned on a main Bogota avenue. Police blamed the Medellin cartel for the truck bomb. The traffickers said in a communique Friday that they would step up their war against police and the country's political and business elite. The cartel pledged more bombings and killings in response to police's alleged torture and killing of traffickers. An earlier communique by the cartel threatened more attacks in retaliation for government refusal to abandon its policy of extraditing drug suspects. The Barco administration has sent 15 drug suspects to the United States for trial since intensifying a campaign against traffickers in August. More than 200 people have died in drug-related violence since the government launched the U.S.-backed campaign against cocaine cartels. The crackdown came after traffickers killed a leading presidential candidate. In December, traffickers exploded a 1,100-pound truck bomb at the secret police headquarters in Bogota, the capital. The blast killed 63 people. Also Wednesday, the Valle state government reported the bodies of 14 people kidnapped in a southwestern town were found in a river near Obando, about 185 miles west of Bogota. The victims had been kidnapped in Trujillo, 37 miles south of Obando on March 1, after an attack by a leftist guerrilla group on a military patrol. Six soldiers died in the attack by the National Liberation Army. The army blamed the rebel group for the kidnappings. But guerrillas said in a communique that a right-wing death squad was responsible. Many of the country's death squads are financed by drug traffickers.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department May Freeze Assets of Some S&Ls, Officers
DOC.TEXT: The Justice Department is considering freezing assets of savings and loans and S&L officers accused of fraud, but most of the cases already under investigation won't be affected. The authority to freeze the funds was included in last year's S&L bailout bill passed by Congress, Justice spokesman David Runkel said Tuesday. It became effective on Aug. 10. Because the bill is not retroactive, however, the fraud or other wrongdoing must have been committed after that date for assets to be frozen, Runkel said. Thus far, no ``appropriate cases'' have been found, since most of the cases being scrutinized by the Dallas Bank Fraud Task Force concern ``allegations of wrongdoing that go back several years,'' the spokesman said. Nevertheless, he said, a large number of cases remain under investigation. ``I can't tell you that this is going to lead to substantial sums being attached. But it's a possibility,'' Runkel said. ``And it's something we're looking at, exploring, for possible use.'' The freezing of assets would be done before a final court judgment is entered on criminal or civil cases and ``would prevent assets from being dissipated'' as the legal process is carried out, he said. ``We would have them, so that they would be available for recapture'' by the government after a verdict, he said. The announcement came about a month after a House subcommittee chairman said thousands of S&L fraud investigations were not being actively pursued for lack of money. The S&L legislation enacted in August authorized $75 million for pursuing bank and thrift embezzlement this year, but the administration sought and received only $49.2 million in actual appropriations from Congress, said Rep. Doug Barnard, D-Ga. He said 2,327 cases of financial institution fraud and embezzlement were inactive, meaning they were open but not being pursued. Of those, 1,298 are considered major cases involving losses of $100,000 or more, Barnard told his House Government Operations subcommittee on commerce, consumer and monetary affairs. Justice spokesman Doug Tillett said at the time, ``We are putting every penny ... to work on the problem.'' The slew of Texas S&L cases and the vast amount of money lost prompted the Justice Department to turn to the new method of gaining funds. Throughout the S&L scandal, the government has found that the assets have disappeared before they can be retrieved, Runkel said. ``Out of the Dallas bank task force, we've had $12.5 million in recovery. ... And the alleged illegal activities and the cost to the taxpayers has been substantially more than that, in the hundreds of millions of dollars, out of the Dallas cases alone,'' Runkel said. ``What happens is that the assets are not there following a conviction,'' he said. The Dallas task force has brought charges against 62 people, of whom 49 have been convicted, the Justice Department said. Criminal fines against the 49 total $574,850, and restitution orders total $11.9 million. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh met Tuesday with Timothy Ryan, who was sworn in Monday as the director of the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision. Representatives of the two will meet later this week ``to develop specific plans to ensure the most efficient use of the resources provided'' by Congress, Runkel said. The day before the announcement, the administration acknowledged that its $50 billion savings and loan bailout will not be enough. A congressional report has said costs could reach $500 billion if the economy falters. That estimate includes the government's borrowing expenses over 40 years.

DOC.HEAD: Air Space Over Seven Cities Gets Pilots' ``Black Star'' Rating
DOC.TEXT: Pilots are complaining about air safety conditions over seven U.S. cities, but the Federal Aviation Administration says test air traffic control rules have caused ``no accidents and no close calls.'' The Air Line Pilots Association announced Tuesday that air space over Charlotte, N.C.; Cleveland, Dallas-Fort Worth, Los Angeles, Memphis, Philadelphia and Phoenix has been added to the international ``black star'' list of airports and air space that could pose problems for pilots. Only one other U.S. site is among 24 locations on the list _ the Cyril E. King International Airport in St. Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands. Surrounding terrain requires special training and no night flights, according to pilot groups. ALPA announced the designations after the International Federation of Air Line Pilots Associations added the seven U.S. air spaces to its list. FAA spokesman Fred Farrar said the pilots' complaints arise from a test air traffic control procedure used since 1987 at the seven cities. In 20 other sectors over the busiest U.S. airports, controllers must maintain a separation of three miles between all aircraft. At the seven cities, Farrar said, controllers under limited circumstances need not comply with the set separation between aircraft as long as they are kept safely apart. ``In two years, there have been no accidents and no close calls,'' Farrar said. The new standard for the seven cities has been used in the vast air spaces between airports for six years, also without any accidents or close calls, he said. The procedure is only allowed during clear weather when one plane is flying by instruments and the pilot of the second plane is relying on what he sees out the window, Farrar said. ALPA said the ``black star'' designation does not indicate unsafe conditions but is viewed as ``a serious deficiency in our nation's aviation safety structure'' about which unfamiliar pilots should be warned. ``The added risks, coupled with the inability to measure any gains in efficiency, make this a highly questionable exercise by the FAA,'' said ALPA President Henry Duffy. He said the FAA benefits from the new system because it reduces the number of reportable operational errors, making the skies appear to be safer. No longer do all violations of the three-mile separation have to be reported, he said.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: Bush-Gorbachev Summit Likely to be One-Site Affair
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, weighted down by the crisis in Lithuania and other restive Soviet republics, is resisting proposals from President Bush for a multi-site U.S. summit, administration officials say. The Soviets have given a polite ``nyet'' to White House suggestions that part of the May 30-June 3 summit be held at Bush's oceanside vacation home in Kennebunkport, Maine, said officials who spoke on the condition of anonymity. Chances are that Gorbachev, who doesn't share Bush's love for ocean power boating, had his fill of waves and spray at their last meeting in December _ aboard the Soviet liner Maxim Gorki, tied up at Malta dock in a Mediterranean gale. Also not in the cards: a joint Bush-Gorbachev appearance at the May 31 commencement at West Point. Bush was scheduled to give the keynote address and speculation grew that he might show up with Gorbachev in tow. Administration officials said they have ruled out any such joint appearance and expect that Bush will have to cancel his own participation because of the summit. Lack of Soviet feedback on summit logistics is frustrating planning for the superpower meeting that begins seven weeks from today, the officials said. The upshot is that the summit probably will be held almost entirely in Washington, with a visit to the presidential retreat in Camp David, Md., likely to be the only side trip, the sources said. ``It's going to be a working visit; no time for sightseeing,'' Gennadi Gerasimov, the Soviet Foreign Ministry spokesman, said pointedly. Still, Bush has a record of conducting meetings with foreign leaders in picturesque _ or at least interesting _ places and taking them to sporting events. Malta is a hard locale to beat, at least in photogenic terms. But Bush plans another island session this weekend when he meets with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in Bermuda. He conferred with French President Francois Mitterrand last December on the French Caribbean island of St. Martin, and meets with him again later this month in Key Largo, Fla. He has also had Mitterrand to Kennebunkport. For his summit last month with Japan's Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, Bush selected a posh desert country club near Palm Springs, Calif. He also likes to take foreign leaders to baseball games, although the White House says there are no particular plans for a Bush-Gorbachev outing to the ballpark. Bush joined Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney on Tuesday evening for a game in the sprawling Toronto SkyDome. And a year ago, he took Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak to a Baltimore Orioles game. Mubarak had never seen a baseball game before and he seemed baffled. Of course, with Gorbachev, anything is possible. Just like Bush, he has a history of surprise moves at summits. For instance, the last time he was in Washington in December 1987 he abruptly stopped his motorcade several blocks from the White House, got out and greeted people on the street. Bush no doubt remembers that event all too well. Then-Vice President Bush was in an accompanying limousine and seemed at a loss to know what to do as Gorbachev worked the delighted crowd. He sat passively in his car for several minutes. Then, as Gorbachev was preparing to leave, Bush got out of his limo, stood by it and waved to the crowd. Gorbachev also maintained his own agenda while in Washington, meeting with various interest groups and members of Congress _ all without advance notice to the Reagan administration. White House officials are not ruling out such surprises at next month's summit _ either from Bush or from Gorbachev. However, spokesman Marlin Fitzwater suggests that some of the drama has left such summits because of the frequency of U.S.-Soviet summits in the six years since Gorbachev came to power and because of dramatic changes in the communist world. ``I think we've long since passed the point where you can only meet if you have a treaty to sign,'' he said.
EDITOR'S NOTE: Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Training of New Auditors Causes Lost Revenues
DOC.TEXT: An effort to boost tax collections by hiring more auditors is backfiring in the short run because senior agents who should be auditing returns are training new employees instead, a congressional study says. In just five of the 63 Internal Revenue Service districts, the General Accounting Office estimated, the diversion of auditors to train new agents will cost the government $980 million in lost taxes. If the other districts had similar experiences, the loss could hit $6.5 billion before the training begins to pay off. The GAO, an investigative arm of Congress, said the government lost more than $1 million in taxes over the short run for each new worker who completed a 26-month training course. The IRS conducted a similar study using different methods and came up with a lower figure for lost taxes. ``No matter whose methodology is used, the conclusion is the same: unrealized audit revenues associated with training new revenue agents have been substantial,'' wrote Jennie S. Stathis, tax policy director for the GAO. The GAO study covered agents who were hired between July 1, 1986, and Sept. 30, 1988, most of them as part of an effort by Congress to raise the number of tax returns that are audited. The audit rate has declined steadily for several years, from 150 per 10,000 returns in 1983 to an expected 92 per 10,000 this year. Ellen Murphy, IRS public affairs director, noted Tuesday that the IRS has been under a hiring freeze and has hired no new auditors over the past two years. ``We don't believe there will be future revenue losses from this training factor,'' Ms. Murphy said. ``When we resume hiring ... we will be doing a lot more of on-line training _ reserving intensive classroom training for contractors _ ... and having trainees go with experienced auditors to see how the job should be done.'' The $6.1 billion IRS budget that President Bush has proposed for fiscal 1991 would allow the agency to add 2,400 auditors to the 16,000 now on its staff. The GAO report indicated it will take as long as four years for an earlier effort to pay off. It will take that long for tax collections to rise enough to offset the costs of hiring new agents _ and the revenue lost by having them trained by senior auditors. Once an auditor is fully trained, however, the payoff for tax collections is significant. The GAO estimated that senior auditors in the IRS' Dallas office recommended additional taxes and penalties averaging $5,155 for each hour they spent auditing returns. The Los Angeles average was $4,572; Chicago, $3,777; Atlanta, $3,273, and San Francisco, $3,032. During the 1986-1988 period checked, the IRS hired 7,300 people for the job of revenue agent, whose chief task is to audit more complicated returns, including those filed by large corporations. The five offices that the GAO surveyed hired 1,103, or 15 percent, of that number. The study found that 69 percent of the training assignments for those new employees were carried out by agents who had been auditing returns at the time they were selected. As of last June 30, the use of auditors to train the 1,103 new workers had deprived the government of about $840 million in revenues that the interrupted audits would have produced, the GAO estimated. The total could rise to $980 million by the time all the new employees complete their training. Only 179 of the 1,103 new employees had completed all four phases of training, and the revenue loss was estimated at more than $1.04 million for each trainee who completed the course. The GAO said 848 of the 1,103 new hires were still with the IRS at that time.

DOC.HEAD: Chippewas Open Spearfishing Season Amid Taunts
DOC.TEXT: Anti-Indian taunts and posters greeted supporters of tribal treaty rights Tuesday night at a lake where a band of Chippewas prepared to open the tribal spearfishing season. An estimated 350 supporters and opponents of Chippewa spearfishing gathered at Cedar Lake in northwestern Wisconsin amid tight security. More than 100 law enforcement officials, including more than two dozen in riot gear, were at a boat landing at the lake. The lake was the only one the St. Croix Chippewas had said they would fish. Many other northern lakes remain covered by ice. When members of the American Indian Movement arrived beating a drum in support of Chippewa spearfishing, the crowd swelled around them and taunts were exchanged. ``Red, black and white, spearing ain't right,'' some said. ``Save the walleye, spear the Indian,'' one man shouted. Posters held by those in the crowd had such messages as: ``You have shamed every Native American that ever lived;'' ``Equal rights, not treaty rights;'' and ``Walleye or welfare, make a choice.'' Kevin Wakefield of Star Prairie said he came to the boat landing for the first time because Indian spearfishing must stop. ``They are spearing the walleye out of the lakes. It is just take, take, take,'' Wakefield said. Some AIM members photograped the crowd, which adults and children. It was not clear, however, if there had been any fishing. Polk County Sheriff Ben Ware said he understood one boat of spearers went out, but state spokesman Jeff Welch said he understood there had been no spearfishing. The St. Croix band, one of six Chippewa bands in Wisconsin, has been authorized to take 2,102 walleye from off-reservation lakes over the course of the spearfishing season that usually lasts three weeks, said tribal chairman Ed Bearheart. Before going to the lake, about 100 spearfishing supporters signed a pledge of peace and donned armbands, said Barb Kass of Luck, coordinator for the treaty support group Witnesses for Non-violence. About 25 representatives of the Minneapolis-based AIM, including founder Clyde Bellecourt, attended a rally at the St. Croix band's community center before heading to the lake. Since 1983, federal courts have upheld 19th century treaties giving the Chippewa the right to hunt, fish and harvest timber on off-reservation lands in the northern third of Wisconsin. Tensions between Chippewa spearers and non-Indian critics have grown each year since 1985, when the Indians renewed active spearfishing. A year ago, 271 spearers caught 16,000 walleye. Demonstrations last year opposing Indian spearfishing, mostly near the Lac du Flambeau Reservation, escalated into incidents involving rock-throwing and racial slurs. More than 200 people were arrested. State and tribal leaders have urged supporters and opponents of Indian spearfishing to stay away from boat landings this spring.

DOC.HEAD: Turtles March on CBS
DOC.TEXT: The hit ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'' will come out of their shells even more next fall when they join CBS' Saturday morning lineup. Judy Price, CBS' vice president for children's programs, announced Tuesday that the network bought rights to 26 original half-hour ``Turtles'' cartoon episodes, none of which have previously appeared in a separate 65-episode package syndicated last year to local TV stations for weekday broadcasts. The cartoon turtles are ``the hottest thing going now,'' Price said. A live-action movie version also is a box-office hit, grossing more than $50 million in only two weeks. Price said CBS signed an option for the shows last fall, and ``the movie has been the frosting on the cake.'' CBS' shows, produced by the same company that makes the syndicated version, will appear as a one-hour program, consisting of two half-hour episodes that complement each other's story lines, she said. Price said she was unconcerned that, with five weekdays of turtles on TV, their addition to CBS' Saturday schedule would eventually leave young viewers all turtled out. ``In fact, quite the opposite has happened,'' she said. She cited as an example CBS' ``Muppet Babies,'' which also is syndicated for weekday broadcast, and still is doing well in its sixth season on CBS. It's been shown that children prefer the familiar on TV, she said, while it's difficult to lure them to the new and different: ``The things that get sampled are the known things, the comfortable.'' The only other new series in CBS' Saturday schedule is ``Bill & Ted's Excellent Adventure.'' Based on the movie of the same name, the half-hour show is about two teen-agers traveling through time, aided by a hipster whose voice is that of comic George Carlin. CBS' turtles purchase had been expected by many in the TV industry. It came as CBS became the last of the networks to unveil its fall lineup for Saturday mornings, an increasingly competitive arena in broadcast and cable TV. Unlike NBC, which on Monday said it was dropping such old cartoon reliables as ``ALF'' and ``The Smurfs'' and bringing in the most live-action children's programming in its history, CBS' new schedule remains predominantly animated. CBS axed ``California Raisins,'' ``Dungeons and Dragons'' and ``The Adventures of Raggedy Ann and Andy,'' but is bringing back ``Garfield,'' ``Muppet Babies,'' ``Dink, The Little Dinosaur'' and ``CBS Storybreak.'' Its new schedule has only one live-action show, the partly animated ``Pee-Wee's Playhouse,'' a ratings success returning for a fifth season. Price said ``animation is the most tested and true form for Saturday mornings.'' ``One thing you have to remember: children are exposed to live action seven days a week,'' she added, asserting that contrary to commonly held beliefs, cartoons only account for ten percent of childrens' total TV viewing.

DOC.HEAD: Richards Beats Mattox in Texas Governor's Race
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ^LaserPhoto AT4
DOC.TEXT: State Treasurer Ann Richards defeated Attorney General Jim Mattox on Tuesday to claim the Democratic gubernatorial nomination after a down-and-dirty runoff that dwelled on allegations of drug use and dishonesty. Ms. Richards, who became the first woman in Texas to win either party's nomination since Democratic Gov. Miriam ``Ma'' Ferguson in 1932, will duel with Republican oilman-rancher Clayton Williams in November. ``I want you to rejoice and I want you to celebrate tonight because this is a fantastic win,'' Ms. Richards told cheering supporters at her Austin election night headquarters. But she said Democrats must unite quickly to defeat Williams. ``I want you to remember that there were other people in this primary who did not support our cause, who supported someone else and who felt strongly that they were doing the right thing. And it is time now that we reach out to them and tell them that we must be unified,'' she said. With 90 percent of the precincts reporting, Ms. Richards, the 1988 Democratic National Convention keynote speaker, had 571,742 votes, or 56.2 percent, to Mattox's 445,403, or 43.8 percent. Mattox's loss was his first since losing a 1966 bid for Democratic precinct chairman by three votes. ``I have never made a concession speech before in my life but tonight I feel I must,'' Mattox said, adding that he would work for the party in the fall. ``I want to send a sincere congratulations to Ann Richards. Tomorrow I will be ready to help her up and down the state against the common enemy and the common enemy is Clayton Williams. That's spelled with all dollars and no sense,'' he said. Ms. Richards and Mattox, 46, were the top two vote-getters in the March 13 primary.

The incumbent, Republican Gov. Bill Clements, 72, is not seeking re-election. Mattox's and Ms. Richards' mean-spirited runoff race, which included charges of drug use leveled against both candidates, wrapped up with each decrying the way the four-week battle unfolded. Ms. Richards accused Mattox of profiting from public service and challenged him to release his income tax returns. Mattox alleged that Ms. Richards, a recovering alcoholic, used illegal drugs, including cocaine, 10 years ago and challenged her to release medical records from her alcoholism treatment in 1980. The last week of the campaign brought newspaper reports that Mattox was seen smoking marijuana in the mid-1970s and that Ms. Richards was seen in a restroom where marijuana was allegedly being smoked in 1979. Both dismissed the reports. ``It's been a very unpleasant campaign. It hasn't been good for any of us,'' Ms. Richards said Monday. Ms. Richards, 56, won her first bid for public office when she was elected a Travis County commissioner in 1976. She went on to win two terms as state treasurer, in 1982 and 1986. Mattox won elections to the Texas House in 1972, to Congress in 1976, and as state attorney general in 1982. He won re-election in 1986. With both candidates considered liberal Democrats, there weren't many issues on which they disagreed, although Mattox tried to cast himself as the more conservative. Mattox made adoption of a state lottery his key issue, saying the game could generate $700 million or more a year without new taxes. Ms. Richards' said her campaign was for a ``New Texas,'' with improved education, the economy and the environment her top priorities.

DOC.HEAD: `Twin Peaks' Wins Time Period in Nielsen Ratings
DOC.TEXT: ABC's ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' maintained its viewer appeal in the latest Nielsen ratings and the second-place network's much-heralded premiere of ``Twin Peaks'' also scaled to lofty heights. The new nighttime soap opera that chronicles sex, violence, junk food and power in a small Washington state lumber town was the No. 5 show, according to the latest A.C. Nielsen Co. ratings released Tuesday. Back-to-back episodes of ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' pairing an original show with a repeat, ranked first and tied for second with NBC's ``Cheers.'' It's against ``Cheers'' that ``Twin Peaks'' must compete when the new show created by David Lynch assumes its regular time slot at 9 p.m. Thursday. The highly rated ``Cheers'' is part of NBC's blockbuster Thursday line-up that includes ``The Cosby Show,'' which ranked fourth for the week ended April 8, and ``A Different World,'' which placed seventh. The No. 6 slot belonged to Monday night's showdown between the University of Nevada-Las Vegas and Duke University for the college basketball crown. Although it hardly ranked as drama, with Las Vegas routing the Blue Devils 103-73, the matchup of straight-laced Duke and Jerry Tarkanian's glitter city rebels apparently enticed viewers. ``Carol & Co.,'' featuring Carol Burnett and an ensemble cast, was in 10th place after premiering two weeks ago on NBC. Mid-season replacements ``Bagdad Cafe,'' starring Whoopi Goldberg and Jean Stapleton on CBS and the highly publicized ``Equal Justice,'' on ABC, ranked 36th and 40th, respectively. For the week, NBC was back in first place with a 13.7 average, followed by ABC with 12.8, and CBS with 11.6. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. In the previous Nielsen poll, ABC's 3{-hour Oscar broadcast had helped to push NBC out of the top spot it had occupied for 23 weeks. The Top 10 shows, their network and rating: ``America's Funniest Home Videos,'' ABC, 22.3; ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' and ``Cheers,'' NBC, tied for second with 21.9; ``The Bill Cosby Show,'' NBC, 21.8; ``Twin Peaks,'' ABC, 21.7; NCAA Basketball Championship, CBS, 20; ``A Different World,'' NBC, 19.7; ``Unsolved Mysteries,'' NBC,18.6; ``Roseanne,'' ABC, 18.4 and ``Carol & Co., NBC, 17.5. Fox's Sunday night comedy block continued to pull in viewers, with ``The Simpsons'' ranking 31st with 13.2, and ``Married ... With Children'' snagging 21st place with 14.5. ABC's ``World News Tonight with Peter Jennings'' was the No. 1 network news show with a 10.2 in average ratings. ``NBC Nightly News'' and ``The CBS Evening News'' tied for second place with 8.9.

DOC.HEAD: Police, Elementary School Students Clash
DOC.TEXT: About 100 elementary school students protesting the firing of their principal clashed with stick-wielding police Tuesday, and several were injured, marking the second such incident this year, school officials said. Five students aged 11 to 13 suffered bruises and cuts in the incident in front of the Morrill Elementary School on the city's Southwest Side, officials at the school said. Several parents charged that officers used unnecessary force in breaking up the protest. Police spokeswoman Tina Vicini said no one was arrested and no student was seriously injured. Officers had been called to help school officials get the students back into the building, said Principal Eduardo Cadavid. ``I guess they thought we weren't going fast enough, so they hit a whole bunch of kids,'' said student Charity Kinney. School official Sharon Hayes said she went outside and noticed an officer with a stick. ``I told him I thought we could handle this without sticks,'' she said. ``He started screaming and hollering, and putting his stick in my face. He told me he knew what his job was.'' Teacher Margaret Scott said police came into her classroom and threatened students. She did not elaborate. ``My children were frightened to death,'' she said. For the past several weeks, students have been protesting the local school council's refusal to renew Cadavid's contract. Principal firings have stirred protests at other Chicago schools in recent months since the Chicago School Reform Act went into effect at the start of the year. It set up parent-led locals councils with authority to hire and fire. The other police-student clash occurred last month at Morgan Park High School, when several students were arrested.

DOC.HEAD: Do Turn That Dial _ Interactive Television Takes a Test Run
DOC.TEXT: Want to follow a pro around the golf course without leaving the living room? Join in a game show? For the next five weeks, television watchers in some southwestern Massachusetts households get to do just that as part of a national test of new ``interactive television'' technology. ``It gets the couch potato a half-step up off the couch,'' said Brian Lambert, general manager of Continental Cablevision, which is beaming the program to 300 subscribers. The development is part of long-promised changes for television, cable officials said. ``We keep hoping for these things. I think this is one of the neater presentations I've seen, frankly,'' said Wendell Bailey, vice president for science and technology at the National Cable Television Association. Interactive television has been around for some time, starting with a two-way television experiment Warner Amex Cable Communications Inc. tested in Ohio in 1981. What makes the Springfield tests different, cable officials said, is the level of technological reliability and viewer participation. ``Being able to manipulate that television, to be the director, to be able to select camera angles or answer questions or respond to certain criteria really adds a whole new dimension to watching television,'' Lambert said Tuesday, about three weeks into the eight-week test of the cable technology developed by ACTV Domestic Corp. of New York. The ACTV system is ``sort of multiple-choice TV,'' said Gary Arlen, publisher of the trade newsletter, Interactivity Report. Later this month when a live golf tournament is broadcast, ACTV viewers will be able to pick who they want to follow around the course, choosing from a list flashed up before play begins. Then, during the broadcast, the viewer can switch at any time to the camera trained on that player, said Steven Georgeou, of Geocom Consulting, a marketing consultant to ACTV. Viewers also will be able to punch up instant replays and statistical information on selected players. Tuesday morning, while watching the game show ``College All Stars,'' viewers at home were able to make their own choices. A correct answer brought congratulations from the host. When the viewer was wrong, the host commiserated. ``The whole purpose is to find out what people think of this kind of technology and what kind of programs do they want to see,'' Georgeou said.``We also want to understand how many times people want to push buttons.'' So far, consumers have responded positively to the free test, Lambert said. ACTV options are installed through a ``Smart Box,'' which is a little larger than the regular cable converter box. The cost of the service probably would be about $10 a month, Georgeou said. Whether ACTV becomes a regular fixture will depend on whether sponsors can be persuaded there is consumer demand for interactive television, cable officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 50 years ago, broadcaster Eric Sevareid saw Ronald Reagan on a Warner Bros. movie lot and immediately identified him as ``Mr. America.'' It was 1941, and as a reporter for then fledgling CBS News, Sevareid also met Warner Bros. stars like Gary Cooper and Marlene Dietrich. But Reagan most impressed him, Sevareid recalled Monday night in a speech at Central Missouri State University. ``You could see immediately he was the Eagle Scout, Mr. America,'' Sevareid said. In the White House, 40 years later, Reagan's appeal ``did prove to be almost irresistible for quite some time,'' Sevareid said, in remarks concerning the relationship between the presidency and the press. ``I think he did make most people feel better,'' although by his second term Reagan had nothing new to offer, Sevareid said. Sevareid's son, Michael, is an adjunct lecturer and graduate student at Central Missouri.

Ivana Trump's lawyers are asking court permission to question Marla Maples and dozens of Donald Trump's associates as they add another swirl to the Trump divorce potboiler. Her lawyers also are asking judge Phyllis Gangel-Jacob to force Trump to limit the documents he is demanding that his wife turn over in her lawsuit to invalidate the couple's postnuptial agreements. Among the items his lawyers have asked for are those relating to ``any threats made or undue influence practiced'' by Trump on his wife, all his wife's personal diaries since 1976 and all ``letters, memos, notes and greeting cards'' from him to her. Mrs. Trump's lawyers filed suit last month challenging Trump's claim that she waived her right to half his estimated $5 billion fortune in a series of postnuptial agreements, the last signed in 1987. She alleged in the court papers that Trump intimidated and ``verbally assaulted'' her and repeatedly cheated on her. She also charged her attorney for the agreements was chosen by Trump's lawyer at the time, the late Roy Cohn, and did not act in her best interests. Trump's attorneys say the agreement, which gives Mrs. Trump $10 million and their $12 million mansion in Greenwich, Conn., is ironclad. Mrs. Trump's spokesman, John Scanlon, said Tuesday that after Mrs. Trump gives her deposition, Trump will have to give his, and Mrs. Trump also will ask court permission to question 40 other people _ including Miss Maples, the woman with whom Trump has been linked. Jay Goldberg, one of Trump's attorneys, said the documents his client is seeking would ``demonstrate without question the infirmity of her claim.'' He dismissed her plans to call Miss Maples as posturing. The hearing on Mrs. Trump's motion is scheduled for May 1.

Dan Miller, who spent the past 15 months as Pat Sajak's announcer and late-night sidekick, says the canceled talk show just never found its identity. ``We tried to play it safe,'' said Miller, who was an anchorman at WSMV in Nashville when Sajak was a weatherman at the station from 1972 to 1975. ``It never found its own identity,'' Miller said this week. ``We were trying to take ourselves too seriously.'' There's no hard feelings toward Sajak, said Miller. ``I'm grateful to Pat. It was a nice opportunity, a nice challenge,'' he said. Miller, once an anchorman for KCBS-TV in Los Angeles, said he didn't know where his career would take him next.
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Last two items also moving on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: The maker of a bicycle computer agreed to stop using two-time Tour de France winner Greg LeMond's name, photograph or likeness in advertising without his approval. But the civil lawsuit filed against Avocet Inc. last month by LeMond remains in effect under the stipulation signed by both parties and approved Tuesday by U.S. District Judge Bruce Thompson. LeMond endorsed the Avocet cyclometer in 1989 for a $60,000 fee, but that contract ended last year and he didn't give his permission to continue using his image, according to his lawsuit. LeMond since has endorsed another bicycle computer. Michael Phillips, national sales manager for Avocet, based in Menlo Park, Calif., has said he doesn't know why the racer filed the lawsuit against his company because the ads in dispute depict several riders. Nathan Jenkins, who represents LeMond, said that although the picture shows LeMond with a group of other racers during the Tour de France, ``you can be assured that the American public will only recognize Greg LeMond.'' The Avocet cyclometer functions as an odometer, speedometer, stopwatch and clock, measuring things such as how fast and far a bicycle has traveled per trip or during an extended time period.

Former football star George Rogers was suspended from his 2-month-old job as a fund-raiser for the University of South Carolina after being arrested on cocaine charges. Rogers, 31, who graduated from the university in 1980, has worked since Feb. 3 as a fund-raiser for its College of Applied Professional Sciences, spokeswoman Debrah Allen said Tuesday. He was arrested Saturday for possession with intent to distribute cocaine and simple marijuana possession, along with Marcus Gilliam, 28, another former South Carolina football player, and Melvin Metz, 31. They three were released on $5,000 bonds. If convicted, each faces a maximum of five years in prison. Ed Holler, Rogers' attorney, refused to comment on the case. Rogers, the NFL Rookie of the Year in 1981, spent seven years in professional football. He was the first-round pick by the Saints in 1981 and played four seasons with New Orleans before being traded to Washington. A street is named after Rogers in Columbia, and his picture is painted in a mural on the wall of a building near the Statehouse.

DOC.HEAD: Polish-Born Heiress Opens Art Exhibit In Cultural Conservation Effort
DOC.TEXT: Barbara Piasecka-Johnson, who left Poland to seek her fortune and returned a U.S. multimillionaire, has opened an exhibit of extraordinary art from her private collection at Warsaw's Royal Palace. The Opus Sacrum exhibit of paintings, sculpture and other objects with religious themes is being held in support of the reforms that culminated in the installation of the East bloc's first non-Communist government last fall. Mrs. Johnson ``wanted to honor these changes in a special way _ by organizing a great cultural event of international significance,'' an introduction to the exhibit says. The Old Masters displayed include Renaissance and Baroque works by such painters as Titian, Caravaggio and Raphael. ``They are all my favorites,'' Mrs. Johnson said before guiding journalists through the exhibit. Proceeds from the sale of the catalogue and other publications from the exhibit will be donated to Polish cultural conservation efforts, especially in the historic southern city of Krakow, Mrs. Johnson said. Other Polish exhibits from her collection are planned. Mrs. Johnson inherited much of the Johnson & Johnson pharmaceutical fortune after the death of her husband, Seward Johnson, on whose household staff she had worked. She went through an ugly court battle with other Johnson heirs over her husband's will. Mrs. Johnson lives in Princeton, N.J., at her estate, Jasna Polana. She was hailed as a heroine at the Gdansk shipyard where Solidarity was founded after she offered last June to spend up to $100 million for an interest in the yard, which was threatened with liquidation by the then-Communist government. But the shipyard deal failed to materialize, apparently in part because workers would not agree to the terms she offered. Mrs. Johnson bristled when it was suggested Tuesday that she returned to Poland as an ``industrialist.'' ``That is the wrong idea that I come here as an industrialist. Saving monuments of Polish art and history is my purpose,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Pavarotti Look-Alike Opened in a Bowling Alley
LaserPhoto CX1
DOC.TEXT: Anatomy more than ability turned Larry Stidham, a blue-collar fan of hockey and Bruce Springsteen, into an impersonator of Luciano Pavarotti. Until a few years ago the 43-year-old plumber knew little about opera. ``Who is he?'' Stidham wondered, when his friends mentioned his resemblance to the rotund tenor. But friends insisted he capitalize on the look. His 215 pounds were no match for the comfortably cushioned Pavarotti, so Stidham began expanding, to his present 270. And he has the trademark Pavarotti sparkle in his eyes. With the stage name ``Bearvarotti,'' Stidham dons a tuxedo and white tie to plays weddings, balls and parties. Some describe his voice as ``a howling wolf,'' but he gets rave reviews. ``I even had people break into tears,'' Stidham said Tuesday. There are some differences in his and Pavarotti's careers. Pavarotti made his opera debut in 1961 in ``La Boheme.'' Stidham opened in 1984 in a suburban Algonquin bowling alley. Also unlike Pavarotti, who has been banned from the Chicago Lyric Opera because of numerous no-shows, ``I don't cancel,'' Stidham said. In his debut, a lip-sync contest, Stidham mouthed the words to ``If We Were in Love'' from Pavarotti's movie, ``Yes, Giorgio.'' He placed third, but he was hooked. He bought opera recordings and studied the Italian lyrics syllable by syllable. He watched Pavarotti on TV, trying to pick up his style. Soon, Stidham was doing events with other Chicago area star look-alikes _ a false Sammy Davis Jr., a mock Willie Nelson, a bogus Joan Collins. Stidham even dated a Crystal Gayle look-alike. ``My agent is a guy that looks like Henry Fonda,'' Stidham noted, ``and I got another agent that's a Charlie Chaplin double.'' Bearvarotti met Pavarotti once back-stage after a 1986 appearance by the opera singer at Chicago's Civic Opera House. The two men swapped autographs.

DOC.HEAD: Men Close the Population Gap With Women
DOC.TEXT: Even as women make gains in jobs and pay, their lead is slipping in two areas where they traditionally are ahead of men: how many there are and how long they live. Women still outlive and outnumber men in America, but improving life expectancy rates for males allowed their total number to increase faster than women during the 1980s for the first time since early in this century, the Census Bureau said Tuesday. ``Male life expectancy has continued to improve gradually during the decade. Female life expectancy has improved very little since 1982,'' said Frederick W. Hollmann of the Census Bureau. Life expectancy for men increased from 70.9 years in 1982 to 71.5 years in 1987, an improvement of six-tenths of a year, he noted. During the same time, life expectancy for women went up only one-tenth of a year, from 78.2 to 78.3. The reason is that men's death rates for such major killers as cancer and heart disease dropped during the decade, while the cancer rate for women increased and deaths from heart disease only edged down. ``The male population outgrew the female population in every age group under age 85,'' Hollmann reported. From 1980 to 1989 the number of men in the nation increased by 10,557,000, while the female population grew by 10,448,000, the bureau reported. Even so, women continue to outnumber men in America, 127 million to 121 million, the report showed. The last decade in which the number of men increased faster than women was 1900-1910, the Census Bureau noted. The balance of population is determined not only by the number of people born but by the number of years they remain alive, explained Hollmann. More male babies are born than females, he pointed out, but ``generally a sort of equilibrium is reached since males don't live as long as females.'' The higher death rate for men means that although they outnumber women at birth, women surpass men in total numbers later on. One consequence of males increasing faster than females in the 1980s was that in 1989 there were more men than women at each age group below 34. In 1980 men had been more numerous only through age 26, Hollmann reported. Hollmann said a major contributor to the males outpacing females in the 1980s was the changing patterns of disease as more and more women took up smoking and moved into traditionally male-dominated jobs and lifestyles. ``You could suggest that a lot of women took up smoking back in the 1960s, so the difference between men and women in smoking behavior tended to converge somewhat,'' said Hollmann. ``If behavior (between the sexes) is converging, then you have to expect mortality rates to converge also. ``There is a time lag between the time someone takes up smoking and the time they come to highest risk of death,'' he said, accounting for the change in comparative death rates in the 1980s. Between 1982 and 1986, for example, the cancer death rate for males declined from 164.8 deaths per 100,000 men to 163.6. For women the rate increased from 109.5 to 111.4. For heart disease, the death rate for men declined from 264.4 per 100,000 to 238.2. Women had a smaller decline, from 132.5 to 124.6. And deaths from cerebrovascular disease fell from 39.2 to 33.5 per 100,000 men from 1982 to 1986, while for women the drop was from 33.2 to 29.0, also a smaller decline than for men. The census study used mortality data from the National Center for Health Statistics, a division of the Department of Health and Human Services. While the study did not include a breakdown by sex for immigration, Hollmann said that also was a contributing factor to the increase in males, since refugees coming into the country tended to include somewhat more males than females during the 1980s.

DOC.HEAD: Demand Puts Pressure on Corn, Soybeans Supplies
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. supply of corn and soybeans has tightened because demand has been larger than expected, according to a new analysis by the Agriculture Department. The new supply-and-demand outlook reflected recent figures showing that March 1 corn and soybean inventories were smaller than expected. Thus, Sept. 1 corn inventories are expected to be about 1.33 billion bushels, down from 1.48 billion forecast a month ago. Reduced U.S. stockpiles are also having an effect on global use and supplies of the major grain, the report said. Last Sept. 1, the U.S. corn stockpile was 1.93 billion bushels, reduced sharply by low yields caused by the 1988 drought. On Sept. 1, 1988, the corn inventory was 4.26 billion bushels. Corn prices nationally are expected to average $2.30 to $2.40 per bushel this marketing year, up five cents from the March forecast but still well below the $2.54 average of the 1988-89 marketing year. In 1987-88, before the effects of the drought, corn prices averaged $1.94 per bushel, the report said. On the international level, the report said global trade in corn and other ``coarse'' grains is expected to be down slightly from the March forecast, while world production is ``largely unchanged.'' Global stockpiles of coarse grain _ which include corn, sorghum, barley, oats, rye, millet and mixed grains _ are expected to be down from last month's forecast to their lowest level since 1983-84 because of the reduced U.S. inventory. Soybean inventories going into the new marketing year on Sept. 1 were put at 305 million bushels, down from the March forecast of 330 million. However, that would be up from 182 million bushels of soybeans on hand last Sept. 1. The Sept. 1, 1988 soybean stockpile was 302 million bushels. Marketing year prices averaged $5.88 per bushel in 1987-88 before soaring to $7.42 in 1988-89. With larger production and smaller demand, soybean prices are expected to average in the range of $5.55 to $5.65 this marketing year, unchanged from the March forecast. Global production of oilseeds, which includes soybeans, was forecast at a record 213.2 million metric tons, down slightly from last month but 5 percent more than last year. The report showed little change in the wheat supply and demand for the 1989-90 marketing year that began last June 1. Wheat stockpiles are expected to be about 442 million bushels this June 1, virtually the same as forecast last month. That would compare with 702 million bushels on hand last June 1 and 1.26 billion bushels on June 1, 1988. Nationally, wheat prices were forecast at $3.70 to $3.75 per bushel this marketing year, down a nickel at the upper end of the range, compared with $3.72 in 1988-89 and $2.57 in 1987-88.

The Agriculture Department says the Soviet Union has bought an additional 125,000 metric tons of U.S. wheat at subsidized prices for delivery through mid-May. The sale, according to USDA records, was the first since Jan. 19, when the Soviet Union's authority for buying U.S. subsidized wheat was virtually exhausted. A new allocation of 1 million tons was announced Feb. 23; about 12,950 tons were left over from a previous allocation. F. Paul Dickerson, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said Tuesday the wheat was sold by three private companies, which will receive subsidies under the department's Export Enhancement Program, or EEP. Dickerson said 887,950 tons of wheat remain in the Soviet Union's current EEP allocation. Only wheat has been approved for sale to the Soviets under the price subsidy program. The seventh year of the U.S.-Soviet grain agreement began Oct. 1. With the latest sales, the Soviet Union has bought more than 2.9 million tons of wheat for 1989-90 delivery and more than 12.7 million tons of corn, plus soybeans and soybean meal. All of the wheat was sold under EEP arrangements. A metric ton is about 2,205 pounds and is equal to 36.7 bushels of wheat. The 125,000 tons are equal to almost 4.6 million bushels worth about $19 million at recent U.S. farm prices. Dickerson reported the subsidies at an average of $31.53 per ton, or about 86 cents per bushel. The EEP arrangement allows private exporters to sell wheat and other designated commodities to specified countries at reduced prices to meet foreign competition. The exporters then collect free government surpluses of grain or other products as bonuses, or subsidies. Dickerson said the latest wheat was sold by J. Aron & Co., 50,000 tons; Union Equity Cooperative Exchange, 50,000 tons; and Mitsubishi International, 25,000 tons.

Orange harvest prospects are virtually unchanged from last month, according to new estimates by the Agriculture Department. Production as of April 1 was forecast Tuesday at 172 million boxes, down 18 percent from 209 million boxes last season, primarily because of a freeze in December. Most of the reduction was attributed to a 30 percent decline in the Florida crop, estimated at 103.1 million boxes against 146.6 million in 1988-89. The Texas crop was indicated at 1.2 million boxes, down from 1.85 million in 1988-89. California production, estimated at 66 million boxes, is up from 58.8 million last season, while the Arizona harvest was indicated at 1.9 million boxes, up from 1.7 million last season. Total grapefruit production was forecast at 48.6 million boxes, down 30 percent from last year, reflecting the freeze in Florida and Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Nuclear Plant Workers Exposed to Radiation, Group Says
DOC.TEXT: Workers at the nation's nuclear power plants are exposed to intolerably high levels of radiation, a consumer group says. It said some agency other than the Nuclear Regulatory Commission _ perhaps the Department of Health and Human Services _ should set the level. Power plant employees are exposed to average radiation equal to roughly 20 chest X-rays a year more than the what the general public is exposed to, said Ken Bossong, executive director of an energy research project of Public Citizen, a consumer advocacy group. Public Citizen released a study Tuesday showing more nuclear power plant workers than ever before were exposed to measurable radiation in 1988, albeit at a larger number of plants than ever before. The study found 105,265 instances of worker exposure to measurable radiation at the 107 commercial nuclear reactors in 1988. ``This is the highest number of incidents of worker exposure ever recorded by the U.S. commercial nuclear power industry,'' the organization said. It said its study, based on documents from the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, found 104,511 such incidents in 1987 and 100,992 in 1986. The industry-sponsored Council of Energy Awareness, in a written response to the report, said that ``the total number of exposed individuals increased only because, according to Public Citizen's figures, there were 10 more nuclear energy plants in operation than the year before.'' Actually, Public Citizen said there were nine more plants. In any case, the industry group pointed out that Public Citizen's own numbers show that ``in 1988, the year on which they report, the number of workers per plant who were exposed to any measurable radiation decline to an all-time low, down 22 percent in the five-year period, 1984-1988.'' Public Citizen ``has proven once again that they don't let the facts stand in the way of their determined anti-nuclear diatribe,'' the statement said. There were 98 plants operating in 1987, nine fewer than in 1988. Public Citizen's report acknowledged a decrease in the average collective radiation dose of each reactor's work force. It also said the average number of workers exposed per plant and the average dose of exposure had gone down by 7 percent between 1987 and 1988. Experts on both sides agree that the greatest exposure to workers comes during reactor maintenance work, mostly on older reactors. ``Clearly when you have older plants you do have maintenance more often,'' said Joseph Fouchard, a spokesman for the NRC. But he added, ``With respect to worker exposure to radiation at nuclear power plants we believe it has been steadily improving. We believe the situation is getting better.'' Public Citizen said the United States eventually should stop using nuclear power, but suggested that as long as the plants continue to operate the NRC should lower the limits of worker radiation exposure. The current NRC radiation exposure limit is 5.00 rems per year per worker, with 2.4 times that much permitted for workers whose jobs keep them close to the reactor. The accepted limit for the general population is 500 millirems or one-tenth the amount for nuclear plant workers, the group said. Public Citizen suggested having the exposure standards set by another government agency, possibly the Department of Health and Human Services. The group also criticized the lack of a centralized government repository for information on the health status of nuclear power plant workers.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Nuclear Workers
DOC.TEXT: Here is the list of the 20 nuclear reactors which the consumer group Public Citizen says were worst at exposing workers to radiation in 1988. The group said it considered the number of exposed workers, the collective radiation dose to the work force and other factors. Each reactor is listed with its total number of worker exposures to radiation for 1988, followed by the average exposure per worker, expressed in rem. Federal regulations permit a plant worker to be exposed to 5.0 rem per year _ about five times the highest level reported. Public Citizen said the average exposure in 1988 was 0.390 rem, about the equivalent of 20 chest X-rays. Regulations permit employees who work in closer contact with the reactor 2.4 times more exposure per year _ a total of 12 rems of which no more than 3 rems may be absorbed in any one quarter. However, Public Citizen chose only to use the figure for workers not in close proximity to the reactors. DOC.HEAD: Environmental Study Ranks South Last
DOC.TEXT: New England is leading the way in environmental health, while the South has become the nation's biggest waste dump, according to an environmental scorecard of the 50 states. The ``green index,'' a report released this week by the Durham-based Institute for Southern Studies, examined 35 indicators of pollution, public health, workplace safety and environmental safety. The top five states were Vermont, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Rhode Island and Connecticut. Alabama was at the bottom, with six of its Southern neighbors. George Hamilton, state planning director in Vermont, said the ranking ``reflects the environmental policies that have been passed over the last number of years. There is a strong environmental ethic in the state. It's a bipartisan ethic that has been around for 20 years.'' But Ned Farquhar, acting director of the Vermont Natural Resources Council, said he was surprised that Vermont ranked No. 1. ``Our laws aren't that strong and our budget is pitifully low for environmental protection,'' Farquhar said. ``But the people in our towns all care a lot about the environment so I really think it all comes back to individual action.'' The study ranked the 50 states on a per capita basis and other factors that would minimize differences in population size. The report was based on studies conducted in the mid- to late 1980s, most of them conducted for the federal government, said Bob Hall, research director for the non-profit, independent institute and the study's author. The study focused on the South and concluded that the region has become the nation's biggest waste dump, handling two-thirds of the nation's hazardous waste. The bottom five states were Tennessee, South Carolina, Louisiana, Mississippi and Alabama. Hall said Alabama brought up the rear because of ``a combination of having some significant problems and not having policies, being slow in implementing good policies.'' Environmental officials in Alabama do not have enough information to judge the report, said Catherine Lamar, a spokeswoman with the Alabama Department of Environmental Management. But Pat Byington, executive director of the Alabama Conservancy, a statewide environmental organization, said he was not surprised by the state's last-place finish. ``The state of Alabama has a lot of programs they need to institute, environmental programs,'' he said. ``We do not have a worker right-to-know law, we do not have a land acquisition program or a toxics reduction program _ a pollution prevention program. And we currently do not have a comprehensive solid-waste program, so we're far behind.'' The Northeast and Great Lake states fared poorly on the institute's poison index, which includes standard measures such as pollutants, air quality and per capita number of Superfund sites. But Hall said many of these states have taken aggressive action to solve their problems. Their high scores for policies, public health and workplace safety initiative boost their overall rankings. Most Mountain States ``score poorly in all areas related to government initiative, holding fast to the frontier belief that the less regulation, the better,'' said the report.

DOC.HEAD: Rural Residents Shy Away From Getting Emotional Help
DOC.TEXT: Facing the prospect of losing their 104-year-old dairy farm, Albert and Carol Kobbermann became so battered emotionally that they considered seeking counseling. But they didn't take the 30-mile trip from their farmstead to the clinic in Willmar because they feared their neighbors' prying eyes. ``When you're hit point-blank with a problem, it's what other people think that you worry about, not what's best for yourself,'' Carol Kobbermann said as she recalled her family's feelings during the farm crisis five years ago.``It's difficult to admit that things are out of control. You feel like a failure.'' The stigma of seeking help is one of several difficulties in rural mental health care that are to be the subjectd at a public hearing Thursday in Marshall, in southwest Minnesota. It's the first of four hearings planned this year by the National Advisory Mental Health Council and the National Mental Health Leadership Forum. ``The biggest problem that we face in rural areas is, first, a culture that says there aren't emotional problems in our part of the country, and, second of all, if there are, we don't admit it,'' said Rep. Vin Weber, R-Minn., who will speak at the hearing. ``The extreme financial stress brought a lot of those problems out into the open. Then we had to say, `Hey, we really have problems with teen-age suicide, spousal abuse, depression and other mental and emotional disorders,''' he said. P. Vincent Mehmel, executive director of the West Central Community Services Center in Willmar, said the center is busiest during the hard financial times. ``Farmers who have lost their crop or who have suffered a significant loss, depression is there,'' Mehmel said. ``We're also subject to the problem of unstable families. We once thought (divorce and child and spouse abuse) was an urban problem. Now it's a rural problem, too.'' Statistics show the effect of hard times on mental health in the six-county area, with 120,000 residents, that Mehmel's center serves. Medical Assistance reimbursements for mental health care made to Meeker County residents in 1986 _ at the peak of the farm crisis _ had increased 90.7 percent over the figure reported two years earlier. The figures increased 66.9 percent in Swift County and 45.4 percent in Chippewa County. Mehmel also deals with the difficulties of recruiting psychologists to rural settings, where the money, prestige and cultural amenities don't match those of metropolitan areas. ``It's hard to get them, and when you do get them, they move on in a few years,'' he said. ``To get a stable staff is a very difficult thing.'' About 5,500 patients visit the center's 30 mental health professionals annually. No one knows how many are afraid to seek help. ``The major problem is the mindset that it's not OK to get help for mental problems,'' said Marlyn Benson, the center's rural outreach coordinator. ``You're supposed to be tough and strong, pull yourself up by your bootstraps, don't cry and ask for help. ``It's easier in a metro area to get help and not have your neighbors know. People really know your business out here,'' said Benson, who tells of people so embarrassed about visiting the center that they park at a shopping mall and walk a quarter-mile to their appointment. The Kobbermanns learned to cope with their stress and depression when meetings they organized to discuss the farm crisis turned into impromptu, neighbor-to-neighbor counseling sessions. Later, mental health professionals were invited to speak to the group. The Kobbermanns feel more secure financially then they did a few years ago. But if the bad old days return, Kobbermann believes she'll cope better than she did a few years ago. ``I'm beyond the point of `What the neighbors think,''' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Case Pits Medical Progress Against A Man's Right to His Cells
DOC.TEXT: A landmark biotechnology case is in the hands of California's Supreme Court, which will decide whether a leukemia patient can sue for a share of the profits from an anti-cancer drug derived from his cells. The high court heard arguments Tuesday in the case of John Moore, who claims blood cells from his cancerous spleen were wrongfully used by the University of California, two UCLA researchers and two drug and biotechnology companies that helped develop the drug. University attorney Allen Wagner and lawyers for other defendants argued that the development of lifesaving drugs will be seriously impeded if the justices rule that Moore has property rights to tissue and cells removed from his body. They said that would require researchers to negotiate and pay for human tissue used for research and drug development. A decision in Moore's favor would have ``a devastating impact on medical research,'' said Peter Abrahams, lawyer for defendant Shirley Quan, a research assistant at UCLA. Moore, the 45-year-old president of a Seattle soft drink company, said he is merely trying to defend ``the rights of the individual patient in the case where the physician-researcher is also a businessman-entrepreneur.'' ``Without my knowledge or consent, the doctors and the research institutions used a part of me for their own gain,'' Moore said outside court. ``They stole something from me.'' The high court's ruling is expected within 90 days. A ruling in Moore's favor would allow his 1984 lawsuit to go to trial. The case was dismissed by a Los Angeles Superior Court in 1986, then reinstated in 1988 by a 2-1 vote of a state appeals court. During Tuesday's 70-minute hearing, the seven justices asked questions that suggested sympathy with Moore's claim, but indicated a reluctance to extend personal property rights to cells taken from an organ after it is surgically removed. Moore was an Alaska pipeline surveyor in 1976 when he sought treatment for hairy cell leukemia at UCLA. Dr. David Golde removed Moore's spleen, the standard treatment for the rare leukemia, and his disease went into remission. After the spleen was removed, Golde discovered it contained unique blood cells that produced a blood protein called GM-CSF, now in experimental use as a drug to stimulate the immune system to fight certain cancers and possibly AIDS. Moore's attorney, Sanford Gage, said Moore never was told his cells had great potential value. Yet for nearly seven years, Golde and others brought Moore from Seattle to Los Angeles for blood and other tests while they developed Moore's cells into a self-perpetuating cell line to mass-produce GM-CSF. In 1984, UCLA received a patent for the cell line, naming Golde and Quan as the inventors. The same year, Moore sued University of California regents, Golde, Quan, Genetics Institute Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., and Sandoz Pharmaceuticals Corp. of East Hanover, N.J. The lawsuit claimed the defendants wrongfully ``converted'' to their own use Moore's personal property, namely, blood cells from his spleen. He also alleged they failed to obtain his informed consent and breached their fiduciary responsibility to him. Golde's attorney, Anthony Murray, argued that Moore's diseased spleen was worthless, and Golde and other defendants gave commercial value to the blood cells through their own efforts. ``It's not as if you tap a tree and take maple syrup out of it, put the maple syrup in a bottle and sell it,'' Murray said. ``Diseased tissue has no commercial value.'' Gage replied that Moore's cells were vital to creating the cell line and the drug. Moore is seeking only that share of drug proceeds that can be separated from the efforts of the researchers and manufacturers of the drug. Gage has argued that the market for lymphokines, a family of drugs that includes GM-CSF, has been estimated at as much as $3 billion. He said deals that led to GM-CSF's development and production resulted in Golde and others getting Genetics Institute stock now worth $3 million. UCLA and Golde also received research grants worth $440,000 from Genetics Institute and Sandoz, Gage added. ``The doctors were interested in commercial exploitation, yet they did not reveal that to him,'' Justice Stanley Mosk said. ``Wasn't there an element of deception?'' But Justice David Eagleson said that if Moore's claim is upheld, any patient treated with drugs derived from his cells might be accused of illegally converting Moore's property.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Awards First Medal of Valor
DOC.TEXT: Edmundo Mireles Jr., an FBI agent who was wounded in a Miami shootout and later joined a class-action lawsuit accusing the bureau of discrimination against Hispanics, is winner of the agency's first Medal of Valor. Mireles and fellow agents were involved in a shootout outside Miami on April 11, 1986, when they tried to follow a car carrying two men they suspected were involved in a series of violent bank robberies. ``Special agent Mireles found himself face to face with his moment of truth,'' FBI Director William Sessions said at the award ceremony Tuesday. ``His fellow agents were down. He himself was severely wounded. ``Yet in the face of appalling gunfire, he found the courage and the stamina to return fire and fatally wounded both Michael Lee Platt and William Russell Matix,'' Sessions said. The Medal of Valor is given for ``exceptional acts of heroism in the face of life-threatening situations.'' Mireles accepted the award in part in the memory of the two agents slain that day _ Benjamin Grogan and Jerry Dove _ and gave special recognition to two other agents who helped him survive. ``Gilbert Orantia and Ron Riesner ... saved my life on that day.'' Mireles, 36, took a year to recover from his wounds, which shattered one arm. A federal judge in Texas, ruling last year on the 1988 class-action lawsuit filed by 311 Hispanic agents, found there was pervasive discrimination against Hispanic FBI agents and ordered the bureau to take steps to promote Hispanics.
DOC.HEAD: Census Response Reaches 50 Percent
DOC.TEXT: The Census Bureau says at least half the people asked to fill out census forms have done so. ``We expect the number to grow,'' spokeswoman Paulette Lichtman-Panzer said Tuesday. She said the 50 percent response rate counted only forms that have been ``logged in'' by census offices across the nation and that many places have a backlog of returns waiting to be checked. The Bureau mailed out 88 million forms on March 23 and hand delivered an additional 11 million to homes where proper mailing addresses could not be obtained. In addition, census takers are working with postal officials to correct problems in several communities where forms could not be delivered for one reason or another, officials said. ``If anyone has put off answering the census, now's the time to do so,'' said Lichtman-Panzer, stressing the need to increase the mail response rate. Census officials have told Congress that they hope for a 70 percent response rate. Census offices will begin sending out workers April 26 to homes where no form has been sent back, said Lichtman-Panzer.
DOC.HEAD: Nunn Resigns From All-Male Club In Suburban Washington
DOC.TEXT: In a move bound to fuel speculation about his presidential ambitions, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., has resigned from a private golf club that lost a legal fight over its refusal to admit women members. ``I have dropped out for personal reasons,'' Nunn said in a statement released by his office Tuesday in response to questions about his membership in the Burning Tree Club, located in the affluent Washington suburb of Bethesda, Md. Nunn, who considered running for the Democratic nomination for president in 1988, did not elaborate on his reasons for quitting the club, whose members include some of the nation's most powerful political leaders. ``My priority is to run for re-election to the U.S. Senate,'' Nunn said in the statement. ``As I have said many times, I have no plans or inclination to run for president. At no time have I ever established a pre-set time frame for contemplating a decision on a future presidential campaign.'' Nunn, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, was the favorite of Southern and conservative Democrats during the early part of the 1988 presidential campaign, but he twice refused to jump into the race, citing family pressures and his Senate duties. The Burning Tree Club has been an all-male bastion since its founding in 1922.

DOC.HEAD: Study Reports First Link Between Job Stress, Heart Changes
DOC.TEXT: A study published in a medical journal today links job stress with high blood pressure and with changes in the heart that often precede coronary disease and heart attacks. The changes were noted in male workers in New York City ranging from garbage collectors to stockbrokers. The findings, based on an ongoing study of 215 men from 30 to 60, are reported in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. Job strain resulted when workers felt they faced high psychological demands without having much control over day-to-day decisions, said Dr. Peter Schnall, lead researcher at Cornell University Medical College in New York. Twenty-one percent of the subjects suffered job strain. They faced up to three times greater risk of having high blood pressure than those who did not experience job strain, said Carl Pieper, a Cornell statistician. All men ages 30 to 40 years old with high-stress jobs had a ``clinically significant'' thickening of the heart's left ventricle, or chamber, a condition that often precedes coronary disease and heart attacks, Pieper said in a telephone interview Tuesday. Their heart muscles were an average of 20 grams bigger than those without job stress, a ``substantial'' difference but still within normal range, Schnall said by telephone Tuesday. ``To the best of our knowledge, this is the first time a psychosocial variable based on job characteristics has been found to be related to both hypertension and anatomic increases in heart mass,'' the researchers wrote. ``If our model is correct, job situations where the level of work demands exceeds the individual's ability to control or deal with those demands creates a challenge that activates the sympathetic nervous system and leads to an elevation of blood pressure at work. ``Long-term exposure (over years) to job strain is hypothesized to ultimately result in a sustained elevation of blood pressure that then causes structural change in the cardiovascular system,'' they wrote. While the notion that psychological factors can physically affect the body is not new, it is viewed with skepticism by some medical authorities, Dr. Redford B. Williams of Duke University Medical Center said in an accompanying editorial. ``If these results are considered along with the growing contributions of neuroscience to our understanding of how the brain speaks to the body's organs, perhaps the idea that the brain plays a role in physical disease will soon seem less `revolutionary' and more like `normal science,''' Williams said. The men studied had all worked in the same job for at least three years, none was more than 20 percent overweight and none had suffered heart disease before the study began in 1986. Eighty-one percent were white, the remaining were mostly black, and 87 had high blood pressure at the start of the study. The authors concluded that job strain was ``significantly related'' to high blood pressure and increased heart mass after adjusting for factors such as age, alcohol intake and smoking. ``We're not showing that job strain is causing heart disease,'' Schnall said. ``What we're showing is that job strain is causing a change in muscle mass'' that could lead to disease. The study, based on data gathered through 1989, is continuing for another five years to determine if the changes are permanent or progressive, he said.
