DOC.HEAD: People Often Postpone Death in Waiting for Important Occasions, Study Finds
DOC.TEXT: The mind's power over the body enables many people to keep death at bay while waiting for occasions that are important to them, say researchers who documented the phenomenon among thousands of subjects. The researchers found marked drops in death rates among Jewish men before Passover and among elderly Chinese women before the Harvest Moon Festival, said a report in today's Journal of the American Medical Association. ``The results suggest quite strongly that some people are able to postpone death briefly in order to reach an occasion which is psychologically significant to them,'' said lead researcher David P. Phillips, a sociology professor. ``In the case of the Chinese, there was a drop of 35 percent in the mortality before the holiday,'' he said in an interview Tuesday from the University of California at San Diego in La Jolla. ``There was a peak in deaths of 35 percent the week after, over what would normally be expected.'' In the case of the Jews, the drop was about 24 percent before Passover, Phillips said, and a corresponding peak in the week after the holiday. In both studies the effect was strongest for cerebrovascular diseases, such as strokes, followed by heart disease and cancer, the researchers said. Only natural causes of death were studied. Elderly Chinese women were chosen as subjects because they hold the central ceremonial role in festival observances, the researchers said. Jewish men hold the central role in Passover. Findings about the Jews were first published in 1988 in the British journal Lancet, but the Chinese findings were new. Both groups lived in California, where the research was conducted. ``The research is very sound,'' said Dr. Cecil G. Sheps, distinguished professor of social medicine emeritus at the University of North Carolina School of Medicine at Chapel Hill. ``I think he's done enough of it now to warrant people taking it seriously and pursuing studies that would try to determine what the mechanism is by which these postponements take place,'' he said in a telephone interview Tuesday. Phillips and fellow researcher Daniel G. Smith wrote that the phenomenon may be due to an unidentified interaction between psychology and biology, or to careful adherence to medication schedules or enhanced care by family or physicians. Birthdays and other significant events can help postpone death, the researchers said. A famous example is the death of Thomas Jefferson, the author of the Declaration of Independence, on July 4th, 1826, exactly 50 years after the document's signing. Phillips said Jefferson's death came only after he had asked his physician, ``Is it the Fourth?'' and received the reassurance, ``It soon will be.'' Fellow signer John Adams, the nation's second president, died the same day as Jefferson. Phillips said the study involving the scanning of computerized death records of Chinese women 75 years old and over in California during the 24-week period around the Harvest Moon Festival each year for 25 years _ from 1960 through 1984. The dip in their death rates before the holiday and subsequent peak in death rates immediately afterward was absent among non-Chinese people. The study of about 1,900 Jewish men had similar findings in the non-Jewish population around Passover.

DOC.HEAD: Paper Says Offensive Readied Against Independent Afghan Rebel Leader
DOC.TEXT: Pakistan's military intelligence is organizing a conventional army from Afghan refugees to topple a popular leader of Afghanistan's rebel forces, according to a published report. The Washington Times cited three U.S. officials, none of them identified, as the source for its report that more than 2,000 young Afghans from refugee camps in Pakistan are being prepared for an offensive against Ahmad Shah Massoud, known as the Lion of Panjshir. The report said he is recognized as the only rebel leader with a serious organization at both the civil and military level, but refuses to follow orders from Pakistan's intelligence agency, which coordinates foreign aid to the mujahedeen resistance and directs its operations.

DOC.HEAD: China to Send 3,000 Students to Study Overseas This Year
DOC.TEXT: China will send 3,000 students abroad this year, the same number as in previous years, but most will be older students on short-term programs, an official report said today. China has stressed that it will continue to send students overseas but in the past six months has placed new restrictions on studying abroad. The new regulations were prompted by fears that students would not return, especially after last year's brutal crackdown on the pro-democracy movement. Authorities are clearly concerned about students being exposed abroad to ideas and lifestyles that might make them rebellious or inclined not to return. Official reports have said that 3,000 students sponsored by the central government study overseas each year, although one report said China sent 5,000 students to study abroad last year. Shi Weiren, an official of the State Education Commission, said half of those to be sent this year will be older research students and senior scholars applying for six-month to one-year visiting scholar programs, the official Xinhua News Agency reported. Four hundred students will enroll in doctoral programs overseas, Shi said. In addition, 700 students will go abroad on World Bank Loans, Xinhua said without providing other details. Education Vice Minister He Dongchang said in September that China would increase the number of visiting scholars it sends overseas while reducing the number in graduate and doctoral programs. He said visiting scholars are able to ``attain quicker academic results'' than those enrolled in degree programs because their overseas stays are shorter. Visiting scholars also tend to be older academics who are more likely to return and are considered more politically mature. Shi said, ``Facts have shown that sending student abroad is a very effective way to introduce into China advanced foreign knowledge, science and technology and managerial experience, and to train highly qualified professionals.'' In the past 12 years, China has sent between 60,000 and 80,000 students for education in foreign countries. However, nearly half have failed to return. In addition, more than 20,000 Chinese students have gone overseas on their own, and many have stayed abroad. The new restrictions that have gone into effect recently include requiring self-financed students to work five years before going overseas.

DOC.HEAD: Disney Says Moviegoers Detest On-Screen Advertising
DOC.TEXT: The only kind of commercials most moviegoers want to see in theaters are commercials for other movies, according to a poll commissioned by Walt Disney Co. The poll showed that 90 percent of film patrons surveyed recently in 10 metropolitan areas oppose showing non-movie commercials, Disney said Tuesday to back up its ban on showing them in movie houses with Disney films. ``A commercial is a commercial and one of the reasons we go to the movies is to get away from them,'' Jeffrey Katzenberg, chairman of the Disney Studios, said at a news conference. ``They've been booing (commercials) and the reaction has been getting worse and worse.'' But the poll found that filmgoers embraced watching coming attractions; 95 percent are in favor of commercials for upcoming movies. The survey, conducted by the National Research Group, canvassed 18,772 moviegoers March 31 in New York, Boston, Indianapolis, Chicago, Austin, Oklahoma City, Nashville, Seattle, San Francisco and in Orange County, Calif. Disney announced in February that it would prohibit on-screen advertising in any theater showing films made by Disney or its affiliated studios, Touchstone and Hollywood Pictures. The ban excludes slides shown during intermission and public service announcements approved by Disney. The company's decision was met with criticism from some theater owners who count on advertising to boost revenues. A number of advertisers and advertising buyers were displeased, too. ``When we first announced our policy, we naively thought that we were dealing with an issue in which the facts were self-evident,'' Katzenberg said. ``But even though we received hundreds of letters and phone calls supporting our claim, there were still skeptics who said we had no empirical data.'' Katzenberg also defended the widespread practice of companies paying moviemakers to use their products in films. He said his studio and others had abused the practice, but he averred that movies set in the real world should use real merchandise. He added, however, that Disney no longer would accept payments to place alcohol and tobacco in movie scenes.

DOC.HEAD: Tornado Kills 16 People, Rains Huge Hailstones
DOC.TEXT: A tornado and hailstorm in southern China's Guangdong tore up dozens of buildings and overturned a ferry, killing 16 people, an official newspaper reports. The Yangcheng Evening News said the storm hit coastal Yangjiang city and surrounding towns on Monday afternoon, raining huge hailstones, the largest of which weighted 11 pounds and measured 24 inches across. A ferry crossing the Moyang River overturned and sank, killing 10 people and injuring five. Two were killed and five injured when a small store at an elementary school collapsed, the report said. It did not say how the other four died. It said two people were missing. More than 250 buildings collapsed and 11 ferries and fishing boats were lost, the paper reported. The storm also caused serious agricultural damage, it said without elaborating.

DOC.HEAD: On the Light Side
DOC.TEXT: A bar owner put on the dog for visiting Vice President Dan Quayle, mixing sarcasm with his special of the day. The Quart House's Tuesday special _ the 25-cent Quail Dog _ looks like a real hot dog but is nothing but a turkey on the inside, according to the bar's advertisement. ``What have you seen Dan Quayle do in the last two years? What are his qualifications for anything? All he's ever been is a politician,'' said Bill Ward, the Quart House's owner. ``In my opinion, he's just a hot dog.'' Quayle visited the city of 18,000 about 80 miles west of Omaha to speak about the Job Training Partnership Act and attend a fund-raiser for Republican Gov. Kay Orr, who is seeking re-election. Ward's opinion did not appear to be shared by others in the town, said Dave Beckwith, a spokesman for Quayle. ``The vice president was deeply impressed by the overwhelmingly enthusiastic reception he got in Columbus and he's grateful for the hospitality that he received,'' Beckwith said. ``We saw nothing but a friendly welcome.'' In Peoria, Ill., the Hit the Trail for Quayle Club recently launched a letter-writing campaign to comedians to get the vice president out of punch lines. Meanwhile, Quail Dogs proved to be popular at the Quart House. About 60 were sold by Tuesday night. ``Nobody's giving me any heck about it. People are getting a good laugh out of it and that's what it's really supposed to do,'' Ward said.

DOC.HEAD: Canadians Report 141 Unidentified Flying Objects in 1989
DOC.TEXT: Unexplained flashing lights and strange circles in the ground are spotted in Quebec, a saucer zooms over houses in Newfoundland and a diamond-shaped object zips through the Manitoba sky. Throughout the country, people said they saw at least 141 unidentified flying objects last year, according to what's being touted as Canada's first national survey of UFO sightings. ``It tells us that UFOs haven't gone away, it tells us that UFOs are being seen right across Canada,'' said Chris Rutkowski, a Winnipeg researcher who compiled the study. Rutkowski put together the survey from reports submitted to private investigators, police and the Ottawa-based National Research Council, which supplied two-thirds of the material for the study. Such information was always available but never marshalled into a form that painted a picture of UFO sightings across the country, he said. More than half the reports didn't have enough information to evaluate properly and one third had probable explanations, said Rutkowski, who has a degree in astronomy and is president of the Winnipeg branch of the Royal Astronomical Society of Canada. Of the rest, seven sightings were stamped as solidly unknown, meaning they were seen by several people and investigated by the police and National Research Council, without any explanation being found, he said. He related three such incidents. Startled residents of the rural Quebec community of Ste-Marie-de-Monnoir saw flashing lights glide over a field and out of sight. The next morning, they found strange circles swirled into the ground. At Wesleyville, Newfoundland, eight or nine people noticed a classic saucer-shaped object swoop low over rooftops and along the shoreline. And near Beaver Creek, Manitoba, people reported seeing a diamond shape with red lights zip over their car and out across Lake Winnipeg. Rutkowski stresses that he wants to take a rational, scientific approach to the reports and will not offer any theories about unexplained sightings. But he hopes publicity from the survey will spark more people to come forward with their observations, providing a larger body of evidence that could be investigated by scientists.

DOC.HEAD: Education Secretary Seeks Answers To Hispanic Dropout Problem
DOC.TEXT: Parents are partly to blame for the high dropout rate among Hispanic teen-agers, but economic pressures make it hard for many to finish high school, witnesses told a hearing on Hispanic education. ``The students have to support their families, and I don't think that's right,'' said Liz Cuevas, a 16-year-old San Antonio student. ``They say, `I'm getting money now. I don't know if I'm going to be alive tomorrow.''' Education Secretary Lauro Cavazos told a news conference after he opened the hearing _ the first of five regional meetings on Hispanic education _ that Hispanic parents have to get more involved in education. ``We must have a commitment from Hispanics, from Hispanic parents especially, that their childern will be educated,'' he said. ``That is the first vital step.'' The hearing, and others to follow in Miami, Chicago, Los Angeles and Boston, were organized by a federal task force on what President Bush has called the crisis in Hispanic education. During the 1980s, about 40 percent of Hispanics nationwide left school before high school graduation, Cavazos said. The rate for all groups in the United States is 30 percent. Only 11 percent of Hispanics complete four or more years of college by the time they are in their early 30s, Cavazos said. Gloria Rodriguez, executive director of the Avance family support project in San Antonio, testified that a study by her organization found one reason students drop out is that their parents don't expect them to finish high school. ``Parenting is not something that comes naturally. It is a skill that you learn,'' said Ms. Rodriguez, whose program helps parents learn about child care while furthering their education and job training. Louis J. Agnese Jr., president of Incarnate Word College in San Antonio, said lack of money, lack of preparation and perceptions of failure cause Hispanics to leave school. Agnese proposed a national marketing campaign showing achievement through Hispanic role models. He also said politicians must find equitable funding for all school districts. Cavazos defended his remark to the Texas Legislature last month that a large infusion of money is not necessarily the answer to the state's school funding woes. ``I said that it is not appropriate for me to come here and tell you how to find the money,'' Cavazos said. ``I also said I do not doubt that there are some school districts in this state that need additional funding.''

DOC.HEAD: New Hampshire Governor Vetoes Liberal Abortion Rights Bill
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Judd Gregg vetoed what he called the nation's most liberal abortion rights law, less than two weeks after his counterpart in Idaho rejected the most restrictive state abortion bill. The bill Gregg vetoed would have allowed unrestricted abortions until the fetus could live outside the womb and after that to protect the life or health of the mother or if the fetus had a life-threatening physical or congenital abnormality. ``This bill authorizes abortion for convenience, sex selection, as a form of birth control and with or without parental notification or consent in the case of a minor,'' Gregg said Tuesday in his veto message to the Legislature. Government has an obligation to protect life, the Republican governor said, and life begins at conception. ``I obviously will not support legislation which represents a dramatic expansion of the availability of abortion as a means of terminating life in New Hampshire,'' he said. Idaho Gov. Cecil Andrus on March 30 vetoed a bill that would virtually have banned abortions for the purpose of birth control. Gregg took issue with supporters who claimed the New Hampshire bill sustained the principle of the 1973 U.S. Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion. ``This bill allows abortion throughout the term of pregnancy, including arguably as late as the ninth month, if the `health' of the mother is an issue,'' said Gregg, who called that ``a term so vague as to be worthless as a limiting function.'' Opponents of the measure praised Gregg. ``We thank God for a victory here. It shows the governor is a man of integrity and he kept his promise,'' said Russell Pond, director of the New Hampshire Pro Life Council. Abortion rights advocates argued that the bill essentially legalized current practice. They said 91 percent of all abortions in the country are done in the first 12 weeks and that only .01 percent are done after 24 weeks. ``This is a sad day for freedom in New Hampshire,'' said Robert Spurrier, the state's spokesman for Planned Parenthood of Northern New England. He said Gregg turned his back on ``the solid pro-choice majority of New Hampshire citizens.'' Originally, the bill allowed unrestricted abortions through the 24th week, but the Senate changed that to a fetal viability standard, determined by the woman's doctor. Gregg said that meant abortions could be performed as late as the seventh month ``depending on the doctor's view.'' House leaders haven't set a date to consider overriding the veto. Two earlier votes on versions of the bill failed to generate the two-thirds margin needed for override.

DOC.HEAD: California Puts Cigarette Tax Money to Work in Anti-Smoking Push
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf, `The TV ...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with details of how effort is being financed. Picks up 4th graf pvs. `One commercial ...' ^LaserPhoto LA1
DOC.TEXT: State officials are starting a $28.6 million ad campaign, financed by a tax on cigarettes, that they hope will convince three-quarters of California's smokers to kick the habit by the year 2000. Beginning today, ads with some of the strongest language ever used to attack smoking and tobacco companies will appear on television, radio, in newspapers and on billboards throughout the state, said Dr. Kenneth Kizer, head of the state Department of Health Services. The money for the effort is coming from a 25-cent per pack tax hike authorized under Proposition 99, a referendum passed last year. That brought the total state tax to 35 cents a pack. The TV commercials are aimed especially at youths, pregnant women and minorities. They sharply condemn the way tobacco companies sell their products. One commercial shows a smoke-filled room, packed with cynical executives devising a marketing campaign for cigarettes. One executive discusses the need to lure 3,000 new smokers every day to replace smokers who die from tobacco-related illnesses or who quit. ``We're not in business for our health,'' the executive sneers. ``This is going to be a media campaign about a media campaign _ as much about hype as hygiene,'' says one advertisement, running in 30 newspapers. It accuses the tobacco industry of ``predatory marketing, the selective exploitation of the young, the selling of suicide.'' Kizer said the 15-month campaign will be bigger than any run before. ``The average state spends about $100,000 a year on anti-tobacco messages and education,'' he said. But the tobacco industry, Kizer said, spent about $3.2 billion in 1988 for advertising and promotion. The state hopes the campaign, in tandem with teaching programs, will lead to a 20 percent decrease in smoking by June 1991 and a 75 percent reduction by 2000. About one in four of California's 29 million residents smoke, buying more than 2 billion packs of cigarettes a year. Tobacco-related disease costs about $5.6 billion and kills about 30,000 people annually in California, Kizer said. Brennan Dawson, a spokeswoman for the Tobacco Institute, an industry group based in Washington, D.C., said the ads are an attack on the tobacco industry rather than an attempt to educate the public about smoking's health risks. ``It is a pretty far-flung idea that if you attack the tobacco industry, you're going to get people to stop smoking. ... You're propagandizing,'' she said. Kizer accused tobacco companies of targeting teen-agers in order to hook customers when they're young, and of pushing its products at recently arrived immigrants who don't know how dangerous smoking is. Ms. Dawson said the industry believes adults should have the right to smoke. ``The industry is very much opposed to young people smoking. We don't want them for our customers,'' she said. ``Cigarettes are products for adults like many other things are products for adults, such as alcoholic beverages or cars.'' Steve Kessler, Health Services Department assistant director, said the state's ads are meant to counter the industry's seductive marketing of smoking. ``Smoking is not sexy,'' Kessler said. ``Smoking is not glamorous. It's not youthful. That's the message we're trying to sell. Smoking is dirty. Smoking is dumb from a health perspective.'' Radio commercials feature a series of comedians telling jokes about topics like smokers' breath, smokers' hack, tobacco-stained hands and the expense of smoking. ``A crazy thought,'' says one comedian. ``I mean why sell cigarettes? Why not just sell phlegm and cut out the middle man?'' ``I think some of (the ads) are going to be controversial, and there will be some debate over them,'' Kessler said. ``But first and foremost, we're trying to protect the health of Californians.'' Smoking is the leading preventable cause of death and disease, killing more people than alcohol, illegal drugs, accidents, homicides and suicides combined, said state Health and Welfare Secretary Clifford Allenby. Smoking is associated with an increased risk of heart disease, stroke, high blood pressure, emphysema and several kinds of cancer.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Fall In Tokyo, Dollar In Rebound
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's chief index erased its early gains and fell back today as the dollar quickly rose against the Japanese yen in the afternoon. The dollar ended at 158.50 yen, up 0.35 yen from Tuesday's close of 158.15 yen. It opened lower, at 157.60 yen, and ranged between 157.50 and 158.50 yen. The currency rose as investment trust companies bought it for technical position adjustments following the currency's lower opening in Tokyo after its overnight downswing on overseas markets, dealers said. Many players, including institutional investors, remained on the sidelines, said Shinzo Yamamoto, a trader with Daiwa Bank. ``The dollar started rising as market players bought it when it fell as low as 157.50 yen, but there was no dollar-selling drive to push it back,'' he said. On the stock exchange, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 184.40 points, or 0.62 percent, ending the day at 29,440.28 points. The index regained 320.33 points, or 1.08 percent, at the end of morning trading. On Tuesday it lost 773.25 points. Volume on the first section, where most blue chip stocks are listed, was a thin 500 million shares, down from 550 million the previous day. A Nomura Securities trader attributed the index's afternoon losses to the yen's downturn and an increase in the commercial paper (CP) rate. ``The market was largely discouraged by the upswing in the CP rate, which rose above 7 percent,'' he said, adding that the increase renewed fears of increased interest rates. CPs are unsecured promissory notes for corporations, issued to provide short-term financing. They are sold at a discount and redeemed at face value, and their rates are considered a key indicator of short-term interest rate movement. Higher interest rates tend to discourage stock investment. Japan's central bank raised its official discount rate last month to 5.25 percent from the previous 4.25 percent, but Japan's central bank and Finance Ministry have since ruled out any additional discount rate hike. In earlier trading, the Nikkei rose following the yen's higher opening against the dollar, traders said. ``The yen plunged yesterday because of doubts about Group of Seven cooperation in supporting the yen, but its overnight gain overseas wiped out such fears among Japanese participants,'' said Katsuya Igarashi, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. Bank of Japan Governor Yasushi Mieno, after returning from a meeting of financial authorities of the G-7 nations in Paris last weekend, said they had pledged to intervene in currency markets to support the falling yen. The G-7 is composed of Japan, Canada, the United States, Britain, France, Italy and West Germany. But market analysts say some G-7 nations regard the yen's weakness as Japan's internal problem and are reluctant to help the currency rise unless Japanese financial authorities take further steps, such as raising domestic interest rates. Traders said Japanese market players generally assume the same. Stock traders said the key to a stock market recovery is the yen's stability. Discouraged by the yen's downswing, the price of the benchmark No.119 Japanese government bonds closed at 86.30 points, down from Tuesday's close at 86.54. Their yield rose to 7.295 percent from the previous day's 7.245 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Candidate Who Promised Pink Lifeboats Loses
DOC.TEXT: Despite her promise to buy pink lifeboats to guard residents against floods, voters in this small town in the wine-growing region rejected the mayoral aspirations of transsexual Terri Pohrman. Pohrman, 37, who favored red sequin gowns with decolletage, attracted national attention by bringing a light touch to the race and giving glittery campaign shows at the local California Veterans Home. While still a female impersonator, she had entertained the home's elderly residents, which make up 40 percent of the 1,800 registered voters in Yountville (population: 3,200). Pohrman got 280 votes Tuesday, against 621 for Mayor pro tem Carlee Leftwich. Former City Councilman Aaron Mosley finished third with 187 votes.

DOC.HEAD: List Conviction, Sentence Depend on Reading of Mental State
DOC.TEXT: John E. List's attorney has conceded that the former Sunday school teacher killed his family 18 years ago, but how long List is likely to spend in prison depends on the jury's reading of his mental state. List's attorney, Elijah L. Miller Jr., rested his case Tuesday, and the jury was expected to receive it today. The bulk of Miller's defense depended on a psychiatrist and a psychologist who testified that List suffered from an obsessive-compulsive disorder that prevented him from acting rationally. Because of this disorder, the pressures of impending bankruptcy and his wife's terminal illness, Miller has argued, List could see no alternative other than to murder his wife, mother and three children on Nov. 9, 1971. On Monday, Superior Judge William L'E. Wertheimer ruled that the jury could find List guilty of second-degree murder, carrying a 30-year maximum prison term; or first degree murder, which carries a life term. For a first-degree conviction, the state must prove that List acted willfully, premeditatively and deliberately, a point that a psychiatrist testifying for the prosecution stressed Tuesday. ``At all times, John List was capable of deliberating upon the deed,'' Dr. Steven S. Simring said. List definitely had an ``obsessive'' personality, but his condition could not be defined as a personality disorder, said Simring, who read from what he said were notes of List's chilling account of the killings. ``It was a horrible thing but, when I started, it was like I was on auto, autodrive. It was almost with a sigh of relief that I killed all of them and there weren't one or two survivors,'' List was quoted as saying. Simring said List told him he shot his wife, Helen, 46, at the breakfast table while she had toast and coffee, then went to the third floor and shot his mother, Alma, 85, at close range. He left to do errands, returned for lunch and killed each child successively: Patricia, 16; John, 15; and Frederick, 13. Simring said List choked up and became teary at the point in the interview when he talked of shooting John. As Simring went through his notes, List hunched forward in his chair and his face turned red. List, who had been living in Virginia under an assumed name, was arrested in June after a caller responded to a televised show about the murders.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Fire Controlled in Wisconsin
DOC.TEXT: Floating booms corraled an oil slick on the Milwaukee River after billowing smoke from a warehouse fire forced authorities to halt expressway traffic, evacuate homes and close businesses. About $2 million was lost in the nine-hour blaze Tuesday that consumed the Harrison Oil Corp., a distributor of engine lubrication oils and pesticides, said Norman Wichman, the fire chief. The cause has yet to be determined. No one was seriously injured. One firefighter was overcome by fumes and heat, and another gashed his face when he fell. Traffic on a three-mile section of Interstate 43 in the northern Milwaukee suburb was detoured for several hours. Two schools and a stereo equipment manufacturer were closed because of fears the thick, dark smoke was toxic. Three square blocks of houses were evacuated, but most homeowners were allowed to return by Tuesday evening. Officials said an unknown quantity of oil, anti-flame foam and insecticides seeped into the river and might kill fish and waterfowl there. The Coast Guard helped lay booms across the river, which feeds Lake Michigan, to contain the slick, said Dean Kelley, emergency response coordinator for the state Department of Natural Resources. Plant manager Gil Dombek said the building held 50,000 to 100,000 gallons of outboard engine oil and 2,000 to 3,000 gallons of kerosene. Nearly all the contents were engulfed by noon, he said. About 150 gallons of a cattle insecticide were believed to have burned and could have produced toxic fumes, Dombek said. No workers were in the building when fire started shortly after 4 a.m., Wichman said. The fire, which apparently started near some boxes in a stock area, was extinguished with foam from an airport fire truck.

DOC.HEAD: Easter Visits Approved for Young Brothers
DOC.TEXT: A pair of young brothers, separated when their adoptive parents returned one of them to an orphanage, will be allowed a brief visit with each other for the first time since the Christmas season. The parents, who rejected 11-year-old Rick because they said he wouldn't ``bond'' with them, have refused for three months to allow the boys to see each other. The issue became public when the parents were sued earlier this month by Cook County Public Guardian Patrick T. Murphy. Rick _ not his real name _ was told of the meeting on Monday at the foster home where he lives. ``He's very, very happy about it,'' Murphy said Tuesday. ``But the next thing he said was, `When is the next visit?' At this point we have to say, `We don't know.''' Rick's 9-year-old brother is still living with the suburban Bellwood couple. Murphy said the parents' concession for a single visit is cruel and likened it to a Chinese water torture. ``One visit doesn't mean anything,'' he said. Rick ``can't go through the rest of his life wondering when he will be allowed to see his brother again.'' The boys have been permitted three visits and three telephone conversations after the parents took Rick to the orphanage in November, more than five years after the adoption. The last visit was shortly after Christmas. The parents, identified in court papers as Pamela and Joseph Doe, adopted the brothers in August 1984. The state took the boys from their natural mother because she was accused of abusing them. The county is seeking a court order compelling the parents to allow the boys to visit each other. It also seeks $50,000 for alleged emotional distress to Rick.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``We certainly did put to rest the whole business of the mudslinging in this campaign. I think the people of Texas rejected that. That's one of the reasons I feel so good about this coming November.'' _ Ann Richards, state treasurer of Texas, who faces Republican Clayton Williams in the general election after a bruising Democratic gubernatorial runoff against Attorney General Jim Mattox.

``Until four minutes, everything was fine and gorgeous. Then bang, back down to depression.'' _ Francesco Paresce, a scientist with the European Space Agency, after the latest delay in the launch into space of the Hubble Space Telescope, NASA's most expensive and complex payload.

``The constitutional parliamentary life is our common choice, and the path from which there will be no turning back.'' _ King Hussein of Jordan, who is drafting guidelines for legalizing political parties outlawed 33 years ago.

DOC.HEAD: No More Jail Time for Missile Protesters
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Daniel J. Berrigan, his brother Philip and six other protesters have been spared further jail time for a 1980 protest in which they damaged nuclear missiles and poured blood on documents. A judge on Tuesday ruled that the time the ``Plowshares Eight'' defendants had already served was sufficient punishment. But he warned that further law-breaking could send them back behind bars. Common Pleas Judge James Buckingham, who was assigned to handle the resentencing in the town outside Philadelphia, expressed sympathy for the defendants, although he did not condone their actions. ``The defendants were attempting to make a statement of their deep-felt convictions,'' he said. ``I agree with many of those convictions. We are all concerned about nuclear war.'' The eight, including three priests and a nun, were convicted in 1981 of burglary, conspiracy and criminal mischief. They were originally sentenced to terms ranging from 1{ to 10 years and had served sentences ranging from five days to 9{ months. ``I think it was a fair decision and for once we ran into a decent judge,'' said Philip Berrigan, 66, of Baltimore. ``What he did was totally unexpected.'' ``I was all set to go to jail,'' said Daniel Berrigan, 68, of New York, displaying a toothbrush he was carrying. The other defendants were the Rev. Carl Kabat, 56, of Baltimore; attorney John Schuchardt, 45, of Madison, Conn.; Dean Hammer, 35, of New Haven, Conn.; Elmer Maas, 51, of New York; Molly Rush, 57, of Pittsburgh; and Anne Montgomery, 62, of New York. The convictions stemmed from a protest on Sept. 9, 1980, at the General Electric Co. plant in King of Prussia. The defendants took hammers to the nose cones of two Minuteman 3 nuclear missiles and poured blood on papers. Claiming they didn't get a fair trial, the defendants appealed through state and federal courts. The U.S. Supreme Court refused to hear the case in October. ``We did not act out of anarchy, but out of a belief that men shall not kill,'' Maas told the judge. ``We shun the use of killing and violence as a way to protect power.'' Maas is serving a prison sentence for another protest. Two other defendants, Kabat and Ms. Montgomery, are also serving prison terms for protests. ``I am sorry that all of us didn't go free and I was sorry to see our three friends leave the courtroom in handcuffs,'' Daniel Berrigan said. The judge formally sentenced the defendants to minimum sentences equal to time already served. But he said law-breaking in a future protest would be a violation of parole that would return them to prison. He asked each of the defendants whether they planned to continue their protests. None ruled it out. Kabat, who has been in jail for 5{ years, said, ``I would certainly rest for awhile.'' The defendants took their name from the biblical prophecy that swords will be beaten into plowshares. In a statement, the defendants said ``We saw our action as one of hope for the future and gratitude for God's creation which was, and is, under threat of planetary extinction. We wanted our action to ring with the truth that everyone can take responsibility for the weapons produced in our name.'' Outside the courthouse, scores of supporters held a vigil. ``If first-rate weaponry like nuclear missiles are judged within the law and what we did is outside of it, so be it and we will go to prison in good spirit,'' Daniel Berrigan told the judge. Hammer said the judge ``should choose against nuclear weapons rather than punishing the defendants.'' ``Somehow governments have the right to act insanely,'' he said. ``If an individual acted like the government he or she would be locked away. What we did was right.''

DOC.HEAD: Republicans See Problems With Children's Rights Amendment
DOC.TEXT: A lawmaker proposed adding a declaration of children's rights to Florida's Constitution but the idea was tabled when other legislators said they couldn't guarantee ``freedom from want'' for children. The amendment discussed Tuesday by the House Children & Youth Committee outlines rights to food, housing, clothing, medical care, education and protection from abuse, neglect and exploitation. Republicans praised the sponsor, Rep. Mike Langton, D-Jacksonville, for his motives but went on to express doubts. ``History has shown that there are events beyond anyone's control _ famines and disease and war and all kinds of things that occur that don't guarantee us this,'' said Rep. David Troxler of Jacksonville. The amendment would generate lawsuits from children who thought their needs weren't met, said Rep. J. Bruce Hoffman of South Miami. The proposal could ``encourage families to abandon their own responsibilities,'' said Rep. Richard Graham, R-Ormand Beach. One of the panel's six Republicans, Rep. Tim Ireland of Cape Coral, offered an amendment to strike the phrase ``guaranteed freedom from want.'' But after it was approved on a voice vote, Langton, the chairman of the committee, asked that it be rescheduled so that he would have time to consult with committee members on the wording. A staff report concluded that the state needs almost $1 billion more to implement the children's services now mandated by law. ``There's so much unmet need out there ... that if we don't make a statement that they shall be guaranteed these rights, I don't think they ever will be,'' Langton said.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell in early European trading today on the heels of Tuesday's sharp drop in New York. Gold prices also fell. ``The market was taken by surprise and a lot of people were caught out with long dollar positions,'' said one trader in Milan, Italy. Unconfirmed rumors that the credit rating for a major U.S. bank had been lowered sparked a dollar selloff Tuesday that bumped the currency below the 1.69 West German mark level. Currency dealers said this, combined with more positive comments from West German officials about unification with East Germany, encouraged heavy selling of the dollar against the Deutsche mark in the Far East early today. West German Economics Minister Helmut Haussmann helped the mark rally by predicting it would rise after monetary union between the two Germanys, provided East Germany introduces a free-market economy. The Japanese yen remained weak despite last weekend's Group of Seven meeting in Paris. Market analysts say some G-7 nations regard the yen's weakness as a domestic problem and are reluctant to help the currency rise unless Japanese financial authorities take further steps, such as raising domestic interest rates. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.35 yen to a closing 158.50 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 158.25 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Tuesday: _1.6778 West German marks, down from 1.6900 _1.4890 Swiss francs, down from 1.4955 _5.6400 French francs, down from 5.6750 _1.9054 Dutch guilders, up from 1.9030 _1,233.00 Italian lire, down from 1,240.00 _1.1595 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1613 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6402, compared with $1.6345 late Tuesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $374.25 a troy ounce, down from $375.15 bid late Tuesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $374.10. In Zurich, the bid price was $373.70, down from $375.25 late Tuesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.84 to close at a bid $375.13. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.09 a troy ounce, from Tuesday's $5.13.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Deployed After Student Dies of Injuries Suffered in Political Violence
DOC.TEXT: A student died today of injuries he suffered in street battles between supporters of rival political parties, and thousands of troops hit the streets to try to avert more bloodshed. Hundreds of wailing people had camped outside a city hospital where Najeem Ahmad, 22, had been in a coma since Friday. Authorities said up to 10,000 troops were deployed after his death was announced to prevent any retaliatory acts by his supporters, who blame a rival political party that represents Indian immigrants. Ahmad belonged to Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's Pakistan People's Party. Meanwhile, the militant leader of the Indian immigrants, Altaf Hussein, pressed on with a hunger strike he began to demand the release of 21 supporters arrested in Friday's violence. Thousands of wailing supporters have kept a vigil outside Hussein's home, and doctors weaved their way through their prostrate bodies to check on the hunger striker. As many as 60 people have died in the last month in pitched battles between supporters of Ms. Bhutto and Hussein. A one-time ally of Ms. Bhutto, Hussein's Mohajir Qami Movement switched allegiances in November when he gave his party's 14 National Assembly votes to the opposition. The defections led to a no-confidence vote, which Ms. Bhutto narrowly survived. Rivalries between the Pakistan People's Party and the Indian immigrants' movement erupted in violence in early February when 47 people were killed and scores injured in a single day of shooting. There were sporadic gunfights until Friday, when a 24-hour shooting spree left 17 people dead and 55 wounded, including Ahmad. Police arrested 30 people. Troops were ordered into central Karachi on Sunday after Hussein began his hunger strike, and today several took up positions outside Karachi's civic center, the busiest intersection in this port city of 8 million. Hussein has demanded the release of 20 of his followers as well as a Karachi municipal councilor, Khalid Bin Walid, who was arrested in connection with the shooting of Ahmad. Walid belongs to Hussein's party. So far the Sindh province government, dominated by Ms. Bhutto's party, has refused Hussein's demands.

DOC.HEAD: King Withdraws From Active Participation in Politics
DOC.TEXT: King Birendra has withdrawn from politics and wants the government to ease the hostility and bitterness caused by the bloody crackdown on the pro-democracy movement, the foreign minister said today. State radio said all charges would be dropped against activists arrested since the movement began on Feb. 18. The opposition says about 300 political prisoners are in jail. Foreign Minister Pashupati Rana's comments were the first on the king's role in Nepal's new multiparty system, which Birendra established on Sunday by lifting a 29-year ban on political parties. Rana told reporters talks were continuing with a centrist party and a left-wing coalition on the formation of a provisional government. The Nepali Congress Party and the United Left Front said Tuesday that they would not participate in the proposed government unless the current partyless national assembly, the Rashtriya Panchayat, is dissolved. The two parties led the seven-week pro-democracy campaign that forced Birendra to establish a multiparty system. Rana refused to give details about the talks. ``Allow us the privacy of dialogue ... if you want the process of orderly and democractic Nepal to continue.'' ``For 29 years there was virtually no dialogue, no discussion. We hardly knew each other. We settled that in two days. From a highly troubled situation, we brought the country to a fairly stable situation,'' he said. Political parties were banned in Nepal in 1961 when the democratically elected government headed by the Nepali Congress Party was sacked by Birendra's father, Mahendra, ending Nepal's only experiment with Western-style democracy. The king has wielded power through a largely rubber-stamp government and a national assembl dominated by his nominees. The Congress Party went underground and continued to campaign for multiparty democracy. A left-wing coalition joined it on Feb. 18, setting off a popular movement supported by academicians, doctors, engineers, pilots and peasants. The government last cracked down on Friday, when troops fired on 200,000 demonstrators as they marched on the royal palace. Witnesses said at least 200 were killed; the government said 10 people were killed and 107 injured. ``For one-and-a-half months a period of harshness, of great casualties, of great loss of lives has gone through this country. We want to heal these wounds to soothe anybody's feelings wherever they are hurt,'' Rana said. Rana said the king, by removing a reference to the ban on parties in the constitution, has ``relinquished participation in active politics.'' State-run radio continued to refer to the government as ``his majesty's.'' To a question on the king tolerating criticism of the monarchy, Rana said: ``Freedom of expression has been established. ... It is more likely that there would be praise of the king.'' Under Nepalese law, the press or citizens are not allowed to criticize the institution of monarchy and the royal family, although criticism of the government is tolerated. Reporters who have broken the law have been jailed. Birendra, 44, is the heir of the Shaha dynasty, which has held the throne since the middle of the 18th century. Many Nepalis, especially farmers who comprise the bulk of this country's 17 million people, view him as the reincarnation of the Hindu god, Vishnu.

DOC.HEAD: Chippewa Open Spearfishing Season Amid Taunts
DOC.TEXT: Chippewa Indians began their annual spearfishing harvest of walleyed pike while deputy sheriffs patrolled the lake to keep taunting picketers at a distance. About 400 people, some in favor and some opposed to the tribe's treaty rights, debated beside Cedar Lake in western Wisconsin as the two tribal boats paddled about Tuesday night. ``There were a few intelligent conversations between Indians and non-Indians,'' said Bill Means, a member of the American Indian Movement contingent on hand to support the tribal fishermen. More than 100 law enforcement officials, including two dozen in riot helmets, patrolled the shores of the lake. Since 1983, federal courts have upheld the 19th century treaties that allow Chippewa to hunt and fish on public property in the northern third of Wisconsin. Treaty critics call the rulings unfair to non-Chippewa hunters and fishermen, complaining the spring spearing depletes the supply of walleye. During the season last year, about 200 protesters were arrested after confrontations that included rock throwing and racial insults. Temperatures were in the 30s and 40s on Tuesday, too cold for walleye to leave Cedar Lake's depths in great numbers. The season generally begins when the fish begin spawning in the shallows, where they are easily speared in the glare of spotlights mounted on boats. The season lasts for several weeks. Of two St. Croix boats with two fishermen each, the first to return reported catching 10 walleye of one pound or less apiece, and two largemouth bass. One of the spearers, Lorne Pewaush, 19, of rural Hertle said the fish will feed his family. Rick Jett, a treaty defender from Rhinelander, said his car was forced off a road by pickup truck. ``I got his license number and gave it to the police,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Teresa Resigns As Head of Order for Health Reasons
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II has accepted the resignation of Mother Teresa as head of the religious order she founded to care for the sick and poor in Calcutta, India, the Vatican announced today. Deputy Vatican spokesman Monsignor Piero Pennacchini said Mother Teresa, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1979 for her charity work, submitted her resignation for health reasons and was happy to turn over the reigns to ``younger hands.'' The 79-year-old nun was hospitalized last year for heart troubles, and surgeons implanted a permanent pacemaker on Dec. 1. Pennachini noted that Mother Teresa was no longer able to leave Calcutta to visit her missions in other parts of the world. Mother Teresa, who was born in Yugoslavia, founded the Missionaries of Charity in 1950 in Calcutta's squalid slums. The order, recognized by the Vatican in 1965, expanded and now has 3,000 nuns working to help the poor in 87 countries. A new head of the order will be elected in Calcutta on Sept. 8, Pennachini said.

DOC.HEAD: Peres Bid to Form Coalition Government Fails
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Peres failing to form government, other details. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Labor leader Shimon Peres failed today to present a new government to parliament for approval after two members of an ultra-Orthodox religious party defected from his coalition at the last minute. The dramatic turnaround was a major embarrassment for Peres, who only hours before had predicted he would have a 61-60 majority in the 120-seat Knesset, or parliament, and had named his candidates for the proposed Cabinet. Peres, who had vowed to make peace talks with Palestinians his first priority, told President Chaim Herzog in a letter that he would need more time. Peres' bid to form a coalition fell apart when two hard-line members of the ultra-Orthodox Agudat Israel Party backed out. The defectors oppose a government that depends on Arab members of the parliament for support and they also reject the return of occupied land in exchange for peace. Pandomonium broke out in parliament when it became clear that Peres lacked a majority, and lawmakers shouted and wagged fingers at each other. At one point, four security guards surrounded a right-wing lawmaker who appeared to threaten Arab parliament member Abdul Wahab Daroushe. Parliament Speaker Dov Shilansky, a member of the right-wing Likud bloc, ruled there would be no point in going forward with a vote after reading a letter from Peres saying Labor had failed in its attempt to form a government. Shilanksy rejected calls by Likud supporters to go ahead with the vote, which could have further embarrassed Peres with a tie or a loss. ``I do not believe that there is any point in inviting Peres to the podium to present his government since he announced that it is not in his hands,'' Shilansky said. He said he lacked the authority to grant Peres an extension of 48 hours, which was sought by Labor. The ruling left the decision in the hands of the president. Herzog, who granted Peres three weeks to form a government on March 20, is empowered to grant Peres an extension of up to 21 days. Peres supporters said he would request up to three weeks more. The president's office said Peres was expected to visit later in the day. Meanwhile, Israel radio reported efforts were under way to bring together another Labor-Likud coalition in which Yitzhak Rabin of Labor and the incumbent Yitzhak Shamir of Likud would each take turns being prime minister. Asked about the possibility, Peres said on Israel Television that he had received a mandate from the party to form a government that would give a positive reply to U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker's proposals for a Palestinian-Israeli dialogue. He said he had asked the Agudat Israel Party if it could still guarantee him the backing of all five of its parliament members after the two hard-liners, Avraham Verdiger and Eliezer Mizrahi, announced they would oppose a Labor-led coalition. Earlier, Peres declined to tell reporters his plans but said: ``I think I have a chance'' when asked if he could still form a government. Labor sources said Peres needed an extra two days to give the Augudat Israel Party time to replace or bring into line Verdiger and Mizrahi. Verdiger announced his resignation from parliament. It would take two days for his resignation to take effect, after which he could be replaced. Mizrahi said that as an act of conscience he would oppose a Labor-led government despite his party's decision to accept Peres. ``For the peace and safety of the 3 million Jews of this country, I oppose the government,'' said Mizrahi. In this predominantly secular country, Agudat Israel and other small religious parties hold disproportionate sway by virtue of the split between the country's two major forces _ Labor and the right-wing Likud bloc. In recent days, people have staged mass rallies and hunger strikes demanding electoral reform, such as direct election of the prime minister.

DOC.HEAD: Perjury Charges Dismissed Against Former PTL Minister
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has dismissed perjury charges against a former PTL pastor for lack of evidence. The Rev. Sam Johnson was accused of lying to a federal grand jury in 1987 and 1988, saying he did not remember where he got $10,000 in cash to lend former PTL top executive Richard Dortch. That money was to pay for former church secretary Jessica Hahn's silence about a 1980 sexual encounter with ministry founder Jim Bakker. Bakker is serving 45 years at a Minnesota prison after being convicted in October of mail and wire fraud and conspiracy. U.S. District Judge Robert Potter dismissed the charges Tuesday, saying, ``I think I'm afraid if I let it go to the jury I would cause this defendant to have to go through the appeals process.'' Johnson, 50, hugged his wife, Joyce, and sobbed when Potter announced the decision after both sides presented their cases. ``I feel born again. Friday's coming and Easter's not far away. For me, I'm glad it came early,'' Johnson said outside the courthouse. Jerry Miller, the assistant U.S. attorney who prosecuted Bakker and who testified Tuesday about Johnson's statements to the grand jury, said he thought the government's case went as well as he expected. ``Judge Potter obviously had a difficult call to make,'' Miller said. ``We stated our position. He disagreed. That's his function.'' Johnson reiterated his testimony that he never denied making the loan to Dortch and never denied that the funds could have come from mission funds or another source. Earlier in the day a former PTL executive testified that Johnson used church offerings to provide the money paid to Ms. Hahn. David Taggart, a former Bakker aide serving 18 years in prison for tax evasion, said he attended part of a meeting in which Dortch arranged the loan with Johnson. Dortch is serving eight years in prison. He pleaded guilty in August to mail and wire fraud and conspiracy, and agreed to testify against Bakker in a plea bargain with prosecutors. ``Reverend Dortch shared with Sam Johnson that a woman had alleged she had been raped and that money was needed for psychological counseling,'' Taggart testified. Taggart said Johnson then agreed to lend him the $10,000 and said the money would come from church offerings. Johnson had been charged with 12 counts of perjury and faced five years in prison and a $250,000 fine if convicted.

DOC.HEAD: Tehran Paper Appeals for Freedom for Other Western Hostages
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 14th graf, `Most have...' to UPDATE with Irish hostage spending birthday in captivity. Pickup 15th graf, `The Tehran ...'
DOC.TEXT: A leading Iranian newspaper today said the release of three Western hostages in Lebanon should be a prelude to freedom for all hostages because keeping people captive contradicts Islamic teachings. It was the third time in as many months that the Tehran Times had advocated the release of Western hostages held in Lebanon by militant pro-Iranian groups. ``In fact, the issue of hostage-taking should come to an end for all with no discrimination,'' said an editorial in the newspaper, which often reflects the opinions of President Hashemi Rafsanjani. Rafsanjani and other Iranian moderates have stressed their support for releasing the hostages held in Lebanon, seeing it as a way of improving ties with the West at a time Iran seeks financing and technical aid. But radical hard-liners, who apparently hold greater sway over those holding the hostages, have repeatedly said they support hostage-taking as a way to confront the ``corrupt'' West. Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency carried excerpts of the Tehran Times editorial, which said Iran was working to get all hostages freed. Iran finances Hezbollah, or Party of God, the umbrella group for the Shiite Moslem factions holding most of the 18 Western hostages in Lebanon. Frenchwoman Jacqueline Valente, 32, Belgian Fernand Houtekins, 43, and their daughter, Sophie-Liberte, 2, were released Tuesday by the Palestinian terrorist group led by Abu Nidal and flown to Paris. The Tehran Times said it hoped their release was ``a prelude to freedom of all hostages regardless of their nationality, religion and belief.'' The Libya-backed guerrilla group held them for nearly 2{ years after grabbing them from a yacht off the Gaza Strip in 1987. Palestinian sources said the three had arrived in Lebanon from Libya by boat days before their release. Because they were believed held in Libya, their case is considered unrelated to the 18 Westerners held in Lebanon. The fate of those hostages is believed linked to a power struggle in the Iranian government. The hostages in Lebanon include eight Americans, four Britains, two West Germans, two Swiss, and Irishman and an Italian. The longest-held is Terry Anderson, the 42-year-old chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Most have been held for more than three years. Hostage Brian Keenan, an Irishman who taught English at the American University of Beirut, marked his fourth year as a hostage today with no word on his whereabouts. No group has claimed to hold the 39-year-old from Belfast, but he was seen kidnapped by gunmen as he walked to the university campus on April 11, 1986, shortly after he took up his teaching post in Beirut's Moslem sector. The Tehran Times said a large number of Moslems held in Israeli jails should also be considered hostages because they were imprisoned without due process. Freedom for hundreds of Lebanese Shiite Moslems jailed in Israel has been a repeated demand of all the groups claiming to hold Western hostages. The other demand has been freedom for 15 men, some related to influential Shiites in Lebanon, jailed in Kuwait. They have been imprisoned since 1983 for bombing attacks on the French and American embassies. Kuwait has said their prison sentences are not negotiable.

DOC.HEAD: Peacekeepers Arrive Amid Warnings of More War
DOC.TEXT: United Nations peacekeeping troops have arrived in Honduras to begin disbanding the Contra rebels, while the ruling Sandinistas warned there could be renewed fighting. A contingent of 170 Venezuelan paratroopers arrived Tuesday in Honduras, where the Contras have base camps. Their Spanish commander, Gen. Agustin Quesada Gomez, said Venezuela will send 700 soldiers. They will be joined by troops from several other countries. The United Nations observer force will supervise the demobilization in both Honduras and in Nicaragua and the destruction of their U.S.-supplied arms. The Contras on Nicaraguan territory are supposed to gather in ``safety zones'' once the U.N. peacekeeping force can ensure a cease-fire. About 9,000 Contras have gone back to Nicaragua in recent months, leaving the Honduran camps nearly deserted. The rebels agreed Monday to begin disbanding the remains of the Honduran force on April 18, but have not set a deadline for demobilization inside Nicaragua. The Sandinistas were pessimistic about demobilization Tuesday. The leftist party's newspaper Barricada and the pro-Sandinista daily El Nuevo Diario ran editorials and stories calling the accord nothing but a ploy to gain time and influence before the April 25 inauguration of Nicaragua's conservative president-elect, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro. They also accused the rebels and her United National Opposition of trying to take over the Sandinista People's Army. ``Unless this situation is resolved in the briefest term ... all the efforts for peace and reconciliation could ... revert into a fresh outbreak of the war,'' Barricada said. Barricada's editorials are considered the official Sandinista party line. The war between the U.S.-backed Contras and the Sandinistas has killed an estimated 30,000 people since it began in 1981, two years after the Sandinistas came to power in a revolution that toppled rightist dictator Anastasio Somoza.

DOC.HEAD: Guard Held Hostage in 12th British Prison Hit by Violence
DOC.TEXT: Forty inmates at a maximum-security prison attacked guards and took one hostage, officials said today. The prison was the 12th in Britain to be hit by violence this month. Two guards were injured in the incident Tuesday night, and a group of inmates continued to hold their hostage this morning, according to a statement by the Scottish Office, which operates Scottish prisons. The office said the hostage, 30-year-old prison guard Jim Rankin, appeared to be unharmed. Scores of police arrived as authorities began negotiations with inmates to try to secure his release. The Scottish Office said the 40 inmates involved smashed up cells before barricading themselves in on the second floor of B Hall at the Shotts Prison near the southwest Scottish port of Glasgow. The prison was built three years ago and has 434 prisoners. There was no immediate explanation for the violence. Other riots this month took place at aging, overcrowded prisons. Shotts is the 12th British prison or young offenders' institution to be hit by violence since April 1, when inmates rioted at Strangeways Prison in the northern English city of Manchester. Authorities at Strangeways said less than 20 prisoners today were still on the loose inside the prison refusing to surrender. One prisoner in Strangeways awaiting trial on charges of indecently assaulting three children died from injuries he received at the hands of other inmates. Relatives of inmates in the 122-year-old prison complained of overcrowding, unsanitary conditions and prisoners kept locked in their cells for up to 23 hours a day. In copycat violence, rioting subsequently occurred at Dartmoor Prison in southwest England, and prisons at Bristol in western England, Cardiff in Wales, Hull in northeast England, Leeds in northern England, and London's Pentonville and Brixton prisons. Rioting also occurred at three young offenders' institutions.

DOC.HEAD: Solidarity Chief Backs Away from Presidential Declaration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to ADD likely date for presidential election, new translation on Walesa quote on reaction to announcement, details on Walesa seeking Solidarity chairmanship, CORRECTS date of next parliamentary vote.
DOC.TEXT: Solidarity leader Lech Walesa told reporters today that his announcement that he would run for president was misconstrued and that he meant only to encourage more rapid reform. Walesa said his ``metaphor'' about running for president, in comments to the official Polish news agency on Tuesday, was a warning to the government to work faster in transforming Poland from a Communist to a democratic system. Nevertheless, politicians in Poland expressed little doubt today that Walesa would run for president, with the only question being when the voting would take place. President Wojciech Jaruzelski's term is not due to end until 1995, but there is a strong possibility that a general election for president will be moved up as part of an overhaul of the Polish Constitution. The most likely time for elections appears to be spring 1991, when Poland would be marking the 200th anniversary of its first written constitution. Jaruzelski is a former head of the now-dissolved Communist Party that ruled Poland until popular forces led by Solidarity won control of the government last year. He was elected by a Parliament seated after elections that were only partially free and under an arrangement that allowed his allies to hold on to the Defense and Interior Ministries in the Solidarity-led government. It had been widely expected that Walesa would seek to force Jaruzelski's early resignation. There has been no comment from Jaruzelski or his aides about a Walesa presidential bid. Jaruzelski began a trip to the Soviet Union today. Walesa, speaking with reporters today during a visit to his Gdansk union headquarters by Czechoslovak Deputy Premier Jan Carnogursky, predicted his remarks would lead to a political backlash. ``As a result of the announcement, I will surely not become president,'' Walesa said. He then stressed that his ``signal'' was aimed more at quickening the pace of reforms than putting himself into the president's office. ``The slogan in which I say that Lech Walesa is ready to run for president means that he wants to speed up reforms, so that the reforms are quicker and better, not that Lech Walesa wants to take the post of president,'' he said. Walesa added that his remarks to a reporter from the Polish press agency had been misconstrued. ``Today on radio and TV, I hear that Lech Walesa agreed to be president. I didn't say so at all,'' he said. ``I simply did not guard my tongue enough somewhere.'' The verbal retreat from his declaration of candidacy was vintage Walesa, who typically is circumspect in discussing his political moves and often makes seemingly contradictory statements. For instance, he hinted repeatedly in August that he would be Solidarity's candidate for prime minister, a factor that helped persuade two smaller parties long allied with the Communists to support a Solidarity-dominated government. In the end, Walesa handed the union nod to adviser Tadeusz Mazowiecki, who became the East bloc's first non-Communist prime minister. ``The fact that Walesa intends to run for president of the Polish Republic is not a surprise for me,'' Labor Party leader Wladyslaw Sila-Nowicki said in today's editions of the newspaper Rzeczpospolita. ``The circles connected with Lech Walesa have long been disclosing such intentions of the Solidarity chairman,'' said Marek Jurek, a Solidarity parliament deputy. At least one Solidarity deputy, Aleksander Malachowski, said Mazowiecki would be a better candidate for president. The discussion of a presidential bid by Walesa comes just days before the Solidarity labor union is due to hold its first national congress in nine years. Walesa has said he is committed to winning re-election as Solidarity chairman at next week's congress. But he is expected to face a challenge from union members who feel Solidarity has strayed from its original ideals of 1980 by putting politics ahead of trade-union goals such as defending workers' interests. Walesa has also found himself in conflict with the Mazowiecki government, which he has accused of acting too slowly in privatizing the state-dominated economy and removing other remnants of the old Communist system. In general, Solidarity members of Parliament and the government have been content to move more slowly toward new voting for Parliament and the presidency. The main argument for delaying new elections is that for the present a nationwide campaign would be too divisive and distract energies from the fundamental task of restructuring the economy and local governments. Local government elections are scheduled for May 27 and the next parliamentary vote is not due until 1993. Those close to Walesa have argued for holding elections more quickly because of public impatience for political change during a time of great economic sacrifice.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Blacks Killed In Clashes Nationwide
DOC.TEXT: Eight blacks were killed, including six by police fire, in dozens of clashes in black townships across the country, police said today. The police unrest report, which covered incidents from Monday night through this morning, listed 56 instances of violence nationwide, all in black areas. Today's unrest report was one of the lengthiest yet since violence erupted in black areas two months ago. More than 400 people have died, most of them in black factional fighting in the southeastern province of Natal. Six men died when police said they used combinations of shotguns, pistols, rubber bullets and tear gas at six separate locations to disperse mobs or ward off attackers. Three of the police shootings were in Natal Province, two in Transvaal province, and one in Cape Town. Two blacks were killed by mobs in separate incidents in Natal, police added. Police also said more than 200 people were arrested and dozens injured. Many of the incidents involved stone-throwing and the setting alight of vehicles, private homes and government offices in black areas. Some 4,000 people have died in the Natal fighting since 1986. The main combatants are supporters of the African National Congress and Inkatha, a relatively conservative Zulu organization. Both organizations have large numbers of youthful supporters they cannot control. The King Edward VIII Hospital in the port city of Durban said it was so overcrowded due to the Natal fighting that it has temporarily stopped admitting patients in need of surgery, even emergency cases. ``We simply cannot carry out any more surgery,'' said the hospital superintendent, Dr. A.M. Seedat. ``We have reached a situation where we cannot take on a single extra patient.'' Other hospitals in the areas also are at or near capacity due to the recent fighting.
