DOC.HEAD: Now It's Claytie and the Lady
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, bgng `With 96 percent' to UPDATE with 100 percent vote totals. Pickup 8th graf, `It was...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos AT2, AT4
DOC.TEXT: State Treasurer Ann Richards emerged victorious from a mudslinging Democratic gubernatorial runoff, setting up a November election battle that pundits quickly dubbed ``Claytie and the Lady.'' Ms. Richards now faces millionaire oilman-rancher Clayton Williams, who cruised to the GOP nomination with 61 percent of the primary vote March 13. Republican Gov. Bill Clements did not seek re-election. ``I have seen demolition derbies much like (this),'' Ms. Richards said of her down-and-dirty race against Attorney General Jim Mattox. She claimed her victory represented a condemnation of negative campaigning by Mattox, who kept charging that Ms. Richards was unfit to govern because of her refusal to say whether she had used illegal drugs. ``We certainly did put to rest the whole business of the mudslinging in this campaign. I think the people of Texas rejected that. That's one of the reasons I feel so good about this coming November,'' she said. With 100 percent of the ballots counted, Ms. Richards had 639,126, or 57 percent, to Mattox's 479,384, or 43 percent. It was Mattox's first election loss since 1966, when he fell three votes short in a contest for Democratic precinct chairman. Since then, he had won elections to the Texas House, Congress and two terms as attorney general. The Richards-Mattox faceoff was a mean-spirited one. Ms. Richards responded to the drug charges with claims that Mattox had profited from public service. She repeatedly challenged him to release his income tax returns. Mattox challenged Ms. Richards, a recovering alcoholic, to release medical records from her alcoholism treatment in 1980. The last week of the campaign brought newspaper reports that Mattox was seen smoking marijuana in the mid-1970s and that Ms. Richards was seen in a restroom where marijuana allegedly was being smoked in 1979. Both dismissed the reports. But Ms. Richards and Mattox quickly started the kiss-and-make-up process for the fight against Williams. ``There were other people in this primary who did not support our cause ... And it is time now that we reach out to them and tell them that we must be unified,'' Ms. Richards said. Mattox pledged to help. ``Ann Richards has proven she's a very strong candidate, proven that she can overcome this drug problem,'' he said. ``Clayton Williams doesn't need to be governor of Texas.'' Williams and the Republicans held their own rally Tuesday night in San Antonio. He indicated that Ms. Richards' refusal to say yes or no to questions of ever using illegal drugs wouldn't be an issue come fall. ``The rehash of the Democratic campaign is of no interest to me. Read my lips: No more mud,'' said Williams, who earlier had voiced some reluctance about facing a woman. ``I think what we'll be talking about _ and I hope Ann will join me _ is a real discussion of whose philosophy is the best way to win the war on drugs.'' Ms. Richards echoed the Republican's sentiments. ``Both Clayton Williams and I will work very hard to keep this an ideological campaign where we really do focus on the issues because we do have disagreements on the issues,'' she said. Williams spent more than $8 million _ $6 million from his own pocket _ in winning the GOP nomination. But Ms. Richards insisted she isn't worried about being outspent by a Republican ticket that also will include the well-funded U.S. Sen. Phil Gramm. ``I doubt seriously if we can match him dollar-for-dollar. But I don't think the governor's mansion is for sale,'' she said. ``In the first primary, I got 50,000 more votes than Clayton Williams and he spent eight times what I did.''

DOC.HEAD: Rehnquist Refuses to Block Rebroadcast of Hilary Foretich Documentary
DOC.TEXT: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist refused today to block rebroadcast of part of a cable television documentary about the child-custody battle over Hilary Foretich. Rehnquist rejected a request to keep a four-minute segment of the telecast off the air. The request was made by Nathan Lewin, a lawyer appointed to protect the interests of Hilary, 7. Lewin said each time the segment is aired it violates Hilary's privacy rights by letting more viewers see footage ``likely to be highly distasteful and embarrassing during (Hilary's) entire life.'' The documentary, first shown in this country on April 6, is scheduled for rebroadcast Saturday and again April 19 by Lifetime cable network. The documentary chronicles Hilary's odyssey with her maternal grandparents from Northern Virginia to England to New Zealand to avoid unsupervised visits with the girl's father, Dr. Eric Foretich. A four-minute portion of the British Broadcasting Corp. documentary, entitled ``Hilary in Hiding,'' shows the girl in a therapy session in which she demonstrates with dolls alleged sex abuse by her father. Foretich has denied abusing his daughter. U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin ordered the broadcast not to be shown last week. But hours later the U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overruled Sporkin and allowed the telecast. The girl's mother, Dr. Elizabeth Morgan, sent Hilary into hiding after a judge here ordered her to allow Foretich unsupervised visits with the girl. Morgan spent almost two years in jail for refusing to obey the judge's order. The case is Foretich vs. Lifetime Cable, A-701.

DOC.HEAD: Two More Kidnap Victims Killed, Train Bombed; Troops To Srinagar
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th graf, `The group...' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with five bombs found in another Bombay suburb. Pickup 6th graf `The New...'
DOC.TEXT: Militant Moslem separatists escalated their campaign for an independent Kashmir, killing two more hostages in Srinagar and bombing a crowded commuter train near Bombay today, police said. About 1,000 troops in battle gear were trucked into Srinagar, the center of the secessionist campaign in the mostly Moslem northern state bordering Pakistan. The bodies of the two hostages were found late Tuesday night, several hours after the body of another hostage was dumped near a Srinagar fire station. Their killings brought to at least 259 the number of people killed in Kashmir since a government crackdown in January. Telephone callers purporting to speak for the ``Mujahedeen Kashmir,'' or Islamic Holy Warriors of Kashmir, claimed responsibility for the bombing today that injured 34 people near the Malad station on the outskirts of Bombay, United News of India reported. Later today, police said they found five crude bombs hidden in a water tank in another Bombay suburb. It was not immediately known whether the discoveries were connected with the train bombing. The Mujahedeen Kashmir was first heard of Tuesday when it claimed responsibility for bomb blasts that injured at least nine policemen in two New Delhi police stations. The New Delhi and Bombay bombings were the first time any Kashmiri separatists had claimed responsibility for attacks outside Kashmir since the government of predominantly Hindu India launched a crackdown on the Moslem secessionists Jan. 20. Police found the bodies of the vice chancellor of Kashmir University, Mushir Ul-Haq, and his secretary, Abdul Ghani, dumped on a road near the city's airport late Tuesday, the police official said. Both men, who were Moslems, had been shot in the back. Earlier Tuesday, the body of L.M. Khera, a Hindu industrialist, was discovered with five bullet wounds. ``The dastardly murders ... are the grossest violations of human rights where innocent persons are being made victims of senseless externally inspired and motivated violence,'' Foreign Ministry spokesman Aftab Seth told reporters in New Delhi. All three were kidnapped Friday and threatened with execution if three top militants were not released. They were the first civilians not accused of being police informers to be killed by militants. The government had refused to negotiate. It imposed an around-the-clock curfew after the kidnappings and detained between 300 and 400 people it suspected of links with the secessionist movement. The killings triggered an even tighter crackdown on the secessionists. About 100 Indian army trucks carrying an estimated 1,000 soldiers were seen moving into Srinagar today. The state government ordered local police and civilians holding curfew passes to stay off the streets until further notice, said a senior police official who spoke on condition of anonymity. In New Delhi dozens of members of a Hindu militant group, the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Army, marched to the Pakistan Embassy and held a demonstration. ``We will crush Pakistan,'' shouted the demonstrators, who were prevented from reaching the embassy gate by police. The group was formed in March to counter the Moslem Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, which is leading the secessionist campaign. Prime Minister V.P. Singh, in the most aggressive statement yet by an Indian leader, said Tuesday that India should be ``psychologically prepared'' for an armed conflict with Pakistan over what he called the Islamic nation's territorial ambitions in the Kashmir Valley. Singh made the comments in Parliament hours after Khera's body was found. He accused Pakistan of fomenting the insurgency in the northern state of Jammu-Kashmir and could ``make a limited intervention.'' Pakistan ``will not get away with it,'' Singh said. ``You will have to pay a very heavy price and we have the capability to inflict this cost.'' Moslem-dominated Kashmir is a former princely state whose Hindu ruler opted for union with India in 1947 when the subcontinent was divided into Hindu-majority India and Islamic Pakistan. India and Pakistan fought wars over the region in 1948 and 1965. A U.N.-monitored cease-fire line separates the valley into Indian and Pakistani sectors. The two countries also fought a war in 1971 that led to the independence of Bangladesh.

DOC.HEAD: Ferry Captain Testifies Before Maritime Inquiry
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 16 grafs to UPDATE with captain testifying at maritime inquiry, quotes and details. Pickup 7th graf, ``They are...''
DOC.TEXT: The captain of the Scandinavian Star today testified at a maritime inquiry into last weekend's ferry disaster that he had been awakened by a crewman who told him, ``someone is playing arsonist.'' Capt. Hugo Larsen also rejected allegations by passengers that safety was substandard and that his crew of Filipino and Portuguese sailors was unprepared for an emergency. Police in Sweden said they have recovered the bodies of 127 people, but up to 200 people may have died when flames engulfed the 10,500-ton ship on a voyage from Norway to Denmark, in one of the worst recorded fires at sea. On Tuesday, a maritime commission from three Scandinavian countries agreed to crack down on foreign-flagged ships and tighten safety regulations for all passenger ferries. Larsen said he went to sleep at midnight, but was roused by an officer at 1:55 a.m. Saturday reporting that woolen blankets were burning in a passageway on the port side of the ship. ``Someone is playing arsonist,'' Larsen quoted the officer as saying. Shortly afterward another crew member reported smoke in the ship, and fire patrols discovered fires on both sides of the ship almost simultaneously, Larsen told the inquiry. The fire spread ``incredibly fast'' at the midships section, he said. The captain said he had checked safety and fire fighting systems and the crew underwent a boat drill before the ship's first Scandinavian voyage on April 1. A fire drill had been planned for Sunday, the day after the fire destroyed the ship, he said. He also rejected charges from passengers, who told reporters the crewmen could not communicate with them. He said most spoke ``usable English,'' and responded well in the crisis. The inquiry, headed by Maritime and Trade Court President Frank Poulsen, was expected to hear 15 or 20 witnesses. Norwegian police were heading a separate investigation. In Oslo, Norwegian police withdrew a decision to release the names of 186 people believed dead or missing from the fire on the voyage to the Danish port Frederikshavn. The list was intended to help clear up the mystery of how many people were on board the 20-year-old ferry when it caught fire. But deputy police chief Arne Huuse said families objected that it would appear more like ``a death list'' than a list of missing required for the investigation. Latest estimates put the number of passengers and crew at 530, but the figure has changed constantly as bodies were recovered and the fate of rescued passengers clarified. ``There were instances where people were listed twice,'' said Oeystein Berger of the Oslo police. In the Swedish port of Lysekil, investigators said the work of recovering bodies from the fire-gutted ship was slowing as it became harder to collect the remains. ``They are mostly ashes. Sometimes there are two, three or four people together,'' said police spokesman Leif Skoglund. The ferry was towed to Lysekil still smoldering on Saturday evening. It took until Sunday night to extinguish the fire, which burned at temperatures reaching 570 degrees, consuming everything combustible in the midships sections. At a meeting late Tuesday, the maritime directors of Sweden, Norway and Denmark approved tighter measures to inspect ships flying foreign flags of convenience in Nordic waters. About 60 million passengers travel Nordic routes every year, more than three times the total populations of the three countries. Twelve ships, including the Nassau-registered Scandinavian Star, fly foreign flags. The commission decided that the foreign-flagged ships should undergo safety checks by a Nordic maritime authority, said a statement released by the Danish Maritime Board. Until now, primary responsibility for safety standards has been with the registering country, and foreign-flagged ships were subjected to spot checks. The statement said crews must demonstrate fire fighting qualifications and training for emergency evacuations. The group also decided to require complete passenger lists on ferries traveling at night, it said.

DOC.HEAD: Wisconsin Adults Most Obese in Nation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT percent for Wisconsin to 28 percent sted 25.
DOC.HEAD: Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: For a third consecutive year, Wisconsin adults weighed in as the most obese in a national survey, probably due to a diet heavy in the state's best-known products: cheese, butter and bratwurst, a researcher says. ``Wisconsin has consistently had the highest percentage of obese adults among the 37 states surveyed over the past three years,'' said Dr. Patrick Remington, author of a study released Tuesday by the state Division of Health. One million Wisconsin adults, or about 28 percent of the adult population, are at least 20 percent overweight, the study said. Women are more likely to be overweight than men. Obesity was defined as 20 percent or more above desirable body weight, Remington said. Wisconsin, nicknamed America's Dairyland, was followed by West Virginia, Indiana, Michigan and North Dakota. States with the highest prevalence of obesity ``tended to be in the Upper Midwest,'' Remington said. ``I think that in the Upper Midwest we probably have a higher intake of dietary fat: cheese, butter, ice cream, bacon, sausages, bratwursts.'' Another factor could be the high percentage of ``Germanic and northern Europeans in our population'' and their greater tendency to be obese, he said. ``If both your parents were obese, you have an 80 percent chance of being obese,'' he said. ``If neither was obese, your chances are only 18 percent.'' The 1988 Behavior Risk Factor Telephone Survey found 30.3 percent of adult women were obese compared with 25.5 percent of adult men, Remington said. For example, a man who is 5 feet 10 inches tall and weighs more than 193 pounds would be obese. A woman who is 5-feet-4 and weighs mmore than 158 pounds would be obese, he said. Remington said the prevalence of obesity generally increased with age for women, peaking in the 45-54 age group and remaining high among older ages. For men, however, the risk of obesity declined among those in the older age groups, he said. Remington said the telephone survey in Wisconsin involved 1,272 telephone contacts. The survey was coordinated through the U.S. Centers for Disease Control, which provided identical questionnaires to the states and recommended 1,200 to 1,800 survey contacts in each state, he said. The study contained the following percentages on overweight adults for the top 20 states: Wisconsin, 28 percent of adults obese; West Virginia, 24.4 percent; Indiana, 24.1 percent; Michigan, 24 percent; North Dakota, 23.3 percent; District of Columbia, 23 percent; Kentucky, 23 percent; Missouri, 22.9 percent; South Dakota, 22.9 percent; Illinois, 22.7 percent; Alabama, 22.5 percent; Nebraska, 22.5 percent; Florida, 22.3 percent; Ohio, 21.9 percent; South Carolina, 21.5 percent; Maine, 21.5 percent; Massachusetts, 21.4 percent; California, 20.9 percent; Minnesota, 20.9 percent; New York, 20.8 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Quayle to Visit Mexico City After Trip to Nicaragua
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle will stop in Mexico City for talks with President Carlos Salinas after the April 25 presidential inauguration in Nicaragua, his office announced today. Quayle is leading the U.S. delegation to the inauguration in Managua of Violeta Chamorro, who defeated incumbent President Daniel Ortega in the Feb. 25 election. He will hold talks in Mexico City on April 26 with Salinas and other Mexican officials, returning to Washington that night, his office said.

DOC.HEAD: Snow Scattered Across North and Plains, Rain Sweeps Deep South

DOC.TEXT: Snow blanketed parts of Nebraska and northern New York today, and rain drenched the storm-swept Deep South. Rain fell in Ohio and Pennsylvania and down the Atlantic Coast as far south as Florida. Strong winds downed trees and power lines Tuesday across Alabama, northern Georgia and northwestern Florida. In northern and central Georgia, authorities in Troup, Houston and DeKalb counties reported tornadoes touching down, though there was no confirmation from the National Weather Service. Heavy rains closed Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport for about an hour. Storms also brought hail and damaging winds elsewhere in the South. Winds blew a mobile home off its blocks near Laurel, Miss., injuring one occupant. Hail was reported at Ashland, Ala. Light snow lingered in parts of Montana, Wyoming, North Dakota and Minnesota, and fell today in Omaha, Neb., and Buffalo, N.Y. Today's forecast called for showers in parts of Oregon, Washington and Idaho, and flurries in a crescent from northern Michigan and Wisconsin to New York. Rain was expected in parts of New England. Rain changing to thunderstorms was predicted along the Atlantic Coast States. The high temperature in the Lower 48 was 99 degrees at Palm Springs, Calif. DOC.HEAD: Protestants Demonstrate Against Haughey Visit To Belfast
DOC.TEXT: A crowd of 300 Protestant demonstrators hurled insults at Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey today as he arrived on a rare visit to the British-ruled province of Northern Ireland. Demonstrators gathered outside the Europa Hotel where Haughey delivered a speech to the Institute of Directors in his capacity as chairman of the European Community's Council of Ministers. The Rev. Ian Paisley, leader of the Protestant Democratic Unionist Party, and a dozen of his colleagues managed to get through a huge security cordon around the hotel to the rooftop of their nearby party headquarters. As Haughey's motorcade swept up to the hotel, Paisley and his group shouted down at him ``Haughey! Haughey! Out! Out! Out!'' and other taunts. The 95 percent Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland lays formal constitutional claim to predominantly Protestant Northern Ireland. Hundreds of police and security officers swarmed the area around the hotel, closing off roads to keep other demonstrators away. Marksmen took up positions on nearby rooftops. In his speech to business leaders, Haughey focused on economic issues and made no reference to the protests or to recent violence in Northern Ireland. Newspaper advertisements had urged Protestants to join the ``Haughey is not Welcome'' rally. Despite fears the protests could turn violent, there were no major scuffles and police said most demonstrators left after Haughey arrived.

DOC.HEAD: Striking Drivers to Face Charges in Shots Fired at Buses
DOC.TEXT: Two striking Greyhound drivers have been arrested by federal agents and charged with firing shots at a Greyhound bus last month in Illinois. Roy B. Simes, 35, and Harry T. Lewis, 42, both of suburban St. Louis, were scheduled to appear this afternoon before a U.S. magistrate in St. Louis who will determine whether they should be sent to Illinois to face federal charges filed Tuesday in East St. Louis federal court. They were being held without bond. The charges were in connection with a March 22 shooting of a bus in Collinsville, Ill., just across the state line from St. Louis. Authorities said Simes and Lewis were also considered suspects in another bus shooting in Missouri the same day, but no charges were immediately filed in that incident. The two were charged with endangering people on board a vehicle used in interstate or foreign commerce, commission of a felony with a firearm that has been transported in interstate commerce and use of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime. If convicted, Simes and Lewis could face up to 10 years in jail and a $10,000 fine. Using a firearm during the commission of a felony carries a mandatory five-year jail term. The federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms announced last week it was investigating the more than 30 Greyhound shootings that have occurred since 6,300 drivers and 3,000 other workers walked off the job March 2 over wages and job security. The men's arrests Tuesday were the second and third nationwide since a series of shootings involving Greyhound buses began last month. The other arrest took place March 16, when a striking driver was accused of shooting at a bus on March 12 near Hartford, Conn. Simes admitted he and Lewis were involved in the March 22 shootings involving a bus in Collinsville and one traveling on Interstate 55 about 12 miles south of St. Louis, Stephen Higgins of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms said in a sworn statement. The statement said Simes also consented to a search of his residence and turned over a .22-caliber revolver. No one was hurt in either shooting incident. Simes has been a Greyhound driver for 12 years and Lewis for 10 years, according to the court documents filed in East St. Louis. On Monday, Greyhound Lines Inc. filed a $30 million civil racketeering suit against the union in a Jacksonville, Fla., court, near the site of a previous sniping incident in which seven passengers were injured, two seriously.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-Con Singleton Arrested on Theft Charge
DOC.TEXT: Lawrence Singleton, a convicted rapist whose release from prison sparked a furor in California when several communities chased him out of town, has been arrested and accused of trying to steal a $10 camera. Singleton, 62, was not jailed after his arrest Sunday at a Brandon drug store but was given a notice to appear in court May 2 on the misdemeanor charge of petty theft, authorities said. A security guard at the Phar-Mor store spotted Singleton taking a disposable camera from a display, tucking it under his arm and try to exit the store without paying, a sheriff's report said. Singleton was convicted of raping a 15-year-old hitchhiker, hacking off her arms and leaving her for dead along a remote road in central California in 1978. He was freed in 1987 after serving eight years and four months of a 14-year sentence. He attempted to live quietly in several California communities after his release, but public outrage when his identity was discovered forced authorities to keep moving him for his own protection. He finally wound up in the Tampa area a year later. Singleton told deputies he lives at his sister's house in eastern Hillsborough County. A woman who answered the telephone there said Singleton stays alternately with his sister and his brother, who lives in northwest Tampa. The brother refused to comment.

DOC.HEAD: France Says it Didn't Barter for Hostages' Release
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts 2 grafs after 6th graf, `In an...' with analyst's comment, inserts 1 graf after 11th graf, `State Department ...' with newspaper comment.
DOC.TEXT: The French government responded to mounting criticism today by insisting it had not dealt with terrorists in negotiating the release of a French woman, her Belgian companion and their child. The three were released in Lebanon by Abu Nidal's Libyan-backed Palestinian terrorist group on Tuesday after 2{ years in captivity and flown to France, spending the night at a military hospital outside Paris. Foreign Minister Roland Dumas said negotiations for the release of the three, who were believed to have been held in Libya, were on the level of ``state to state.'' He said France ``did not speak with the abductors.'' Those who criticized the government's praise for Libyan leader Col. Moammar Gadhafi for helping to free the three were ``being picky,'' he said. Gadhafi has backed Abu Nidal, who along with some of his followers has been convicted of terrorist attacks abroad, reportedly allowing him to live near the Libyan capital of Tripoli. There have also been reports, however, that the Libyans have restricted the movements of Abu Nidal and his lieutenants. In an editorial today, the conservative newspaper Le Figaro branded Gadhafi the ``real abductor'' of the newly freed hostages. Paul Wilkinson, director of the Research Institute for the Study of Conflict and Terrorism, said the hostage release proves an ongoing link between Gadhafi and Abu Nidal. ``The public should be warned against euphoria over the latest hostage release in Lebanon,'' Wilkinson said in London. ``It was obtained by a deal which violates the European Community policy of `no concessions under duress to terrorists or their sponsors.''' A month ago, France returned to Libya three French-made Mirage jet fighters that had been in France for repairs since 1986. Libya, pressing for delivery of the aircraft, closed its ports to French ships in December. In its editorial, Le Figaro said: ``One imagines that the thank-yous addressed by Roland Dumas to Col. Gadhafi were part of a `deal' which permitted the end of three years of imprisonment.'' ``We have been working on this case for months,'' Dumas told reporters late Tuesday after the hostages' arrival. ``We alerted a large number of countries, particularly Libya. Our discussions were only state to state, with respect for the principles which are ours.'' Previous releases of French hostages by pro-Iranian Lebanese groups prompted charges that France barters with terrorists, claims France has denied. State Department officials in Washington welcomed the release but were critical of France's warm words for Gadhafi. ``Such rhetoric is nauseating,'' the British newspaper The Independent wrote in an editorial criticizing France. President Francois Mitterrand had personally thanked Gadhafi for his ``determining'' role in the releases, and Dumas declared that tense French-Libyan relations would now improve. ``France is being nicer to Libya than we think they should be,'' said one of the State Department officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The U.S. officials said France and other countries should press Libya to expel the group and stop alleged efforts to make chemical weapons. Jacqueline Valente, 32, Fernand Houtekins, 43, and their 2-year-old daughter Sophie-Liberte made no public statements upon their arrival, refusing to discuss conditions of their captivity or where they were held. They were taken to a military hospital and all appeared healthy. The three had been dropped off at the French Embassy in Beirut Tuesday morning by masked gunmen in cars with drawn curtains. Ms. Valente and Houtekins were seized in November 1987 from a French yacht off the Gaza Strip and the Abu Nidal group accused them of collaborating with Israeli intelligence. Friends said they were on a holiday cruise. Their release leaves four Belgians abducted with them _ Houtekins' brother Emmanuel and his family _ still held hostage. Two other daughters of Ms. Valente were freed as a result of Libyan intervention on Dec. 29, 1988. Dumas told reporters that French and Belgian authorities remained in contact for the release of the four. Nidal's group linked freedom for them to the release of Nasser Sa'eed, a Palestinian serving a life term in Belgium for a June 1980 grenade attack on Jewish youths in Antwerp. The Belgian government has not responded to the offer. Because the hostages were believed to have been held in Libya, the case is considered unrelated to the 18 Westerners, including eight Americans, held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem factions. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Gadhafi said Tuesday that the Abu Nidal group was ``distancing'' itself from its terrorist reputation by releasing the hostages, Libya's official news agency JANA reported. The group has been blamed for scores of terrorist acts, including the December 1985 attacks on Rome and Vienna airports that killed more than 20 people.

DOC.HEAD: Telescope Resting Inside Discovery at Launch Pad
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Hubble has...', to DELETE erroneous reference to protective cover on telescope.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto staffing, LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: It should be orbiting 380 miles high today and looking at the heavens, but instead the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope rests inside space shuttle Discovery, shielded from earthly dust and debris. The shuttle's launch was scrubbed four minutes before liftoff Tuesday because of a malfunctioning power unit, and NASA said the mission will be attempted again in a week or two. The space agency needs the time to replace the unit and recharge the telescope's batteries. ``We are certainly concerned about contamination every day that we're here on Earth, and we will do everything we have done in the past to assure that we take care of any problem like that,'' said Fred Wojtalik, a NASA project manager. Hubble has a 94-inch mirror that is the finest ever made and even a speck of dust would impair its efficiency. The delay was the latest of many for Hubble, NASA's most expensive and complex payload. The telescope originally was scheduled to take its place in space in 1983, but technical problems and the 1986 Challenger explosion interfered. Wojtalik said the National Aeronautics and Space Administration had not decided whether to charge the telescope's nickel-hydrogen batteries while they are inside the orbiter or at a laboratory. Discovery's commander, Loren J. Shriver, said before heading back to Johnson Space Center in Houston today that he and the other four astronauts are ``disappointed just like everybody else.'' ``That's kind of the name of the game,'' he said. ``We go when the equipment is ready to go, and we're always ready to go.'' The hundreds of astronomers gathered at Kennedy Space Center for the launch also went home disappointed. ``We came in and it was bad weather, so we had very low expectations. Then the weather cleared up and it was beautiful and all our spirits went up with it,'' said Francesco Paresce, a scientist with the European Space Agency. ``Until four minutes, everything was fine and gorgeous. Then bang, back down to depression. So it's been a swing which is really incredible,'' he said. The countdown had moved uninterrupted to the four-minute mark when sensors detected that one of three auxiliary power units was running too fast. Computers halted the launch process. ``We don't like to find problems late in the launch count,'' said launch Director Bob Sieck. ``However, when we have problems, we do like to find them on the ground, and that part of the system worked.'' The auxiliary power units pressurize the shuttle's hydraulic system, which is used to move wing and rudder surfaces and in the ship's braking and steering systems. NASA forbids a liftoff unless all three units operate properly. NASA will have to remove the 100-pound unit from Discovery while the shuttle is in an upright position, something the space agency has never done before. Auxiliary power units have caused postponements of shuttle launches twice previously, but the work was performed before the shuttle reached the launch pad. Tuesday's scrub cost NASA $377,000 in fuel and $247,000 in labor and materials. That excludes the cost of other NASA centers supporting the mission. The delay, irksome though it was to many, didn't bother John Holtzman of the Lowell Observatory at Flagstaff, Ariz. ``The universe has been around for a long time,'' he said. ``It will stay around for a couple more days.''

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers throughout the country. April 10 Portland (Maine) Press Herald on Poindexter: Like Oliver North before him, former National Security Adviser John Poindexter has been convicted of criminal charges growing out of the Reagan administration's Iran-Contra scandal. So, why care? President Reagan's watch has ended. A free election has been held in Nicaragua. The Ayatollah Khomeini is dead. Poindexter's and North's military careers have been ruined. True, American hostages remain prisoners, but why not let the scandal rest? Because, in the name of patriotism, Poindexter and North rode roughshod over our concept of government as one of laws, not men. They established a shadow government in the National Security Council that cavalierly made and carried out secret foreign policy. In the process, they broke the laws they were pledged to protect. That's worth remembering.

April 5 Burlington County Times, Willingboro, N.J., on abortion and politics: It doesn't matter how you stand on abortion, or even if you elect to avoid the argument altogether, there's one aspect of the issue that bids to do you harm. That's today's tendency to put all the eggs in one political basket, to vote for or against a candidate strictly on how he or she stands on abortion. At least one organization actually targeted New Jersey candidates for defeat at the polls if they did not measure up to the organization's stand on abortion. The National Organization for Women actually tried to boycott an entire state, Idaho, and a defenseless vegetable, the potato. Though the state Legislature passed a restrictive abortion measure there, Idaho's Gov. Cecil Andrus _ perhaps fearing for the fiscal health of his fiefdom _ reversed the process with a last-minute veto. We oppose the notion that candidate should be thrown out of office (or thrown in for that matter) just because of a stand on one issue. The abortion issue is an emotional one, but it has a direct effect on only a small percentage of marchers on either side, including those who fail for one reason or another to use readily available preventive measures. Our political system is often perceived as corrupt, but there is little excuse for our corrupting it deliberately.

April 6 The Press-Enterprise, Riverside, Calif., on ``foreign'' cars: The battered American automobile industry received another blow from its foreign competitors last year when the Honda Accord became the best-selling car in the United States. The Accord is about to set another precedent in the continuing transformation of the American automobile market: The 1991 models turned out at Honda's Marysville, Ohio, plant may be officially designated ``American'' cars by the federal government. The Environmental Protection Agency, which monitors the content and fuel efficiency of all cars sold in the U.S., conveys that designation on vehicles that have more than 75 percent American ``content'' _ the parts and labor used to build them. ... The Japanese cars bought by American consumers are increasingly built by Americans, often with predominantly American-made parts. Honda's plants in Ohio, for example, turn out virtually all of the Honda Civic models sold here and most of the Accords. During the past three years, Japanese auto makers have opened eight manufacturing plants in the United States _ the same number that the American Big Three has closed during that period. Many of those displaced Americans now work for Toyota, Nissan and Honda _ the newest immigrants. Americans with a true preference for foreign cars might have to go back to those European models.

DOC.TEXT: April 5 Red Wing (Minn.) Republican Eagle on America's appetite for oil: Joseph Hazelwood will be doing his time cleaning up the oil-soaked shoreline as payment for his role in misguiding the Exxon Valdez. The fiasco of the Exxon Valdez, however, is one tiny piece of a much bigger issue. That's the gluttony of Americans when it comes to cheap energy. The overconsumption of oil places more pressure on our domestic sources. That in turn steps up the intensity to rely solely on such deposits as those along Alaska's North Shore. The tragedy of the Exxon Valdez taught us all a bitter and long-lasting lesson. It rightfully has spurred Congress to pursue tougher sanctions such as mandatory double-hulling of ships to prevent future disasters. In the short term, the Valdez incident emphasizes the need for the industry to hire competent employees and to operate under stricter standards. In the long run, America must reduce its appetite for energy if it's to lessen the pressure to take the type of shortcuts which permitted the tragic accident in Alaska.

April 8 The Independence (Kan.) Daily Reporter on energy savings: A recent report on the National Resource Defense Council's new electricity-frugal headquarters in New York points the way to huge nationwide energy savings. The technology is available; the payback time for additional costs is reasonable. What we need is the national will to do what is required. The council, aided by a $100,000 power company grant, spent $166,000 more than the cost for normal lighting. But it expects to retrieve that amount in about three years through electricity savings. Congress, whose initiative years ago hastened the development of more fuel-efficient cars, ought to consider similar legislative action to prod businesses and speculative builders into following the NRDC's lead.

April 10 The Joplin (Mo.) Globe on funding the arts: Rep. Mel Hancock, R-Mo., is still swinging from the floor in delivering verbal haymakers to the solar plexus of the federally subsidized arts. Last week, the southwest Missourian urged a congressional panel to halt the federal government from bankrolling the National Endowment for the Arts. He disparaged the NEA as just another wasteful bureaucracy _ in many cases an obscene waste. He complained that federal money had gone to the arts that he described as ``obscene, indecent, sacrilegious and racist, which are offensive to the vast majority of our nation's taxpayers.'' ... It has been said that a culture defines itself by the limits it sets for its people. We sense that either severe constraints are coming down the pike for the National Endowment for the Arts or abolishment of the agency. The latter is preferred.

April 7 Shawano (Wis.) Evening Leader on college basketball: March Madness lived up to its name this season, with the college basketball tournament more competitive than it has ever been. But while the game itself couldn't be healthier, there are still many problems with a sport that puts such a high price on winning. College presidents talk of running clean programs with an emphasis on players who graduate. Then they turn around and fire coaches who do both of those things. Why? Because their teams don't win more often. The system that is still being used amounts to nothing more than a tremendous incentive to cheat. Currently, each of the 64 schools selected for the NCAA tournament receives upwards of $250,000, with each ensuing tournament victory worth an additional $250,000. Schools that advance to the Final Four are raking in over $1 million. Unless the system is changed, those numbers are only going to increase next year, when the NCAA enters into a seven-year, $1 billion TV contract with CBS, in effect tripling the money from the last contract. ... The tournament's growing popularity has nothing to do with the money involved. It would be followed just as closely if the players were playing strictly for a championship trophy, and not some million-dollar check for their school. Besides, there is something inherently wrong about unpaid amateur athletes earning enormous sums of money for an institution. By simply distributing the $1 billion among all 291 Division I schools and eliminating the huge financial rewards given to winning teams, some of the pressures on coaches and athletes would be removed.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Businesses Planning 7.6 Percent Increase in Spending
DOC.NOTE: EDs: CORRECTS 4th graf, This year, to make it fourth, sted third, consecutive increase
DOC.TEXT: American businesses plan to increase spending on plant and equipment by a healthy 7.6 percent this year, the government said today in a report reflecting renewed optimism about the economy. The Commerce Department said a survey completed in March found businesses planning to spend $503.4 billion for expansion and modernization this year. If realized, that would surpass the previous record of $467.8 billion in capital spending set last year. This year would mark the fourth consecutive increase in investment. However, the rate of growth would be the slowest in three years. Capital spending rose 8.6 percent in 1989, 8.9 percent in 1988 and 4.2 percent in 1987. The new estimate for capital spending growth in 1990 is only slightly below last year's rise and represents a substantial increase from an earlier survey of 1990 plans released in December. At that time, businesses said they planned to boost spending by only 4.9 percent. All of the figures have been adjusted for inflation. The earlier survey occurred when many economists were predicting a recession this year. Since then, the economy has proved more resilient than expected and as a consequence companies have planned for expansion more optimistically. The projected increase in spending would be good news for the economy, providing needed momentum this year at a time when the stimulus from a shrinking trade deficit is fading. Economists say the increased productivity that results from investment spending is the only way in the long run to bolster economic growth. The Federal Reserve Board has been keeping interest rates relatively high in an attempt to keep the economy from overheating and fueling inflation. The 7.6 percent investment increase for all industries includes a 4.6 percent rise in manufacturing and a 9.5 percent increase for companies engaged in mining, transportation and other non-manufacturing areas. Manufacturing and housing have been the sectors of the economy hardest hit by the Fed's tight money policy. Manufacturers are projecting investment spending this year of $190.2 billion. The anticipated rate of increase, although lower than the average for all industries, was still sharply up from the 1.4 percent projection in December. The manufacturing gain includes a 2.2 percent rise in durable goods and a 6.6 percent increase for non-durables. Durable goods are ``big ticket'' items expected to last three or more years _ everything from washing machines to warships. Because buyers usually borrow to buy durable goods, their sales are more sharply depressed by high interest rates. In the December survey, durable goods manufacturers had projected a 1.5 percent drop in investment spending.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS items on Robb, Robinson; No separates moved for the PMs cycle. Sobek also moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Harrison L. Winter, former chief judge of the Fourth Circuit U.S. Court of Appeals, died Tuesday of lung cancer at age 69. Winter was appointed by President John F. Kennedy in 1961 to the U.S. District Court in Maryland. He was an assistant state attorney general and was Baltimore city solicitor from 1959 to 1961. He was appointed to the appeals court in 1966 and became chief judge in 1981. He stepped down last year because of his illness. As a lawyer and judge, Winter was a member of the American Bar Foundation, the American Law Institute, the American College of Trial Lawyers and the Judicial Conference of the United States.

J. Kenneth Robinson, a Virginia Republican who served seven terms in the U.S. House of Representatives, has died of complications from pancreatic cancer. He was 73. Robinson died Sunday at his Frederick County home, said his former administrative assistant, Chris Mathisen. Robinson represented the state's 7th District, in northern Virginia, from 1970 until in 1985, when he said he was retiring from politics because he was frustrated wiith being in the minority. During his tenure, Robinson earned a reputation as a fiscal conservative who pushed for a strong defense. He concentrated on budgetary matters in the agricultural, defense and intelligence fields. Robinson was born May 14, 1916, in Frederick County. He received a bachelor of science degree in horticulture from Virginia Tech in 1937 and then entered the family orchard business. He served as an Army major during World War II. In 1965, Robinson assumed the state Senate seat held by Harry F. Byrd Jr., who was appointed to the U.S. Senate to replace Byrd's father. Robinson held the seat until he was elected to Congress.

David M. Robb, professor emeritus of art history at the University of Pennsylvania, died Monday at his home. He was 86. Robb retired in 1974 after 35 years on the faculty of the University of Pennsylvania. He was chairman of the art history department from 1939 to 1955. In 1956-57 he received both a Guggenheim fellowship and a Fulbright research scholarship. He was president of the Art Association of America in 1960. Born in Tak Hing Chau, China, he graduated from Oberlin College in 1926 and received a doctorate in Princeton University in 1941. He served on the faculty of Colgate University and the University of Minnesota before going to Pennsylvania.

Jim White, a former U.S. Mint security guard who lost a campaign for sheriff against a dead man, died Monday in a plane crash in Texas. He was 36. In White's 1986 campaign for San Mateo County Sheriff, incumbent Brendan Maguire died of a heart attack five weeks before the election but still was elected by a 4-to-1 margin. The county supervisors appointed then-undersheriff Leonard Cardoza as acting sheriff. White ran again for sheriff again in June 1987, finishing fourth in a field of six candidates.

George Sobek, who spent 40 years in the Chicago White Sox organization as a scout and manager, died Monday at age 70. The cause of death was not disclosed. Sobek was a scout and minor league manager from 1945 to 1985 for the White Sox. During his tenure he signed 30-game winning pitcher Dennis McLain to the team and recruited pitcher Steve Trout and first baseman Mike Squires. Sobek left the team in 1985 to scout for the Giants.
DOC.HEAD: Anthony ``Cap'' Watkins
DOC.TEXT: Anthony ``Cap'' Watkins, the first black police captain in Indianapolis, died Monday at age 73. Watkins worked for the Indianapolis Police Department for 24{ years until his retirement in 1968. Earlier this year he was named by Gov. Evan Bayh a Sagamore of the Wabash, the highest civilian award bestowed by the governor.

DOC.HEAD: Man Convicted Through Ear Impression on Doors
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of more than 30 burglaries was identified and convicted through ear imprints he left on the doors of the apartments he burglarized. A Lausanne court Tuesday sentenced Gregore Roman, a 39-year-old Romanian exile, to three years in prison. Authorities said he was part of a gang that netted $200,000 in valuables through burglaries in western Switzerland in 1988. Before breaking in, Roman would put his ear to the door of a home to be sure no one was home. Police experts said they positively identified Roman's ear impressions in 11 cases.

DOC.HEAD: Ultimate Easter Egg Not For Eating
DOC.TEXT: The ultimate Easter egg was unveiled Wednesday in London, but it's not for eating or painting on Easter Sunday. The egg, valued at $11.5 million, is made from 33 pounds of gold and nearly 20,000 pink diamonds. It is called the Argyle Library Egg and was commissioned by Argyle Diamonds of Perth, Australia, which markets precious gems. The 15-inch-hih egg opens electronically to reveal a revolving stand of miniature books and portraits in jeweled cabinets. It sits on a gold and diamond stand nearly as high as the egg itself. ``We don't know who might be likely to buy it,'' said the egg's designer, Paul Kutchinsky, who runs a jewelry design business in London. His team of craftsmen labored more than 7,000 hours over two years to make the egg. Its design was inspired by the Easter egg gifts of the Faberge jewelry-makers for the Russian imperial family before the 1917 revolution. The Argyle egg will be displayed at a watch and jewelry fair in Basel, Switzerland, April 19-26, and in London's Victoria and Albert Museum until May 6. After that it will be shown in Tokyo and New York.

DOC.HEAD: Chief of Army's Communist Party Dies
DOC.TEXT: Admiral Petar Simic, chief of the Communist Party within the Yugoslav armed forces, died in Belgrade on Wednesday of a brain hemorrhage, the Tanjug news agency reported. He was 57. Simic had advocated strong army and Communist Party influence in Yugoslav politics. His hard-line stands were often criticized by the media and officials in Slovenia and Croatia, the liberal Yugoslav republics that have rejected Communist Party monopoly. Tanjug made no mention of survivors.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Shakes Northern Japan
DOC.TEXT: A moderate earthquake struck the city of Kushiro and neighboring areas on Japan's northernmost main island of Hokkaido on Wednesday, but police said there were no immediate reports of injuries or major damage. The Central Meteorological Agency said the quake occurred at 4:53 p.m., roughly 40 miles off the coast of Kushiro in the Pacific Ocean. The agency said the quake registered 5.5 on the Richter scale. It was strong enough to topple vases and other objects in people's homes. The Richter scale gauges the energy released by an earthquake. A quake of 5.5 can cause considerable damage in a populated area.

DOC.HEAD: Floods Kill At Least 50 People, Leave Thousands Homeless
DOC.TEXT: Rescue workers used helicopters and canoes Wednesday to search for survivors of floods that killed at least 50 people and left about 30,000 homeless in southeast Tanzania, officials said. After rivers burst their banks a week ago, thousands of homes were destroyed and bridges were washed away. It was the coastal region's worst flooding in 50 years. Heavy rains continued to lash the Indian Ocean port town of Mtwara and surrounding villages Wednesday, government officials said. The death toll, reported Saturday at 27, has risen to more than 50, they said. The final toll was expected to be higher. Flooding disrupted communications to many regions, making it difficult to obtain accurate information. In Dar es Salaam, the capital of this east African nation, officials estimated that some 72,000 people in the southeast needed emergency relief supplies.

DOC.HEAD: Two Crewmen Missing After Danish Trawler Sinks
DOC.TEXT: Two crewmen were missing after a Danish fishing boat sank off the Dutch North Sea coast Wednesday, the Coast Guard said. The H.B. Brock sank shortly before 9 a.m. approximately 75 miles northwest of the Dutch port of Den Helder, said Coast Guard spokesman Don Pimentel. Three helicopters were searching Wednesday afternoon for the two missing crewmen. Two other crewmen were rescued from a life raft by nearby ships, according to Dutch Television. There was no immediate report of the circumstances surrounding the sinking, and the identities of the missing crewmen were not immediately available.

DOC.HEAD: Freighter and Tanker Crash, Leaving Oil Spill
DOC.TEXT: A cargo ship crashed into the side of an oil tanker in western Japan on Wednesday and caused a 2-mile-long oil spill, an official at the Maritime Safety Agency said. The freighter Sumiryu Maru went out of control and smashed into the No. 10 Waei Maru in Osaka Bay, the official said. No injuries were reported, but the impact ripped a hole in the tanker and created the oil spill, according to the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He said the amount of oil leaked was not immediately available. The 121-ton tanker was fueling a ferry boat when it was hit by the 499-ton freighter, he said. The agency was questioning the Sumiryu Maru's captain about the cause of accident, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Sticky Mess After Train Strikes Molasses Tanker
DOC.TEXT: A freight train plowed into a tractor-trailer carrying molasses, dumping 48,880 pounds of the brown goo on the tracks. City workers, volunteers and representatives of the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency spent hours cleaning up the spill. They dumped sawdust and sand on the molasses and used suction devices. The driver was taking the molasses to the nearby Purina Mills plant when the accident occurred Tuesday morning. The train was moving about 15 mph when it struck the tractor-trailer's tank, said police Officer Guy Forberger. None of the 21 cars in the Norfolk & Western train derailed, and no one was injured. The truck driver, David Wise, of Tremont, Ill., was cited for obstructing the path of the train, Forberger said. Circleville is in central Ohio about 25 miles south of Columbus.

DOC.HEAD: Separate Earthquakes Rock New Zealand's South, North Islands
DOC.TEXT: A moderate earthquake rocked the lower part of the South Island on Wednesday, just hours after a smaller quake shook the lower North Island. Authorities said there were no immediate reports of injuries or major damage. The southern earthquake, measuring 5 on the Richter scale, occurred at 9:45 a.m. and appeared to be centered in the Fiordland National Park along the island's southwestern coast, said seismologist Murray Lowry of the Department of Science and Technology. Residents reported ``a rocking sort of motion'' that rattled windows, said Lloyd Matheson, a local policeman. The northern earthquake, centered north of Wellington, the capital, measured 4.5 on the Richter scale and occurred at 5.46 a.m. The Richter scale is a measure of ground motion as measured by seismographs. Every increase of one number means a 10-fold increase in magnitude.

DOC.HEAD: Barbara Bush, Celebrities to Attend Ryan White Funeral
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with five grafs to UPDATE with Mrs. Bush heading to Indianapolis, mourners at church. Picks up 3rd graf, `The eulogy...'. Note funeral set for 3 p.m. EDT
DOC.TEXT: Elton John handed tissues to tearful mourners at a viewing ceremony for Ryan White, who inspired compassion for AIDS sufferers while losing a 5{-year battle to the disease. White was to be buried today at a ceremony that Barbara Bush, Gov. Evan Bayh, pop star Michael Jackson and others promised to attend. The first lady flew to Indianapolis along with White House physician Burton Lee, who is a former member of the president's National Commission on AIDS. About 300 people were waiting outside the church this morning before visitation began. ``To me he was inspiration to all young people, his fight for life and everthing else he went through,'' said Gladys Lewis, who was among the mourners. ``I'm glad to see that he was so thought of that so many are here. It shows that somehow we all learned something from his battle.'' The eulogy was to be read by the Rev. Raymond ``Bud'' Probasco, chosen by the 18-year-old White in his dying days. Probasco grew close to the youth while serving at St. Luke's United Methodist Church in Kokomo. White, who won a court battle to attend public school near Kokomo and later became a spokesman for sufferers of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, died Sunday of lung congestion from an AIDS-related respiratory infection. He contracted AIDS in 1984 from blood products used to treat his hemophilia. Between 1,000 and 1,500 people filed past White's casket at the funeral home in Carmel, an Indianapolis suburb, Tuesday afternoon and evening. Jackson was among family and close friends who paid last respects earlier before the home was opened to the general public, said Brian Buchanan, vice president of Flanner & Buchanan Mortuaries. White's body was outfited with a red pullover shirt and a faded jean jacket, and his eyes were covered with sunglasses. A photograph of a baby rested in the knotty pine casket with him. The viewing area, set up by White's mother, Jeanne White, featured floral arrangements, a painted portrait, magazine covers that told his story and photographs of White with celebrities, including Lukas Haas, who portrayed him in a made-for-TV movie, actress Loni Anderson and Indiana University basketball coach Bob Knight. Pop singer John, who had comforted the family during the youth's final days in the hospital, accompanied Mrs. White to the funeral parlor and handed out tissues to mourners. The callers included Dr. Martin Kleiman, an infectious disease specialist who treated Ryan after he contracted AIDS in 1984. In today's edition of The Washington Post, former President Ronald Reagan wrote a column, saying White ``was patient and kind and did not wallow in self-pity.'' ``We owe it to Ryan to open our hearts and our minds to those with AIDS,'' Reagan wrote. ``We owe it to Ryan to be compassionate, caring and tolerant toward those with AIDS, their families and friends. It's the disease that's frightening, not the people who have it.''

DOC.HEAD: Fomer Circus Performer Convicted of Slashing Guard
DOC.TEXT: A former circus performer who prosecutors said can swallow and regurgitate sharp objects at will was convicted of slashing a jail guard. The blade was never found. Benjamin Carnesoltas, 36, was convicted Tuesday of assault for cutting the neck of Municipal Corrections Institution officer John Wickizer on Oct. 29. The injury required about nine stitches. The defense said reasonable doubt existed because no one found the razor blade. ``He swallows razor blades and brings them back,'' Assistant prosecutor Jim Humphrey told Jackson County Circuit Court jurors. ``I wouldn't be surprised if he had one now.'' Jail records indicated that guards had seen Carnesoltas move his throat and produce parts of razor blades or sharp metal on about five occasions. Carnesoltas, who came to the United States in the 1980 Mariel boat lift from Cuba, testified he could not swallow sharp objects. He said he was a circus trapeze performer in Cuba, not a knife artist. Prosecutors said he either was a sword swallower or learned that talent while working in the circus. Carnesoltas had been out of a Missouri prison for nine days after being paroled on a burglary charge when he attacked Wickizer at the jail, authorities said. He had been sent there to complete a term for a 1987 assault conviction and escape charge. Carnesoltas faces a possible sentence of one to 10 years. Judge John R. O'Malley set sentencing for May 11.

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Launches Atlas Rocket With Three Science Satellites
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, bgng `Worsdale said...' with 1 graf to UPDATE with satellites reaching orbit. SUBS last graf with 6 grafs to UPDATE with details of experiments aboard.
DOC.TEXT: An Atlas-E rocket roared toward space today, carrying three small scientific satellites on a $22 million mission aimed at improving military communications and aiding navigation. The 96-foot rocket lifted off the pad at Space Launch Complex-3 at 8 a.m., said Maj. Tom Worsdale, an Air Force spokesman at this sprawling coastal military base 140 miles northwest of Los Angeles. ``It looked excellent,'' he said. ``It's the smoothest launch I've seen in the year I've been here. Everything went perfect.'' Worsdale said the rocket flew south over the Pacific Ocean, and the satellites, weighing from 120 to 150 pounds each, went into orbit at 8:15 a.m. The three satellites, containing four experiments, were propelled toward a 460-mile polar orbit by the Atlas, which was topped by a Scout-Altair upper stage booster. The mission was named P87-2 Stacksat. The Air Force hasn't explained the meaning of P87-2, but Stacksat means the satellites were stacked atop the rocket for launch. The Atlas, similar to the one that lifted John Glenn to the first manned orbit of Earth in 1962, was built by General Dynamics and once served as a nuclear warhead-tipped intercontinental ballistic missile at Forbes Air Force Base in Kansas. It was refurbished in 1987 for use in launching payloads into space. The instruments on the three research satellites will help make navigation charts and test ways to overcome phenomena in Earth's atmosphere that can interfere with military and other communications. The devices will be turned on in about 30 days and operate for at least a year, Capt. Mark Goodman, project manager, said in a statement issued before the launch. The uppermost satellite, named Polar Orbiting Geomagnetic Survey, contains two experiments. The first is a magnetometer that will measure the strength of the Earth's magnetic field at various locations. The data will be used to help construct new Defense Mapping Agency geomagnetic charts, which are updated every five years as the magnetic field changes. The satellite also contains the Solid State Recorder experiment, meant to demonstrate the use of high-speed integrated circuit designs as computer memory devices in space, said Ed Parsons, chief spokesman for the Air Force's Space Systems Division in Los Angeles. The second satellite, named TEX, or Transceiver Experiment, will study communications problems by bouncing radio waves off the ionosphere, the part of Earth's atmosphere rich with electrically charged particles. The third satellite, the Selective Communications Experiment, carries a variable-power radio transmitter that will also bounce radio waves of varying frequencies off the ionosphere for similar studies.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Recalls the Day John Dillinger Held Her Hostage
DOC.TEXT: It was more than half a century ago, but Ruth Harris Davidson still remembers the day she held hands with bank robber John Dillinger. The desperado and an accomplice had just robbed the National Bank of Fostoria of $17,000, shot seven people, and was speeding out of town with Mrs. Davidson balanced precariously on the running board of the careening getaway car. The robbery occurred May 3, 1934, during one of Dillinger's Midwestern crime sprees. Since then Mrs. Davidson, then a teller at the bank, has lived what she terms ``a quiet life.'' But events of that day still bring a sparkle to her eyes. She chuckled on learning recently that the Warner Bros. movie studio is scouting northwest Ohio for a place to film a movie about Dillinger. She lives in Bowling Green, about 20 miles northwest of Fostoria. Mrs. Davidson, 78, recalled her suprise at the suddenness of the holdup by Dillinger and Homer Van Meter, and the whirlwind pace of her kidnapping. ``They came in and both were wearing long coats,'' she said. ``One of them _ I can't remember which _ shouted, `Everybody out of the cages.' ... I thought it was a joke until they brought out the machine guns from under the coats.'' Employees were lined up across the glass entrance to shield the holdup men from police gunfire from outside. Dillinger ordered bank president Andrew Emerine to open the vault. ``When he took a little too long to get the keys, Van Meter shredded the glass partition between the cages and vault with his machine gun and they went in,'' Mrs. Davidson said. ``Then they came out and cleaned the money out of the tellers' cages. I can remember just standing there shivering.'' When the bandits fled, Mrs. Davidson said, ``Van Meter grabbed me and held me in front of him.'' They also took another employee as a hostage. ``I can only remember saying, `I'll do anything, I just want to go home to my mother.''' They made the hostages stand on the running boards of the car to keep police from shooting as they sped away. `We thought we were going to fall off or the car would tip over. We had to scoot down against the wind, and Dillinger held onto my hand the whole time,'' Mrs. Davidson said. Two miles out of town, the bandits slowed down, thanked their hostages politely, and told them to jump. They then drove away. ``It was a long time before I wasn't afraid of something happening,'' she said. ``I didn't follow Dillinger's career after that. ... But I still feel that man's arm around me once in a while.'' Dillinger was killed by police in Chicago two months later.

DOC.HEAD: Businesses Revise Capital Spending Plans Upward
DOC.TEXT: The nation's businesses, shrugging off economists' gloomy recession predictions, have significantly increased their plans for modernization and expansion this year, the government said Wednesday. The Commerce Department said a survey completed in March found businesses planning a record $503.4 billion in plant and equipment spending in 1990, up 7.6 percent from last year. Businesses had projected a much less optimistic 4.9 percent rise in an earlier survey released in December, when many analysts were forecasting the imminent end of the economy's seven-year expansion. ``The significance of this is it's one more piece of evidence we're not going into a recession,'' said economist Gordon Richards of the National Association of Manufacturers. ``Capital spending ... (will be) providing some strength to an otherwise weak economy.'' If the new projections are realized, spending would surpass the previous record of $467.8 billion set last year and would mark the fourth consecutive increase. Capital spending rose 8.6 percent in 1989, 8.9 percent in 1988 and 4.2 percent in 1987. All the figures have been adjusted for inflation. The surprisingly strong investment plans come at a time of generally sluggish economic growth and declining corporate profits. Most analysts are forecasting growth, as measured by the gross national product, of around 2 percent this year, down from 3 percent last year. The survey indicates businesses appear to be looking beyond the slowdown and are making the improvements they need to ensure increased productivity and better profits in the future, economists said. ``Despite all the stories of gloom and doom you read, ... this shows that businesses are not ... as shortsighted as many say,'' said economist Stephen S. Roach of Morgan Stanley & Co. Over time, capital spending not only will bolster economic growth, it will increase profits and ease inflation, he said. The current profit squeeze is being caused by companies' inability to pass on higher costs to their customers. Modernization spending should help eliminate the production bottlenecks that are driving up those costs, he said. The report should be received as good news at the Federal Reserve, which has been using relatively high interest rates to dampen economic growth and prevent demand from swapping production capacity and adding to inflation pressures. ``The Fed's wish list is probably not so much an economic slowdown, but a shift from consumer spending to savings and investment,'' Roach said. Economist Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch said capital spending plans are weakest in businesses most affected by lackluster domestic demand for ``big ticket'' durable goods, such as autos, and strongest in sectors supported by strong overseas demand, such as paper, aircraft and non-electrical machinery. The 7.6 percent planned investment increase for all industries includes a 4.6 percent rise in manufacturing and a 9.5 percent increase for companies engaged in mining, transportation and other non-manufacturing areas. Manufacturers are projecting investment spending this year of $190.2 billion. The anticipated rate of increase, although lower than the average for all industries, was still sharply up from the 1.4 percent projection in December. The manufacturing gain includes a 2.2 percent rise in durable goods and a 6.6 percent increase for non-durables. Durable goods are items expected to last three or more years _ everything from washing machines to warships. Because buyers usually borrow to purchase durable goods, those sales are more easily depressed by high interest rates. In the December survey, durable-goods manufacturers had projected a 1.5 percent drop in investment spending. Before adjusting for inflation, the department predicted a 7.8 percent increase for all businesses this year to $512.8 billion after rising 10.4 percent last year. That was up from the earlier 1990 forecast of 6.4 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Angolan Government Agrees to Peace Talks in Portugal
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with UNITA reaction, CORRECTS attribution in 5th graf `De Moura said...' to show sources, sted de Moura, gave date and venue
DOC.TEXT: The Angolan government has agreed to start direct peace talks with Jonas Savimbi's U.S.-backed rebels this month in Portugal, the Angolan state news agency ANGOP reported today. In a dispatch released in Lisbon, the agency quoted Angolan Deputy Foreign Minister Venancio de Moura as saying: ``Probably this month (and) next month, representatives of the Angolan government and elements of UNITA will meet to discuss the internal problem.'' The Soviet-backed Marxist government has been fighting the rebels of the National Union for the Total Independence of Angola, or UNITA, since shortly after the southern African nation gained independence from Portugal in 1975. ANGOP quoted unidentified sources in Luanda as saying initial direct contacts would be held in Portugal, probably on April 16, with more talks following in the West African island nation of Cape Verde. The site of the talks ``cannot be an obstacle, because peace can be negotiated in any part of the world if the (negotiators) are interested in a determined objective,'' de Moura said. The report said de Moura made his comments in an interview with journalists of the British Broadcasting Corp. in Luanda. A UNITA spokesman in Lisbon, Norberto de Castro, said he had received no official confirmation of the report, but welcomed the Angolan government's readiness to talk. The government is ruled by the Popular Movement for the Liberation of Angola (MPLA). ``This is a sign the MPLA understands the situation. ... for us, any date will do,'' de Castro told The Associated Press in a telephone interview. The announcement follows the rebels' offer on Monday of an immediate cease-fire. Fighting has intensified in recent months, and the rebels have stepped up urban bomb and sabotage attacks in the capital, Luanda.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets Baltic-American Leaders
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 4 grafs White House reaction; CORRECTs spelling of Mazeika thruout; edits to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of Baltic-American groups urged President Bush today to take steps toward recognizing Lithuania's declaration of independence from the Soviet Union, but were unable to persuade him to take that step. ``Our policy, we believe, is the correct one and it does not involve recognition,'' White House Press Secretary Marlin Fitzwater said afterwards. ``The president did not change his views but was impressed with the strength and depth of their convictions,'' Fitzwater said. Emerging from the meeting, Anthony Mazeika of the Baltic American Freedom League said, ``We are disappointed with the official policy of the United States by not extending recognition'' to President Vytautas Landsbergis' government. Even so, the Baltic-American leaders said they were pleased to have had an audience with Bush as last, after being turned down for meetings earlier. ``We have a lot of very good contacts on the lower- and mid-levels of the State Department. It's just the White House we haven't been able to penetrate. We used to wear out the threshold of the previous administration,'' said Mari-Ann Rikken, chairman of the Joint Baltic American National Committee. Bush and Secretary of State James A. Baker III spent more than an hour with Americans representing the interests of Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, the three Baltic states annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Mazeika said they pressed Bush and Baker to grant de facto recognition of the Landsbergis' government as an intermediate step toward full diplomatic ties. Asked if Bush left the impression he was sympathetic to that idea, Ms. Rikken said, ``No, we don't have that feel. But te fact that he met with us, the fact that I think we made an impression, that this is not some sort of an emotional appeal ... I think that had an impact.'' Mazeika said that Bush expressed sympathy for their cause but said he ``has to consider the other agendas as well as his feeling that there must be a way to support (Soviet President Mikhail S.) Gorbachev's overall efforts for democratic reform.'' Bush said Tuesday that Gorbachev's tolerance of democratic freedoms in Warsaw Pact nations had demonstrated ``a commitment to reform and openness that's remarkable.'' ``So give him credit and deal openly'' with him on problems such as Lithuania, the president said. ``But when you have difficulties like we have today, talk frankly with him about it.'' Bush's twin-edged message of praise and restraint appeared intended to put pressure on Gorbachev not to use force or additional intimidation against Lithuania to abandon its declaration of independence. Bush, on a visit to Toronto, said no one could have predicted Gorbachev's willingness to accept changes in Eastern Europe. ``In other words, he has demonstrated that he is committed to peaceful change and the evolution of democracy,'' he said. Mulroney was the first of three Western leaders holding talks with Bush over a 10-day period. Bush will see British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in Bermuda on Friday and confer with French President Francois Mitterrand in Key Largo, Fla., on April 19. The chief topics of Bush's talks with Mulroney were the tensions in Lithuania and the president's five-day summit with Gorbachev beginning May 30. Bush said that if the situation in Lithuania deteriorates, ``it would be extraordinarily difficult to move forward as rapidly as I'd like to see us move forward with them on a lot of questions.'' He said the presence of Soviet tanks in Lithuania make it ``even more important to have good-faith negotiations'' over the fate of the republic. ``I would just appeal to all sides and anyone with any influence to encourage dialogue and discussion,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Irish Leader Urges Economic Unity With British Province
DOC.TEXT: Irish Prime Minister Charles Haughey brought a message of economic unity to Northern Ireland on Wednesday, but Protestant demonstrators shouted support for the island's political division. ``Haughey, Haughey, out, out, out!,'' demonstrators cried. Haughey, chairman of the European Community's Council of Ministers, told a conference on cross-border trade that ``economic forces will inevitably interlink the economies of both parts of Ireland.'' ``As the technical and fiscal borders disappear, and both economies will converge, it will make simple common sense for us to combine in facing the problems and opportunities that the situation will present equally to us both,'' Haughey said. ``These are the economic realities of the future.'' The overwhelmingly Roman Catholic Republic of Ireland has been separated from Protestant-dominated Northern Ireland since 1922, when Ireland gained independence from Britain. Ireland's constitution lays claim to the whole island, and Northern Ireland has been torn by conflict between advocates of Irish unity and those loyal to Britain. Reg Empey, the lord mayor of Belfast and a Protestant, spoke to the conference before Haughey and denounced Ireland's claim on the province. About 300 Protestants gathered outside the Europa Hotel before Haughey's speech. They were kept under control by a large security operation mounted by the Royal Ulster Constabulary, Northern Ireland's police force. ``Haughey is here to dance on the graves of the province's bereaved,'' the Rev. Ian Paisley told reporters outside the hotel. Paisley, leader of the Democratic Unionist Party, referred to the slaying of four members of the Ulster Defense Regiment. They were killed Monday by an Irish Republican Army bomb. Ireland's foreign minister, Gerry Collins, earlier this year had called for the heavily Protestant unit to be disbanded. Haughey repeatedly stressed the two parts of Ireland should cooperate within the 12-nation European Community. Haughey currently speaks on behalf of the bloc; its presidency rotates every six months. ``Our economic and social characteristics, which are shared by both parts of Ireland, would benefit if a combined approach could be established,'' Haughey told the conference, which was organized by the Institute of Directors. ``We have a clear mutual interest in strengthening community policies for the less developed regions. It makes sense for both parts of the island to cooperate and share the costs in developing strategy.'' Earlier, as he was ushered quickly past the demonstrators into the hotel, Haughey was asked whether he worried about his personal security while in Belfast. ``Not particularly,'' he said. ``I know the RUC (Royal Ulster Constabulary) will make every effort to look after me.'' A front-page cartoon in The Irish Times of Dublin on Wednesday taunted Haughey for his past criticism of British rule in Northern Ireland. The cartoon showed Haughey surrounded by RUC men with the prime minister saying: ``Still a police state!! Thank goodness.'' Irish leaders have rarely visited Northern Ireland since sectarian and political fighting flared in 1969. Haughey's predecessor, Garret FitzGerald, was in the province in November 1985 to sign the Anglo-Irish Agreement with Mrs. Thatcher. The accord, deeply disliked by Protestants, gives Dublin a formal consultative role in Northern Ireland's affairs and pledges the two governments to cooperate against terrorism.

DOC.HEAD: It Doesn't Hurt to Laugh, Says This Doctor
DOC.TEXT: Don't laugh now _ unless you're feeling achy _ but the town doctor of Motala, Sweden, says his research among the dour folks of his community shows that humor can relieve pain. ``There was a linear relationship between the degree of fun and the level of symptoms,'' Dr. Lars Ljungdahl, medical director of the Motala Primary Health-Care Center, told a news conference Wednesday, reporting on his ``laugh therapy'' research. Ljungdahl, 40, a fan of Peter Sellers and ``The Cosby Show,'' is in the United States for a conference on humor and to consult with medical researchers to bolster his theory that laughter suppresses the hormones that cause stress and thus helps people with chronic pain. He described his research with six Motala women suffering from muscular-skeletal disorders and depressive moods. The patients met at his clinic weekly for 13 weeks, used funny books, records and videos. Ljungdahl reported in a letter to the Journal of the American Medical Association that the women ``learned to give higher priority to humor in our everyday lives.''
