In response to more specific questions, 46 percent said he was doing an ``only fair'' job in dealing with long-term economic problems, 42 percent that he was doing only fair on long term health care problems, 43 percent that he was doing only fair on long-term education problems and 39 percent only fair on long-term environmental problems. The percentages rating his performance good or poor were smaller. Only 2 to 5 percent of those responding rated him excellent in dealing with the various issues. People were also asked what vegetable it is that Bush recently said he wouldn't eat. Seventy-six percent answered correctly that it was broccoli. Four percent named some other vegetable and 20 percent didn't know or wouldn't answer. The survey results are based on telephone interviews conducted under the direction of Princeton Survey Research Associates April 5-8. The survey covered 1,212 adults aged 18 or older. The Gallup Organization did the interviewing. The results are subject to a sampling error of 3 percentage points. The Times Mirror Center for The People and The Press is an arm of Times Mirror, a corporation that owns the Los Angeles Times and other publishing and broadcasting enterprises.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement On Governing Coalition
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Leads with 9 grafs to UPDATE with comment from de Maiziere, Kohl-de Maiziere background. Pickup 10th graf `An increasingly...'
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister-designate Lothar de Maiziere finished forming his government Wednesday and reached an agreement with political partners on East Germany's terms for unification with West Germany. The agreement clears the way for Parliament to formally put de Maiziere's government in office so it can begin talks with West Germany on merging their nations. ``Now it is good,'' de Maiziere said after nearly a week of coalition talks ended. His conservative alliance won a majority in the country's first free election March 18. No details were immediately available on the coalition agreement. But de Maiziere, whose Christian Democrats favor speedy unification and a dramatic shift to capitalism, gave key ministerial posts to Social Democrats who favor a slower transition. Some concessions were likely. Many East Germans fear hard times when subsidies and other aspects of the 4-decade-old Communist system are scrapped. A new study said 1.5 million people in this country of 16 million could be thrown out of work in five years unless unification brings a spurt of growth. On Thursday, Parliament is expected to formally name de Maiziere prime minister and install his 24-member Cabinet, and the policy agreement is to be signed. Social Democrats were nominated to hold seven of the portfolios, including party chief Markus Meckel as foreign minister and Walter Romberg as finance minister. In Bonn, a West German government spokesman said Chancellor Helmut Kohl wants to sign a treaty on monetary union between the two states by May 6, with the currency merger to go into effect by July 7. Kohl's spokesman, Dieter Vogel, said the chancellor wants talks to begin as quickly as possible on the sensitive issue of converting East German currency into West German marks. But de Maiziere said an East German timetable for unification ``was not yet fixed.'' An increasingly restive work force worried about rampant unemployment planned demonstrations to coincide with Thursday's second session of the nation's first freely elected Parliament. A farmers organization said it would drive tractors and farm implements through East Berlin to demand an orderly transition to private ownership of property. Telephone and other electronics workers fearing unemployment called a three-hour strike Thursday in East Berlin. While workers worry about their future, foreign businesses have been flooding the East bloc to tap the new consumer market. The East German government news agency ADN said 599 joint ventures have been formed since the borders were opened in November. Another 400 are expected by the end of April. It said 60 percent of the enterprises are in the service and tourism industry, and about 96 percent involve West German companies. But East Germany would have to experience an 8.5 percent annual growth rate to head off massive unemployment, according to a study by the Institute for International Politics and Economics in East Berlin. ADN quoted the agency as saying a 5 percent growth rate still would result in up to 1.5 million jobless by 1995, and 2.6 million by 2000. De Maiziere's coalition favors quickly enacted laws allowing ownership of private property and private ownership of East Germany's factories and enterprises. The Social Democrats want employees to be able to take part in ownership of factories. They say East Germans will face higher prices and many will lose their jobs as inefficent businesses and enterprises are closed. A key point in the coalition talks was how much the virtually worthless East German mark would be worth in a unified Germany. West Germany's central bank proposes exchanging most East German marks at a 2-1 rate to West German marks. Savings accounts with less than 2,000 marks, about $1,200, would be exchanged at a 1-1 rate. De Maiziere's designated economics minister, Gerhard Pohl, said Tuesday that he favored a 30,000-mark ceiling on 1-1 conversions. De Maiziere's three-party coalition holds the most seats in the new 400-member Parliament but needs a two-thirds majority to rewrite the constitution to make a merger with West Germany possible. The new government will eventually take part in talks with West Germany and the four World War II allies _ the United States, Britain, France and the Soviet Union _ on reunification. One of the biggest questions to be dealt with in those talks is the military alliance of a united Germany. West Germany is currently a member of NATO, but the Soviet Union has refused to accept NATO membership for the new Germany. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze has expressed interest in dual NATO-Warsaw Pact membership for a united Germany, according to an article to be published next month in ``NATO's Sixteen Nations,'' an independent magazine that covers international security issues. Reacting to the article, NATO spokesman Florent Swijsen said the Western military alliance remains opposed to dual membership.

DOC.HEAD: European Space Agency To Cooperate With Soviets
DOC.TEXT: The European Space Agency will sign a 10-year agreement with the Soviet Union this month aimed at promoting cooperation for the first time in space exploration, the agency announced Wednesday. ``This is a very important step forward,'' said Reimar Luest, the space agency's director-general. He said it would be beneficial to both sides. Past cooperation has been based on an exchange of letters between the Soviet Academy of Sciences and the European Space Research Organization, one of the European Space Agency's precursors. It has been concerned largely with exchange of scientific information. The space activities to be covered by the new accord will include exploration of the solar system, space astronomy and astrophysics, earth observation, and other fields. Working groups will be established to recommend joint projects, the 13-nation space agency said. The agency said the agreement, to be reassessed after 10 years, would not call for any exchange of funds. It described the accord as ``a positive development in the course of relations between the Soviet Union and Western Europe.''

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Warns of Ethnic Bloodbath if Borders Recarved
LaserPhoto MOS27
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned in remarks broadcast Wednesday that recarving internal Soviet borders would lead to civil war and ``such bloody carnage that we won't be able to crawl out of it.'' He told members of the Communist Youth League he had spent more time thinking about whether he should allow changes in the country's political map than any other issue, and decided against it. More than 100 ethnic groups inhabit the Soviet Union. Under Gorbachev's democratizing reforms, many have begun to clamor for lands that were historically theirs and for more freedom from Moscow. Lithuania based its March 11 declaration of independence on claims it was illegally annexed 50 years ago. Gorbachev said redrawing Soviet boundaries ``would pit all peoples and all nations against each other and bring about a situation in this society the likes of which has never been witnessed by our country or by the world.'' And if other republics follow Lithuania's example and try to secede, he said, ``If we begin to divide up, I'll give it to you bluntly. We'll end up in such a civil war, in such bloody carnage that we won't be able to crawl out of it.'' Gorbachev issued dire predictions about ethnic conflict before, but his statements Tuesday at a question-and-answer session with a congress of young Communists, broadcast by Soviet TV on Wednesday, appeared pointed at Lithuania. The Kremlin has been locked in a confrontation with Lithuanian leaders since they declared the Baltic republic's independence. Gorbachev issued the latest in a series of harsh warnings to the Lithuanians Monday, but Tuesday he backed off, saying he did not see a need to impose presidential rule there yet. In the broadcast remarks, Gorbachev said he was sure residents of Lithuania would vote against the republic's independence once they understood the frightening array of problems it created. ``The Lithuanian people are a wise people,'' he said, and will realize that Lithuania ``needs independence, but within the framework'' of the Soviet Union. He spelled out the major problems facing the breakaway republic. Territorial disputes with Byelorussia and over the port of Klaipeda loom, some Soviet plants are cutting off their ties with Lithuanian enterprises and many non-Lithuanian residents may need to be resettled outside the republic. Gorbachev accused leaders of Sajudis, the movement that spearheaded Lithuania's independence drive and now controls its government, of trying to persuade ethnic activists in the Caucasus region to create disturbances in their support. He said they appealed ``to certain circles in Azerbaijan and Armenia saying `What are you sitting here for, light a fire, to create a front against the center.'' Gorbachev added that the ``full weight of the law'' should be brought against ethnic agitators. Lithuania's independence drive has remained non-violent, but ethnic conflicts in the Caucasus region and Central Asia have left hundreds of victims the last two years. Gorbachev, who spoke in a warm, somewhat fatherly tone to the Komsomol members, also touched on an impending split in the country's Communist Party. A toughly worded statement by the party's Central Committee, issued Tuesday and printed in Wednesday's Pravda, accused leading radicals of trying to split the entire party nationwide and indicated they could be expelled. It was aimed at the Democratic Platform, a union of party members demanding faster and more radical reforms than Gorbachev seeks. Gorbachev said the statement ``was not a call for a schism, nor for attacking a fraction, or people who think differently, but rather a call for consolidation.'' A leader of the Democratic Platform, Vyacheslav Shostakovski, said Wednesday he believed some members of the group would defect and form a totally new party. He told Interfax, a news service affiliated with Radio Moscow, that the Democratic Platform would fashion a public response and would also appeal for support to the party Congress, formally the party's highest body, when it meets this July.

DOC.HEAD: Reruns of `Wiseguy' and `21 Jump Street' Succeed Sajak
DOC.TEXT: CBS, which this week axed its late-night ``The Pat Sajak Show,'' said Thursday it will replace the show with repeats of its ``Wiseguy'' series and two reruns of Fox Broadcasting's ``21 Jump Street'' through June 1. Sajak was on vacation when his low-rated talk show was cancelled. The guest host of its final broadcast on Friday will be Pul Rodriguez, whose ``Grand Slam'' series was cancelled by CBS earlier this year. Starting Monday, ``Wiseguy'' repeats will be shown in Sajak's former time period, although the slot will be filled Friday by a pre-Earth Day special, ``Save The Planet: A CBS@Hard Rock Cafe Special.'' After that, ``Wiseguy'' reruns will return, except for May 11 and June 1, when ``21 Jump Street'' repeats will be shown, CBS said. The network said it is working on original late-night programming for next fall.

DOC.HEAD: Army to Temporarily Abandon Shooting Goats for Medical Training
DOC.TEXT: The Army will no longer shoot goats to train physicians at Fort Sam Houston to treat gunshot wounds, a physicians group that sought the moratorium said Wednesday. The Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine said 800 to 1,000 goats were being shot each year at the San Antonio, Texas, base. The practice continues at Fort Bragg, N.C., and as many as 1,200 goats are involved, the committee said. Dr. Neal D. Barnard, a psychiatrist and president of the organization, said the group sought in moratorium after specialists such as radiologists and psychiatrists, who normally don't treat trauma victims, were told to participate in the Fort Sam Houston training. ``It's not a very nice thing to be shooting these animals. Secondly, it's not even very good training,'' Barnard said. The wound of a goat is far different from a human wound, he said. Shooting a goat in the leg ``has no relation to an abdominal wound or a chest wound or a head wound. ... The tissue feels different in the goat _ it's got thick, hairy skin.'' Barnard said the Army had been shooting goats to train doctors since 1958. Pat Davis, chief of public affairs for the Army's Academy of Health Sciences at Fort Sam Houston, said she couldn't confirm how long the shootings had been taking place. The ban took effect about 90 days ago. The physicians group, she said, was inaccurate in saying the goats were being shot. The Army uses a ``firing mechanism,'' which she described as a small square box, to fire a ``projectile,'' or metal pellet, into a goat's leg. The military had been using the pellets to simulate the ``shocking impact'' of firing at a human from a military weapon. Military weapons fire projectiles at a far higher speed than handguns, she said. Military weapons cause ``a great deal of destruction to the tissue,'' she said. If military physicians don't clean the wound correctly, ``the guy will lose his limb and probably his life.'' Barnard said the Army's decision was only temporary and that his organization would push for a permanent ban, along with a ban at Fort Bragg. Ms. Davis said she was not sure whether the ban was permanent or temporary. Goats will still be used for other surgical procedures, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Kurt Masur Named NY Philharmonic Music Director
DOC.TEXT: Kurt Masur, who for 20 years has led the Gewandhaus Orchestra of Leipzig, East Germany, was named Wednesday as the New York Philharmonic's music director. Masur, 62, will replace Zubin Mehta, who told the Philharmonic in November 1988 that he would leave as music director after the 1990-91 season. Masur's appointment is for five years and begins in the 1992-93 season, the Philharmonic's 150th anniversary season. He will conduct for 14 weeks that season and spend four weeks here in other activities. Stephen Stamas, chairman of the New York Philharmonic Society, announced the appointment on a day when Masur was in Paris. Stamas said in a news conference that Masur will be ``music director designate'' in the 1991-92 season. He will conduct two weeks that season, which has been set for some time. ``We were aware he is a leader of the New Forum and hero of the revolution (in East Germany) and had non-musical interests that might have made it difficult for us to attract him to New York,'' Stamas said. ``He is still very active with the New Forum, which has decided not to become a political party. I believe he'll maintain a healthy interest in what is going on in Germany, while his interests will be largely musical.'' Masur was born July 18, 1927, in Brieg, Silesia, now in Poland. He studied at the music college of Leipzig. From 1960 to 1964 he was senior director of music at Berlin's Komische Oper and from 1967 to 1972 was chief conductor of the Dresden Philharmonic. Stamas said that Masur will remain principal conductor of the Gewandhaus Orchestra through the 1993-94 season, its 250th anniversary, and will maintain some association there. He first conducted the New York Philarharmonic in June 1981 and has conducted 22 concerts here, most recently in January 1989. Stamas said that conductors Colin Davis and Leonard Bernstein will give the New York Philharmonic more than their usual amounts of time during the changeover of music directors. For the first time, a six-musician committee from the Philharmonic took part in the selection. Oboist Joseph Robinson said that three of them flew to Paris and talked to Masur on Monday, flying back for Tuesday night's concert here and that the final decision was made after that. Masur is married to soprano Tomoko Sakurai. They have a 12-year-old son. Masur also has four children from previous marriages. Other candidates for the New York Philharmonic included Claudio Abbado, who was near signing with the orchestra when he was engaged to replace the late Herbert von Karajan with the Berlin Philharmonic. Rumors that Leonard Slatkin would be named did not stop even after his re-signing with the St. Louis Symphony.

DOC.HEAD: New Greek Premier Sworn In, Vows to End Instability
LaserPhoto ATH1
DOC.TEXT: Constantine Mitsotakis was sworn in as premier Wednesday, ending 10 months of political deadlock to cap his conservative party's comeback nine years after being defeated by the socialists of Andreas Papandreou. The new government leader immediately pledged four years of stable leadership. His New Democracy party won elections Sunday after two inconclusive polls in June and November. Shortly after the new 38-member Cabinet was sworn in by Greek Orthodox Archbishop Seraphim at the presidential mansion, the fledgling administration received the blessing of the nation's elder statesman, six-time premier and former President Constantine Karamanlis. After the 45-minute meeting at Karamanlis' home, Mitsotakis said the 83-year-old elder stateman had accepted a proposal to run for president. Karamanlis, who introduced the institution of the presidency in 1974, relinquished his bid for re-election in 1985 when the governing socialists reneged on a promise to back his candidacy. Karamanlis is almost certain to gain the 151 votes in Parliament needed for his election. New Democracy won 150 seats in the 300-member Parliament in Sunday's elections. On Monday, it gained the support of the lone deputy elected on the right-wing Democratic Renewal party ticket, giving it a majority. ``This government can and will accomplish much substantially, and we are determined to accomplish this with a four-year term in mind,'' Mitsotakis said after his Cabinet's first meeting. One unusual name in the new Cabinet list was composer Mikis Theodorakis, who gained fame in 1963 with his score for the award-winning film ``Zorba the Greek.'' He was appointed minister without portfolio. New Democracy returns to power after losing to Papandreou's Panhellenic Socialist Movement, or PASOK, in a landslide in 1981 during a wave of anti-Americanism. Mitsotakis has promised to improve relations with the United States, which has four military bases in Greece. He also has said he would be willing to extradite to the United States a Palestinian suspected of involvement in the bombing of an American passenger jet in 1982. Previous governments were ambivalent about the bases and stalled on extraditing the suspect. The new conservative government faces a $15.6 billion budget deficit and an inflation rate that reached 17.8 percent last month _ more than triple the European Community average. The government plans to improve the economy by slashing state spending, streamlining the huge public sector, and encouraging private investment. Mitsotakis has asked President Christos Sartzetakis to speed up the opening of Parliament, scheduled for April 23, so the government can present its programs and seek a vote of confidence next week. After the June elections, a governing New Democracy-Communist alliance indicted Papandreou and senior socialists on corruption charges but failed to tackle pressing economic and foreign policy issues. No trial dates have been set. The worsening economy prompted the conservatives, Communists and socialists to join in a three-party administration after another inconclusive election in November. But this alliance was also short-lived and ineffective. ``Without a doubt, our parliamentary majority is slim,'' Mitsotakis said Wednesday. ``But there is also the margin given to us by the broader spectrum of our people: the tolerance and the hope that it has stored in us.''

DOC.HEAD: Workers Dispute Report That They Are Exposed to Most Radiation in the U.S.
DOC.TEXT: A report that called the Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station the nation's worst plant for protecting workers from radiation has come under heavy criticism from the employees themselves. ``My friends make a lot of jokes about me glowing in the dark,'' said Margaret Martin, a radiological control worker who has worked at the plant since 1988. ``That's just lack of education.'' A study released Tuesday by Public Citizen, a Washington-based organization founded by consumer advocate Ralph Nader, said there were 2,875 incidents of worker exposure at Oyster Creek in 1988. The figure is double the plant's 1987 exposure mark and triple the 1988 average of the nation's other 106 commercial nuclear power plants, according to the report, ``Glowing on The Job.'' Gleaned from Nuclear Regulatory Commission documents, the report also said Oyster Creek, the nation's oldest commercial plant still in operation, had the second-highest number incidents of worker exposure from 1980 to 1988 among 20 plants considered the nation's worst. Oyster Creek's 20,486 cases of worker exposure trailed only the 27,701 recorded at Pilgrim 1 in Plymouth, Mass. At the end of work Tuesday, many of Oyster Creek's 990 workers said they were aware of the risks of working at a nuclear plant, but do not believe they are in any greater danger than their counterparts nationwide. ``They brainwash you to make it sound like it's dangerous,'' said Jeff Manning, who has worked at Oyster Creek for three months. ``This place doesn't bother me a bit,'' said Roger Mengle, a Waretown man who has handled hazardous materials at the plant since June. Before that, he worked for eight years at Three Mile Island in Middletown, Pa., which was the site of the nation's worst commerical nuclear accident. ``This is my job,'' Mengle said. Some Oyster Creek workers said they chose to work in the nuclear industry because of the high pay. ``There's better money to be made here,'' said Martin. Oyster Creek spokesman Sandy Polon said he would not divulge the range of salaries at the plant. Karl Neddenien, another plant spokesman, said the report was ``needlessly alarming.'' Neddenien did not dispute findings that each worker was exposed to an average dose of radiation equivalent to 26 chest X-rays, but argued that non-plant workers in Ocean County receive naturally occurring background radiation that is more than 40 percent of that figure. Neddenien said that although Oyster Creek, which began producing electricity in 1969, had more exposures than the nation's other commerical nuclear plants, the level was well within federal standards for total exposure. Neddenien also said the station's older design required more employees to work in a more compact area, exposing them more frequently. ``Working in a nuclear power plant entails possible exposure to radiation,'' Neddenien said. ``It's certainly not a surprise.'' He said officials are trying to reduce the number of worker exposures by installing permanent scaffolding inside the plant's dry well to prevent workers from spending extra time setting it up before repairs. He also said more radiation shielding is being installed. Harry Sharma of Toms River, a nuclear engineer for nine years, said the exposure to radiation was relative. ``If you fly on a plane, you get radiation. It doesn't mean you don't fly. We're still within the limits and the limits are artifically low,'' he said. Oyster Creek is a subsidiary of General Public Utilities Corp. of Parsippany. It is operated by GPU Nuclear Corp. and owned by Jersey Central Power & Light, which gets power from Oyster Creek for about 200,000 of its 800,000 customers.

DOC.HEAD: Poindexter Lawyers Get 7-Day Extension in Bid for New Trial
DOC.NOTE: EDs: TOPS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with comment from Poindexter attorney, CORRECT extension to seven days; picks up 6th graf: Poindexter, 53 ...
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge on Wednesday gave former national security adviser John Poindexter, convicted of five felony counts in the Iran-Contra scandal, an extra week to file motions for a new trial. U.S. District Judge Harold Greene approved the extension until April 24 sought Tuesday by the office of Poindexter's attorney, Richard W. Beckler. The office of independent counsel Lawrence E. Walsh, which has been investigating the Iran-Contra scandal since December 1986, filed court papers Wednesday saying it did not oppose the extension. Beckler's motion requested the extra time to file motions for a directed verdict of acquittal and for a new trial, both of which would require the judge to set aside last Saturday's jury verdict. Frederick Robinson, an attorney with Beckler's office who signed the request for the extra time, said the motions will not be based on new evidence, but he declined to say what arguments will be made. ``Those are things we're working out now,'' he said. ``I'm not at liberty to get into all the grounds yet.'' The deadline for such motions without an extension would have been April 17, he said. Poindexter, 53, was convicted Saturday of conspiracy, obstruction and lying to Congress. He could face up to 25 years in prison and $1.25 million in fines when he is sentenced June 11. Beckler said immediately after the conviction that he planned to appeal. ``We're naturally disappointed with the verdict in this case, but we're going to appeal it and we're going to keep fighting it as hard as we can,'' Beckler said at the time. Poindexter was the third top Reagan administration figure convicted in the scandal. The others, former Poindexter aide Oliver North and former national security adviser Robert McFarlane, have not served any jail time. Poindexter was convicted of conspiring with North, businessman Richard Secord and others to conceal the truth about the Iran-Contra affair from Congress. Specifically, Poindexter was accused of covering up North's secret Contra resupply network and the U.S. role in a CIA-assisted shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran in November 1985. North's Contra military assistance operation occurred during a congressional ban that required the CIA to withdraw military support for the rebels fighting the Sandinista government in Nicaragua.

DOC.HEAD: Third Man Arrested in 1976 Murder of Former Chilean Diplomat
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs `Jose Dionisio ...' with 2 grafs to CORRECT name to Jose Dionisio Suarez y Esquivel and UPDATE with court appearance. Picks up 4th graf pvs `Letelier, who ...'
DOC.TEXT: The 1976 murder of former Chilean diplomat Orlando Letelier on a tree-lined traffic circle in Washington touched off a furor that strained U.S.-Chilean relations and sent two men to prison. A third man was arrested Wednesday by the FBI in St. Petersburg, Fla. Jose Dionisio Suarez y Esquivel, 51, was charged with conspiracy to murder a foreign official. The FBI said Suarez provided the explosives and detonating devices for the bomb that killed Letelier. In federal court in Tampa, Suarez waived his right to a bond hearing and was ordered detained while he awaits trial in Washington. Suarez faces life in prison if convicted. Letelier, who had criticized human rights policies of the Chilean military government that exiled him, died Sept. 21, 1976, when the bomb under his car exploded as he drove to work along Washington's Embassy Row. Ronni Moffitt, a Letelier associate at a Washington-based think tank, also was killed. Her husband, Michael, was injured. Michael V. Townley, a U.S. citizen employed by the Chilean intelligence agency, was arrested in April 1978. Townley was extradited to the United States, confessed to planting the bomb on the order of superiors and was sentenced to 40 months in prison. A former Chilean Secret Service officer, Maj. Armando Fernandez Larios, was sentenced in May 1987 to between 27 months and seven years after pleading guilty to being an accessory to the assassination. Immediately after the bombing, U.S. legislators and Letelier associates charged that he was murdered by agents of the Chilean government. Friends said Letelier had told them of repeated death threats. Resolutions were introduced in Congress calling for an investigation and protest demonstrations were held outside the Chilean Embassy. The embassy denied any government involvement. Letelier had been foreign minister in the cabinet of the late President Salvador Allende when Allende was overthrown by the armed forces in 1973. He had been ambassador to the United States from 1971 until earlier in 1973. He was arrested and held until September 1974, when he was released exiled. Letelier lived briefly in Venezuela, then moved to Washington and joined the Institute for Policy Studies, a privately financed study group. Initially, he was silent on Chilean affairs. In the months before his death, however, he denounced the military junta's alleged use of torture and other rights violations. On Sept. 10, just 11 days before the bombing, the junta revoked Letelier's Chilean citizenship. ``I was born a Chilean, I am a Chilean, and I will die a Chilean,'' Letelier said in response. In pleading guilty to the accessory charge in 1987, Fernandez said he gave a map and surveillance notes to Townley. A federal court in Washington also indicted two other Chilean Secret Service officers, Gen. Manuel Contreras Sepulveda and Col. Pedro Espinoza Bravo, in connection with the assassination. The Chilean Supreme Court refused to extradite them, saying the evidence was insufficient. The Chilean government ordered its own investigation, headed by Gen. Hector Orozco Sepulveda. In 1987, Orozco was implicated by a former Chilean army major in a cover-up of Chile's role in the killing. The Justice Department sought to question him, but the Chilean Supreme Court said he could not be questioned about any official activities related to his role as military prosecutor in the probe. In January 1989, however, the Supreme Court in Santiago approved a U.S. request to question seven other former officials of the military government. On March 11, an elected civilian government took power in Chile, ending 16{ years of the right-wing military rule of Gen. Augusto Pinochet. Sen. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., a leading critic of the Pinochet regime, said he expected the new democratic government to allow prosecution of Contreras and Espinoza. Espinoza headed the Chilean National Intelligence Agency, while Contreras was the agency's operations director.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Spurns New Appeal to Recognize Lithuania as Independent Nation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 12-14: ``Bush said,'' with comparison to 1956 situation in Hungary and Fitzwater quote
DOC.TEXT: President Bush spurned appeals from Baltic-American leaders Wednesday to recognize the renegade government in Lithuania. He declared support for its struggle for independence but voiced concern about the impact on the Soviet Union. ``Our policy, we believe, is the correct one and it does not involve recognition,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said. Anthony Mazeika, director of the Baltic American Freedom League, said, ``We are disappointed with the official policy of the United States'' not to recognize the government of Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis. Mazeika had urged Bush to extend ``de facto'' recognition of Landsbergis' government, one step short of formal recognition. Bush met for more than an hour with 13 Baltic-Americans representing the interests of Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia, which were forcibly incorporated into the Soviet Union in 1940. Members of the group said they had been seeking a meeting with Bush since January, recognizing that a crisis was looming in Lithuania's drive to secede from the Soviet Union and Moscow's refusal to let it go. ``We have a lot of very good contacts on the lower- and mid-levels of the State Department. It's just the White House we haven't been able to penetrate,'' said Mari-Ann Rikken of the Estonian-American National Council. ``We used to wear out the threshold of the previous administration.'' Yet, members of the group said the mere fact that Bush met with them will be seen in the Baltic states as a positive step. Ms. Rikken said, ``Mr. Bush had a failure with China. He does not want to see a similar kind of thing happen in the Baltic states. ``He's very concerned,'' she added. ``He wants to find a way out, a way out of the Soviet Union for the Baltic states that will not result in a cataclysm for the Soviet Union and that will not result in a blood bath for the Baltic states.'' Fitzwater said Bush told the group ``the U.S. must avoid taking actions that would inadvertently make Lithuania's task more difficult by inflaming the situation'' and stressed the importance of quiet diplomacy. Bush said he did not want to see a situation akin to 1956 when the United States encouraged Hungary's revolt for democracy but then stood by helplessly as the Soviet Union crushed the uprising with force, Fitzwater said. Ms. Rikken said Bush was ``very, very worried about what happened in Hungary'' and that ``he kept bringing this up during the meeting.'' She said, ``Our job is to convince him that letting the Baltic states go could be the best thing that would happen to the Soviet Union.'' Fitzwater said, ``We believe that our present position is the correct one and the president did not indicate that we were willing to change our position.'' The meeting fell one month after Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence. Since then, the administration has been walking a narrow diplomatic line, endorsing Lithuania's aspirations for self-determination but refusing to recognize the new government. While emphasizing that the United States never recognized the Soviet takeover of the Baltic states, the administration argues that Lithuania does not control its own territory. Lithuania's determination to secede has posed a major challenge to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who is struggling on other fronts to carry out his programs of economic and political reforms, known as perestroika, and openness, known as glasnost. While admonishing Moscow not to use force in Lithuania, Bush credits Gorbachev as a driving force behind the democratic reforms in Eastern Europe and changes within the Soviet Union. Fitzwater said Bush, in meeting with the Baltic-Americans, ``pointed out in forceful terms that the United States approaches this problem with many ramifications to consider. ``He did say that we support glasnost and perestroika,'' Fitzwater said. ``He pointed out that we have had these dramatic changes in Hungary, Czechoslovakia and Poland. And, indeed, we have the atmosphere whereby Lithuania could consider its future in a different light because of glasnost and perestroika.'' Fitzwater said Bush shared the concerns of the Baltic-Americans and reiterated his support for the right of the Baltic states to self-determination. Bush was joined by Secretary of State James A. Baker III; White House chief of staff John Sununu; Brent Scowcroft, the national security adviser, and others. ``The problems that are taking place in Lithuania are going to multiply threefold,'' said Ojars Kalnins of the American Latvian Association. ``The Latvians will be declaring independence in two weeks,'' he said. ``Estonia is in the same process.'' He said that by the time Bush meets with Gorbachev on May 30, ``We will have a situation in all three republics which is comparable to what is happening today'' in Lithuania.

DOC.HEAD: Defendant: Wasn't Trying to Bring Jack the Ripper Back to Life
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents of 11th graf, `The prosecutor ...'
DOC.TEXT: A woman testified Wednesday she hit a man with a hatchet to protect herself from being sexually attacked and denied she tried to kill him to bring ``Jack the Ripper'' back to life. Deborah Kazuck, 27, took the stand in her trial on a charge of attempted first-degree intentional homicide. She has pleaded innocent and innocent by reason of mental disease or defect. The case went to the jury Wednesday afternoon. Two co-defendants pleaded guilty and agreed to testify against Ms. Kazuck, of Milwaukee. Ms. Kazuck said she met Jeffrey Meka a few days before he was struck with the hatchet. She said they visited his apartment and discussed their mutual interest in Jack the Ripper. She said she hit him with the hatchet on May 29 at her apartment to fend off an intended sexual assault. Ms. Kazuck said she regularly carried a backpack containing a hatchet, a drill and knives. Ramona Barry, 27, and Catherine Lipsham, 23, who have pleaded guilty, testified the three had planned to ``kack'' Meka. Ms. Barry and Ms. Lipsham testified Tuesday that the word ``kacking'' was was their code word for killing. Ms. Kazuck said the word was part of a code she devised and meant ``catch the thief'' who had robbed her apartment. Ms. Kazuck said she carried weapons ``for protection against the thief.'' She said she didn't intend to hurt anybody but ``if somebody would harm me, I would have to use it.'' The prosecutor told the jury in his opening arguments that Ms. Kazuck planned to dismember Meka's body, drain his blood and eat his kidneys in a ritual she believed would bring Jack the Ripper, the 19th century English serial killer, back to life. Assistant District Attorney Mark Williams said Ms. Kazuck plotted the assault with the help of Ms. Barry and Ms. Lipsham. The two pleaded guilty to attempted first-degree intentional homicide Friday and agreed to testify against Ms. Kazuck in exchange for the prosecution's promise to seek no more than eight years in prison for each. Both women testified they went out with Ms. Kazuck several times looking for people to ``kack,'' but assaulted no one. Defense attorney Alan Olshan described his client as a ``young, nervous and immature girl with childish ideas.'' Meka, 27, whose head wound required 50 stitches, testified Tuesday he was attacked when he went to the bathroom after being invited to a woman's South Side apartment. ``I opened up the shower curtain. I saw four feet. As I was looking up, I heard a scream and a child's voice: `Redrum. Redrum.' As I was looking up, `boom' I was hit,'' he said. Redrum is the word murder spelled backwards.

DOC.HEAD: World Media Group Meets with Gorbachev
DOC.TEXT: Participants in the World Media Conference met with Mikhail S. Gorbachev on Wednesday and heard the Soviet president's latest assessment of how the Kremlin's reforms were progressing. Gorbachev told the delegation that Soviet society ``is leaving the rallying stage and is becoming involved in real deeds,'' the Soviet news agency Tass reported. ``Availing ourselves of these sentiments, we want to radicalize the process of reforms,'' Tass quoted him as saying. Gorbachev is to meet Saturday with his major advisory bodies to make final decisions on the program of radical economic reform he has been promising since becoming president with greatly expanded powers last month. The World Media Conference, meeting for the first time in Moscow, gathered for a three-day symposium on Tuesday to discuss the impact of political change in the Soviet Union on global communications. About 500 delegates from 60 countries, including more than 40 former heads of state, attended the opening of the association founded by the Rev. Sun Myung Moon to encourage East-West communication in politics, economics and the environment. Gorbachev told conference participants Wednesday that ``we are only at the beginning of the process of shaping a new world order,'' Tass said. He called the media conference a ``very important element of cooperation,'' the agency said. Much of Wednesday's discussions focused on ecology. Two of the Soviet Union's best known environmental figures spoke: Nikolai Vorontsov, chief of the government's committee on the environment, and Alexei Yablokov, a prominent ecologist who has helped publicize frightening facts about pollution in the Soviet Union. Yablokov proposed a program of urgent ecological measures to help coordinate environmental laws around the world and require each country to preserve endangered species, Tass reported. Moon said in his opening remarks Tuesday that it was perestroika that made it possible for the association to hold its meeting in the Soviet capital. ``I feel there is no place more appropriate to gather for these discussions than right here in the Soviet Union,'' Moon said.

DOC.HEAD: Three Surinamese Arrested in Killing of Soviet Diplomat
DOC.TEXT: Three Surinamese men were arrested Wednesday in connection with the slaying of a Soviet diplomat during an apparent robbery, police said. The three were captured in the western district of Nickerie, which borders the neighboring South American nation of Guyana, while trying to sell the diplomat's car, said police Inspector Ronald Gayadhar. Stasis Obukauskas, 41, consul and second secretary in the Soviet Embassy, had left home Monday night in the car, a station wagon with diplomatic plates, police said. His body, with three bullet wounds in the head, was found Tuesday in a gutter along Kennedy Highway, the main road between Paramaribo and the capital's Zanderij International Airport. Gayadar said the three men confessed to the killing. He said one of them was carrying a revolver, but it was not known whether police thought the weapon was used in the slaying. He said police had ruled out a political motive for the killing but circumstances remained unclear. The Soviet news agency Tass said Obukauskas had been traveling to the airport to pick up another diplomat when a blue taxi overtook his vehicle, blocked the road and forced him to stop. The dispatch from Washington quoted the embassy's first secretary, A.I. Kavalerov, as saying the attackers shot Obukauskas, ``threw his body into the ditch and drove the car away.'' Kavalerov was quoted as saying that two similar crimes had been committed recently in the area. He said it was the first slaying of a diplomat in the former Dutch colony since it achieved independence in 1975. The three men arrested, all Surinamese citizens, were being held Wednesday in an undisclosed police station pending formal charges. They were not identified.

DOC.HEAD: British Journalist Freed by Liberian Guerrillas
DOC.TEXT: Liberian rebels freed a kidnapped British journalist on Wednesday and returned him to this neighboring West African nation. Mark Huband, a correspondent for United Press International and the London Financial Times, was taken hostage Friday by the guerrillas, who seek to overthrow Liberian President Samuel Doe. He was seized during an ambush of a freight train that he was riding on in Liberia's eastern Nimba County, where the insurgents invaded in December. Speaking from his home in Abidjan, Huband said the insurgents contacted British Embassy officials and arranged for them to meet him at the Ivorian-Liberian border on Wednesday. Huband said he had not been mistreated during the four days with the guerrillas in Nimba County.

DOC.HEAD: Poland Formally Votes to End Censorship
DOC.TEXT: Poland's lawmakers Wednesday formally ended censorship, one of the final relics of four decades of Communist rule. The decision by a 266-0 vote, with eight abstentions, was largely symbolic. Censorship has been almost non-existent since the Solidarity-led government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki was voted in to power last fall. Solidarity deputy Juliusz Braun said censorship had actually ``allowed slandering with impunity'' without permitting a person to defend himself. The censorship law allowed the former Communist authorities to control all kinds of publications and stage and film performances, preventing criticism of the political system. Many Poles turned to underground printing, which flourished through the 1980s. Solidarity, the East bloc's first independent trade union, fought for elimination of censorship since its foundation in 1980.

DOC.HEAD: Snow From Rockies To Maine
DOC.TEXT: Snow was scattered Wednesday from the northern Rockies across the upper Midwest and Great Lakes to New England, where up to a foot of snow accumulated. Light snow showers remained over northern Maine during the afternoon following a storm that left 12 inches of snow at Telos Lake, 9 inches at Grand Lake Matagamon, 8 inches at Clayton Lake and 7 inches at Limestone. Snowshowers also were scattered over north-central Wyoming, south-central Montana, west-central Minnesota, central Iowa, northern Illinois, eastern Wisconsin, much of Michigan, northern Indiana, from south-central Pennsylvania across eastern West Virginia, and over northeastern New York state. Rain fell along the northern Pacific Coast, as well as over southeastern Virginia and northeastern North Carolina. The heaviest rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT was 1.68 inches at Cape Hatteras, N.C. Authorities said Wednesday severe thunderstorms that rumbled through Georgia late Tuesday had caused nearly $150,000 in damage in Troup County, where 14 buildings were hit by trees and other debris. No injuries were reported from the storms, but Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport was closed for about an hour and about 10,000 Georgia Power Co. customers in the Atlanta area lost power for a short time. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 24 at Marquette, Mich., to 95 at Palm Springs, Calif. Wednesday's low for the Lower 48 states was 9 at Valentine, Neb.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Ryan White, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here are the lyrics to ``Skyline Pigeon,'' a song from Elton John's ``Empty Sky'' album that he sang Wednesday at the funeral for AIDS victim Ryan White.
Turn me loose from your hands Let me fly to distant lands Over green fields, trees and mountains. Home along the lanes of the skyway.

For this dark and lonely room Projects a shadow cast in gloom And my eyes are mirrors Of the world outside Thinking of the way That the wind can turn the tide And these shadows turn from purple to grey.
For just a skyline pigeon Dreaming of the open Waiting for the day He can spread his wings And fly away again Fly away, skyline pigeon, fly Towards the dreams You've left so very far behind.
Just let me wake up in the morning To the smell of new-mown hay To laugh and cry, to live and die In the brightness of my day.
I want to hear the pealing bells Of distant churches sing But most of all please free me From this aching metal ring And open out this cage towards the sun.

DOC.HEAD: Jaruzelski Arrives in Soviet Union, Hints at Talks on Massacre
DOC.TEXT: Polish President Wojciech Jaruzelski arrived in the Soviet Union on Wednesday and hinted talks would be held on a World War II massacre of Poles that still clouds relations between the two countries. Jaruzelski said discussions during his four-day official visit will focus partly on ``revealing painful pages in our common history.'' He appeared to be referring to the Katyn forest massacre of thousands of Polish officers during World War II. Moscow has long denied any Soviet role in the mass executions, but there have been recent indications officials might finally confirm Western historians' claims that Soviet secret police were to blame. Before his departure from Warsaw, Jaruzelski told the Polish news agency PAP he also expected his talks with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to address changes in Eastern Europe, German unification and the status of Soviet troops in Poland. Jaruzelski arrived Wednesday in the Ukrainian city of Lvov and then traveled to the republic capital of Kiev. The visit comes after the weekly Moscow News, in its March 25 edition, shed light from official Soviet records on the Katyn incident, one of the last grisly deeds of the Stalin era to be touched by Gorbachev's policy of glasnost. It published a two-page spread refuting claims that it was Nazi invaders who killed the cream of the Polish intelligentsia held prisoner just south of the western city Smolensk. Other articles have called for the truth about Katyn, but none went so far as to document the Soviet role in what has become the most painful World War II incident for Poles. Most estimates say about 4,000 people died at Katyn. Hitler's army invaded western Poland on Sept. 1, 1939, starting World War II. Weeks later, the Red Army marched into eastern Poland and remained there until the Germans pushed them out in 1941. Katyn has remained a source of lingering Polish mistrust of the Soviet Union. A joint Polish-Soviet commission has investigated the massacre, but it never came to a final conclusion.

DOC.HEAD: Jockey Accused of Hiding in Fog and Dashing to Victory Suspended for 10 Years
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 16 grafs to UPDATE with 10-year suspension, quotes, picking up at the 11th graf pvs, ``I thought...'' Version moved on the sports wire.
DOC.TEXT: When a 23-1 longshot called Landing Officer burst out of thick fog and across the finish line at Delta Downs, spectators and track officials knew right away the horse had finished too fast and too far ahead. It had. On Wednesday, Jockey Sylvester Carmouche was banned from racing in Louisiana for 10 years, accused of taking a fog-shrouded short cut to win the race. ``As my mother use to say. I don't know how you spilled the milk, I just know you spilled it,'' state Racing Commission member Jeffrey Kallenberg said as he made the motion to suspend Carmouche. The jockey was accused of slipping Landing Officer out of the race near the start on Jan. 11, waiting until the rest of the horses rounded the track and slipping back in ahead of the pack near the final turn. The horse, which had a record of only five wins in 53 races, won by 24 lengths and 1.2 seconds off the track record in the mile-long race. ``It ain't right. I know I ain't did it. I leave it up to my lawyers what to do,'' Carmouche said after the commission's 7-1 vote. Carmouche's lawyer, Kent Schaffer, said he would appeal to a state judge and ask for a stay that would allow the jockey to keep racing pending a decision. Carmouche also had declared his innocence after the race, but track stewards stripped him of his victory and suspended him from racing at Delta Downs for two months. Wednesday's hearing was a continuation of a hearing held a month ago to determine whether any more action was to be taken against him. In testimony prior to the vote, Carmouche insisted that he completed the race. But commission chairman Harold Thomas noted that two jockeys in the race said no horse passed them at any time. ``They never noticed me,'' Carmouche replied. Commission member Jeffrey Kallenberg said the panel saw a videotape of the race. Fog obscured details but Kallenberg said that at no time could Carmouche's colors or the number ``8'' on his horse be seen. ``How can that be that we did not see you?'' asked Kallenberg. ``I don't know, but I know I rode the whole race. The camera must have missed my horse,'' said Carmouche. Track employee J.L. Vincent, assigned to count horses at various points along the route, told commissioners he saw only eight of the nine entries pass under the bright lights at the first turn. ``I thought maybe one horse had stayed in the starting gate,'' he said. At the final turn, however, he saw all nine horses, including No. 8, Landing Officer. ``The No. 8 horse was ahead and running so fast he looked more like a quarter horse,'' said Vincent, referring to a breed that runs faster over shorter distances. At last month's hearing, Delta Downs veterinarian James Broussard testified that Landing Officer wasn't breathing heavily after the race and that the horse's leg wrappings were clean. ``In my opinion he didn't appear to have participated in a mile race,'' Broussard said Wednesday under cross examination from Carmouche's defense attorney.

DOC.HEAD: Government Says Potatoes Safe
DOC.TEXT: Consumers shouldn't stop buying potatoes because unusually high levels of a pesticide were found on a small number of potatoes in a single field, the government said Wednesday. A major manufacturer of the aldicarb, Rhone-Poulenc AG Co., said earlier this week it was stopping the sale of the pesticide for use on potatoes until it can determine why residue levels were unusually high. The residue levels on a sample of 10 potatoes among about 300 tested from 26 fields reportedly were nine times the levels allowed by the Environmental Protection Agency. All 10 potatoes were from a single field. The EPA commended the company for voluntarily halting sale of the chemical for use on potatoes. ``Consumers should not be alarmed and they should continue their normal consumption of potatoes,'' said the EPA, adding that the advice was endorsed by the Food and Drug Administration and the Agriculture Department. Aldicarb, a toxic chemical that causes flu-like symptoms including nausea, headaches and dizziness, is used on a broad range of fruits and vegetables to control insects, mites and nematodes. The chemical has been under review at the EPA for some time for its affect on groundwater, and agency officials are considering whether to examine possible concerns about residues on food products. ``While we believe the continued use of aldicarb is safe, we have a responsibility to the public to conduct additional research ... to determine the reasons for the unexplained residue levels,'' Rhone-Poulenc said in a statement. Aldicarb has been used since 1970 on such crops as potatoes, citrus fruits, soybeans, peanuts and cotton. Katherine Karr of the National Coalition Against the Misuse of Pesticides said the reports from Rhone-Poulenc demonstrate the need for additional goverment action on the chemical. ``The EPA should suspend the use of aldicarb until they can determine what risk levels there are out there for the food supply,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Vargas Llosa Postpones Decision on Quitting Peruvian Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Mario Vargas Llosa has postponed a decision on whether to drop out of a runoff election for president following a disappointing showing in the first round, associates said Wednesday. The celebrated novelist, who put aside his writing two years ago to campaign, was a strong favorite until a week ago to become president of this Andean nation. Associates, speaking on condition of anonymity, confirmed Wednesday that the writer has considered stepping aside to allow Alberto Fujimori, the runner-up in elections Sunday, to become president-elect. They said he wanted to save Peru, suffering from growing rebel violence and severe economic problems, from two more turbulent months of political campaigning. Vargas Llosa's advisers said he would announce his decision Monday. Until then, he is spending the Easter holidays in seclusion at a friend's beach home 30 miles south of Lima. Manuel d'Ornellas, editor of Expreso newspaper and a close friend of the novelist, confirmed in a column Wednesday that Vargas Llosa had been planning to announce his resignation Tuesday afternoon but was pursuaded by advisers to put off a decision until Monday. D'Ornellas said Vargas Llosa was prepared to step aside because the people had not given him the majority required for an outright victory. Vargas Llosa received 32 percent while Fujimori, an agricultural engineer and former university rector running as an independent, received nearly 30 percent. The remaining votes were split between seven candidates. D'Ornellas said Vargas Llosa offered Fujimori his detailed plan of government, which 200 economic specialists had composed. He said the writer also proposed forming a bloc in congress of the two candidates' supporters to guarantee Fujimori congressional backing. Vargas Llosa was persuaded to reconsider stepping down because his decision might jeopardize the stability of a future Fujimori government, the editor said. ``The mandate that Fujimori would receive after Vargas Llosa's resignation could be questioned in the future, opening the doors to a possible military coup,'' d'Ornellas wrote. Fujimori was given little chance of making the second round a month ago, but a late surge in popularity sapped the ranks of Vargas Llosa voters and propelled the Japanese-Peruvian into second place. The left-of-center governing Aprista Party and Peru's leftist parties have indicated they would most probably support Fujimori in the second round. That would make a Vargas Llosa victory unlikely. Vargas Llosa's Democratic Front, a center-right coalition, also fell far short of a majority in the congressional elections Sunday. News reports suggested Vargas Llosa may not be interested in leading the government without control of Congress. Without congressional support he would have great problems imposing the harsh austerity measures he advocates to revive Peru's moribund economy.

DOC.HEAD: Unmarried West German Claims He Lost Family in Ferry Fire
With AM-Ferry Fire, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: An unmarried West German claimed he lost his wife and four children in a North Sea ferry fire in a scam that netted him $50, police said Wednesday. An estimated 168 people died in Saturday's disaster aboard the Danish ferry the Scandinavian Star. People earlier put the estimate at up to 200. Among those removed from earlier estimates was the non-existent West German family, said Bjoern Gran, of the Oslo police department. ``No Germans are missing. He is not married, and there is no record of him having any children. It was a swindle,'' said Gran. The policeman said the German, whom he declined to identify, walked into offices of German and Belgian sailors' groups in Antwerp, Belgium, and pleaded for cash. He claimed his family died in the fire and that he had no money, said Gran. ``The Belgian clergyman did not think he looked grief-stricken enough, so he called the German mission and then the police,'' said Gran. The German, who had previous fraud convictions, disappeared, Gran said. He got a total of about $50 from the seamen's groups. ``It wasn't much money. But to try to take advantage of this kind of tragedy is just unthinkable,'' said Gran.

DOC.HEAD: Britain Stops New Shipment for Iraq
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to UPDATE with company suggesting cylinder might be for a petroleum pipe, not a gun; pickup 5th pvs, `On March...'
DOC.TEXT: British customs officials impounded a shipment of suspected gun parts bound for Iraq, officials reported Wednesday. The seizure came two weeks after U.S.-made components for nuclear detonators were confiscated en route to Baghdad. Press Association, Britain's domestic news agency, said the consignment impounded Tuesday night on a dock in northeastern England included parts for a 131-foot gun barrel, apparently the largest of its type ever made. ``It is capable of firing a nuclear shell which could easily hit Iran or any other Middle East trouble spot from Iraq,'' Press Association quoted an unidentified Customs and Excise Office spokesman as saying. No one was arrested, the news agency said. Press Association said the massive cylinder was manufactured by Sheffield Forgemasters of Sheffield. British Broadcasting Corp. television quoted a company spokesman as saying that if the impounded material was indeed made by Sheffield Forgemasters, it was a petroleum pipe _ not a gun barrel. On March 28, customs authorities seized American components for nuclear bomb triggers and arrested five people in a case that aggravated Western worries about Iraq's military capabilities and plans. Customs officials confirmed the goods were stopped. ``Last night, we intercepted a consignment of goods being loaded upon a ship that was destined for Iraq, a ship that had been chartered by the Iraqi Maritime Services. The goods appear to be of a military nature,'' a Customs spokesman said, speaking on condition of anonymity. On Wednesday morning, Customs officers raided offices in Sheffield and Birmingham ``and took away papers relevant to the specifications, ordering and delivery arrangements for this piece of equipment,'' the spokesman said. Press Association quoted the Customs spokesman as saying, ``We are considering the possibility that the gun was made to order in Britain for the Iraqis.'' The agency said the parts were packed in eight crates on the dock at Middlesbrough. The shipment impounded Tuesday was about to be loaded on the Bermuda-registered Gur Mariner, Press Association said. It will not be formally seized unless it is positively identified as containing weapon parts, Press Association said. ``It is certainly the biggest gun barrel we have ever uncovered in this country,'' the Customs spokesman said, according to the agency. The largest gun built previously was the U.S. High Altitude Research Project gun with barrels 119 feet long, according to the Guinness Book of Records. There was no immediate reaction to the impoundment Wednesday from Iraq. After the March 28 seizure, the Iraqi government denied involvement in the alleged smuggling. Iraq has also denied it seeks to develop nuclear weapons. However, earlier this month, Iraqi President Saddam Hussein threatened to attack Israel with binary chemical weapons if it attacks Iraqi installations. That threat, along with the smuggling case in Britain, brought a chorus of anti-Iraqi criticism from Western governments and news media. Iraqi officials have accused Western governments of deliberately orchestrating the campaign to prepare for an Israeli attack. British relations with Iraq have also been soured by Iraq's hanging March 15 of an Iranian-born journalist based in Britain. He was accused of spying.

DOC.HEAD: Germans Would Welcome Total U.S. Troop Withdrawal, Poll Shows
DOC.TEXT: West Germans would welcome a complete withdrawal of U.S. troops from their country, but Americans have reservations about leaving, according to poll results released Wednesday. The telephone poll conducted in March found 66.3 percent of Americans and 78.4 percent of West Germans favored reunification of East and West Germany. A total U.S. troop withdrawal from West Germany would be welcome, said 56.5 percent of Germans surveyed while 38.6 percent said they would not welcome such a move. Among Americans, 11.9 percent favored a total withdawal, 43.9 percent wanted a cut in the number of U.S. troops stationed in West Germany and 41.9 percent wanted no change. Just 34 percent of Americans said a unified Germany could threaten peace in Europe. They cited fears of a powerful economy, a revival of fascism and an attempt to expand territory. The survey found 76.8 percent of West Germans accepted the current border with Poland and giving up any claims to former German lands taken over by Poland after World War II. Sixteen percent of West Germans said they did not accept the current border with Poland. The telephone survey, conducted in early March by German and American polling organizations, was sponsored by the Friedrich Naumann Foundation, a research institute affiliated with the West German Free Democratic Party. The Germans were asked to rate world leaders from minus 5 for those they like least to plus 5 for those they like most. Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev was most popular with a 3.7 average rating, followed by Bush at 2.3 and French President Francois Mitterrand at 1.8. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher was last with a minus 0.9. Pollster Holli A. Semetko of the Institute for Social Research in Ann Arbor, Mich., attributed Mrs. Thatcher's unpopularity to her misgivings about German unification. Americans were not asked to rate leaders, but they gave Britain a popularity rating of 2.9, compared with 2.2 for West Germany, 2.0 for France, 1.6 for Poland, 1.5 for Japan, 0.9 for Israel and 0.7 for the Soviet Union. The West Germans put France at the top of their list at 2.4, the United States at 2.2, the Soviet Union at 1.6, Japan at 1.2, Britain at 0.5, Israel at 0.3 and Poland at 0.1. Britain was named as the West European country on which the United States could most rely by 56.3 percent of Americans, far more than the 12.3 percent who chose West Germany and 6.3 percent that picked France. The poll found that 67.4 percent of Americans viewed the Japanese as friendly, compared with 66 percent rating Germans as friendly. Among Germans, 88.6 percent said the Japanese were friendly, and 82.5 said Americans were friendly. Japan was viewed as a threat to the U.S. economy by 82.5 percent of Americans, but only 21.3 percent saw West Germany as a threat. Among Germans, 56.6 percent saw an economic threat from Japan, compared with 10.5 percent seeing a threat from the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Government Calls on Exiled King to Postpone Planned Visit
DOC.TEXT: The interim government on Wednesday appealed to exiled King Michael of Romania to postpone his return to the country he left 42 years ago, saying they were worried his visit could provoke violence. In Geneva, the king's oldest daughter, Princess Margarita, said her father and mother, Queen Anne, will go ahead with their Thursday visit to Romania. Margarita, scheduled to join her parents in Bucharest, said the deposed monarch will visit as a private citizen and plans to attend Easter services. It would be the first time King Michael has set foot on Romanian soil since he was forced into exile by the Communists on Dec. 30, 1947. The government urged Michael to postpone his visit until after national elections, scheduled for May 20. In a statement by the state news agency Rompres, the government said it feared the visit could lead to violence. ``It is increasingly clear that the former king's visit to this country at this time would be of a nature exacerbating existing conflicts, while also endangering his personal security,'' it said. The statement said that ``there is a possibility of some violent manifestations'' during Michael's visit. Princess Margarita, said Wednesday on Swiss television that Michael was returning to Romania on a spiritual pilgrimage and was not concerned with possible violence. ``My father is Romanian and every citizen ... has the right to return to his country to pray at the festival of Easter,'' she said in the French- language broadcast. She said the king ``has absolute confidence in the Romanian people. There is no indication that the Romanian people will not welcome him.'' ``He will represent history ... traditions and perhaps hope, but from the political point of view this visit is private,'' she said. The exiled king, who lives in the Swiss village of Versoix, near Geneva, plans to attend midnight Mass Saturday at Bucharest's Patriarhie Cathedral to mark Orthodox Easter. Earlier this week, several political parties asked that the visit be postponed until after national elections, citing fears that it could affect the campaign. Raud Campeanu, presidential candidate for one of the leading parties, the National Liberal Party, said Michael should not come before the elections, ``thinking he is wanted.'' Only two of the almost 70 parties that have formed since December's overthrow of dictator Nicolae Ceausescu have advocated the establishment of a constitutional monarchy. Following the December revolution, Michael said he was prepared to return as monarch but indicated the move must be approved by a national referendum. Michael's second daughter, Princess Helen, 39, arrived Tuesday in Bucharest with a convoy carrying 130 tons of relief material.

DOC.HEAD: Cuban Immigrant Pleads Innocent to Social Club Fire Charges
DOC.TEXT: The man accused of starting a nightclub fire that killed 87 people in the deadliest U.S. blaze in 13 years pleaded innocent Wednesday to 174 murder charges and other counts. Julio Gonzalez, guarded by four marshals and speaking through a Spanish translator, mumbled ``no culpable'' when asked how he pleaded to the charges during his arraignment in the borough of the Bronx. Gonzalez, 36, is accused of setting the March 25 fire that raced through the Happy Land social club, trapping most patrons on the second floor of the tiny, illegal establishment and killing 87 people, mostly Honduran immigrants. Only five people escaped the deadliest blaze since a 1977 nightclub fire in Southgate, Ky. A grand jury indicted Gonzalez on double murder charges for each victim, one for murder by arson and the other for murder by depraved indifference. He also was charged with two counts of arson and one each of assault and attempted murder. At the time, there was speculation that Gonzalez could be sentenced to several thousand years in prison if convicted on all charges. But state Judge Burton R. Roberts said Wednesday that Gonzalez could be sentenced to only one term of 25 years to life and might be eligible for parole in 25 years even if convicted on all murder charges. Roberts said that under state law, when there are two or more victims from a single crime, sentences must run concurrently rather than consecutively, as in separate crimes. The judge acknowledged that the social club fire was a special case, but said he wanted to dispel misconceptions about a possible penalty. Roberts set the next court appearance for April 25. ``I understand we're a long way from trial,'' the judge said. Gonzalez is undergoing a psychiatric evaluation at Bellevue Hospital. Assistant District Attorney Eric Warner gave Gonzalez' court-appointed attorney, Richard W. Berne, transcripts of a videotaped statement in which Gonzalez, according to police, admits setting the fire after a fight with a former girlfriend working at the club. Warner said he would also give Berne the videotape to copy. Berne said he planned to move for dismissal of all charges on grounds he was not given access to the taped statement before having to decide whether his client should testify before the grand jury. Gonzalez did not appear before the panel. Berne conceded his motion to dismiss, even if granted, was a ``procedural matter'' and that the prosecution would be sure to request a new indictment of Gonzalez.

DOC.HEAD: Kosovo Premier, Five Ministers Quit, Citing Serbian Pressure
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with added resignations, harder attribution, U.S. mission's criticism, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The premier and five other Cabinet members of ethnically troubled Kosovo province have resigned after four months in office, citing pressure by Serbia, the official Tanjug news agency reported Wednesday. The ``irrevocable'' resignations of Premier Jusuf Zejnulahu, Deputy Premier Mazlum Bega and the four others coincided with strong criticism leveled against Serbia's communist authorities Wednesday by a U.S. congressional delegation for alleged human rights abuses against ethnic Albanians in Kosovo. Kosovo province, an administrative part of the Serbian republic, has been a scene of continuing unrest since Serbia assumed near-total control over the region the past year _ virtually abolishing its former autonomy _ and introduced a state of emergency to suppress huge protests by Albanians. Ethnic Albanians comprise 90 percent of Kosovo's 1.9 million population. Tanjug did not make clear when the resignations were offered, but a newspaper said Zejnulahu offered his Tuesday. Zejnulahu, Bega and the other ministers are all ethnic Albanians. First indications of a rift between the provincial Communist Party leadership and the government emerged a few weeks ago. The Belgrade daily Borba carried Wednesday what it said was Zejnulahu's letter of resignation to Parliament. In the letter, Zejnulahu reportedly charged that Kosovo's Serbian-dominated communist authorities undermined government efforts to resolve the difficult situation in the province by leveling a stream of unfounded accusations against his administration. Sen. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., leader of the U.S. fact-finding mission, told reporters after returning from a one-day visit to Kosovo, ``We noted with great concern the heavy-handed (practices) that have caused great problems and offered no solutions for Kosovo.'' DeConcini said ``atrocities'' committed by Serbian police against ethnic Albanians could not solve the intercommunal tensions, which led to at least 60 people of Albanian origin being killed the past 13 months. Serbian authorities say Kosovo's mainly Christian Slav minority is harassed and terrorized by ethnic Albanians, who are predominantly Moslem. Rep. Steny Hoyer, D-Md., said Serbia's communist leader Slobodan Milosevic, who met with the four-member delegation Tuesday, was ``inflexible'' and refused to accept a dialogue with ethnic Albanian alternative movements, describing them as ``separatist and terrorist.'' Also Wednesday, the military filed criminal slander charges against a secessionist presidential candidate in the republic of Slovenia, Tanjug reported. Tanjug said the candidate, Joze Pucnik, accused the army of ``killing our children, poisoning our economy and imperiling our freedom.'' It did not elaborate. Slander charges were filed in the Slovenian city of Maribor on April 6, said Col. Vuk Obradovic, an army spokesman. He said the army was insulted by Pucnik's remarks. A slander conviction could bring a jail sentence of up to three years. Pucnik said in a telephone interview he was not prepared to comment on the report. Slovenia will choose its first freely elected president since 1945 in a runoff between Pucnik, a conservative secessionist, and Milan Kucan, a Communist reformer, April 22.

DOC.HEAD: Gadhafi Disputes Bush's Statement on Passover
DOC.TEXT: Libyan leader Moammar Gadhafi accused President Bush of ``reversing the truth'' by saying the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel was a march of freedom, the official Libyan news agency JANA reported Wednesday. Gadhafi referred to Bush's Passover message issued Monday, in which Bush said, ``A great march of freedom is under way for Soviet Jewry, and this year many thousands will celebrate the Seder with their families in Israel.'' JANA quoted Gadhafi as saying Palestinians had been expelled from their homeland in ``the biggest deportation process witnessed by contemporary history.'' ``Facing such crime we see the U.S. president reversing the truth,'' he said, according to the dispatch, monitored in Rome. Palestinians and Arabs object to resettling large numbers of Soviet Jewish emigrants in Israel and vehemently oppose moving them to the Israeli-occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Gadhafi said the ``greatest march of history'' was the one begun by the Libyan revolution, which had ``overwhelmed Eastern Europe and will overwhelm Western Europe and America,'' JANA reported. The leader of the radical Arab North African country also criticized the formation of ``revolutionary'' political parties or religious-based parties in various countries. He said such parties were ``bound to fail, because it is not an era in which rule can be achieved in the name of vanguard, sect or denominations,'' a separate JANA dispatch said. Gadhafi suggested formation of Libyan-style ``people's congresses'' instead of parties.

DOC.HEAD: Contra Leader Refuses to Demobilize
DOC.TEXT: The senior Nicaraguan Contra commander announced Wednesday that his rebels will not give up fighting until Sandinistas in Nicaragua's military bow to civilian rule. It was the harshest statement yet by Contra leader Israel Galeano since his subordinates signed an agreement with aides of President-elect Violeta Barrios de Chamorro to disarm by her April 25 inauguration. There was no immediate response by the outgoing Sandinista government in Managua, but it has said the refusal of the Contras to disband could threaten the transition. Galeano said in an interview that he will refuse to turn over arms to peacekeeping forces of the United Nations or the Organization of American States until ``true democracy'' emerges in Nicaragua. ``Mrs. Chamorro defeated the Sandinistas in elections, but I believe she will not be able to impose her authority on the Sandinistas once she takes office,'' Galeano said. ``And if she doesn't, there will be no democracy in Nicaragua.'' He said ``from the mountains in Nicaragua, armed and at the head of my troops, I shall observe the process of demilitarizing the Sandinista army.'' Galeano said his ``rebel army will honor its commitments and will abandon its camps in Honduras on April 18. But the army of resistance will continue fighting in the mountains inside Nicaragua until there is true democracy in our nation.'' Mrs. Chamorro's U.S.-supported coalition of 14 parties won elections Feb. 25 by a landslide, ending a decade of leftist Sandinista rule. But the Sandinistas have insisted the Contras, which they have been fighting for nine years, demobilize immediately while the Sandinista People's Army _ except for its uppermost ranks _ remain intact. About 9,000 armed Contras have infiltrated back into Nicaragua in recent weeks, leaving behind 1,000 wounded rebels and stragglers with old firearms at their base camps at the Honduran border town of Yamales. On Monday, the Contras and Mrs. Chamorro's representatives agreed to start dismantling their Yamales camps April 18, under the supervision of U.N. and OAS peacekeepers. The rest of the Contras were also expected to rally in ``safety zones'' inside Nicaragua to surrender their weapons and disband, once the international peacekeepers arranged cease-fires with Sandinista troops. Contra spokesman Alejandro Acevedo announced in Tegucigalpa he and six other members of a special rebel commission, including three civilians, will go to Managua on Monday to try to negotiate a truce to the fighting. ``We are going to negotiate a definite cease-fire,'' he said. Acevedo said the commission will meet with Roman Catholic Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo, Mrs. Chamorro and officials of her United National Opposition _ but not with the Sandinistas. Galeano said only the rebels who remain in Honduras will surrender their weapons. Oscar Sovalbarro, another Contra commander, also urged Sandinista military officers to step down. ``It is important that all the high officers leave their positions in the Popular Sandinista Army,'' he told Radio Catolica, the Roman Catholic Church station. Under a transition protocol that Sandinistas and UNO signed March 27, Mrs. Chamorro promised to respect ``the integrity and professionalism'' of the armed forces but prohibited all senior officers from holding positions of leadership in any political parties. The protocol was a compromise that allows the Sandinistas to retain control of the army while giving it at least a semblance of political neutrality. The Contras contend the army will remain a branch of the Sandinista party.

DOC.HEAD: Kentucky, Mississippi Governors Sign Far-Reaching Educational Reform Bills
