DOC.TEXT: Kentucky's governor signed a bill Wednesday making unprecedented changes in the administration of his state's struggling schools, and Mississippi's governor approved nearly $1 billion in aid to the nation's lowest-rated school system. In Frankfort, Ky., Gov. Wallace Wilkinson said the bill, which turns the state into a national laboratory for school reform, was as significant as drafting the state constitution. The 1,000-page statute establishes a minimum spending level of $2,900 for each of Kentucky's 570,000 students. Under the old system, spending varied from $1,800 to $4,200 a year per student, depending on a district's wealth. In the new system, ``geography is a subject to be taught, not a factor that determines the quality of a child's education,'' said Wilkinson, who said he had been a victim of unequal educational opportunity as a child. The measure raises taxes by about $1.3 billion over the next two years; about half the money goes to school reform. It also eliminates grades for the youngest students and calls for committees of parents, teachers and principals to make day-to-day decisions on running schools. In Jackson, Miss., Gov. Roy Mabus signed a bill committing $182 million to improve public school curricula over the next three years and another calling for nearly $800 million in bonds to replace aging school buildings and buses. He called the package ``far-reaching'' and ``visionary.'' But Mabus said he'd call a special legislative session June 18 because lawmakers didn't fund the program during their regular session, which ended Friday. ``All of us had a mandate from the people to significantly improve the way we educate our children,'' he said. Kentucky's law was spurred by a state Supreme Court ruling last June that the state's public school system was inequitable and unconstitutional, and followed nearly a year of political wrangling. The state has the lowest percentage of high school graduates in the nation. Wilkinson signed the bill at the Frankfort Civic Center as hundreds of schoolchildren shipped in for the occasion looked on. The governor said other states face the same sort of court orders to restructure their school systems. ``Once they see what we have accomplished, they are sure to follow,'' he said. In recent years, courts have ordered 11 states, including Kentucky, to overhaul inequitable school finance systems. The others are New Jersey, Kansas, Wisconsin, California, Connecticut, Washington, West Virginia, Wyoming, Arkansas and Montana. In Mississippi, students have consistently scored lowest in the nation on standardized achievement tests, although their performance has improved since a series of school reforms adopted in 1982. In addition to curriculum improvements, the new reform package provides for programs to fight illiteracy, teen-age pregnancy and dropouts in the 505,000-student public school system. The immediate challenge is finding the money to pay for the program. Mabus proposed a lottery to fund about a third of the reform package introduced in August, but the Senate killed the lottery and attempts to revive it. Mabus rejected the idea of a tax increase. ``It's going to be a difficult task, but I think the Legislature is committed to funding the programs,'' state Sen. Irb Benjamin, who heads the Senate Education Committee, said Wednesday. The package calls for the state to finance all curriculum improvements and issue bonds to pay for new buildings and buses. Local districts would repay 80 percent of the money borrowed for construction projects, and 20 percent of the funds for improving transportation.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Officer Escapes from Rebellious Inmates in Britain
DOC.TEXT: A prison guard escaped Wednesday from inmates holding him hostage in a Scottish jail and the prisoners then gave up, government officials said. Twelve British prisons have been wracked by disturbances this month, beginning April 1 at Strangeways Prison in the northern English city of Manchester. Three more prisoners surrendered there Wenesday, leaving fewer than 15 on the loose. Guard Jim Rankin, 30, escaped unharmed after being held 20 hours by rampaging inmates at Shotts jail, the Scottish Office said. The 40 inmates involved in the disturbance surrendered shortly after the officer escaped, said the office, which runs Scottish prisons. Two guards were injured in the rampage Tuesday night, the office said. Dartmoor prison in southwest England was hit by another disturbance Wednesday night when three prisoners got onto the roof of a prison wing, said the Home Office, which is responsible for prisons in England and Wales. The three surrendered late Wednesday, the Home Office said. The lawyer for Paul Taylor, the self-described ringleader of the rioters at Strangeways, said his client was about to give up. ``Mr. Taylor seemed to be in good spirits,'' John Ballam told reporters after meeting with Taylor through a fence. ``He was a little tired, but calm. In his own words, he said he would be giving himself up in the next day or so.'' Prison authorities have ruled out taking the facility by force. Instead, they have relied on negotiations and harassment to wear down the rebellious prisoners. During the rioting, one prisoner suffered fatal injuries, and a guard died of an apparent heart attack. In response to demands by the Prison Officers' Association, Home Secretary David Waddington announced Wednesday that 200 more officers will be recruited immediately instead of waiting until 1991. Waddington also announced 3,000 vacant prison cells will be returned to use to ease overcrowding. Other prisons hit by rioting include Bristol in western England, Cardiff in Wales, Hull in northeast England, Leeds in northern England and London's Pentonville and Brixton prisons. Disturbances were also reported at three young offenders institutions.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Nominees Promise to Talk Issues, Not Mud
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 4th graf, `There was ...,' to UPDATE with Mattox, Richards' comment from Wednesday news conference; picks up 5th graf, `Ms. Richards ...' INSERTS 4 grafs after 8th graf, `She handed ...,' to UPDATE with more Mattox, Richards comment, voter turnout; picks up 9th graf, `Voters' attention ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto AT7
DOC.TEXT: Ann Richards, who won the Democratic nomination in a ``mudslide,'' and Republican Clayton Williams, still stinging from criticism after a joke about rape, promised to stick to issues as they vied for governor. ``Both Clayton Williams and I will work very hard to keep this an ideological campaign where we really do focus on the issues because we do have disagreements on the issues,'' Ms. Richards said after defeating state Attorney General Jim Mattox in Tuesday's down-and-dirty primary runoff. Williams, who earlier voiced reluctance about running against a woman, said, ``The rehash of the Democratic campaign is of no interest to me. Read my lips: No more mud.'' There was little discussion of the issues in the runoff, in which Mattox alleged that Ms. Richards, a recovering alcoholic, used illegal drugs, including cocaine, 10 years ago when she was a Travis County commissioner. ``The voters didn't care about that issue as deeply as I do, or as deeply as I thought they did,'' Mattox, who had called the runoff a referendum on the drug question, told an Austin news conference Wednesday afternoon. Ms. Richards said the issue of whether she has used illegal drugs ``was put to rest'' after her overwhelming runoff victory. Ms. Richards, 56, now state treasurer, accused Mattox, 46, of profiting from public service and challenged him to release his income tax returns. The last week of the campaign brought newspaper reports that Mattox was seen smoking marijuana in the mid-1970s and that Ms. Richards was seen in a restroom where marijuana allegedly was being smoked in 1979. Both dismissed the reports. They also accused the each other of starting the mudslinging, but Ms. Richards said her victory showed that Mattox's negative campaigning turned off voters. She handed Mattox his first major political defeat in 18 years, rolling up a margin of 639,126, or 57 percent, to Mattox's 479,384, or 43 percent, in unofficial returns. Mattox said Wednesday that he was defeated because of a growing trend of women being elected to higher office regardless of their credentials. He said Ms. Richards enjoyed the support of a ready-made nationwide network of feminists despite his strong advocacy of civil rights and women's issues. In a separate news conference, Ms. Richards claimed support from both men and women. ``I never felt that women support women simply because they're women,'' she said. Slightly more than 15 percent of the state's 8.3 million registered voters cast ballots in the runoff, the highest runoff turnout since 2 million Texans went to the polls in 1972, said Secretary of State George Bayoud. Turnout in the March 13 primary was 28 percent. Voters' attention was taken off the runoff briefly when Williams, a rancher and oilman in Midland, told reporters during his spring cattle roundup that bad weather was like rape _ if it's inevitable, ``relax and enjoy it.'' Williams, 58, who has never run for political office, apologized for the comment, but Ms. Richards said it illustrated his inexperience in public life. Aside from promising not to raise taxes, both candidates are at opposite ends on most issues, including abortion rights. Ms. Richards is pro-choice. Williams opposes abortion except in cases of rape, incest and endangerment of the mother. The victor in November's election will not have an easy task. Court-ordered education reforms, according to current proposals, will cost anywhere from $4 billion to $10 billion during the next governor's term and the state welfare agency is projecting a $550 million deficit next year. Mattox and his supporters say they will forget the runoff mudbath and rally behind Ms. Richards. ``I want to send a sincere congratulations to Ann Richards,'' said Mattox, who has won every political race he has entered since 1972, including the state House, Congress and attorney general. ``I will be ready to help her up and down the state against the common enemy, and the common enemy is Clayton Williams,'' he said. Incumbent Republican Bill Clements, 72, is not seeking re-election.

DOC.HEAD: Striking Drivers to Face Charges in Shots Fired at Buses
DOC.TEXT: Two striking Greyhound drivers were ordered held without bond Wednesday on charges they fired shots at a company bus last month just east of the city. Roy B. Simes, 35, and Harry T. Lewis, 42, both of suburban St. Louis, appeared Wednesday before U.S. Magistrate Frederick R. Buckles. A federal agent said one of the men confessed to the March 22 attack in Troy, Ill. Buckles is to determine whether bond should be set for the defendants and whether they should be moved to East St. Louis, Ill., where federal charges against them were filed Tuesday. Greyhound Lines Inc. has reported more than 30 shooting attacks on its buses, 70 bomb threats and more than 100 incidents of violence. A picketing driver was killed March 3 in Redding, Calif., when he was crushed by a bus driven by a replacement driver. A number of drivers attended Wednesday's brief court session, and some shouted encouragement as Simes and Lewis were led out of the courtroom. ``Hang in there, guys,'' said Don McCulley, committeeman of Amalgamated Transit Local 1500 in St. Louis. McCulley said that he was shocked at the charges and did not believe the defendants could have fired the shots. ``I've told them and told them, `No violence, no violence,''' McCulley said. Authorities said Simes and Lewis, who were arrested Tuesday, are suspects in another bus shooting in south St. Louis County earlier the same morning as the Illinois incident. According to an affidavit by U.S. Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms agent Stephen Higgins, Simes admitted he and Lewis were involved in both shootings. The complaint said Simes also consented to a search of his residence and turned over a .22-caliber revolver. Greyhound's 6,300 drivers and about 3,000 office and maintenance workers walked out March 2 in an argument over wages and job security. Greyhound has been operating a reduced schedule since, using permanent replacements and drivers willing to cross picket lines. Greyhound President Frank Schmieder says a strong Easter holiday weekend could boost the company to the financial break-even point. The five-day Easter travel period ending Monday is one of the five busiest times of the year for Greyhound. Schmieder said in an interview this week that the company projects revenue in the next few days will be between 70 percent and 73 percent of revenue at the same time last year. ``Seventy-three percent of revenue is cash break even, and when we do that, we figure we've turned the corner,'' said Schmeider. Jeffrey Nelson, a spokesman for the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, called Greyhound's latest claims ``preposterous.'' ``They've been claiming they turned corners for the last six weeks,'' said Nelson. Negotiations have been stalled since last month. The company has refused to bargain until seven days have passed without major violence. Simes and Lewis have been charged with endangering people on board a vehicle used in interstate or foreign commerce, commission of a felony with a firearm that has been transported in interstate commerce and use of a firearm during the commission of a violent crime. If convicted, each would face up to 10 years in jail and a $10,000 fine. Their arrests were the second and third nationwide since the strike began. The other arrest took place March 16, when a striking driver was accused of shooting at a bus March 12 near Hartford, Conn.

DOC.HEAD: Obsessed Fan Convicted of Attacking Actress Remains Jailed
DOC.TEXT: The obsessed fan who stalked and nearly killed actress Theresa Saldana eight years ago was scheduled for parole Wednesday, but he was kept in prison for threatening her again, a prosecutor's spokesman said. ``If he had been a good little boy and not threatened Theresa Saldana while in prison, he would have ... been a free man today,'' said Mike Botula, news secretary for the district attorney's office. Arthur Jackson, 54, was convicted of attempted murder and assault with a deadly weapon in the March 15, 1982, attack on Miss Saldana. He attacked the actress outside her apartment, stabbing her 10 times and bending the blade of his kitchen knife with the force of his blows. His 12-year sentence had been cut in half for good behavior. Jackson was being held at the Men's Central Jail without bail Wednesday pending trial on 16 felony counts of menacing Miss Saldana and her rescuer, Jeff Fenn, Botula said. Jackson could enter pleas to the new charges as early as Friday, when a preliminary hearing is scheduled, Botula said. The prisoner was transferred last month from the California Medical Facility in Vacaville to county custody for a March 15 arraignment, which was postponed because he didn't have an attorney, Botula said. Deputy District Attorney William W. Hodgman said Jackson still poses a danger to the actress. ``It is evident he still has a fixation on Theresa Saldana,'' the prosecutor said. The latest charges were based on seven letters sent to Miss Saldana and Fenn, a former water deliveryman who rescued her in front of her West Hollywood apartment and held Jackson for police. Fenn is now a sheriff's deputy. ``The general tone of the letters was he was making special demands and if she didn't meet those demands he would have her assassinated,'' Hodgman said, refusing to elaborate. Jackson, a Scottish drifter with a history of mental problems, entered the United States illegally in 1982 to stalk Miss Saldana. Authorities said he became obsessed with her after watching her films, including ``Raging Bull'' and ``I Want to Hold Your Hand.'' Jackson is charged with eight counts of threatening to use force and eight of making terrorist threats in letters. The charges carry a maximum seven years and eight months in prison. But if convicted, Jackson faces sentencing under provisions of a 1986 state law that bars freeing deranged inmates who continue to make credible threats. The law, inspired by the Saldana case, makes it a crime for a convicted felon to threaten a victim or witness. Authorities learned weeks before his scheduled release last June that Jackson had allegedly sent the letters. At the same time as charges were filed in Los Angeles, prison authorities tacked 270 more days onto his sentence for three custody violations, including breaking prison windows.

DOC.HEAD: Shevardnadze Wants Dual NATO-Warsaw Pact Membership for Germany
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with U.S. rejection of Soviet idea. Picks up 5th pvs, `Last week...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-East Germany, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze has expressed interest in dual NATO-Warsaw Pact membership for a united Germany, according to an article to be published next month. Shevardnadze also said he foresaw a security arrangement among Europe, the Soviet Union and North America that eventually would replace both military alliances. ``Many of our experts ... believe that the idea of `dual membership' for Germany could provide a pragmatic way out of the difficulties emerging now,'' Shevardnadze wrote in a piece for the May issue of NATO's Sixteen Nations. It is an independent magazine covering international security issues. ``I would favor a serious and thorough analysis of this option,'' he said. But the Bush administration on Wednesday rejected the idea of a united Germany's temporarily being part of both NATO and the Warsaw Pact and insisted Germany would have to side with the Western alliance. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said, ``That Germany should be a member of NATO and the Warsaw Pact is another formula for neutrality. It is a status that we believe, the Germans themselves and their neighbors believe is undesirable. We strongly support full membership of a united Germany in NATO. ``We are opposed to neutrality.'' Last week in Washington, U.S. officials said the Soviet Union dropped its demand that a unified Germany be militarily neutral. It continued to oppose membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. West Germany is a NATO member. East Germany is in the Soviet-dominated Warsaw Pact. The Soviet foreign minister wrote that dual membership proposal ``would help overcome further the division of Europe, contribute to its unification and create integrated spaces in it.'' The article was made available Wednesday to The Associated Press. Reacting to the article, NATO spokesman Florent Swijsen said the 16-nation Western alliance remains opposed to dual membership. ``The allies are not considering the possibility of a unified Germany being part of both NATO and the Warsaw Pact,'' he said in a statement. ``Even several members of the latter (Warsaw Pact) have indicated their preference for a united Germany as a member of NATO.'' NATO officials have said that after unification, Soviet troops could be temporarily stationed in what is now East Germany. Shevardnadze said in his article that the Kremlin believed ``Germany should become a military non-aligned state and a demilitarized state in the sense that it ought to possess the lowest possible military capability sufficient for defense.'' ``At the same time, we hold that in the final analysis Germany should be a fully equal member of today's family of nations and become a state like all other states,'' he wrote. He suggested the new state ``declare that it will not have nuclear, chemical or other weapons of mass destruction.'' The Soviet official outlined his view of how a ``Greater Europe'' security structure should look, based on the 35-nation Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe. The 35 nations _ the United States, Canada and all in Europe except Albania _ will hold a summit later this year. He suggested the organization hold summit meetings of national leaders every two years, with foreign ministers gathering yearly as the top political body. ``Europe is heading for a new status in terms of its instruments of security,'' Shevardnadze wrote. ``If and when the blocs vanish into thin air _ and the process must not be artificially boosted _ no vacuum should be allowed to form.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Begins Deliberations on 2-Decade-Old Murders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts one graf after the 3rd to UPDATE with jurors recessing for night.
DOC.TEXT: A jury Wednesday began deliberating whether former Sunday school teacher John E. List was a ``hideous angel of death'' or was mentally disturbed when he killed his wife, three children and mother. List's attorney, Elijah L. Miller Jr., has conceded during the eight-day trial that List, 64, committed the killings 19 years ago. But he sought a lesser verdict of second-degree murder. First-degree murder, as sought by the prosecution, required the Union County Superior Court jury to find that List acted with premeditation. It carries a life term, with parole eligibility in 15 years. Second-degree murder has a 30-year maximum, with parole possible after a third of the term. The jurors deliberated for six hours, then recessed until Thursday morning. Before stopping, they asked for a re-reading of the judge's instructions on the element of first-degree murder, willfullness, deliberation and premeditation. Authorities found the bodies of List's wife, Helen, 45; mother, Alma, 84; daughter, Patricia, 16; and sons, John, 15 and Frederick, 13, in their 18-room Westfield mansion on Dec. 7, 1971. Miller argued that List, a pious and strictly raised Lutheran, was watching his ``whole world falling to pieces'' when an ``obsessive-compulsive'' personality disorder _ combined with twisted religious belief _ forced him to act. List was beset by pressures, couldn't provide for his family after a series of job failures, and saw his family slipping from the church, Miller said. He was also oppressed by the irrational behavior of his wife, who suffered from terminal syphilis. List ruled out suicide because that would ensure his damnation, Miller argued. Killing his children ensured their entry into heaven, he said. ``He looked to religion for an answer, and he corrupted that answer,'' said Miller. Eleanor Clark, an assistant prosecutor, argued that List ``acted as a hideous angel of death, weighing the options right up until the night before, killing his family. ... ``The state says today, `Mr. List, have you no shame!''' she shouted, stalking toward the defense table, her index finger raised. Miller relied on testimony by psychiatric witnesses and five ministers from List's past. The state presented 41 witnesses in 2{ days, most of them investigators, forensic experts and acquaintances who traced List's actions the day of the slayings. List said he shot his victims in the back of the head to spare them knowledge that they were about to die, Mrs. Clark told the court, but she reminded the juors of autopsy reports that showed the bullets entered the side of the heads. The younger John List was shot more than 10 times because he struggled, List wrote in a letter to his pastor. Evidence indicated that John surprised his father that day and knew something was wrong. ``His father, his loving father, took a 9mm gun and a .22 and riddled his body with bullets,'' she said. On the day of the slayings List wrapped up his affairs in a meticulous manner. He cleaned the house, ate meals before and after the killings, washed the dishes, left instructions on the funerals and his financial affairs and withdrew money from the bank, authorities said. The next day he dropped his car off at John F. Kennedy International Airport in New York and zig-zagged across the country by train until settling in Denver because he liked mountains, List told prosecution psychiatrist Steven S. Simring. Simring testified that List told him he expected to be caught early on and constantly thought of the killings in the first year. As he resumed another identity and remarried, the memory faded, returning only on the anniversary of the killings, Simring said. List, an accountant who later moved to the Richmond, Va., area, was arrested in June after the killings were dramatized on a television crime show and a viewer tipped authorities.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs Rome-dated item to CORRECT that concert will be on eve of final game, not eve of month-long competition.
DOC.TEXT: Singers Luciano Pavarotti, Placido Domingo and Jose Carreras are expected to draw a worldwide television audience of 800 million when they get together for a World Cup concert, Italian organizers said Wednesday. The outdoor concert July 7, on the eve of the final game in the month-long soccer competition, also will feature a 186-member orchestra led by Zubin Mehta. Delegations from the 24 teams performing in the World Cup will be among 6,000 spectators in the Roman Terme di Caracalla theater on the night preceding the championship final scheduled at Rome's Olympic stadium. The concert will be telecast live in most countries, including the United States, Japan and Canada, said Gian Paolo Cresci, managing director of the company organizing the event.

DOC.HEAD: Earthquake Measuring 6.3 Rattles Western Japan, No Injuries
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake jolted western Japan Thursday morning but no damage or injuries were reported, the Central Meteorological Agency said. The earthquake, which had a preliminary reading of 6.3 on the Richter scale, occurred 222 miles underground in the southwestern part of Fukui prefecture (state), the agency said. Fukui is 200 miles west of Tokyo. An official of the agency's Seismic Division said shock waves from an earthquake originating so deep underground largely dissipate before reaching the surface and rarely cause damage, said the official, who declined to be identified. On Wednesday afternoon, an earthquake measuring 5.5 struck Kushiro and neighboring areas on Japan's northernmost major island of Hokkaido, but police said there were no reports of injuries or damage. That quake ocurred about 40 miles undersea off Kushiro, which is 540 miles north of Tokyo. The open-ended Richter scale is a gauge of the energy released by an earthquake, as measured by the ground motion recorded on a seismograph. Every increase of one number on the scale means a tenfold increase in magnitude. An earthquake of 5 on the Richter scale can cause considerable damage in populated areas. A quake measuring 6 is considered severe and capable of widespread damage near the epicenter.

DOC.HEAD: Hydrogen Fire, Explosion Shut Down Oil-Fired Unit
DOC.TEXT: Leaking hydrogen gas fueled a fire and explosion that shut down an oil-fired generator at the troubled Turkey Point power plant complex Wednesday, utility officials said. No one was injured. Two nuclear power plants and another oil-fired plant at Turkey Point were not affected, spokesmen said. The fire was confined to an enclosure housing an exciter, a small auxiliary generator. Plant operators took the Unit 2 generator off line when they detected a loss of hydrogen pressure, and the fire was discovered in the exciter about 15 minutes later, said Florida Power & Light Co. spokesman Gary Mehalik. The hydrogen is used to cool the generator. ``The visible damage is very, very moderate,'' said FPL spokesman Dale Thomas. The plant's fire brigade had to put out the fire twice because the highly flammable hydrogen continued leaking and exploded a second time, he said. ``It has an invisible flame but it is searing hot,'' said Joe Jenkins, director of the state Public Service Commission's electric and gas division. The hydrogen leaked from the sealed room where the gas cools the spinning generator, passed through a turbine shaft and into the shed-sized exciter enclosure, Mehalik said. Utility workers will have to remove the generator housing on Unit 2 to determine the extent of damage and the cost of repairs, and that will take a day or two, Thomas said. Unit 2 was the only one operating at Turkey Point at the time of the fire, which left the 2,090-megawatt plant idle idefinitely. One nuclear unit and one oil-fired unit were down for scheduled maintenance, and the other nuclear unit automatically shut down Monday when an electrical relay failed in an unrelated incident. The loss of Turkey Point's generating capacity was not considered crucial because FPL could boost the power generated at other plants or turn on idle units elsewhere in its system. FPL declared ``an unusual event'' at the nuclear plant Wednesday for almost two hours even though the fire did not affect the nuclear side of the operation, Mehalik said. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission designation is the lowest emergency classification. The plant's nuclear units have been derided by consumer groups as among the most unsafe nationally with a history of security lapses and poor training. The utility responded by launching a major quality-control improvement program and won Japan's most prestigious quality award last October. The NRC took the plant off its ``watch list'' earlier this year. Miami-based FPL is Florida's largest utility, serving 3 million customers from Key West almost to Jacksonville. The power plant complex is in an unpopulated area on the edge of Biscayne Bay about 30 miles south of downtown Miami.

DOC.HEAD: Jewish Settlers Move into Christian Sector of Arab East Jerusalem
DOC.TEXT: About 150 Jews moved into the Christian sector of Jerusalem's Old City Wednesday, sparking Arab outrage at the the first Jewish presence in the area in 54 years, Arab and Israeli sources said. Angry Christian Arabs threw stones at the settlers and Greek Orthodox bishops arrived at the site to question the legality of the move, Arab sources said. There were no reports of injuries and police spokesman Uzi Sandori could not confirm any violence. Settler Shifra Blass, a spokeswoman for the Ataraot Cohanim Yeshiva, or Jewish seminary, said the families moved into a building in the Christian Quarter as part of an effort to expand the Jewish presence in Arab areas. ``We are doing the worthwhile job of advancing the avowed government policy of Jewish settlement throughout the city,'' Blass said. Mahdi Abdul Hadi, director of an Arab think tank on foreign policy in East Jerusalem said the settlers were ``escalating the confrontation by provoking Palestinians in their daily life.'' ``They are threatening the present and future existence of the Palestinians in this city,'' he said. Benny Elon, an official at the seminary, said the institute legally purchased the building in the Christian Quarter in a secret deal with an Arab resident. He would not say when the purchase was made. Officials at the Greek Orthodox church said the building is church property and was illegally acquired. Sandori said a police investigation concluded that the purchase was legal. Almost 50,000 Moslems live in the Old City, along with 7,000 Christians and approximately 4,000 Jews. More than 3,000 of those Jews live in the Jewish Quarter. The Moslem Quarter is home to 40 Jewish families and two seminaries including Ataraot Cohanim. The two-story building under question is near the Jewish Quarter and is in an area that was a thriving Jewish commercial center in the nineteenth century. The Jews living in that commercial center fled in 1936 after a series of Arab riots. Israel captured the Old City along with the West Bank from Jordan in the 1967 Arab Israeli war. The government annexed the Old City shortly after the war and called the unified city Israel's eternal and indivisible capital. The capital has not escaped the violence that has surged through the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip since the Palestinian uprising began in December 1987. Six Arabs and four Israelis have been killed in Jerusalem as a result of uprising-related incidents. The latest attack was Friday when an unidentified assailant stabbed a 35-year-old yeshiva student living in the Moslem Quarter, slightly wounding him.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary to Delay Routing Soviet Jews to Israel
DOC.TEXT: Hungary's ambassador said Wednesday his government has instructed Soviet authorities to stop letting Jewish emigres go to Israel via Budapest until the backlog is cleared of those already holding tickets. Ambassador Erno Simonyi estimated it could take months before up to 2,500 ticketed Soviet Jews are transported to Tel Aviv. Reacting to threats from Palestinian extremists, Hungary's national airline Malev announced last month it would transport no more Soviet Jews to Israel. Hungary later reversed the announcement for scheduled flights and fired Malev's manager, but a ban remained on charter flights for Soviet Jews. Simonyi told reporters, ``The Hungarian airline is now taking without discrimination any nationals, including Soviet Jews. But we aren't taking any new passengers until those who already have tickets are transported. ``They are about 2,000-2,500, so it will take several weeks, probably months.'' He said Hungarian authorities also told the Soviet carrier Aeroflot not to issue tickets on Malev flights from Budapest to Tel Aviv. Simonyi apparently chose to address the issue in Cairo to emphasize that the decision to continue flying Soviet Jews to Israel should not affect Hungary's relations with Arab countries. As in the rest of the Arab world, emigration to Israel of thousands of Soviet Jews has caused an uproar in Egypt, the only Arab country at peace with the Jewish state. Simonyi said ``some 1,000'' Soviet Jews have used the Budapest-Tel Aviv route since it opened last fall. Palestinians and Arab governments fear a large influx of new Israelis will settle in lands Israel captured from Jordan and Egypt in the 1967 Middle East War. Israeli officials say they expect up to 750,000 Soviet Jewish immigrants by the end of the decade.

DOC.HEAD: New York, Joined by Other States, Sues For Census Adjustment
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead to fix time element; INSERTS 1 graf after 7th graf, `The city ...,' to UPDATE with census director comment; picks up 8th graf, `Former city ...' SUBS 12th graf, `The Commerce ...,' with 2 grafs to UPDATE with Commerce Department comment; picks up penultimate graf, `Mayor Jimmy ...'
DOC.TEXT: New York City and state sued the federal government on Wednesday in an effort to boost an expected undercount of minorities in the 1990 census, which they claim uses ``biased and unconstitutional guidelines.'' The legal action was joined by the cities of Chicago, Los Angeles and Houston; Dade County, Fla.; the state of California; the U.S. Conference of Mayors; the League of Cities; the NAACP and the League of United Latin American Citizens. Mayor David Dinkins, calling the undercount of urban minorities ``a national disgrace,'' said that problem and other factors would mean ``cities across the country will once again lose hundreds of millions of dollars in federal aid and dozens of seats in Congress.'' ``Yet the national government _ from the White House to the Commerce Department to the Census Bureau _ seems to want to pay it no mind. They have gotten away with statistical malfeasance for 200 years and figure they can get away with it for another 10.'' The lawsuit, filed against the Department of Commerce in U.S. District Court, asks Judge Joseph McLaughlin to invalidate the Census Bureau's ``biased and unconstitutional guidelines'' for adjusting the expected undercount of minorities, Dinkins said. Around the country, more than 2.3 million of the 88.5 million census forms mailed out to households could not be delivered, the mayor said. In addition, 250,000 of them designated for delivery to residents in the New York City boroughs of Brooklyn and Queens had been kept in the bureau's Indiana warehouse, he said. The city maintains it was undercounted by 450,000 people in the 1980 census and subsequently lost one congressman, one state senator and one state assemblyman as well as $657 million in federal aid, which was based on population. In a statement, Census Director Barbara Everitt Bryant called the timing of the lawsuit ``particularly unfortunate.'' ``Today we are stretching all available resources to ensure that every American is counted in the census. There is time enough later to litigate the adequacy of this effort,'' she said. Former city Corporation Counsel Peter Zimroth, who is serving as attorney on the lawsuit, said the city and state are seeking to overturn guidelines set forth by the Commerce Department last month concerning the accuracy of this year's count. The Commerce Department has claimed the right to decide whether the census's raw figures are right or whether a post-census survey sampling should be conducted, as the mayor and others have urged. Commerce has said it has the right to reject a survey even though the survy might be more accurate on grounds that it would ``unduly disrupt the transfer of political power in the United States,'' since census figures are used to determine electoral districts, Zimroth said. Zimroth complained, ``That means the Department of Commerce would decide what is fair representation.'' The department's undersecretary for economic affairs, Michael R. Darby, defended his agency's efforts. ``The guidelines are designed to ensure that we have the most accurate census possible and to prevent manipulation of the census figures for political purposes,'' Darby said in a statement. Mayor Jimmy Kemp of Meridian, Miss., a member of the census task force of the United States Conference of Mayors, joined Dinkins in the press conference in City Hall and said he, too, expected an undercount and urged that an adjustment be made based on a post-census survey. ``All persons count and all persons should be counted, whether in Meridian, Miss., or New York City,'' he said. ``The overriding issue is one of fairness.''

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Removes First of Cruise Missiles from West Germany
DOC.TEXT: HAHN AIR BASE, West Germany _ The U.S. Air Force on Wednesday pulled out the first of 64 cruise nuclear rockets to be removed from West Germany by May 1991 under a U.S.-Soviet treaty. The first eight missiles, based with the other 56 at the Wueschheim missile site seven miles north of Hahn Air Base, were packed in special containers and then loaded aboard a giant C-5 transport jet for shipment to the United States. Air Force spokesman Capt. Eric Schnaible, briefing reporters Wednesday, said the eight missiles would be returned to Davis-Monthan Air Force Base at Tucson, Ariz., for destruction. The missiles were maintained by the Air Force's 38th Tactical Missile Wing at Wueschheim. Another eight missiles will be shipped to the United States on Friday, U.S. Air Force Col. Richard A. Myers said. Myers, commander of Wueschheim Air Station about 80 miles west of Frankfurt, said all the cruise missiles will be out of West Germany by the end of May 1991. The missile site was a frequent target of anti-nuclear demonstrations before the Intermediate Nuclear Forces treaty was signed by President Reagan and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in December 1987. The INF treaty bans all U.S. and Soviet ground-launched nuclear missiles with a range of 300 to 3,400 miles.

DOC.HEAD: Ruling by Kuwait's Moslem Theologians Closes Oyster Market
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait's Islamic theologians ruled that buying oysters on the chance they could bear pearls was sinful, and a newspaper said Wednesday that the decision led to the closure of a decades-old oyster market. The daily Al-Qabas said the formal prohibition came after a citizen approached the Ministry of Endowment and Islamic Affairs for an opinion on the practice. Islamic experts told The Associated Press that the practice was considered tantamount to gambling, banned by the Moslem religion. ``The sale of pearls before cracking the oyster is illegal because only Almighty God knows if it includes pearls or not,'' they quoted Sheik Mishaal Mubarak al-Sabah, head of the Islamic judgment department, as saying. The newspaper explained that oysters in Kuwait are purchased for the sole purpose of searching for pearls and compared the trade to a lottery or gambling. If an oyster is cracked before a sale _ and sold as food _ the purchase is legal, the newspaper said. Small-size varieties of the marine mollusk are considered a delicacy in some Mediterranean countries, including Islamic countries. The flesh inside the ones sold in Kuwait is also eaten at times. According to Al-Qabas, the Minister of State for Municipal Affairs Mohammed al-Refai, in response to the ruling, immediately ordered the closure of the oyster market in Shuwaikh, which has been running for decades. Shuwaikh is six miles north of Kuwait city. Al-Qabas said the oyster dealers were protesting the closure of the market and petitioning the concerned authorities. The oyster is sold in bags containing about seven pounds for a price ranging from $20 to $155. Reports of pearl finds are extremely rare. Diving and search for pearls once was a key occupation of Kuwaitis. With the oil era and with the Japan's development of artificial pearls, the occupation declined.

DOC.HEAD: Inmate With AIDS Convicted Of Attempted Murder In Biting Guard
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to UPDATE with Smith, attorney comments, guard not tested positive for AIDS, possible sentence. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An inmate who has AIDS was convicted Wednesday of attempted murder for biting a sheriff's officer and telling him to ``die, you pig!'' A jury spent seven hours over two days before announcing its conviction of Gregory D. Smith in the June 11 attack on Albert Waddington, a Camden County corrections officer. The panel also convicted Smith of four counts of aggravated assault, and one count of making terroristic threats. The jury acquitted Smith on one count each of aggravated assault and making terroristic threats in separate incidents involving two other officers. Smith showed no emotion when the verdict was read. Waddington, 26, who has not tested positive for the AIDS virus, clapped his hands and bowed his head as the jury foreman read the guilty verdict. He quickly left the courthouse, and declined comment. Smith shouted at the guard as he left, telling him, ``On your way home, Waddington, stop in church and ask God to forgive you for that lie.'' He also shouted at Superior Court Judge John B. Mariano that he would appeal, and sheriff's officers quickly handcuffed him and led him away. Sentencing is scheduled for May 18. Smith, 26, who is serving a five-year sentence for a robbery conviction, faces a maximum sentence of 30 years imprisonment. Smith was indicted for attempted murder in August for biting Waddington on the hand three times. Waddington contends Smith also spat on him and said: ``Now die, you pig. Die from what I have.'' Smith denied biting the guard. His attorney said the case was generated by AIDS hysteria and that scratches on the officer's hands were caused by the jagged edges of Smith's handcuffs. ``If it wasn't for AIDS this man would never have been here,'' defense attorney Ralph Kramer said outside the courtroom. ``I'm very happy for Al Waddington because he went through hell,'' said Harold Kasselman, assistant county prosecutor. ``We're not going to tolerate this kind of conduct on our corrections law enforcement officers.'' Kramer said he would appeal on the contention that the judge improperly allowed the jury to consider testimony from a prosecution medical expert who said there was a slight possibility AIDS could be transmitted through a bite. He said medical experts maintain it is very unlikely that the virus can be transmitted through contact such as biting or spitting. The fatal disease is generally transmitted through intravenous drug use, blood transfusions and sexual contact. The case is one of about 10 in the country in which an AIDS-stricken individual has been accused of attempting to spread the virus through biting or spitting. Medical and legal experts fear it will fuel misconceptions about how the disease is transmitted. ``What the criminal justice system is doing here is posing a very serious crime for a highly improbable result,'' said Larry Gostin, executive director of the American Society of Law and Medicine and an associate professor at Harvard's School of Public Health.

DOC.HEAD: Jordan to End Martial Law; U.S. Senators See Hussein
DOC.TEXT: Interior Minister Salem Massadeh said Wednesday the government next month plans to scrap the 55-year-old defense law under which martial law has been imposed in Jordan since 1967. He said the government will propose a new law for potential states of emergency when Parliament resumes its sessions early next month. ``The law will cancel the old law, but it will be inactive until it is used in emergency cases for the national security of the country,'' Massadeh told a news conference. The announcement came as King Hussein discussed Middle East issues Wednesday with a senior delegation of U.S. senators led by Robert Dole, R-Kan. The senators spent more than three hours with Hussein after arriving from Egypt. There were no substantive details on the talks. Prime Minister Mudar Badran promised in December to cancel both the defense law and martial law within six months. Jordan declared martial law under the 1935 legislation during the Arabs' 1967 war with Israel, and the country has lived under that decree ever since. But Badran this year stripped military courts of most functions and returned power to civilian tribunals. He declared martial law ``frozen.'' Both Jordan and Israel inherited versions of the defense law from the British mandate period before World War II. Both have used it widely. It provides much of the legal foundation for Israel's detention without trial of thousands of Palestinians during the continuing uprising on the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Massadeh noted that the many laws and decrees imposed under martial law over 23 years often affected routine affairs, and he said the government is studying which need to be replaced by new legislation proposed to Parliament. The action continues a yearlong series of liberalizing reforms prompted largely by the April 1989 riots in southern Jordan over economic problems and what was viewed as government high-handedness. The Parliament that will consider the new legislation was elected in November during Jordan's first nationwide election since 1967. Jordan has also returned passports confiscated by the General Intelligence Department, dropped all travel and work bans and freed all of its purely political prisoners, according to government officials. Massadeh said 31 people convicted of political offenses remain in prison, but he said all were also convicted of other crimes, such as possession, use or smuggling of arms and explosives or attacking security forces. The U.S. senators meanwhile arranged to fly on to Baghdad Thursday to discuss issues that have strained U.S. relations with the Iraqi government of President Saddam Hussein. The lawmakers ran into protests in Amman over a Senate resolution recognizing Jerusalem as Israel's capital. A peaceful gathering of about 150 demonstrators, including several former high-ranking officials, met the senators on their return from the palace shortly before midnight to protest the Senate action. ``We feel perfectly dismayed'' by the March 22 vote, former Foreign Minister Hazem Nuseibeh told Dole. Nusibeh and other prominent Jerusalem figures gave the senators a document outlining their opposition. Dole assured the group the Senate action was a non-binding resolution that did not affect U.S. policy, which does not recognize the disputed holy city as Israel's capital. ``I don't think it has any importance,'' Dole said. ``The big picture is getting the peace process started.'' Roughly half Jordan's 3.1 million people are from families that lost homes in Palestine when Israel was created or when it captured the West Bank and East Jerusalem from Jordan in 1967. Columnist Tareq Masarweh noted in the daily newspaper Al Rai that that one of the visitors, Sen. Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, was a sponsor of the Jerusalem resolution. ``Why should we welcome him?'' asked Masarweh. Other delegates are Sens. Alan Simpson of Wyoming, James McClure of Idaho, Frank Murkowski of Alaska and Charles Grassley of Iowa, all Republicans.

DOC.HEAD: 1,500 Say Goodbye to AIDS Victim Ryan White
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `Scores of ...,' to ADD weather. SUBS 19th graf, `Hundreds of ...,' to ADD name of funeral home. ADDS 2 grafs to UPDATE with statement by John, Mrs. White; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: More than 1,500 friends and admirers, including first lady Barbara Bush and singer Michael Jackson, bid farewell Wednesday to Ryan White, the young AIDS victim who taught the nation a lesson in courage. ``Ryan and his family always believed there would be a miracle,'' the Rev. Raymond Probasco said in his eulogy. ``But that didn't happen. I believe God gave us that miracle in Ryan. He healed a wounded spirit in the world and made it whole.'' Ryan's mother, Jeanne, sat with her 16-year-old daughter, Andrea, and Jackson, who had befriended Ryan. Ryan's father, Wayne, who is divorced from Mrs. White, also attended the service at the Second Presbyterian Church. Singer Elton John, who had maintained a bedside vigil during Ryan's final week of life, led the congregation in singing a hymn. He then accompanied himself as he sang his own composition, ``Skyline Pigeon,'' about a captive bird yearning to be freed. Ryan died Sunday of complications from the disease he had fought for more than five years. Probasco noted that many celebrities had befriended the youth during his struggle with AIDS and his legal battle to attend public school. He said Ryan's life, like theirs, also was successful. ``He helped us to care and to believe that with God's help, nothing is impossible, even for a kid,'' said the minister, who is pastor at Center Chapel United Methodist Church in Muncie and has known the White family for years. John, wearing a black sequined hat, served as a pallbearer with Los Angeles Raiders football player Howie Long, talk-show host Phil Donahue and three local friends of Ryan: Tommy Hale, Leo Joseph and John Huffman. About 300 of Ryan's schoolmates at Hamilton Heights High School in Arcadia, 25 miles north of Indianapolis, came by bus to the funeral, which was carried live by Cable News Network. Scores of people were left during the service standing outside the Gothic-style church, which was filled to capacity, in chilly wind and rain. Members of the school's choir sang ``That's What Friends Are For.'' Ryan found friendship and acceptance at the school after his family moved from Kokomo. A private burial service was held for the family and close friends in a cemetery in Cicero, the small town near Arcadia, where the Whites have lived nearly three years. Gov. Evan Bayh ordered flags across Indiana to fly at half-staff in tribute to the youngster who not only confronted a devastating disease but helped to educate the world about it. Former President Reagan, who with his wife, Nancy, joined Ryan in the youth's last public appearance two weeks ago in Los Angeles, remembered him in a newspaper column as a young man of patience and kindness who did not wallow in self-pity. ``Ryan accepted his situation with awe-inspiring courage and magnanimity. He did not run and hide, and he graciously accepted the public responsibilities thrust on his young shoulders,'' Reagan wrote in the tribute published Wednesday on the op-ed page of The Washington Post. Ryan was diagnosed with acquired immune deficiency syndrome in December 1984. He had contracted the disease from tainted blood products used to treat his hemophilia. During the following two years, he and his mother won a court battle to allow him to attend public school near Kokomo. The youngster appeared on television talk shows and magazine covers and at Washington hearings as a spokesman for young sufferers of AIDS. In between appearances at star-studded fund-raisers, the teen-ager tried to lead a normal life by attending classes and dances, skateboarding and getting his driver's license. Hundreds of friends and strangers waited in line Tuesday at the Flanner & Buchanan Mortuary in suburban Carmel to file past his open casket. They saw him one last time wearing his faded denim jacket and reflective sunglasses. Visitation continued Wednesday morning at the church, where 300 people were waiting in line when the doors opened. ``I'm glad to see that he was so thought of that so many are here,'' said Gladys Lewis of Indianapolis. ``It shows that somehow we all learned something from his battle. What he went through, it brought so many people _ whites, blacks, people of all religions and ages _ he brought people together.'' ``It's obviously a very sad day for all of us that knew him and worked with him,'' said Dr. Woodrow A. Myers at the church. The former Indiana state health commissioner who supported the Whites' school battle is now New York City health commissioner. ``Ryan really led us all. Here's a kid who was 14 years old who led the nation by his example,'' Myers said. After the funeral, Elton John and Mrs. White issued a statement thanking the media for ``respectful and sensitive'' coverage of the death and mourning. ``As Ryan understood, the role of the media in educating others about AIDS is critically important,'' the statement said. ``He showed us all that we need to devote ourselves to fighting the disease of AIDS, not those who suffer from it.''

DOC.HEAD: Sailors Charged in Drug Probe
DOC.TEXT: Five sailors, including a drug testing supervisor, were charged with using and distributing illegal drugs aboard a guided missile frigate, authorities said. Four other sailors serving on the USS John A. Moore face administrative sanctions for drug use, Lt. Cmdr. Steve Chesser said Tuesday. The charges resulted from a seven-month investigation into allegations that sailors used and distributed marijuana and crystal methamphetamine, or ``ice,'' Chesser said. Chief Master at Arms David Riley, the ship's top law enforcement officer, was charged with four counts of using methamphetamine, two counts of using marijuana and ``compromising the command's urinalysis program,'' Chesser said. Petty Officer 1st Class Alden Hendrickson and Operations Specialist 2nd Class Kevin McPike were charged with use and distribution of methamphetamine, Chesser said. McPike also was charged with using marijuana, he said. A preliminary hearing on the charges was planned. The three sailors could face courts-martial, Chesser said. Electricians Mates 3rd Class Lonnie Fessler and Thomas Hawley were charged with one count each of distributing methamphetamine, he said. Hawley and Fessler could be tried by special courts-martial, which provide less severe penalties upon conviction than general courts-martial, Chesser said. The sailors being dealt with administratively were not identified. The Moore is assigned to the Naval Reserve and previously escorted oil tankers in the Persian Gulf.

DOC.HEAD: Editors, Paper Receive Support
DOC.TEXT: More than two dozen people canceled subscriptions to protest a newspaper's decision to fire two editors for their leadership roles in an anti-abortion group, the paper's editor said Wednesday. Fairfield Ledger Editor Jan Nierling said she was sorry to lose the readers and that ``every subscription counts,'' but said the cancellations had a ``minimal'' economic impact. The independently owned paper has more than 5,000 daily subscribers. ``We had a couple of letters in protest, and we'll print them,'' she said. ``But we also had someone come in last night who renewed his subscription ... and said he was proud that we did what we felt we had to do.'' A few advertisers, including a Christian book store, had pulled ads, she said. ``We had one call back who said, `I apologize, I thought it through and I realize in business there are some tough decisions to make,' '' Ms. Nierling said. On Monday, the paper fired News Editor John Kennedy and People Page Editor Terri Lambertsen because they declined to resign from their positions as secretary and president of a new anti-abortion group. Ms. Nierling said the two violated the paper's policy that prohibits journalists from taking active positions in groups subject to news coverage. Kennedy said no legal action was planned against the paper, but, ``I'd like to see this be righted. Their action is wrong in our eyes.'' He said the Southeast Iowa Pro-Lifers group has not done anything other than hold an organizational meeting. ``My beliefs on abortion are not political views, it's religious,'' Kennedy said. ``They're my Christian convictions, it's not some political bent I'm on. ``There have been a lot of Christians calling, offering support and prayers,'' he said. ``That's been very encouraging. And I've got a lot of support from people who aren't Christians, just on the principle that it's wrong for a paper to fire people for their beliefs.'' Kennedy and Ms. Lambertsen are members of the International Church of the Four Square Gospel, which encourages members to be socially active. Ms. Nierling said she, too, had received numerous calls of support. She said editors from around Iowa called to say the Ledger made the right decision. ``It was nice to have the supportive phone calls,'' she said. ``They said it was a tough call, that they wouldn't want to be in my shoes. But they said they'd do the same thing.''

DOC.HEAD: Swede Fights for Right to Fly Native Flag
DOC.TEXT: A Swedish woman whose flag was removed from a condominium flagpole says she'll go to court to fight for the right to fly the banner of her native country. Zenta Rowley, who moved to the United States from Sweden five years ago, hired an attorney after her flag was removed last week from the community flagpole at Mariner Village. ``This is ridiculous. I like my flag and I know my rights,'' said Rowley, who was given the blue-and-yellow banner recently by friends from Sweden. ``What she wants to do is something very patriotic that doesn't hurt anybody in the neighborhood,'' said her attorney, James Rich. The president of the Boynton Mariner Village Homeowners Association, Mark Ifill, also is seeking advice from a lawyer. He refused to respond to Rowley's accusation that he was responsible for the flag's removal. The Swedish flag was taken down a few hours after Rowley raised it on the complex's flagpole, beneath the U.S. flag. Also on the pole are four nautical flags that signify the village association. Rowley said she then collected signatures from 34 of the 36 unit owners supporting her effort to fly the flag and checked with Boynton Beach officials to make sure city law doesn't prohibit display of foreign flags. ``We don't have any problems with it _ as long as the American flag is on top, of course,'' Code Enforcement Administrator Scott Blasie said. But Rowley must get permission from her homeowners association before the Swedish flag can be flown, said complex manager Gene Schuler. ``It is a shame that you need attorneys for something like this, but sometimes there is no other choice,'' he said. ``If you let the Swedes fly their flags, then you have to do the same for the Mexicans and Italians, which could lead to a lot of problems,'' said Schuler.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards Former San Antonio Heart Surgeon $28 Million
DOC.TEXT: A jury has awarded a $28 million libel judgment to a heart surgeon who claimed a San Antonio television station ruined his medical practice with stories of allegations that he performed unnecessary surgery. Attorneys for KENS-TV said they likely will appeal Tuesday's verdict. Dr. Sudhir Srivastava filed the lawsuit against KENS-TV and Harte-Hanks Television in 1985 after the station broadcast a series of reports alleging that a ring of physicians had performed unnecessary surgery on elderly patients for profit. The jury found that the reports that the doctor had performed such surgery, based on interviews with relatives of some of his patients, were false as a whole and had ruined Srivastava's reputation. ``We're elated,'' the doctor, with his wife and two children, said after the verdict. ``Finally justice came through.'' ``They saw the truth,'' Srivastava said of the jurors. ``They saw all the evidence that was there and the facts convinced them.'' In the series, KENS-TV journalist Ed Gonzalez reported that Srivastava had lost his privileges to practice at Santa Rosa Hospital and the Baptist Memorial Hospital System amid claims of unnecessary surgery. The doctor contended the series ruined his San Antonio practice. His malpractice insurance skyrocketed and he was forced to move to Midland, where he now practices at a loss, said his lawyer, James Branton. Eleven jurors _ one more than needed to validate the decision in civil court _ voted to award the doctor $28 million after hearing two weeks of evidence and deliberating six hours. KENS-TV lawyer Mark Cannan said an appeal is likely. ``Adverse jury verdicts against the media are not uncommon,'' Cannan said. ``But this is just round one.'' Branton described Srivastava as a promising young surgeon who had performed more than 2,000 open-heart surgeries by the end of 1984. He also claimed the station was ``out to get someone'' during a ratings period. KENS-TV stood behind the broadcast, calling it good journalism on a subject of great public concern. Cannan argued that the medical community already knew of Srivastava's hospital suspensions and, therefore, the doctor's reputation was damaged before the first KENS-TV story aired. He noted the suspensions also were reported in the San Antonio Express-News the morning before the first broadcast. Cannan said the series ran over a period of several days and Srivastava had an open invitation to appear on the program. Dallas lawyer Chip Babcock, who represents the Dallas Times Herald and KDFW-TV in Dallas, said the verdict is one of the biggest libel awards against a Texas news organization. KENS-TV President and General Manager Michael J. Conly said: ``The verdict relates to a newscast that ran over five years ago. We are amazed and very disappointed by it. ``At the same time, we know media companies frequently lose verdicts at the jury level, for whatever reasons, but then win on appeal because the law recognizes the crucial role the media plays in educating the public and protecting our democratic institutions,'' Conly said.

DOC.HEAD: Five Killed in Clashes, Civilians Dig Mountain Caves for Shelter
LaserPhotos BEI1, BEI2
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces exchanged machine gun and sniper fire Wednesday, killing three people, as civilians dug caves in mountains to protect themselves in case of renewed shelling duels. The inconclusive showdown between renegade army Gen. Michel Aoun and Christian warlord Samir Geagea for mastery of the Christian enclave has left nearly 900 dead since it began on Jan. 30. In another development, Shiite Moslem militias allied with Iran and Syria battled in the ancient town of Baalbek, 53 miles northeast of Beirut. Police said one militiaman of the Syrian-backed mainstream Shiite Amal militia, and another from the pro-Iranian Hezbollah, or Party of God, were killed in the shootout. The two factions have been fighting intermittently for more than two years for dominance among Lebanon's 1.2 million Shiites, the largest community in the war-torn nation. The Lebanese civil war itself is in its 15th year. A police spokesman, who cannot be named in line with regulations, said a majority of the 1 million residents of the Christian enclave have fled the area. He said some Christians who could not afford to flee were digging caves along the rocky slopes of the Kesrouan mountains for shelter in case of renewed artillery duels. At least a dozen caves were under construction in the Bou Mizan region near the shell-shattered mountain resort of Kleiat, 15 miles northeast of Beirut. Kleiat, well-known for its plush restaurants, nightclubs and villas, has become a no-man's land with both Aoun's soldiers and Geagea's fighters repeatedly storming the area to gain control of the network of narrow mountain roads which it commands. ``Most of those digging caves are poor villagers who cannot afford to rent houses or hotel rooms in other areas,'' the police spokesman said. Lebanon gained independence from France in 1943.

DOC.HEAD: Harold Ballard, Eccentric Owner of Toronto Hockey Team, Dead at 86
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with quotes from friend, NHL president; picks up 6th pvs, `In an...' A version also moved on sports wires
DOC.TEXT: Harold Ballard, the colorful and eccentric owner of the Toronto Maple Leafs of the National Hockey League, died Wednesday in a Toronto hospital after a long illness. He was 86. Ballard died of a combination of factors, including diabetes, heart problems and kidney and respiratory failure, doctors at Wellesley Hospital said in a release. Ballard's children _ Harold Jr., William and Mary Elizabeth Flynn _ and his longtime companion, Yolanda Ballard, had visited him earlier Wednesday. ``I was holding his hand,'' said his oldest friend, former Toronto mayor Allan Lamport, who had visited Ballard just before he died. ``He squeezed my hand. It showed he understood.'' His death came months after he abruptly called off a scheduled marriage on a Caribbean island to Ms. Ballard, 57. Ballard, who owned Maple Leafs Gardens and built a fortune estimated at more than $100 million, reveled in his reputation for being cantankerous and unabashedly sexist, and his personality often made more headlines than his team. NHL President John Ziegler, whom Ballard once called ``a know-nothing shrimp,'' said his death marked the end of an era. ``Harold was his own public relations, marketing and promotional (man), not only manager but performer.'' In an interview in October, Ballard said: ``I think that every girl thinks that if she hangs around with a guy that she's going to be his wife someday. She isn't getting any headway with me.'' When asked about women sportswriters in the locker room, he said: ``I told them once, if you want to go in there you can _ but you've got to take your clothes off too.'' Ballard called professional hockey players overpaid and often criticized warmer Soviet relations with the West, particularly on the ice. He once threatened to bar a Soviet team from his arena for an exhibition match. In 1972, Ballard was convicted of fraud and theft involving $205,000 in the arena's funds and served one year of a three-year sentence. Ballard spent much of the last two years in and out of hospitals because of diabetes-related heart problems. In July 1988, he underwent heart bypass surgery at Toronto General Hospital. In January 1988, he had a heart attack while on vacation and spent almost a month in the Miami Heart Institute. In February 1986, Ballard spent 16 days in the hospital for prostate gland surgery. Perhaps the strangest episode in his soap opera life began in 1982 when he met Yolanda MacMillan, who in 1987 had her last name legally changed to Ballard in anticipation of a wedding. But, on Jan. 3, just hours before the two were to be wed in the Cayman Islands, Ballard backed out, saying he was not ready for marriage. Hours later, Ballard became ill and had been hospitalized since. A judge in Toronto declared Ballard mentally incompetent and appointed personal and financial guardians. William Ballard referred to Ms. Ballard as ``the dragon lady,'' and said she had taken advantage of his father's loneliness while trying to isolate him from his family. She responded: ``They were a long-battling family many, many years before I came to know Mr. Ballard. It just breaks my heart to see this kind of discontentment.'' Ballard was born in Toronto on July 30, 1903, the only son of a skating company owner. He began in hockey as the owner of a minor league team. He became vice president of the Maple Leafs in the 1960s and president and governor of the club in 1971. He was inducted into the Hockey Hall of Fame in 1977, the year the Leafs celebrated their 50th birthday. He bought the Hamilton Tigers-Cats of the Canadian Football League in 1978 and sold it in 1989. His wife, Dorothy, died of cancer in 1968.

DOC.HEAD: Safety Board Says Hanford Tanks Pose Little Risk to Public
DOC.TEXT: Hydrogen gas building up inside nuclear waste storage tanks at the Hanford nuclear reservation poses no risk to the public, the head of a congressional review group said Wednesday. Two members of the Defense Nuclear Facilities Safety Board have spent the past two days at Hanford, conferring with officials for the U.S. Department of Energy about the tanks. Experts have said there is a chance the tanks could explode because of the hydrogen buildup. ``We don't believe there is any kind of risk to the public,'' said John Conway, chairman of the board, in a brief telephone interview. Asked whether the issue has unnecessarily alarmed the public, as Energy Secretary James Watkins has contended, Conway said, ``The public has a reason to be concerned, unless it is explained properly to them.'' Conway spoke after he and board member Herbert Kouts had eight hours of briefings from DOE and experts. Hanford manager Mike Lawrence announced last month that new findings indicated hydrogen was building up inside 20 of Hanford's 177 waste storage tanks. He said there was a low risk of the hydrogen catching fire or exploding. Watkins subsequently criticized Lawrence before Congress for alarming the public over such a low risk. Lawrence has said the problem is that hydrogen is trapped under the hard crust that forms at the top of the wastes, which are byproducts of the production of plutonium for nuclear weapons. Scientists monitoring the wastes have watched them rise as much as 33 inches in past years, apparently the result of gases building up under the crust, DOE has said. Conway said DOE officials must continue taking precautions to prevent the tanks from exploding. The Energy Department has stopped taking wastes in and out of the tanks, and reduced probing activities to prevent a spark from triggering an explosion. ``There are more things they'll have to do,'' Conway said, but did not elaborate. The board needs additional information before making its recommendations to Watkins, and will visit Hanford again, he said. The safety board was set up by Congress last year to monitor safety at DOE facilities.

DOC.HEAD: Puerto Ricans Find Fortune in Dollars in Buried Steel Drums
DOC.TEXT: Federal investigators have moved in after hearing residents of the coastal town of Vega Baja were on a spending spree, and reportedly found the people had unearthed steel drums containing millions of dollars, according to a news report Wednesday. The English daily The San Juan Star quoted unidentified sources as saying the FBI recently recovered one drum filled with $1.5 million, most of it in $20 bills issued in 1985. Ten empty drums were found nearby. FBI spokeswoman Alina Bloom said Wednesday night, ``We are not giving out any information pending the completion of the investigation.'' Vega Baja is a small town 35 miles west of San Juan. Residents were said to have uncovered about 10 drums packed with cash three weeks ago and apparently started buying houses, boats, cars and VCRs like they were going out of style. Newspapers reported that suspicious bank officials called authorities last week after a Vega Baja auto mechanic paid cash for a $170,000 house and a sports car and deposited $50,000 in cash in the bank. Although it's not known where the steel drum money came from, speculation was the buried treasure belonged to drug traffickers. The FBI was reportedly trying to persuade townsfolk to turn over the money. In Puerto Rico, a U.S. commonwealth, the law states anyone finding ``treasures'' in private property in the Caribbean island can keep half of it, with the balance going to the commonwealth.

DOC.HEAD: Ex-IRS Agent Sentenced for Money Laundering
DOC.TEXT: A former Internal Revenue Service agent who was caught in an FBI sting was sentenced Wednesday to 41 months in federal prison for money laundering. U.S. District Judge Edward B. Davis warned he would have been harsher if Ricardo Hawkins, 40, committed the crime while he was still with the IRS. ``This court is severe with people who violate the public trust,'' he said. Defense attorney Richard Sharpstein, noting his client's contrition, had asked for the minimum 33-month term under guidelines ranging up to 51 months. Sharpstein promised to appeal. Hawkins was arrested last May 24 as he stepped from a plane at Miami International Airport on a flight from Atlanta, holding $225,000 given to him by an undercover FBI agent posing as a cocaine dealer as part of a money-laundering sting. Hawkins was living in Marietta, Ga., at the time of his arrest. He served as an IRS agent in Ohio from 1973 to 1982 and then as chief deputy sheriff in Stark County, Ohio, until 1984. Davis allowed him to remain free on $100,000 personal surety bond pending his surrender May 11 to a federal prison.

DOC.HEAD: Solidarity Chief Backs Away from Presidential Bid
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS graf 10 `Now we' to CORRECT spelling of Jan Carnogursky. Picks up 11th `By this...'
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa denied Wednesday he had decided to run for president of Poland, and said the campaign that most concerns him is winning re-election next week as Solidarity chairman. Walesa backed away from remarks attributed to him Tuesday by the official Polish news agency PAP that indicated he would be a presidential candidate in the next election. ``Today on radio and TV, I hear that Lech Walesa agreed to be president. I didn't say so at all,'' Walesa protested. ``I simply did not guard my tongue enough somewhere.'' Walesa said he had been ``cajoled'' into giving an answer, and was misunderstood. Asked about whether he would run for president, Walesa was quoted by PAP as replying, ``I confirm.'' ``We have many wise and valuable people in government, holding various posts,'' Walesa told PAP. ``However, one must speed up the pace of reforms and destroy the old arrangements.'' On Wednesday, Walesa said his ``metaphor'' about running for president was simply his way of warning the present Solidarity-led government to work faster in transforming Poland from a communist to a democratic system. Walesa expressed concern that a premature presidential bid might cost him support among Solidarity activists who will be electing a chairman next week when the once-outlawed union holds its first congress in nine years. ``Now we have the union elections, and a lot of activists will say I would vote for you but if you want to jump from the union to the presidency, I will not vote,'' Walesa said, speaking to reporters during a visit to his Gdansk union headquarters by Czechoslovak Deputy Premier Jan Carnogursky. ``By this false start, I can lose the basic things,'' he said, referring to the union chairmanship. Walesa faces a challenge from a Solidarity faction that feels the union has strayed too far from its founding ideals of 1980 by putting politics ahead of trade union goals defending workers' interests. Despite his denials, however, other politicians showed little doubt Wednesday that Walesa eventually intends to seek the presidency. President Wojciech Jaruzelski's six-year term is not due to end until 1995, but there is a strong possibility the election will be moved up as part of a general overhaul of the Polish Constitution. ``The fact that Walesa intends to run for president of the Polish Republic is not a surprise for me,'' said Labor Party leader Wladyslaw Sila-Nowicki in Wednesday's edition of the government newspaper Rzeczpospolita. The retreat from a declaration of candidacy was vintage Walesa, who typically is circumspect in discussing his political moves and often makes seemingly contradictory statements. One close adviser to Walesa, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Solidarity leader is now biding his time regarding the presidency. ``After the (union) congress, we will launch the battle with a firm hand,'' the adviser said. There was no immediate comment from Jaruzelski or his aides about a potential Walesa presidential bid. Jaruzelski, who began a trip Wednesday to the Soviet Union, was elected president by parliament last July with Solidarity's passive assistance despite leading the 1981 martial law crackdown that suppressed the union. Jaruzelski resigned as Communist Party leader shortly after assuming the presidency. But at a time when the old Communist leaders have been swept away throughout Eastern Europe, many Solidarity activists are upset Jaruzelski remains president. The discussion of a presidential bid by Walesa also brings into focus his growing differences with the government of Tadeusz Mazowiecki, a union adviser who became the East bloc's first non-communist prime minister last August. Walesa has accused the government of acting too slowly to privatize the state economy and remove the old Communist elite from positions of influence in factories and local governments. Reiterating his criticism, Walesa told reporters Wednesday that despite Solidarity's achievements since its founding, there are still too few practical improvements in people's lives. ``There has been a victory, but no use is being made of this victory,'' Walesa said.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Convicts Man of Killing Ex-Wife While on Prison Furlough
DOC.TEXT: A jury on Wednesday found a convict guilty of murdering his ex-wife while free on a prison furlough. Alan L. Matheney, 39, could receive the death penalty for the 1989 beating death of Lisa M. Bianco. The jury was to return to court Thursday to decide whether Matheney should be executed or go to prison. The jury rejected Matheney's insanity defense in convicting him of murder and burglary after nearly seven hours of deliberations. Matheney listened impassively to the verdict, chewing gum as he stood at the defense table with his hands folded in front of him. Moments later, bailiffs and sheriff's deputies led him from the courtroom. The victim's father, Eugene Bianco, listened quietly to the verdict, then wept as a prosecutor's assistant came up to hug him. He declined to comment on the conviction. Before deliberations began, the judge told jurors they could find Matheney guilty, innocent, not responsible by reason of insanity or guilty but mentally ill. The judge and jury were brought to South Bend for the trial from Lake County to the west in a change of venue. In closing arguments, the prosecution described Matheney as a methodical killer trying to manipulate the courts by pleading insanity. ``There's no evidence whatsover on the insanity issue,'' St. Joseph County deputy prosecutor John D. Krisor said. ``And he was able to appreciate the wrongfulness of his conduct on March 4, 1989.'' Matheney received an eight-hour furlough that day from the Indiana Reformatory near Indianapolis and drove to the South Bend suburb of Mishawaka, where he broke into Ms. Bianco's home, chased her outside and beat her to death, prosecutors say. Matheney had been serving an eight-year term for a 1987 assault of Ms. Bianco. In his closing argument, defense attorney Scott L. King repeated a concession to the jury that Matheney killed the 29-year-old woman. ``This defense never, never sugar-coated anything to you,'' he said. King attacked the state's evidence on the burglary charge _ a key element in the prosecution's attempt to seek the death penalty.
