DOC.TEXT: Investor Harold Simmons said he failed in an attempt to oust Lockheed Corp.'s directors but won on several shareholder issues, including seeking to abolish the company's so-called poison pill. Citing preliminary tallies, Simmons said Tuesday that four shareholders' rights proposals each received 57 percent to 97 percent of the votes cast at last month's annual shareholders meeting. Incumbent Lockheed directors were re-elected with between 58 percent and 61 percent of the votes each, the billionaire investor said.

Casting its vote in the growing debate over oil tanker safety, Conoco Inc. said it will switch to double-hull tankers to help guard against spills like last year's catastrophe in Alaska's Prince William Sound. Conoco said it had placed an order for two double-hull oil tankers and would order only twin-hull vessels in the future. The step was part of a nine-point environmental program the company unveiled Tuesday that also included efforts to reduce toxic air emissions.

The Chicago Board of Trade acted within ethics rules when it declared an emergency and ordered traders to reduce July 1989 soybean holdings, congressional investigators said. The General Accounting Office reported Tuesday on its probe of last summer's order to liquidate large stakes in the July futures contract. The controversy centered on Ferruzzi Finanziaria S.p.A., one of the world's largest soybean processors.

In an effort to even the financial scales in the savings and loan scandal, the Justice Department says it may freeze the assets of thrifts and S&L officers accused of fraud. The device, authorized by Congress in last year's S&L bailout bill, ``would be used to freeze assets that are derived from savings and loan wrongdoing,'' Justice Department spokesman David Runkel said Tuesday. Throughout the S&L scandal, the government has found that the assets have disappeared before they can be retrieved, he said.

A federal judge said regulators should explain why they slashed the estimated value of financier Charles Keating's Lincoln Savings and Loan Association and other investments. ``The government says it's $2 billion in the red and the former operator says it's $600 million in the black,'' U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin said Tuesday. He suggested calling in the court-appointed receiver in the case to explain the difference.

A federal judge ruled that Eastern Airlines' pilots union can seek arbitration over the union's contention that Eastern has been merged with its sister carrier Continental Airlines. U.S. District Judge Robert W. Sweet also decided Tuesday that the pilots union may proceed with a lawsuit against Eastern over its practice of leasing aircraft and crews from Continental. The rulings reversed earlier decisions by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland, who had ruled that in both cases the bankruptcy court was sole forum for deciding those issues.

UAL Corp. said it had formalized its agreement to sell the company, the parent of United Airlines, to its employees for about $4.38 billion. The formalization of the buyout pact Tuesday sets into motion the process for leaders of the pilots, machinists and flight attendants to seek rank-and-file approval of wage cuts and other contract concessions designed to save $2 billion over five years as a contribution toward the buyout.

AST Research Inc., a small U.S. computer maker, is invading Japan with a clone of that country's most popular personal computer, a rare attack on a market dominated by domestic machines. The AST computer to be unveiled today in Tokyo runs programs designed for NEC Corp.'s PC-9801, but can be switched over to the different operating system used by IBM Corp. It will be the first PC in Japan to run both systems, and AST says it will be priced competitively with NEC computers.

United Auto Workers union President Owen Bieber sounded a confrontational note toward management before the union's skilled-trades workers, three months before contract negotiations begin with the Big Three automakers. ``America's industrial challenge is not a little bit management's fault and a little bit the union's fault. It's management's failures, plain and simple, that have put us in the precarious situation we face in so many sectors today,'' Bieber told the union's Skilled Trades Department on Tuesday.

Stock prices ended mixed in quiet trading Tuesday as the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 9.01 to 2,731.08. The dollar declined sharply against most major currencies in thin trading. Bond prices lost ground, hurt by the results of an auction of 40-year bonds to rescue the ailing thrift industry. Crude oil futures tumbled to their lowest levels in more than a year; cocoa futures surged to their highest close in nearly a year; precious metals fell; grains and soybeans were mixed; and livestock and meat futures rose.

DOC.HEAD: Creditors Request Trustee; Judge Rules in Favor of Eastern Pilots
DOC.TEXT: The unsecured creditors of Eastern Airlines have asked a bankruptcy court to appoint a special trustee to take over the ailing carrier and seek a buyer for it. Tuesday's request by the committee of unsecured credits came one day after preferred shareholders challenged Eastern's reorganization proposal and submitted a plan that would put the airline in the hands of the shareholders, unsecured creditors and new managers. The two groups are Eastern's biggest creditors, owed a total of more than $1.6 billion. After long supporting management, the creditors have become exasperated by Eastern's growing losses and its recent plans to cut debt payments. Meanwhile Tuesday, Eastern's pilots union won a key victory when a federal judge reversed earlier decisions by U.S. Bankruptcy Judge Burton R. Lifland. U.S. District Judge Robert W. Sweet ruled that the union can seek arbitration over its contention that Eastern has been merged with its sister carrier Continental Airlines. Sweet also decided that the pilots union may proceed with a lawsuit against Eastern over its practice of leasing aircraft and crews from Continental. Lifland had previously ruled in both cases that the bankruptcy court was the only proper forum for deciding those issues. In his 71-page opinion, Sweet wrote that the important question was ``when and in what forum collectively bargained-for rights may be enforced against an employer who has sought protection from creditors in bankruptcy.'' If a court concludes that Eastern and Continental have effectively been merged, it would trigger certain protective labor provisions, such as seniority rights, contained in the pilots union's contract with Eastern. Eastern's pilots, Machinists and flight attendants struck the Miami-based airline on March 4, 1989, forcing it into Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection five days later. The Machinists union remains on strike against Eastern. Lifland had denied the pilots' request to lift an automatic stay protecting Eastern against arbitration on the union's contention that the transfer of Eastern assets to Texas Air and Continental constituted a merger between Eastern and its sister carrier. Lifland ruled last September that arbitration would usurp the bankruptcy court's role in Eastern's reorganization and ``thwart the goal of judicial speed and economy'' necessary for rehabilitating the airline. In Sweet's second ruling, the pilots union was allowed to proceed with its suit in U.S. District Court in Miami aimed at blocking Eastern's practice of leasing jets with crews _ known as ``wet-leasing'' _ from Continental. The union had claimed the leases violated its contract with Eastern because Continental pilots have been used rather than Eastern fliers. Last fall, Lifland issued an injunction against the union's suit, maintaining it was an attempt to interfere with the bankruptcy court's jurisdiction. A bankruptcy court hearing on the trustee issue was scheduled for Friday morning. At the same time, Lifland was slated to consider Eastern's request for $80 million to be withdrawn from escrow funds for operating expenses in the second quarter and some payments to creditors. Eastern's unions have been attempting for some time to have a trustee appointed to replace Frank Lorenzo, chairman of Eastern's parent Texas Air Corp. The unions accuse Lorenzo of funneling assets from Eastern to Continental and to Texas Air. The committee of unsecured creditors, who are owed $980 million, agreed last week to reject the airline's latest reorganization proposal and seek the appointment of a trustee. In formally filing its motion for a trustee Tuesday, the committee said ``Eastern's devastating, constantly expanding and unending losses are extremely damaging to unsecured creditors.'' The motion said Eastern and Texas Air have been unable to project the results of Eastern's operations, ``to the extent that the committee has lost confidence in their stewardship of the business.'' Bruce Simon, an attorney for the Air Line Pilots Association, said he believes there is a ``very real'' possibility that Lifland could decide at Friday's hearing to name a trustee. Eastern spokeswoman Karen Ceremsak in Miami reiterated the airline's position that there is no ``legal or policy basis'' for the appointment of a trustee. She called the creditors' motion a ``ruse'' that is being used as a negotiating tool. Ms. Ceremsak said Sweet's rulings were ``procedural,'' rather than on the merits of the case. Art Kent, a Texas Air spokesman in Houston, said the creditors' motion ``totally ignores the historical, continuing and proposed support by Texas Air and Continental of Eastern's recovery.''

DOC.HEAD: Judge Puzzled by Varied Estimates of Worth of Keating Empire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: With PM-S&L Seizures, Bjt. Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge is trying to determine why government regulators and Phoenix millionaire Charles H. Keating Jr. put widely varied valuations on holdings in Keating's collapsed real estate and savings and loan empire. Keating, testifying Tuesday in his suit to reclaim his $5.5 billion Lincoln Savings and Loan Association seized by regulators a year ago, estimated that the thrift was worth $500 million to $700 million at the time. Regulators who seized the Irvine, Calif., thrift and its real estate holdings in Arizona, Texas and Louisiana, contend that taxpayers eventually will have to absorb up to $2 billion in losses of federally insured deposits that Keating used to finance his empire. ``The government says it's $2 billion in the red and the former operator says it's $600 million in the black,'' U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin said Tuesday. ``I'm in a quandary. Let's get the receiver in here.'' Representatives of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp., the receiver that took over Lincoln and downgraded its value, are to testify next week. In a civil suit accusing Keating and a dozen associates of fraud and racketeering, regulators allege that Lincoln inflated the value of its real estate holdings and loans far beyond a price they would command on the open market. However, Keating, in his fourth day on the witness stand, put the blame for the entire S&L crisis on thrift regulators undervaluing S&L holdings and loans. He said it ``caused a panic in the real estate market'' that brought about a self-fulfilling prophecy. ``There's no question that the economy of Phoenix has been wrecked in the cause of thrift regulation,'' Keating testified. ``Today's market is not a happy situation because the government now owns $20 billion of Arizona real estate that it's dumping on the market.'' As an example, he pointed to the luxurious Phoenician Resort that, using Lincoln funds, he built outside Phoenix at a cost of $275 million. Lincoln later sold a 45 percent interest in the Phoenician and another hotel in Phoenix to interests in Kuwait for $170 million. Keating estimated that Lincoln's 55 percent interest in hotel is now worth $190 million, almost double the $99 million asset value listed by government regulators on their books _ if the development potential of adjacent land is considered. ``It's a complete misunderstanding of value to write that hotel down,'' he said. ``You can't just take a piece of dirt in the desert and sell it as a piece of dirt. You have to look at what it was put there for, its highest and best use.'' James Murphy, representing the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision in the suit, said Keating's testimony on the valuation of the property was vague. ``We can't look at what an asset is worth in 10 years,'' he said. ``We have to look at what we could get for it today. If the assets aren't greater than the liabilities, an S&L's insolvent. That's the definition of insolvency.'' Keating is expected to spend at least another two days on the witness stand in the evidentiary hearing, which began in January and has now consumed more than 20 full days of courtroom time. Murphy said he plans to call four rebuttal witness next week, including the FDIC representatives that Sporkin wants to testify. The judge said Tuesday he wanted to hear closing arguments in the case in June.

DOC.HEAD: Cargo Door Search to Continue Following Report
DOC.NOTE: Eds: With PM-Airline Safety, Bjt. Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A deep-sea search will be conducted for the cargo door that blew off a United Airlines jet even though investigators determined why nine people were sucked out of the airliner over the Pacific Ocean, officials say. The National Transportation Safety Board voted 3-0 Tuesday to blame United, the Boeing Co. and the Federal Aviation Administration for failure to correct problems with the door of the jumbo jet before the Feb. 24, 1989, incident aboard Flight 811. An aviation lawyer, meanwhile, said the board's conclusions should spur the FAA into acting more quickly to correct dangerous deficiencies in airliners. NTSB investigators said inspection of the door that popped off at 22,000 feet, carrying a section of fuselage and nine people with it, still could provide evidence for improving aircraft safety. A sophisticated Navy probe unit will be lowered into the ocean in June, said board accident investigator Ron Schleed. If it can spot the door, another device will be dispatched to recover it, he said. ``If they don't find it within 12 to 15 days, that'll be the end of it,'' Schleed said. The board concluded that even without the door it had enough evidence to determine the probable cause of the incident: ``the sudden opening of the improperly latched forward lower lobe cargo door in flight and the subsequent explosive decompression.'' Flight 811 returned to Honolulu after the harrowing incident on a scheduled flight to New Zealand. Five other passengers were seriously hurt and 33 received minor injuries when the plane decompressed. The flight carried a crew of 18 and 337 passengers. The NTSB cited United for failing to maintain and inspect the door properly. It said Boeing and the FAA failed to take timely corrective action after a door on a Pan American Boeing 747 popped partially open over the Atlantic in 1987. Contributing to the cause of the Flight 811 accident was ``a deficiency in the design of the cargo door locking mechanisms, which made them susceptible to in-service damage, and which allowed the door to be unlatched, yet to show a properly latched and locked position,'' the board said. The latch indicator systems would be changed with an imminent FAA order that would require detectors on the locks, investigators said. The NTSB issued a list of recommendations to ensure that cargo doors are properly latched and that passengers can be safety evacuated from an aircraft. It also recommended that emergency vehicles at the Honolulu airport be painted in highly visible colors rather than military camouflage patterns that cannot be seen at night. NTSB conclusions and recommendations carry no judicial weight, and its determination of a probable cause may not be introduced as evidence in court cases. Lawyer Arthur Wolk of Philadelphia, who has brought several cases against airlines and manufacturers for safety deficiencies, praised the NTSB findings as the first time the board has ``come up with the right conclusion and the right cause of an accident.'' ``It shows they have the courage to assess blame properly,'' said Wolk. ``Hopefully, this will lead to greater FAA oversight of the industry which is seeing stepped-up production.'' He and other safety advocates have criticized the FAA for giving airlines too long to correct cargo door deficiencies and other problems. ``If you don't act in an immediate fashion when you deal with aviation, you're going to kill somebody,'' Wolk said. United spokesman Robert Dowdy said the airline properly maintained and inspected the door of the plane used for Flight 811, although he acknowledged that a required December 1988 inspection was omitted because of a clerical error. Boeing had recommended that the board conclude that probable cause of the incident could not be determined. In Seattle, Boeing spokesman Jack Gamble noted that changes have been made in the doors and in inspection processes since the accident. ``All of the necessary actions have been taken to ensure integrity of that door's operation in flight,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Job Security is Base For Other Issues, Bieber Says
DOC.TEXT: Job security isn't a key issue only for the United Auto Workers in this summer's contract talks, UAW President Owen Bieber says. It's also critical to the Big Three automakers' hopes of arresting their sliding fortunes, he says. ``Threatening workers with more insecurity and more cutbacks will merely continue the downward spiral our companies are on,'' Bieber said Tuesday during the opening session of a three-day bargaining conference of the union's Skilled Trades Department. The union meets in Kansas City next month to chart a course for bargaining in July with General Motors Corp., Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. The Big Three have blamed sluggish car sales for the temporary or permanent closing of assembly plants during the current contract. Thousands of auto workers have been laid off because of the companies' actions. The UAW wants that to end. ``They can and they must work with us for success, starting from the firm foundation of a secure work force,'' Bieber said. ``This search for a firm foundation will be at the heart of our collective bargaining program and many other demands will flow from it.'' Resolutions up for debate during the conference include job security, training, health and safety, plant closings, wages and education. ``America's industrial challenge is not a little bit management's fault and a little bit the union's fault,'' Bieber said. ``It's management's failures, plain and simple, that have put us in the precarious situation we face in so many sectors today.'' The 1-million member union has been shrinking as the automakers trim their operations. Plants have closed because of slow sales, some work performed by UAW members has been sent to Mexico or overseas and automakers have laid off employees as they seek to maintain profitability. The meeting that began Tuesday is one of several held by the UAW across the country prior to the union's bargaining convention May 21-24 in Kansas City. At that meeting, delegates from all 1,200 UAW locals gather to determine priorities in the national contract talks. The union's Skilled Trades Department has jurisdiction over workers such as tool and die makers, drafting employees and designers who have more technically oriented jobs than other factory workers. Skilled trades employees are paid more than others, such as assemblers. The UAW opens negotiations in July with each of the Big Three automakers. Later in the summer, the union will focus its efforts on one company. The agreement with that company will serve as a pattern for contracts with the other two. A potential contract issue that appears to be gaining steam within the union is cost-of-living protection for retirees, which doesn't exist in current auto contracts. The Big Three have an aging work force, one that is more conscious of retirement programs than the much younger employees at the largely non-union U.S. assembly plants operated by Japanese companies. None of the 20 resolutions up for debate during this week's skilled trades workers conference specifically mentions cost-of-living adjustments in retirees' benefits. Bieber did not specifically mention the issue in his speech. But at a news conference he said, ``The bottom line is that we have taken care of our past retirees and will continue to do it now.''

DOC.HEAD: California PC Maker Invades Japan With New Machine
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Safi Qureshey is cq.
DOC.TEXT: A small U.S. computer company is launching a daring plan to sell PCs in Japan, introducing a machine it claims offers more features than the home-grown models that dominate the Japanese market. AST Research Inc., a decade-old Irvine company, planned to unveil its new machine today in Tokyo. The Dual SX-16 runs programs designed for IBM Corp. PCs and also for machines made by NEC Corp., the Japanese computer giant that dominates its home market much more than IBM does here. NEC has an estimated 70 percent of the Japanese PC market. ``I think it's a bold move on the part of AST,'' said Sam Albert, a 30-year IBM executive who now heads his own computer consulting firm in Scarsdale, N.Y. PC makers such as AST have multiplied in recent years, and now are struggling to set themselves apart from the rest. ``I've got to believe there's at least 10'' makers such as AST, Albert said. ``It's clear that Compaq and IBM are on the dealers' shelves, and there's only so much shelf space,'' he said. ``The market is getting crowded in the United States and people are looking for other shelves.'' AST, which lost $7.5 million on sales of $457 million last year, believes it can find those shelves in Japan, the world's second-biggest market for PCs. The company turned profitable again in the last few quarters after selling off its non-PC businesses, and spokesman Joel Don said it is poised to move into Eastern Europe as well as Asia. A basic NEC computer, with no hard disk, no monitor and a 80386SX microprocessor from Intel Corp., costs about 390,000 yen, or the equivalent of $2,475, Don said. A similar NEC ``clone'' computer made by Japan's Seiko Epson Corp. costs 328,000 yen, or about $2,080, Don said. AST's computer will be priced somewhere in between, but officials said they believed it would still sell well because of its ability to run both the NEC and IBM programs. ``The Japanese cannot say that the product is missing features,'' AST President Safi Qureshey said in a telephone interview. ``It counters the arguments that American companies are lazy, just comfortable with the U.S. market.'' Don said the company probably will build the first machines at its Fountain Valley plant in Southern California, then shift production to Taiwan. AST teamed with Japan's Kawasaki Steel Corp. and Tomcat Computer Corp. to develop the computer, which will be sold under the brand names of Japanese distributors. AST is negotiating with several potential distributors, including Sharp Corp., Don said. AST's machine will have a hard time making inroads into NEC's dominion because the Japanese are so loyal to the company, said Tim Bajarin of the Santa Clara-based Creative Strategies International computer consulting firm. He noted that IBM and Apple already sell computers in Japan, and suggested they might be the ones who lose Japanese market share to AST. Qureshey and Albert said they believed it likelier that the Epson machines would be the losers. ``My view is that the knockoff will take share away from the other knockoff,'' Albert said. Qureshey said AST will be happy with just a small chunk of the big Japanese market. ``NEC is so dominant that a small percentage of their share means a lot to a small entrant,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Troubled Bank Announces Agreement to Sell Subsidiary
DOC.TEXT: The troubled Bank of New England Corp. said it will sell its New England Commercial Finance Corp. subsidiary to the National Bank of Canada, the latest move in a downsizing program triggered by the bank's bad real estate loans. The price of the transaction wasn't disclosed. ``The transaction involves about $665 million in assets which were sold at a premium. Both parties have agreed not to reveal that premium,'' said Thomas Lavelle, a bank spokesman. The deal is subject to regulatory approval but is expected to close before the end of April, Lavelle said. New England Commercial Finance is an asset-based lending operation with offices located outside of New England, the company said in a statement released Tuesday. The sale is part of Bank of New England's restructuring plan, under which the bank is retrenching to raise cash and focus on its New England operations. ``The operation that we have sold is not in New England _ its offices are outside the region,'' Lavelle said. ``As a New England regional institution we will be focusing our attention on New England.'' He said the sale was made to enhance the company's liquidity, improve equity capital and contribute to other downsizing efforts. Last month the Bank of New England announced that losses for 1989 had hit the $1.11 billion mark, mostly because of bad real estate loans. The company also reported $2.2 billion in non-performing assets at the end of 1989, and estimated that $1 billion in loans were performing but borrowers were experiencing financial difficulty. As a result of the financial difficulty, the bank signed an agreement with federal regulators last month that sets tight guidelines for lending practices and other operations. On April 4, the bank announced it would cut 5,600 employees and slash $300 million in costs in order to strengthen the institution. As a part of Tuesday's sale, the National Bank of Canada will retain most of the subsidiary's employees. Boston-based Bank of New England Corp. is an interstate bank holding company with assets estimated at $25 billion. The institution has banking offices in four New England states.

DOC.HEAD: Simmons Loses Try For Lockheed Directors, Wins On Shareholders' Rights
DOC.TEXT: Stockholders have rejected investor Harold Simmons' plan to win control of Lockheed Corp.'s board, but the Dallas billionaire says he was pleased with victories on shareholders' rights issues. ``It appears we achieved a clean sweep on the issues of confidential voting, opting out of the Delaware anti-takeover law, abolition of the poison pill and anti-greenmail,'' said Simmons, who controls about 19 percent of Lockheed stock. ``The shareholders have spoken clearly on these issues and we will expect Lockheed's board of directors to take prompt action to implement the shareholders' wishes,'' he said. Simmons, who owns 18.9 percent of Lockheed's common stock, had sought to replace company directors with his own nominees after his request for representation had been turned down. Citing preliminary tallies, Simmons said the four shareholders' rights proposals each received 57 percent to 97 percent of the votes cast at last month's annual shareholders meeting. Incumbent Lockheed directors were re-elected with between 58 percent and 61 percent of the votes each, he said. Lockheed, maker of the stealth fighter and other military hardware, said its directors won with 62 percent of the overall vote and 78 percent of the vote of shareholders not controlled by Simmons. The company also confirmed the outcome of the shareholders' rights provisions, but did not reveal specifics. The election was conducted at the company's March 29 annual meeting in Burbank, Calif. The results announced Tuesday are preliminary and final figures won't be available until Monday. Of the four proposals, only the one requiring the company to opt out of Delaware's strict takeover statute is binding. The three others are all advisory, although Lockheed Chairman Daniel Tellep said during the annual meeting that he would work to implement the confidentiality proposals if supported by a ``significant'' minority of voters. Despite the binding nature of the proposal, Tellep said Tuesday the board would have to review the ``poison pill'' provisions. He said he is concerned abandoning the pill would leave the company vulnerable to hostile takeovers. Lockheed's ``poison pill'' kicks in once an investor acquires 20 percent of the company's stock. It allows other shareholders to purchase additional stock at lower prices, diluting the large investor's holdings. Under the takeover law in Delaware, where Lockheed is incorporated, companies can chose to adopt other provisions that make hostile takeovers more difficult and expensive, including limits on sales and mergers involving the company. The anti-greenmail proposal would prohibit Lockheed from buying back its own stock at a premium from selected investors. Instead, all shareholders must be able to cash in on the higher prices. Simmons had undertaken the proxy fight after accumulating the Lockheed shares, and watching his $530 million investment drop $100 million in value. Tellep and the company fought Simmons, claiming he had no experience running a defense or aerospace company. Simmons insisted the company could be managed better and urged Lockheed to improve profits at non-core business or sell them. Simmons, who won some large institutional investors to his side, attributed the loss in the directors' races to Lockheed's employee stock ownership plan. The ESOP holds 19 percent of the company's stock, 90 percent of which was cast for company nominees, he said. The ESOP was created last year after Simmons began buying Lockheed stock through his Houston-based NL Industries Inc. ``We feel we did very well for our first try,'' Simmons said. ``Last year, for example, confidential voting received 35 percent of the votes and this year it received about 60 percent support. Last year, 27 percent of the votes were cast in favor of opting out of the Delaware anti-takeover statute. This year the proposal garnered over 60 percent.''

DOC.HEAD: Conoco Announces Environmental Program
DOC.TEXT: Casting its vote in the growing debate over oil tanker safety, Conoco Inc. said it will switch to double-hull tankers to help guard against spills like last year's catastrophe in Alaska's Prince William Sound. Conoco said it had placed an order for two double-hull oil tankers and would order only twin-hull vessels in the future. The step was part of a nine-point environmental program the company unveiled Tuesday that also included efforts to reduce toxic air emissions. ``We are in the business by the public's consent,'' said Constantine S. Nicandros, Conoco president and chief executive officer. ``We are sincere in our concern for the air, water and land of our planet as a matter of enlightened self-interest.'' Oil companies have faced increasing pressure to switch to double-hull tankers since the Exxon Valdez ran aground, gushing nearly 11 million gallons of crude into Alaskan waters in the nation's worst spill ever. Many politicians and environmentalists claim a second hull might have averted the spill. Many oil industry officials have argued against twin-hull vessels, claiming that they could be less stable than conventional tankers if their outer hull is pierced. Several panels are studying the issue, including the American Academy of Sciences, which set to release a report this summer. But Nicandros said, ``We cannot wait for a verdict'' from the study. ``We realize that doubled-hulled tankers are not the total solution, but they do offer an increase margin of protection against oil spills,'' he was quoted as saying in The New York Times. The newspaper quoted Conoco officials as saying they believe it was the first American oil company to place an order for a twin-hull tanker. As part of its plan, the company also said it would: _ Support the creation of citizen advisory councils at all major installations worldwide to monitor environmental performance. _ Reward top managers for emphasizing and implementing plans that benefit the environment and penalize lack of performance in the area. _ Provide double containment systems at all newly constructed and renovated gasoline outlets. _ Intensify research and development of fuels that improve the environment. _ Create yearlong environmental fellowships to let several outsiders work within the company on environmental matters. _ Emphasize environmental sensitivities in developing oil and gas discoveries. _ Work toward recycling all waste generated at Conoco's 2,500-employee headquarters complex in Houston. Conoco is a subsidiary of E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Co.

DOC.HEAD: McCabe Back in Ad Business After Self-Imposed Exile
DOC.TEXT: In the mid-70s, he was the youngest person ever selected for the New York advertising copywriters' Hall of Fame. A dozen years later, he decided he had had enough, quit his agency and left the business. He asked for bids on his collection of cars and art, sold the midtown Manhattan apartment and dismissed the butler. He went off to drive in a transcontinental automobile race. He wrote a book about his adventures. And now Ed McCabe is back. The former president and creative director of the Scali McCabe Sloves advertising agency that created award-winning campaigns ranging from durable cars to tender chickens said Tuesday he has joined the regional ad agency Beber Silverstein & Partners of Miami. McCabe, 51, will become a creative partner and the agency is changing its name to Beber Silverstein McCabe & Partners. ``I'd been in advertising for 32 years and that is a long time to do any one thing without a break,'' McCabe said in an interview of his decision to quit the ad business in late 1986. He had no intention of getting back into it, but said, ``In three years of looking around, I haven't found anthing else I would want to do.'' McCabe is probably best known for creating the commercials for Perdue chicken that used the line, ``It takes a tough man to make a tender chicken.'' The ads helped build the brand and made a celebrity of founder Frank Perdue. He also worked award-winning ads for Volvo automobiles, stressing their durability and safety. Others included Hebrew National meats and Maxell tapes. He was a co-founder of Scali McCabe Sloves in 1967, and was elected in 1974 at the age of 35 to the New York Copy Club's Copywriters Hall of Fame. Fellow adman George Lois calls him ``one of the really terrific copywriters of the past 25 to 30 years.'' McCabe became a millionaire when Scali McCabe Sloves was acquired by the company that owned the Ogilvy & Mather ad agency in 1978. He stayed on under new ownership. But he decided to leave both the agency and the ad business in late 1986. ``I left because I had done enough with the company. I like to build things ... But when a thing gets big, it gets less new,'' he said. A few months later, he competed in the grueling Paris-to-Dakar race that runs 8,000 miles through the Sahara Desert. He dropped out of the competition on the eighth day of the 21-day race after falling asleep at the wheel and running out of gas. He said he and a partner completed the trek anyway. The race inspired him to write a book, ``Against Gravity,'' which is expected to be published by Warner Books in June. He wrote magazine articles, did consulting work for a British ad agency in London and looked into starting a film production company, discarding that idea because of the heavy costs. He was frustrated by unsuccessful efforts to assist the losing presidential campaign of Democrat Michael Dukakis. He went back to London to finish the book in late 1988, and returned to the United States last summer to consider his options. He decided against starting his own agency because ``I did that once,'' and against returning to his old agency, now a part of British-based WPP Group PLC. Joyce Beber, one of the founders of Beber Silverstein 18 years ago, said she had known McCabe for years and approached him earlier this year about the possibilities of building a regional agency into a national agency. ``I guess I piqued his interest,'' she said. Beber Silverstein handles $70 million in annual billings for a number of clients, including Humana Health Services, Florida Power & Light, First Florida Banks and FloridaGold Orange Juice. The agency also claims credit for casting Leona Helmsley as ``The Queen'' in ads for her Helmsley Hotels. The agency was fired in 1987. Mrs. Helmsley no longer appears in the ads. She was convicted on tax evasion charges last year. McCabe will split his time between the Miami and New York offices, and will be chairman of the New York office. ``He is an extraordinary talent, and I'm rooting for him,'' said Marvin Sloves, who founded Scali McCabe with McCabe and remains with that agency. McCabe said he hopes to ``help create on the great indepedent regional agencies in the country'' while having some fun and making some money. He said the most creative ad work is no longer coming from New York City but from places like Portland, Ore.; Richmond, Va. and San Fancisco. ``I don't see why Miami shouldn't be right at the top of that list,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Norton, Baker Hughes and Justice Department Reach Acquisition Arrangement
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. Justice Department said it has entered into a consent decree with Norton Co. and Baker Hughes Inc., removing the final obstacles to Norton's planned $550 million sale of Eastman Christenson Co. to Baker Hughes. The companies said Tuesday they expected to close the sale within the next few days. To allow the sale to move forward, Justice Department officials required Baker Hughes, a Houston, Texas-based energy products and services company, to sell the diamond drill bit business of the Hughes Tool Co. Last year the division sold $17 million in drills, said Ron Turner, corporate vice president at Baker Hughes. Turner said several parties had expressed an interest in buying the product line, but nothing was settled. He declined to name the potential buyers. Eastman Christenson also makes diamond drill bits, but on a bigger scale, Turner said. Last year the drills earned the company $40 million in sales, he said. ``The part of the (Eastman) business that is not in contention is a very important part of it,'' Turner said. The consent decree stipulates that if the drill business is not sold by Aug. 6, the business must be placed under the oversight of a trustee, to manage and sell the company for Baker Hughes. ``That's just a legal provision in case the management of the company decides to stonewall it, a provision that `If you don't do it we will,' '' Turner said. Norton, a leading maker of abrasives such as grinding tools and sandpaper, is a target of a $1.6 billion, $75 a share hostile takeover bid from the British conglomerate BTR PLC. The Norton board of directors has rejected the offer, but BTR PLC has threatened to take control of the board at the company's upcoming annual meeting. Frank Doherty, a Norton spokesman, denied the Eastman Christenson sale had anything to do with defensive maneuvering. ``It's not related to BTR. We announced it Dec. 15th and this is just the final step,'' Doherty said. ``It just happens to be completed now.''

DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Weaker in London at Midday
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices fell on the London Stock Exchange Wednesday with investors reluctant to buy ahead of the four-day Easter weekend. Company reports indicating a weaker situation in the oil and real estate sectors also affected the market, traders said. At about noon in London, the Financial Times Stock Exchange 100-share index was down 4.9 points, or 0.22 percent, at 2,212.6. Volume at midday was a moderate 190.9 million shares, down from 233.5 million shares traded at the same time Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Bechtel to Manage $16 Billion Construction Project in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Bechtel Group Inc. has won a contract from the Hong Kong government to manage a $16 billion construction project scheduled for completion in 1997, when the Chinese government will take over Hong Kong from England. The company announced the contract Tuesday but did not disclose how much it would be paid to oversee and coordinate the project which is to include a new airport, the world's longest suspension bridge, a harbor tunnel, and a rail transit system. Michael K. Stephenson, a Bechtel senior vice president, said the company purposely focused on taking an oversight role rather than that of a contractor in making its bid. ``Our track record and world experience in moving major megaprojects together on time and within budget (was) one of the factors'' in winning the contract, Stephenson said. Stephen D. Bechtel Jr., company chairman, said in a memo to employees: ``The development is comparable to Saudi Arabia's Jubail Industrial City in complexity and diversity.'' Bechtel's plans to manage the Hong Kong project rank second only to the company's involvement in the creation of the Saudi Arabian city _ the largest construction project in history. Bechtel became involved in the Saudi Arabian city, still being built, in the late 1970s.

DOC.HEAD: New Thrift Bailout Bonds Poorly Received at Auction, Traders Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Recasts lead and CORRECTS first name of Brusca in graf 5.
DOC.TEXT: The government sold $3.5 billion of 40-year bonds to finance the bailout of the savings and loan industry but traders said the auction was disappointing. The bonds were sold Tuesday at an average yield of 8.89 percent, up from 8.60 percent at the last auction Jan. 23. The bonds will carry a coupon interest rate of 8~ percent with a $10,000 bond selling for $9,983.40. The Resolution Funding Corp., or Refcorp, received bids totaling $8.90 billion, compared with $8.17 billion in bids in January for what was a larger issue of $5 billion. Nevertheless, traders said the bonds were poorly received. The government could not sell all of the bonds at the low bid of 8.86 percent and had to sell some for as much as 8.94 percent. ``It was a poor reception,'' said economist Robert Brusca of Nikko Securities Co. International Inc. He said bond buyers were worried about the extra interest rate risk of the longer maturity. They were fearful that the S&L problem is worse than anticipated and the government will have to flood the market with borrowing, he said. Treasury Department officials had been hoping institutional investors such as pension funds would show more demand for the longer maturity, thus allowing the government to offer a lower interest rate. Legislation in August authorized the government to borrow $30 billion through Refcorp, an arrangement that keeps the spending out of the budget deficit. Refcorp has now borrowed $13 billion. The first bond auction, for $4.5 billion in 30-year bonds, was in October.

DOC.HEAD: Consolidation of Swiss Banking Seen After Major Takeover Move
DOC.TEXT: Plans by the parent company of Credit Suisse to take a majority stake in 235-year-old Bank Leu AG signals the onset of a consolidation of Switzerland's banking industry, analysts and bankers said. CS Holding, parent of the country's No. 3 commercial bank Credit Suisse, and Bank Leu, the fifth-biggest bank and the oldest major Swiss bank, announced Tuesday they are holding talks aimed at setting up a new holding company. The holding company, which would be listed on stock exchanges, would include Bank Leu and two small CS Holding investment management companies, Bank Hofmann and Clariden Bank, with all units retaining their identities. Nikolaus Senn, president of Union Bank of Switzerland, predicted further mergers in the Swiss banking industry will follow. The pace of concentration ``will even intensify,'' the head of Switzerland's biggest commercial bank said. The high cost of competing internationally will lead to deep changes in Swiss and European banking, Zurich financial analyst Thomas Braun said. ``Big banks will swallow the smaller ones, and the small ones will band together,'' he said. Bank Leu, with assets of 15 billion francs, the equivalent of about $10 billion, has faced takeover rumblings in the past. It has recently undergone a management shakeup and corporate restructuring, and analysts say it has improved potential to develop its private client base. The joint announcement said CS Holding group has built up a ``substantial shareholding in Bank Leu over the past two years.'' It did not reveal the size of the stake. Shares of the new holding company would be swapped for equities of Bank Leu, at a ratio to be set later, and CS Holding would end up with a majority interest in the new concern. Assuming that CS Holding controls at least half of the voting shares of Leu, analysts estimated the value of the stake at up to 1 billion Swiss francs, or about $675 million dollars.

DOC.HEAD: USX Threatens Closing South Works Without Concessions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in graf 5.
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. says it is considering shuttering the remnants of its rusting South Works steel mill, a move that would idle 700 workers, unless union officials agree to major concessions by the end of the year. The struggling Chicago facility can't compete with new non-union plants unless fixed costs are substantially reduced, said USX Chairman Charles Corry. The company wants workers to give up benefits and jobs under a new labor contract to take effect Jan. 1. But union leaders angrily rejected Corry's plea for concessions. ``My position is they can go to hell,'' said Willie Ross, president of United Steelworkers of America Local 65, on Tuesday. ``They can close the damn thing. It comes to the point where we're giving and giving and giving and we've got nothing left to give.'' South Works once employed 18,000 workers and has made steel since 1881 under USX's U.S. Steel Co. unit and predecessor companies. Once an integral part of Chicago's heavy industry, the plant fell victim to recession and a slump in the domestic steel industry. All that remains amid vacant buildings on the 574-acre facility are two electric furnaces and a mill that makes about 14.6 tons of raw steel each week. Technology there is more than a generation old. The company has proposed eliminating a shift of workers and allowing other shops to finish business, a move that would trim union employment to 300 workers, Ross said. Corry says the company needs the concessions to compete with new, smaller mills that make finished steel from scrap, at lower costs. The so-called ``mini mills,'' like the non-union Nucor Corp. of Charlotte, N.C. and Northwestern Steel & Wire of Sterling, Ill., are expanding, and analysts say they'll likely crowd the marketplace. ``That's going to play havoc for the market,'' said Christopher Plummer, an analyst with WEFA Group in Bala Cynwyd, Pa. ``Clearly, the writing is on the wall for mini-mills to be taking a significant portion of the market in the future, and somebody's going to have to drop out eventually,'' Plummer said. ``We want to be in it if we can earn return on our investment,'' Corry said. ``If you were to tell me we were going to lose money in structural the next three years, I'd say it's not a business we want to be in.''

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Mostly Higher on USDA Report
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures were mostly higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, partly in reaction to a government report indicating the nation's grain stockpiles are shrinking. Gains in the soybean market were limited by pronounced weaknes in the soybean meal pit, where traders sold futures contracts amid expectations for an increase in Brazilian meal exports. In a report released after the close of Tuesday's trading, the Agriculture Department substantially lowered its forecasts for ending stocks of U.S. corn and soybeans and slightly reduced its wheat stocks projection. The USDA estimated Sept. 1 corn stocks at 1.33 billion bushels, down from last month's estimate of 1.48 billion. Sept. 1 soybean stocks were pegged at 305 million bushels compared with the March projection of 330 million. The USDA projected June 1 wheat stocks at 442 million bushels compared with last month's estimate of 443 million. Brazilian exports of soybean meal are expected to increase due to a 15 percent devaluation of that country's currency, making Brazilian meal cheaper on the world market, said Victor Lespinasse, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. in Chicago. In early trading, wheat futures prices were \ cent lower to 4\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.66\ a bushel; corn was \ cent to 1\ cents higher with May at $2.73 a bushel; oats were \ cent lower to { cent higher with May at $1.51\ a bushel; soybeans were 1} cents to 3{ cents higher with May at $5.93\ a bushel. Cattle futures were mixed while pork futures were higher in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The April live cattle contract set a new record high of 80.35 cents a bushel shortly after the opening. Live cattle were unchanged to .10 cent higher with April at 80.32 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .18 cent lower with April at 84.05 cents a pound; live hogs were .10 cent to .58 cent higher with April at 55.70 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .83 cent to 1.58 cent higher with May at 57.15 cents a pound. Livestock and meat futures settled higher across the board on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Farley Reportedly to Surrender Majority Ownership of Pepperell
DOC.TEXT: Industrialist William Farley plans to surrender majority ownership of West Point-Pepperell Inc. by proposing a debt-equity swap to reduce the costs of his troubled takeover efforts, a newspaper reported today. Farley, who holds 95 percent of the textile giant's stock, is offering certain debt holders a combined stake of 65 percent in a restructured version of Pepperell, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing sources it did not identify. The transfer would help reduce and delay certain interest payments and might be the only way Farley can avoid bankruptcy, the Journal's sources said. Farley couldn't be reached for immediate comment. The spokesmen at the Farley Inc. headquarters in Chicago were traveling today, a secretary said, and they did not return telephone messages. The arrangement would create a new parent company, West Point Holdings Corp., which would hold the stock in the operating unit, the newspaper said. Although the new entity would apparently be a unit of Farley Inc., the debt-equity swap would leave Farley a minority shareholder, according to the Journal. The newspaper said it was not clear whether the preferred shares held by Farley would allow him to retain control of Pepperell, but it said it's believed he would keep majority control of the boards of directors at West Point Holdings and the Pepperell operating unit. Farley acquired control of Pepperell in March 1989 and holds 95 percent of the company's stock, but he has had trouble raising about $83 million needed to acquire the remaining 5 percent. The newspaper said his bankers are likely to lend him the cash needed to complete the deal if certain debt holders agree to the debt-for-equity plan. Meantime, analysts said the $96.5 million sale of Pepperell's Sanderson subsidiary won't be of much help to Farley. Georgia-based Pepperell on Tuesday announced the sale of its U.K. Division, Arthur Sanderson and Sons Ltd., to the Dutch textile group Gamma Holding N.V. ``It looks like a very good price,'' said Richard J. Byrne of Merrill Lynch & Co. in New York. ``It helps, but it's a small step. They need to complete the merger.'' ``He is still highly leveraged,'' said Rich Mercier of Standard & Poor. The $96.5 million ``is not a meaningful number when you're talking over $2 billion in debt.'' The collapse of the junk bond market has dealt a severe blow to Farley's expansion plans. Last week, the Farley subsidiary formed to acquire Pepperell announced it had defaulted on $1.5 billion worth of loan and bond payments. Farley has been trying to restructure a $796 million loan obtained from a consortium of banks for the Pepperell buyout. Farley's other properties include Fruit of the Loom Inc. and Acme Boots. Pepperell manufactures apparel and bedding sold under such brands as Ralph Lauren, Martex, Lady Pepperell, Esprit and Utica.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mostly Lower; Gold Off
DOC.NOTE: Eds: A version for AMs is planned by 5:30 p.m. EDT.
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended European dealings Wednesday broadly weaker, in part because of renewed interest in the West German mark. Gold prices declined. The dollar was quoted at 1.6735 West German marks late in London, down sharply from 1.6900 marks late Tuesday. Earlier, in Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.35 Japanese yen to a closing 158.50 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at 158.15 yen. A flurry of dollar selling against the yen by some European central banks breathed some life into an otherwise dull European session. The intervention, which came in early afternoon, had little impact on the dollar's level against the yen. While dealers saw the intervention as orders executed on behalf of the Bank of Japan rather than any concerted effort by the Group of Seven (G-7) nations to stem yen weakness, they also noted that Japanese commercial buying was among the more active features in the European day. ``If we hadn't had the intervention I think the market would have died earlier,'' said Michael James, head of inter-bank dealing for Midland Bank. ``We could be in for some quiet range trading over the next few weeks.'' The British pound, meanwhile, was quoted at $1.6427 late in London compared with $1.6345 late Tuesday. Other dollar rates in Europe compared with late Tuesd; 1-2 300-500 lb 48.00-49.00; 1-3 500-700 lb 52.00.

DOC.HEAD: MacWorld Exposition Opens to Uncertainty About Market
DOC.TEXT: The opening of the fifth annual MacWorld Exposition was greeted eagerly within computer circles, but product developers at the convention hall expressed uncertainty about the market for Macintosh computers. Industry insiders in attendance Tuesday complained there was little groundbreaking technology at the show, which usually features hot new products and applications for the Apple Computer Inc. machine. ``I don't know of anything really exciting that's going on, so I don't know if the market is going to be able to grow this year,'' said Mike Slade, Macintosh products manager for Microsoft Corp. of Redmond, Wash., the leading supplier of Macintosh software. According to Macintosh product developers, growth in the Macintosh market will remain crippled until Apple comes to market with a low-cost Mac. ``The technical strength is at the high end, and there are people who will always buy that,'' said Michael McConnell, president of SuperMac Technology Inc., a Sunnyvale supplier of Macintosh monitors and software. ``But the high end is now where the volumes are, and in the long run the Macintosh won't become a mainstream computer without a low-end product,'' said McConnell. According to InfoCorp, a Santa Clara market research company, Macintosh shipments are expected to increase only 8 percent this year to 749,000 units. Last year, sales grew 34 percent to 693,000 units. At the convention, some products did manage to draw attention. Aaps Corp., headed by Atari Corp. and PizzaTime Theater founder Nolan Bushnell, displayed its DigiVideo computer board, which allows a Macintosh to act as a video cassette recorder. The 98-channel tuner _ which costs $595 _ and video recorder may be important to desktop publishers who use video images. SuperMac Technology Inc. unveiled the first 21-inch color monitor for a Mac. The color monitor, priced at $4,799, could become a popular item for sophisticated publishing systems that require users to view two color pages simultaneously.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Futures Prices Drop
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices continued to slide in early trading today but managed to recoup some of their losses. The contract for May delivery of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, was down 25 cents to $17.43 a barrel in early afternoon on the New York Mercantile Exchange after having fallen $1.47 over Monday and Tuesday. The May contract fell as much as $1.43 in early trading today before regaining some ground. Refined products traded on the Merc also fell today. The May contract for unleaded regular gasoline was down 1.13 cents to 57.30 a gallon after a drop of 3.68 cents over Monday and Tuesday. Gasoline followed the lead of crude, recovering some of its losses after falling 2.83 cents earlier. Home heating oil for May delivery was down 0.05 cent to 52.35 cents a gallon after slipping 1.31 cents over Monday and Tuesday. Heating oil fared the best among petroleum futures today, retracing most of its steps after having fallen 2.40 cents in early trading. Energy futures prices have fallen in recent weeks to their lowest levels in more than a year. Analysts blame the decline on plentiful supplies and production while demand has been weaker than expected. The analysts cited reports that indicate the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries has been producing an average 24 million barrels of oil a day. That is above the ceiling of 22.1 million barrels a day that OPEC members agreed on for production in the first half of this year. Some OPEC members, led by the United Arab Emirates and Kuwait, have been ignoring their production quotas and calling for their abolition. Another factor cited by analysts is the end of normal maintenance periods for many U.S. oil refineries, which are expected to increase their output. At the same time, the analysts said demand for oil has been weak with big customers either placing smaller orders because of weak business conditions or postponing purchases in anticipation of further price declines. Meanwhile, natural gas for June delivery was quoted at $1.605 per million British thermal units today on the Merc, down from $1.620 on Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Close Mixed
DOC.NOTE: EDS: RECASTS throughout to UPDATE with later activity, closing indices; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Shares closed mixed Wednesday after a session described by dealers as ``desperately quiet'' before the long Easter holiday weekend. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index closed 2.0 points lower, or down 0.09 percent, at 2,215.5. The narrower Financial Times 30-share index ended 0.8 points higher, or up 0.046 percent, at 1,733.3. The Financial Times 500-share index closed at 1,195.32, down 1.55. Volume was a thin 311.7 million shares, down from 367.6 million on Tuesday. ``Nobody seems to want to do anything this side of Easter,'' one dealer said. Good Friday and the Monday following Easter are legal holidays in Britain.

DOC.HEAD: June Ruling Expected in Computer Chip Dispute
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge said he will decide in June whether a key Motorola Inc. computer chip should be pulled off the market until a lawsuit over the chip's patent is resolved. U.S. District Judge Lucius Bunton of Midland said Tuesday he will rule June 18 on a motion filed by Hitachi Ltd., the Japanese electronics giant and former Motorola partner, to temporarily halt the sale of the popular Motorola microprocessor, which is made in Austin. Motorola and Hitachi have been embroiled in a 16-month legal battle over trade secrets that centers on some of their most popular computer microprocessors. Motorola's device, the 68030 microprocessor, is the company's best-selling chip, generating 1989 sales of more than $100 million. On March 29, Bunton banned the sale of the chip and fined both companies for violating each other's patents. The sales prohibition, though, was reversed one day later after Motorola argued that the move could devastate outside computer makers, which depend on the Motorola chips to run their machines. Hours after Bunton announced plans to rule on the case in June, executives from both companies agreed to meet in Chicago late Tuesday to discuss a possible settlement, the Austin American-Statesman reported. Motorola spokesman Chuck Sengstock said Wednesday he had no comment on the report.

DOC.HEAD: To Corporate Biggies, The Lady is a Pest
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: It happens every spring: the first robin appears, baseball players return to the diamond and Evelyn Y. Davis heckles corporate honchos at annual shareholders' meetings across the country. She has exasperated Chrysler Corp.'s Lee Iacocca with unsought diet advice. Her diatribes helped convince Citicorp to limit shareholder questions to three minutes each. She once gave May Department Stores Co. Chairman David C. Farrell a $1,600 check and the warning: ``David, please make sure your man is on time when he comes to hang my drapes. I'm a busy woman.'' Several years ago she nominated soft-porn actress Koo Stark _ then romantically linked with Britain's Prince Andrew _ to ITT Corp.'s board of directors to give the communications conglomerate ``some much needed influence with the British royal family.'' Since 1959 when she first stood _ ``shaking like a leaf'' _ to ask a question at an IBM Corp. shareholders meeting, the 60-year-old diminutive redhead with the abrasive high-pitched voice has been questioning, needling, cajoling, cursing and irritating corporate America's top guns in front of hundreds of other stockholders at about 60 meetings a year. Moreover, the executives listen _ they don't like it _ but they listen because Evelyn Y. Davis has clout. How much clout? Well, for example, she got General Motors Corp., the nation's largest industrial company, to agree last month to adopt an anti-greenmail policy she'd been pushing since 1986 when the automaker paid $700 million to Texas businessman H. Ross Perot so he would leave GM's board of directors. Greenmail, a play on the term blackmail, is a company's re-purchase of its own stock from a corporate takeover strategist or other unwanted stockholder at a price above the fair market rate. Shareholder activists such as Davis complain that these payments are unfair and unnecessary expenditures made by executives more concerned with keeping their own jobs than increasing shareholders' dividends. ``Sometimes it takes that type of person or that type of approach to get management's attention,'' said Ralph Whitworth, director of United Shareholders Association, a Washington-based shareholders rights group. ``I think some of the things she has done have been constructive,'' said Whitworth, whose own group has advocated proposals it says are intended to keep management honest and responsible. ``It's unfortunate that management has been able to put in place the belief that anyone who gets up and asks a question at a meeting is a gadfly,'' he said. Davis doesn't mind. ``A gadfly with a fortune,'' she reminded in an emphatic voice, still heavy with the accent of her native Amsterdam. ``You know this stuff has made me quite wealthy,'' she said. ``But what I like too is this power that this gives me. The power. That's really what life is all about,'' she said. ``It's all how you use it. It's better than being a non-entity. I couldn't stand being a nonentity.'' Davis, however, is not just another eccentric, comfortably-fixed senior citizen with a few shares of stock and time on her hands. She's a millionaire, a couple of times over, with small holdings in about 120 blue chip companies ranging from the Big Three automakers to IBM, CBS Inc. and USX Corp. The seed money came from some securities left by her late father and settlements from two divorces. ``My stocks are my children,'' said Davis, who is childless. ``I sort of just fell into it.'' Her early personal history remains somewhat of a mystery, and Davis is reluctant to talk about it. She emigrated to the United States after World War II. She studied business administration at George Washington University and said she honed her public speaking skills with a $20 YMCA course. From a tiny, windowless office in Washington's Watergate complex she publishes an annual newsletter called ``Highlights and Lowlights,'' sold only to top corporate executives, which she says earns about $250,000 a year. ``I started from nothing. The first few copies were maybe 20 bucks a copy. Now I get $260 a copy with a minimum order of two copies. Its only sold to chairmen of the board and presidents,'' she said. ``I don't deal with flunkies.'' The 20-page newsletter is packed with corporate commentary, social notes and eccentric punctuation that rivals Superman comics for the number of exclamation points _ all vintage Evelyn Y. Davis, who said the Y does not stand for anything. A sampling from the 1989 edition: _ At one of the most important meetings of the year only ONE ``outside'' director, the son of the founder, attended!!! Time Inc.!!!! This showed disrespect for the chairman, the stockholders and other attendees!! _ What happened in China was very unfortunate indeed, BUT business MUST go on as usual. As long as we have diplomatic relations with a country, we should continue to do business even with unpopular regimes!!! _ In Mexico City and Acapulco one STILL has to worry about the food and water. We were there once before in 1966!! With all the taxpayers' money that is going to Mexico, why not insist that it is spent on water PURIFICATION!! Despite her vociferous push for shareholder rights, Davis remains largely a loner, with no clearly defined political leanings. But she bluntly has distanced herself from shareholder groups pushing social resolutions such as South African divestment and sensitivity to the environment. ``After all, a company is there to make money, not to be socially responsible,'' she said. ``That's for the government to do.'' Davis' office is cluttered with letters, annual reports and some of the five newspapers she reads each day to keep tabs on her stocks as well as nearly 1,000 other companies. Her yellow and blue plaid jacket is by Valentino while the gold turtleneck dress beneath it is by Nipon _ purchased at half price. ``Fashion is a hobby _ but only on sale,'' she said. Davis seems equally willing to cause a scene with a waiter or a CEO, as she demonstrated during a recent interview. ``With a woman they say she's difficult and demanding. With a man they wouldn't think so,'' Davis said after kicking up a fuss with a hapless waiter in the elegant Brighton Grill of the Watergate where she lives in a cluttered three-room apartment. Through her newsletter, she has obtained press credentials that have given her access to newsmakers well beyond the corporate world. For example, she has a White House press identification and has popped a few questions to Presidents Reagan and Bush. But one of her proudest moments was what she termed ``a six minute chat'' with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev a few years ago in Moscow, where she had been invited as part of a U.S.-Soviet trade delegation. During a banquet, Davis recalled, she walked over to Gorbachev's table and complained she hadn't been invited to a news conference. ``He said he'd look into it,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Close Mixed After Stocks Report
DOC.TEXT: Futures prices of grain and soybeans see-sawed to a mixed close Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade. Corn futures turned in a surprisingly weak performance in light of a shrinking national corn stockpile. Traders had expected corn futures to rally after Tuesday's monthly Agriculture Department supply-and-demand report, which projected Sept. 1 corn stocks of 1.33 million bushels, down from March's estimate of 1.48 billion. The USDA also lowered its estimates of wheat and soybean stocks, but those numbers came close to market expectations. Corn futures opened lower and quickly turned higher but sold off again in the afternoon after traders tried and failed to bid prices above their previous contract highs, said Victor Lespinasse, a trader with Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. The contract for December delivery traded up to its lifetime high of $2.63{ a bushel but the rally failed at that point, prompting speculative profit-taking, Lespinasse said. At the close of trading, wheat futures were unchanged to 2{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.64{ a bushel; corn was 1{ cents lower to \ cent higher with May at $2.71{ a bushel; oats were unchanged to \ cent lower with May at $1.50} a bushel; soybeans were 1\ cents to 3{ cents higher with May at $5.92{ a bushel.

The stock market declined slightly today in a drifting session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 3.38 to 2,727.70 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street. Losers outnumbered gainers by about 5 to 4 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 648 up, 799 down and 499 unchanged. In the credit markets today, prices of long-term Treasury bonds rose slightly, lowering their yields to the 8.56 percent-8.62 percent range. That reversed an increase in rates Tuesday that occurred as a sale of 40-year savings institution ``bailout'' bonds drew an unenthusiastic reception. DOC.HEAD: Security Pacific Reports Higher Quarterly Profit
DOC.TEXT: Security Pacific Corp. reported Wednesday that its first quarter profit rose 5 percent, due mainly to strong results at its core Security Pacific Bank, California's second largest bank. For the three months ended March 31, the bank holding company earned $188.4 million, compared with $179.3 million a year ago. Per-share earnings were unchanged at $1.54 because there is more common stock outstanding this year, the company said. Taxable net interest income for the first quarter rose 2 percent from the year-earlier period, to $746.6 million. Quarterly non-interest income rose 11 percent to $479.6 million. ``The continuing growth and strength in our primary markets in California produced the second best quarterly net income in Security Pacific history,'' Robert H. Smith, Security Pacific's chief executive said in a statement. ``We expect continued growth for the corporation throughout the year.'' Security Pacific has shown strong results recently despite losses at its Arizona unit due to the collapse of that state's real estate market. ``A significant improvement is expected in 1990 from the $142 million loss reported in Arizona in 1989,'' said John F. Kooken, the holding company's chief financial officer. Total assets rose 6 percent over the first quarter of 1989, to $86.5 million from $81.6 million. Non-performing loans and leases totaled $1.74 billion on March 31, up from $1.64 billion on Dec. 31 and $1.59 billion on March 31, 1989.

The stock market barely budged in a quiet session today as Wall Street drew closer to a long holiday weekend. In the credit markets, prices of long-term Treasury bonds rose slightly, lowering their yields to the 8.56 percent-8.62 percent range. That reversed an increase in rates Tuesday that occurred as a sale of 40-year savings institution ``bailout'' bonds drew an unenthusiastic reception. But analysts said traders were proceeding cautiously as they watched the first corporate earnings reports for the January-March quarter come in. The numbers are expected to be downbeat, for the most part, reflecting persistent weakness in economic growth.
