DOC.HEAD: When Tough Times Means $1.55 Million a Year On Wall Street
DOC.TEXT: Where else but on Wall Street does a drastic pay cut still leave earnings of $1.55 million a year? That was the salary and bonus for Merrill Lynch & Co. Chairman William A. Schreyer, down 38 percent from $2.5 million in 1988. It was no surprise, because the nation's No. 1 brokerage lost money for the first time since going public in 1971. In a bad year for the securities industry, cash compensation for highly paid top executives reflected the fortunes of individual firms, proxy statements issued by publicly owned brokerages show. Some firms did better than others in coping with a downturn in stock trading, mergers and takeovers and other barometers of Wall Street's financial health. Payouts ballooned accordingly. At Morgan Stanley & Co., which made a $443 million profit, the top three executives took home $5.475 million apiece, a 26 percent raise over 1988, not including free stock they may have cashed in. Morgan's top five made more than $3 million each. Its eight executive officers combined to make $28.7 million. Top executives at Wall Street firms usually are paid according to the firm's performance, receiving a minimum salary and a bonus. Payouts are set by compensation committees that include directors and executives. But stock awards and options given to top executives generally inflate earnings. So in spite of lower cash payouts, the upper echelons generally do better than the rest of their firms, Wall Street analysts said. ``Those CEOs that have earned less money have probably suffered in a lesser proportion than the rest of the firm,'' Joan Zimmerman, executive vice president at GZ Stephens Inc., a Wall Street executive recruiting firm, said Wednesday. Overall, bonuses below the executive level on Wall Street last year were flat to down 20 percent, recruiters said, and were as much as 50 percent lower in some areas. A 10 percent bonus hike _ considered peanuts in the booming mid-1980s _ last year was a sign of high regard. Despite Merrill's bad year _ the firm lost $213 million in 1989 _ four executives still made more than $1 million, compared with seven executives the year before. ``When things don't go well they still make a lot of money, but they make a little less than when they do go well,'' said Gary Goldstein, president of The Whitney Group, another search firm. Members of the Morgan troika _ chairman S. Parker Gilbert, president Richard B. Fisher and vice chairman Robert F. Greenhill _ each were outearned by Ernst Weil, an executive vice president at Salomon Inc., who received $6.4 million. Weil's compensation represented a 60 percent pay raise and didn't include a $1.6 million deferred bonus to be paid over two years, according to Salomon's proxy statement. What made Weil Salomon's top executive, let alone the highest paid of Wall Street's boardroom bigwigs? He runs Salomon's Phibro Energy oil trading and refining subsidiary, which was responsible most of Salomon's profits in an otherwise mediocre year. Salomon Chairman John H. Gutfreund took a $500,000 pay cut to $3.5 million. ``The philosophy on Wall Street has been you pay people to make you money,'' said Perrin Long, who follows the securities industry for Lipper Analytical Services. ``As long as they're making the company money, that's all that's important.'' According to the proxies, the biggest pay jump belonged to PaineWebber Inc. chairman Donald B. Marron, who was paid $2.05 million, 64 percent more than in 1988. The firm's profits rose 23 percent. Presidents and chairmen aren't necessarily the best-paid players on Wall Street. Traders who generate large amounts of business typically received bonuses commensurate with their performance. An extreme example is former Drexel Lambert Inc. junk bond director Michael Milken, who for more than a decade received a fixed percentage of income generated by the high-yield bond division. He was paid $550 million in 1987 alone. Wall Street firms are expected to use the industry downturn as a reason for continuing to trim compensation in 1990, their largest expense, analysts said. ``The concern is that on average they will not be able in 1990 to increase their revenue much if any, yet costs continue to rise,'' Long said. ``As a consequence, (profit) margins are squeezed.''

DOC.HEAD: Fannie Mae's Profit Up 67 Percent in First Quarter
DOC.TEXT: The nation's largest investor in home mortgages, the Federal National Mortgage Association, on Wednesday reported record first- quarter profit of $277 million, up 67 percent from the same period last year. Fannie Mae attributed the increase mostly to higher interest income on all investments and the success of mortgage-backed securities, which surpassed last year's first-quarter total by 54 percent. The first-quarter net income of $277 million, or $1.06 a share, compared with $165 million, or 66 cents a share, in the first quarter of 1989. ``Fannie Mae's ninth consecutive quarter of record earnings was based on solid fundamentals,'' said Chief Executive Officer David O. Maxwell. ``We issued the largest volume of mortgage-backed securities in any first quarter, and, properties acquired through foreclosures dropped to their lowest level since peaking in 1987.'' Fannie Mae foreclosed on 2,455 properties in the first quarter of this year, a 44 percent decline from the third quarter of 1987. There were 2,975 foreclosures in the first quarter of 1989. The guaranty fees from these securities increased to $121 million in the first quarter of 1990 from $111 million in the fourth quarter of 1989 and $94 million in the first quarter of 1989. Fannie Mae also said earnings were up due to fees of $18.5 million earned from issuing mortgage investment securities and stripped mortgage-backed securities. This miscellaneous income in both the first and fourth quarters of 1989 was adversely affected by several ``non-recurring charges,'' the company said. The congressionally chartered, shareholder-owned company reported 240,530,000 outstanding shares at the end of March.

DOC.HEAD: CBS Posts 52 Percent Profit Gain in 1st Qtr
DOC.TEXT: CBS Inc. said Wednesday its broadcasts of the Super Bowl and the NCAA basketball tournament fueled a 52 percent increase in its first-quarter profit despite disappointing ratings for its prime time entertainment lineup. But Laurence A. Tisch, the CBS president and chief executive, said the company's second-half outlook is ``uncertain due to a sluggish national economy, heightened competition for television viewers and higher sports rights costs.'' CBS, which operates the CBS Television Network and owns five TV stations, said it earned $85.3 million, or $3.31 per share, in the three months ended March 31 compared with $56.1 million, or $2.18 a share, a year earlier. Revenue rose 16 percent to $851 million from $730.6 million in 1989. The operating profit at the company's broadcast group climbed 89 percent to $87.1 million. The company said the broadcast of the Super Bowl pro football championship in January helped the television network report ``markedly higher'' sales and operating income for the quarter. The network also benefitted from strong advertiser demand for time during the NCAA basketball tournament broadcasts and the shift into the first quarter of the tournament's semifinal games, CBS said. The championship game was played April 2, two days into the second quarter. Profitability of the CBS television stations was aided by the Super Bowl broadcast, the company said. Tisch called the network's primetime ratings performance a ``disappointment.'' The network generally has trailed both NBC and ABC in the ratings for the evening audiences for the past three seasons. Networks can usually charge advertisers more when they have higher ratings. The company said it had net interest income of $41.7 million in the latest quarter, up from $39.4 million a year earlier. Its cash and marketable securities amounted to $2.9 billion at the end of the quarter, CBS said. It has generated the cash through sale over the past few years of several large businesses, including its magazines, records and music publishing operations. In the past few months, CBS has agreed to pay about $3.6 billion for rights to broadcast major league baseball, pro football, college basketball and the next two Winter Olympics.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed; Gold Down
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Precedes LONDON-BC
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended narrowly mixed Wednesday in thin trading as dealers shrugged off continued efforts by some European central banks to shore up the Japanese yen at the expense of the U.S. currency. Gold prices fell. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $374.30 a troy ounce, down 70 cents from late Tuesday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $374.75 an ounce, 75 cents lower. Currency dealers said the dollar selling against the yen by some European central banks had little impact on the dollar's level against the yen, which has been under pressure in recent weeks amid growing signs of a weakening Japanese economy. Most dealers said they saw the intervention, which followed a similar move on Monday, as orders executed on behalf of the Bank of Japan rather than any concerted effort by the Group of Seven industrialized nations to stem the yen's weakness. ``It was a token appearance,'' said Zlatko Glamuzina, chief dealer at the New York office of Banco di Sicilia. ``If the central banks wanted to support the yen, they should have sold their own currencies for yen ... because the yen is weak against all currencies.'' Trading was described as extremely thin Wednesday because of the Passover holiday and in advance of the upcoming Easter holiday. In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar rose 0.35 Japanese yen to close at 158.50 yen. It was later quoted at 158.15 yen in London and at 157.95 yen in New York, up from 157.60 yen late Tuesday. The dollar was mixed against the British pound. Sterling bought $1.6427 in London, up from $1.6345; and $1.6425 in New York, down from $1.6451 Tuesday. Against the West German mark, the dollar fell to 1.6735 marks in London from 1.6900 marks Tuesday. It traded at 1.6720 marks in New York, down from 1.6750. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's quotes, included: 1.4800 Swiss francs, down from 1.4830; 5.6210 French francs, down from 5.6285; 1,230.25 Italian lire, up from 1,230.16; and 1.1644 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1692. Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with Tuesday: 1.4835 Swiss francs, down from 1.4955; 5.6255 French francs, down from 5.6750; 1.8870 Dutch guilders, down from 1.9030; 1,231.75 Italian lire, down from 1,240.00; and 1.1648 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1613. Gold traded in London at $374.75 an ounce, down from late Tuesday's bid of $375.15. In Zurich, Switzerland, the bid for gold fell to $374 an ounce from $375.25. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell $1.84 to close at a bid of $375.13 an ounce. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.129 a troy ounce, up from $5.091 late Tuesday. Silver fell in London to $5.11 an ounce from $5.13.

DOC.HEAD: Defective Fire-Treated Plywood Prompts Lawsuits
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 8th graf to CORRECT attribution to Reinhart; picks up 9th graf pvs, Reinhart blamed...
DOC.TEXT: Decomposition of fire-retardant plywood installed in townhouses in many East Coast states is setting off a legal battle that could last years before the courts assign liability for repair bills, officials said Wednesday. Builders primarily used the fire-resistant treated plywood in townhouses during the housing boom of the early 1980s, said Bill Young, the consumer affairs director for the Washington-based National Association of Home Builders. Builders in other parts of the nation used a code that had not yet permitted use of the treated plywood, also known as FRTP, he said. Attorneys for builders and homeowner associations are suing dozens of wood treatment companies and homeowners' warranty companies seeking payment of the $2,000 to $3,000 needed to replace the defective plywood in each of 1 million units Young estimates have the treated product. ``It's such a mess, a real monster lawsuit,'' said Peter Reinhart, an attorney representing one of New Jersey's largest developers, K. Hovnanian Inc. He said he expects the unraveling of the cases to take at least five years. Not all the plywood is defective. Researchers are conducting tests at the U.S. Forest Products Laboratory in Madison, Wis., to determine the weaker strains of treated plywood, which Young said was used in multifamily housing. Although lawsuits are pending in Connecticut and Florida, New Jersey seems to be a special focus of the litigation _ 45 lawsuits _ because the problem was first discovered there in 1987, said E. Richard Kennedy, a homeowner association attorney who is handling more than 30 cases in New Jersey. Reinhart said K. Hovnanian began seeking relief in the courts after two workers were injured at a condominium in the town of Lawrenceville when a roof gave way, costing $750,000 in repair. Reinhart blamed much of the legal fight on homeowner warranty corporations unwilling to pay for the repairs. ``They say it's not a major structural defect,'' Reinhart said. ``It's crazy. All the homeowners are looking for is somebody to pay the repairs.'' Ken Kanline, the vice president of sales and marketing for Washington-based Homeowners Warranty Corp., said the policies written since 1981 have not included roof sheathing as a major structural defect after the first year. He said the company made its decision before problems arose with the plywood and because too often the warping was cosmetic. ``You had a situation where in the sixth year of a home it wouldn't be a structural claim, but it looked cosmetically unsightly,'' he said. Kanline said the company had received about 120 claims from Virginia and New Jersey, all of which were rejected. New Jersey state Sen. Thomas Paterniti introduced a bill in the Legislature last week that would set up a state ``Superfund'' to allow homeowners to collect repair money immediately. The state Department of Community Affairs is awaiting word from consultants on its proposed regulations that the plywood be able to withstand humidity of 100 percent and temperatures of at least 220 degrees, said department spokesman Jay Johnston. Homeowners of the units with the fire-resistant treated plywood should not go up on the roof but instead check inside an attic for signs of decay, experts say. Signs to look for are if the plywood's normal light creamy brown color has darkened, if the plywood's smooth surface has turned brittle and splintery or if a white powdery substance is building up. The white powder is a leeching of the salts used to make the plywood fire retardant. Heat on the roof as low as 150 degrees can prompt the decay, Young said. Charles L'Hommedieu, the regional director for CNR Realty and Management Co., a property concern in Teaneck, N.J., said his company is continuing to investigate its projects for problems which could arise as time passes. ``These roof systems are projected to start failing within six years,'' he said. Young minimized the problem's effect on housing prices, emphasizing instead the problems created by the plywood for real estate agents. ``I wouldn't say it's significant in depressing prices,'' Young said. ``It is a major concern for people who sell houses. By law they're required to disclose it. That gets sort of messy for people who just find out about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Orange Juice Futures Surge on Bullish Supply Report
DOC.TEXT: Orange juice futures prices leaped Wednesday on the New York Cotton Exchange after the government projected a smaller Florida orange harvest than the market had expected. On other commodity markets, oil futures advanced, ending a six-day price slide; livestock and meat futures were mixed; grains and soybeans were mixed and precious metals were mixed. Prices for future deliveries of frozen concentrated orange juice settled 1.95 cents to 4.85 cents higher in New York, with the contract for delivery in May up 2.55 cents at $1.983 a pound. Analysts said the runup was prompted mainly by the Agriculture Department's monthly orange crop report, which contained the same harvest projections as in March _ 172 million 90-pound boxes, including 103.1 million boxes from Florida. The report was released Tuesday after the close of trading. Speculators were expecting an upward revision in the crop projections and had sold orange juice futures aggressively in the week prior to the report. The May contract had fallen a total of 7.45 cents in the five sessions ending Tuesday. Tuesday's Florida crop projection was about 30 percent below the 1988-89 Florida harvest of 146.6 million boxes, reflecting severe damage caused by a freeze around Christmas. The tight-supply situation created by the freeze has resulted in increased speculator activity and volatility in the orange juice futures market. Sandra Kaul, an analyst with Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., said there are indications a large number of speculators still hold short positions _ meaning contracts to deliver orange juice _ which could lead to more strong rallies as those traders ``cover their shorts'' by buying offsetting contracts. ``There should be massive covering at some point,'' Ms. Kaul said. ``We see explosive rallies in the near future toward at least $2.10 to $2.20.'' Oil futures ended mostly higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange after a day of wild price swings linked to supply concerns. Prices veered lower as trading opened, extending the steep losses posted in the six previous sessions. But by late afternoon the market had recovered the day's lost ground and had risen above Tuesday's close. Analysts said the early move reflected the American Petroleum Institute's report, released after the market closed Tuesday, that U.S. crude oil inventories rose by a larger-than-expected 8.1 million barrels last week. But prices rebounded sharply later in the session after rumors circulated that OPEC nations were consulting by telephone and considering calling an emergency meeting to discuss the recent drop in oil prices. West Texas Intermediate crude settled 29 cents lower to 38 cents higher with May at $18.06 a barrel; heating oil was .60 cent to 1.23 cent higher with May at 53.63 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .55 cent to 1.20 cents higher with May at 59.58 cents a gallon. Live cattle futures reached a record high of 80.40 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange, reflecting record-high prices paid for fed cattle in the Southern Plains. The previous high, posted in 1979, was 80.25 cents a pound. Pork futures rose sharply, with pork bellies surging the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound after a weekly exchange report showed lower-than-expected belly stocks. Live cattle finished .22 cent lower to .15 cent higher with April at 80.37 cents a pound; feeder cattle were unchanged to .30 cent lower with April at 83.80 cents a pound; live hogs were .30 cent to 1.20 cents higher with April at 56.02 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.15 cents to 2 cents higher with May at 57.80 cents a pound. Futures prices of grain and soybeans see-sawed to a mixed close on the Chicago Board of Trade. Corn futures turned in a surprisingly weak performance in light of a shrinking national corn stockpile. Traders had expected corn futures to rally after Tuesday's monthly Agriculture Department supply-and-demand report, which projected Sept. 1 corn stocks of 1.33 billion bushels, down from March's estimate of 1.48 billion. Wheat futures settled unchanged to 2} cents higher with May at $3.64} a bushel; corn was 1{ cents lower to \ cent higher with May at $2.71\ a bushel; oats were unchanged to \ cent lower with May at $1.51 a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents to 3{ cents higher with May at $5.92} a bushel. On New York's Commodity Exchange, gold futures ended 70 cents to 1.10 cents lower with April at $374.30 a troy ounce; silver was 3.4 cents to 3.8 cents higher with April at $5.129 a troy ounce.

DOC.HEAD: Credit Rating Agency Puts Time Warner Debt Under Watch
DOC.TEXT: Standard & Poor's Corp. is taking a closer look at its ratings on about $7.1 billion in long-term public debt and preferred stock of Time Warner Inc. because of the media and entertainment giant's new financial agreement with Pathe Communications Corp. Standard & Poor's, one of the nation's leading credit rating services, said it was placing $1.5 billion in Time Warner debt and $5.6 billion of its preferred stock on its CreditWatch listing with negative implications. The move is not an actual credit downgrade, which if undertaken would increase Time Warner's borrowing costs. The action, announced Tuesday, followed Time Warner's announcement that it had agreed to help arrange $650 million of the $1.2 billion that Pathe would need to complete its acquistion of MGM-UA Communications Co. S&P said in its statement that the arrangement amounted to a guarantee that ``is expected to increase Time Warner's already substantial financial risk.'' Time Warner took on about $10.6 billion in debt last year when the former Time Inc. acquired Warner Communications Inc. The ratings agency said ``Time Warner's own bank agreement calls for sizable repayments in March 1992 (extendable to March 1993) which will require refinancing in a now more difficult environment for financing highly leveraged deals.'' In exchange for the financing, Time Warner would obtain the right to acquire warrants that would amount to a 20 percent stake in the combined Pathe-MGM-UA company at some point. Time Warner's Warner Bros. studio also reportedly would enter into a ``support services'' agreement under which it would handle Pathe and MGM-UA releases for distribution in theaters, on television and on videocassettes. In its own statement, Time Warner said, ``We believe strongly in the long-term worldwide benefits of our agreement, both to Warner Bros. and to Pathe.'' It said the value of the UA library, which is being pledged as security for the financing, ``significantly exceeds the $650 million provided in this deal.'' Even as it placed Time Warner on CreditWatch, S&P said the agency ``continues to view Time Warner's business positions, cash-generating capacity and asset values favorably despite the company's aggressive profile.''

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Say McGowan's Hospitalization Won't Hurt MCI
DOC.TEXT: Industry analysts said Wednesday that MCI Communications Corp. won't be hurt by the hospitalization of the phone company's founder and chairman, William G. McGowan. McGowan, who had a heart transplant three years ago, underwent exploratory chest surgery Tuesday at Presbyterian-University Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was listed in fair condition Wednesday. Doctors decided last week to operate after ``they discovered a condition'' during a routine checkup, said MCI spokeswoman Kathleen Keegan. She would not say what the condition was. His doctor, Bartley Griffith, said the surgery was unrelated to the heart transplant but would not elaborate. McGowan, 62, was expected to be hospitalized for five to seven days. Charles Nichols, an analyst with Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., said McGowan is not in charge of day-to-day operations at MCI, so his hospitalization should not be a blow to the company. Nichols said MCI, based in Washington, D.C., is run on a daily basis by its president and chief operating officer, Bert C. Roberts Jr., and its chief financial officer, Daniel F. Akerson. ``I think MCI is a very well-run company with a very strong management team,'' added Charles Schelke, an analyst at Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Co. ``As important as McGowan has been, it's certainly more than a one-man company.'' Interest in McGowan's surgery was heightened by MCI's announced deal to acquire Telecom USA Inc., the nation's fourth-largest long-distance company. MCI, the No. 2 long-distance phone company after American Telephone & Telegraph Co., announced the $1.25 billion acquisition on Monday. The company's disclosure of McGowan's hospitalization came a day later. MCI officials knew Monday that the chairman was scheduled to enter the hospital that night, but decided to delay an announcement until more was known about his condition, Ms. Keegan said. ``As soon as we knew how the surgery had gone we announced,'' she said. She said McGowan presided over an MCI board of directors meeting Sunday night, conducted by telephone conference call, at which the board approved the Telecom deal.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Says Regulators Arbitrarily Slashed Lincoln's Portfolio
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th graf pvs bg'ng, The document, to CORRECT $1.85 million to $1.85 billion; Also moved on general newswires
DOC.TEXT: To justify seizing Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, regulators arbitrarily wrote down the value of its $1.4 billion loan portfolio by 50 percent and slashed the worth of its extensive land, hotel and stock holdings by 75 percent, the thrift's former owner said Wednesday. ``Without any analysis, they took the entire loan portfolio and said it was non-performing,'' Phoenix financier Charles H. Keating Jr. testified in his fifth day on the witness stand in his suit seeking to recover the Irvine, Calif., S&L. Reading from a Federal Home Loan Bank Board analysis of Lincoln's loan and equity portfolios prepared a week after the government imposed a conservatorship April 14, 1989, Keating called the numbers ``absurd.'' The analysis, in the form of an April 21, 1989 memo from regulators in charge of the Lincoln case to bank board officials in Washington, is the first government document specifying regulators' estimate that alleged losses of federally insured deposits by the thrift could cost taxpayers $2 billion. The document estimated that the thrift's assets were worth only $2 billion to $2.5 billion, or $1.85 billion to $2.2 billion less than what they were listed as on Lincoln's books at the time. For nearly a year, Keating has asserted that he ran Lincoln soundly and that regulators could show that the thrift was insolvent only by placing a lower value on its assets. Comparing the figures from the regulators' analysis with those provided by American Continental's chief financial officer, he testified Wednesday that only 3 percent of Lincoln's $1.4 billion mortage loan portfolio was more than 60 days in default. All of the loans, Keating testifed, were fully secured with the borrowers putting up an average 20 percent down payment on the property. The regulators, however, listed the value of those loans at only $703 million, accounting for a third of the losses they claim that Lincoln suffered. Robert Wurzelbacher, Keating's son-in-law who headed Lincoln's real estate investments, likened the analysis to a family buying a $100,000 home with a $20,000 down payment and an $80,000 loan. Then a regulator comes in and says the value of the home and the loan on it is worth only $40,000, even though the monthly payments are still being made, he said. James Murphy, an attorney representing the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision, repeatedly objected to Keating comparing the numbers from the regulators' April 21 analysis and Keating's own figures on the status of Lincoln's loans and equity holdings as of Dec. 31, 1988. ``This is not by any stretch of the imagination the last word on the implementation of the receivership'' four months later, Murphy said. The Office of Thrift Supervision succeeded the Federal Home Loan Bank Board as the industry's chief regulator under the $50 billion savings and loan bailout passed last year by Congress. The government seized control of Lincoln in April last year under the conservatorship, claiming that it was being grossly mismanaged but making no assertion at the time that it was insolvent. It wasn't until August that the regulators asserted that Lincoln's alleged losses actually exceeded the value of its assets and imposed a receivership that took ownership of the thrift from Keating. U.S. District Court Judge Stanley Sporkin overruled Murphy's objections, but said he wanted testimony from Keating's chief financial officer in addition to hearing from regulators on their justifications for the writedowns. ``You don't write down 50 percent on a mortgage portfolio,'' said Sporkin, who is a former accountant and was at one time the chief enforcement officer for the Securities and Exchange Commission. Keating's attorneys also introduced documents showing that regulators were unhappy with the performance of the consultant they hired at an annual salary of $300,000 to run Lincoln after seizing control from Keating. In a July 19, 1989, memo to the bank board's top officials in Washington, Mark Randall, the government official in charge of managing the conservatorship, said the consultant, Roger Clark, failed to address Lincoln's major problems. ``Roger Clark's inaction, questionable judgment and lack of participation establish his inability to function as a CEO (chief executive officer) of Lincoln,'' Randall's memo read. Keating said that Clark is still holds titles as both the CEO and chief financial officer of Lincoln under a contract that requires the government to pay him a $100,000 termination fee but that other officials are actually running the thrift under the receivership.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Alcohol Consumption Expected To Decline Further; Beer Again No. 1
DOC.TEXT: Beer was by far the nation's most popular alcoholic beverage last year, with Americans consuming nearly 34 gallons per capita, an industry publication reported Wednesday. The industry publication Market Watch, using computer-driven figures to make its estimates, also forecast that by the year 2000 consumption would be lower for virtually all types of wine, spirits and beer. Americans age 21 or older drank an estimated 33.79 gallons per capita of beers in 1989, a figure Market Watch expects will drop by about 4.5 gallons in the next 10 years. Consumption was 34.1 gallons in 1988, according to other industry estimates. Wine consumption is expected to drop from 2.54 gallons per capita in 1989 to 2.12 gallons. Consumption was 3.23 gallons per capita in 1988. Distilled spirits will dip most sharply from 2.15 gallons to 1.63 gallons. Spirits consumption was 2.2 gallons per capita in 1988. Like other industry observers and economists, the publication blamed the effects of health warning labels and anti-alcohol lobbyists as major factors in the general decline of beverage alcohol. The industry also is expected to be affected by added state and federal taxes come on. Many states reportedly are considering added alcohol taxes. In California, voters in November will decide whether to raise the tax on wine from one cent a gallon to $1.29 a gallon; on beer, from 4 cents a gallon to 57.3 cents a gallon; and on distilled spirits, from $2 a gallon to $8.40 a gallon. Per capita consumption of wine, in terms of gallons per person 21 years and over, is currently 2.54 gallons. The leader is table wine (still wine not over 14 percent alcohol), 1.96 gallons, followed by dessert wine (port, sherry) 0.19 gallons; champagnes, 0.23 gallons; and special natural (two or more different fruit products), 0.13 gallons. For distilled spirits, per capita consumption is 2.15 gallons, led by whiskey, 0.81 gallons; bourbon, 0.23; blends, 0.14; Scotch, 0.17; Canadian, 0.26; Irish, 0.01; gin, 0.19; vodka, 0.53; rum, 0.18, and tequila, 0.07. In the specialty category, per capita consumption is 0.38 gallons, led by cordials and liqueurs, 0.25 gallons; brandy 0.11 gallons, and cocktails and mixed drinks, 0.02 gallons. Domestic beers account for 32.24 gallons per capita, and imported 1.55 gallons.

DOC.HEAD: Time Warner, Viacom Reportedly Discussing Merging Comedy Cable Networks
DOC.TEXT: Time Warner Inc. and Viacom Inc. are discussing merging their fledgling comedy cable networks, The Comedy Channel and Ha!, sources at both companies said Wednesday. The companies had previously discussed but failed to agree on merging their comedy networks, according to one of the sources, who spoke on condition they not be identified. The Wall Street Journal reported Wednesday that executives and attorneys from both companies said Time Warner and Viacom are discussing a 50-50 joint venture in a single comedy channel, or a venture that would include equity investments by a group of cable operators. A spokesman for Time Warner said the company had no comment on the report. A spokeswoman for Viacom read a statement from Viacom Chairman Sumner Redstone which said, ``Under all the circumstances that exist in this situation, we prefer not to comment in the media.'' Both companies are believed to be facing trouble lining up cable TV systems that will give them a space on the channel selector. Many cable systems have already filled their available channel space and are reluctant to drop current networks in favor of new ones. Time Warner launched The Comedy Channel last November and says that it has 6 million subscribers. Viacom started its Ha! cable network on April 1. Industry analysts say it generally takes 25 million to 30 million subscribers for a cable network to break even. The two networks follow different programming formats, with The Comedy Channel relying on original programs and snippets from comedy series and movies while Ha! features reruns of sitcoms and programs such as ``Saturday Night Live.'' Time Warner and Viacom are embroiled in a lawsuit in which Viacom's Showtime Networks is asking for $2.5 billion in damages against Time Warner's Home Box Office. Showtime contends that HBO monopolizes the pay-television business in violation of antitrust laws.

DOC.HEAD: Ames Cuts 200 Jobs At Headquarters
DOC.NOTE: EDS: NEW grafs 6-9 to UPDATE with stock activity; picks up 8th graf pvs bg'ng, Ames has ...
DOC.TEXT: Ames Department Stores Inc., the troubled retailer that announced plans earlier this week to close 74 stores, said Wednesday it was cutting 200 jobs in its corporate headquarters. The company said in a brief announcement that 50 employees will be laid off and another 150 vacant jobs will not be filled. The cuts will leave 1,650 workers at the company's Hartford-area headquarters. In January, the company eliminated 325 jobs at its headquarters, 85 through layoffs and 240 by not filling vacancies. The retailer has stumbled repeatedly since its 1988 purchase of nearly 400 Zayre stores. With the purchase, Ames doubled in size and instantly transformed itself from a little-known, New England-based chain into the nation's fourth-largest discounter. Only K mart Corp., Wal-Mart Stores Inc. and the Target division of Dayton Hudson Corp. are bigger. The company, which operates 690 stores, announced Monday that it would report a loss of $228 million for the year ended Jan. 27. Ames also said Monday it was negotiating with its banks for a new credit agreement. Ames stock stabilized Wednesday after dropping steadily beginning last Thursday, when the retailer announced that its sales in March were down 12 percent. The stock, which was trading at $9 a share on the New York Stock Exchange in early January, closed at $4.37{ last Thursday and dropped even further, to $2.37{, after a day of heavy trading Tuesday. In more heavy trading Wednesday, Ames stock closed at $2.50, up 12{ cents. In late 1987, Ames shares were worth nearly $30 each. Ames has attributed its troubles to the sluggish retail market in the Northeast and to problems with the former Zayre stores. The company has been unable to revitalize the stores by renaming them and has even lost some Zayre customers by changing that chain's advertising and pricing policies. The Zayre stores had been known for frequent promotions, heavy advertising and discounted fashion items. Ames, in contrast, stocks more traditional merchandise and runs fewer promotions. ``Ames management is learning that it is very difficult to wean the customer from a promotional vendor,'' said L. Wayne Hood, a retailing analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. Further, the company's attempts to quickly merge Ames and Zayre computer systems resulted in some glitches that delayed payments to suppliers, which led some suppliers to cut off the chain's credit. Ames bought the 392-store Zayre chain on Oct. 28, 1988, for $800 million, doubling its size. It has since closed some of those stores and converted others to the Ames name. The 74 stores to be closed are primarily former Zayre stores in Florida, Illinois, Indiana and Ohio, said Douglas W. Ewing, Ames director of investor relations. Ames announced in December 1989 that it was closing 18 stores, mostly in the Northeast.

DOC.HEAD: Greyhound Says Easter Weekend Could Put It Over The Top
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS throughout to Schmieder sted Schmeider.
DOC.TEXT: A strong Easter holiday weekend could boost Greyhound Lines Inc. to the financial break-even point as it attempts to rebuild from a lengthy bus drivers strike, says President Frank Schmieder. The five-day Easter travel period ending Monday is one of the five busiest times of the year for Greyhound. Schmieder said in an interview this week that the company projects revenue in the next few days will be between 70 percent and 73 percent of revenue at the same time last year. ``Seventy-three percent of revenue is cash break even, and when we do that, we figure we've turned the corner,'' said Schmieder. Jeffrey Nelson, a spokesman for the Amalgamated Council of Greyhound Local Unions, called Greyhound's latest claims ``preposterous.'' ``They've been claiming the turned corners for the last six weeks,'' said Nelson. The company's 6,300 drivers and about 3,000 of its office and maintenance workers walked out March 2 in an argument over wages and job security. Greyhound has been operating a reduced schedule since, using permanent replacements and drivers willing to cross picket lines. Negotiations have been stalled since last month. The company has refused to bargain until seven days have passed without major violence against its buses, which have been hit by gunfire and suffered other attacks. The company also filed a $30 million federal lawsuit earlier this week charging the union was behind the violence. The union claims the company is using the violence as an excuse to avoid negotiations. Greyhound has increased service in stages, with the latest addition scheduled for Thursday when the company plans to add almost 100,000 miles, putting it at 458,595 miles, or 71.8 percent of pre-strike levels. Schmieder said on March 28 that the strike was ``essentially over'' in much of the country, as the company continued expanding to cover more of its pre-strike routes. Union officials claim Greyhound actually is operating only about 20 percent of its pre-strike routes. Through Easter, Greyhound is offering free tickets if its buses are late in the busy Northeast, where strike service has been hardest hit. Schmieder said the promotion has been effective, with about 800 passengers, or 1.4 percent of the total, getting free tickets in the first five days of the offer. Business in the region has risen to about 12,000 passengers a day from around 8,000. Passenger volumes nationwide totaled more than more than 56 percent of the volume for the same day last year, according to company figures. P. Anthony Lannie, Greyhound's executive vice president, said the company should be serving 95 percent of its routes by summer, although cutbacks are possible when the slower fall season arrives. Lannie said Greyhound will have 3,200 drivers by May 1, but will need at least 1,000 more to meet summer demand. While passenger traffic may be growing, the company is missing out on money from its small package express business, which accounted for about $92 million of Greyhound's $1.04 billion in revenue last year. Schmieder said the package business is at about 45 percent of year-earlier levels, although he expects the increased service to raise that to 50 percent. Greyhound's charter operation, which last year brought in $90 million, has been almost non-existent during the strike as the company has used drivers for its mainline operations. Greyhound Lines was created three years ago in a debt-financed buyout of the bus operations of Greyhound Corp. Later that year, Greyhound Lines also bought the Dallas-based operator of the largest Trailways bus system. Despite its reduced cash flow, Greyhound has continued to pay its bills, Schmieder says. The next interest payment is due May 15, ``and if we had to make the payment today, we could do it.''

DOC.HEAD: Raytheon Reports 8.4 Percent Increase in First-Quarter Earnings
DOC.TEXT: Raytheon Inc. said gains in its defense electronics, aircraft and energy divisions helped boost earnings by 8.4 percent in the first quarter on a 7.3 percent rise in sales. ``Raytheon continues to grow on the strength of its diverse government and commercial business base,'' said Thomas L. Phillips, the company's chairman and chief executive officer. Earnings in the period rose to $130.9 million, or $2 a share, from $120.8 million, or $1.83 a share, in the first three months of 1989. Sales rose to $2.225 billion from $2.07 billion. ``During the first quarter, our electronics segment _ led by government electronics _ performed well, the aircraft and energy services segment continued a rapid profit growth, and all five business segments remained profitable,'' he said. Raytheon said its order backlog rose to $9.49 billion at the end of the first quarter, including $6.84 billion in government orders, from $8.88 billion a year earlier, including $6.78 billion from the government. In addition to making missiles and other defense electronics, Raytheon's operations include Beech Aircraft and Amana appliances.

DOC.HEAD: District Court Rejects Norton Bid To Postpone Shareholders Meeting
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge Wednesday delivered a blow to Norton Co. by rejecting the company's attempt to postpone a key shareholders meeting to buy more time to thwart a hostile takeover bid by a British company. U.S. District Court Judge Joseph L. Tauro ordered Norton's board to restore the annual shareholders meeting to its original date of April 26. The company's directors had canceled that meeting and rescheduled it for June 26, in an effort to give themselves more time to fight a $1.6 billion, $75-a-share offer from BTR PLC, a British conglomerate. Norton, a maker of grinding tools and sandpaper, has rejected the offer as ``inadequate.'' The company moved to postpone the shareholder meeting on March 29 after BTR executives said they were considering waging a proxy fight to unseat Norton's board at the meeting. A spokesman for Norton said the company planned to appeal the ruling in the U.S. District Court of Appeals. ``If the Appeals Court allows BTR to compel Norton to hold the April 26 meeting, Norton shareholders will be forced to make an irrevocable decision as to the future of Norton before the Norton Board has had a reasonable opportunity to explore alternatives to the BTR offer,'' John M. Nelson, chairman and chief executive officer, said in a statement. BTR welcomed the ruling in a statement, saying it would give shareholders ``a timely opportunity'' to press management to remove obstacles to the offer. BTR's bid has aroused protests by Norton workers and local officials who fear the Worcester company would be dismantled. BTR officials have disputed those claims.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Department Joins Suit Claiming Overcharges on Jet Parts
DOC.TEXT: The federal government joined a former Northrop Corp. employee Wednesday in suing the defense contractor for allegedly over-billing the Navy by millions of dollars on parts for the FA-18 fighter-bomber. Northrop was accused of developing in 1985 an improved, cheaper way of producing composite fuselage parts for the plane without passing on the savings to the Navy or telling the Pentagon about the improvement. The civil suit, one of several accusing Northrop of over-billing or improper testing, was filed by former employee Eldon Janssen under a federal act that allows people to sue government suppliers for alleged fraud. Details of the action were unsealed after the government intervened Wednesday. ``The government has not yet determined the exact amount of the damages,'' the Justice Department said in a statement. ``Estimates, however, range into the millions of dollars.'' Northrop spokesman Tony Cantafio declined to comment because officials had not seen the lawsuit. The lawsuit is one in a series of legal actions against Northrop. Last month, the Justice Department sued Northrop for more than $5 million in civil damages after the company pleaded guilty in a criminal case to lying about performing all required tests on parts for the Marine Corps' AV-8B Harrier jet. The company agreed to pay a $17 million fine in a criminal case concerning the Harrier. Northrop also has been accused of making political payoffs to South Koreans and overcharging the Air Force by $20 billion on the B-2 stealth bomber. The B-2 suit, like the action over the FA-18, was a so-called ``whistle blower'' case filed by former employees.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Contractor and Two Employees Face Sentencing on Federal Charges
DOC.TEXT: A defense contractor and two employees face sentencing in federal court after pleading guilty to charges of failing to test bolts for use in combat aircraft, including the F-16 fighter and the B-1B bomber. Norman McHaffie and the workers at his Sylmar company, McHaffie Inc., also pleaded guilty to submitting fraudulent certificates to the military that the bolts had been tested and met all specifications. McHaffie, James Hick and William Whitman entered the pleas Monday, and sentencing was set for June 18, said U.S. attorney spokeswoman Grace Denton. If convicted, McHaffie's company could face a maximum of $1.5 million in fines. McHaffie, 56, could be sentenced to 15 years in prison and $750,000. Hicks, 45, and Whitham, 37, cooperated with the government in the case, prosecutors said. Each faces a possible maximum sentence of 10 years in prison and $500,000 fines. The charges of conspiracy and false statements stem from practices over an eight-year-period, authorities say. McHaffie was accused of telling Hicks, his quality control supervisor, and Whitman, his production shop floor manager, to create fake test data and fabricate reports to conceal the fraud, the government's complaint alleged. ``Later, after the government became aware of the scheme, McHaffie and Hicks decided to destroy the falsified documents to conceal the scope of the fraud from government auditors,'' said a statement from the U.S. attorney's office.

DOC.HEAD: United Reduces Discount Fares Between Northeast and California
DOC.TEXT: United Airlines said it was reducing its discount fares between points in the Northeast and California by an average of 15 percent for travel May 1 through June 11. The new round-trip fare will be $358 from noon Monday through noon Thursday and $398 during the rest of the week. Those are reductions of $60 and $70, respectively, from current fares, United said Wednesday.
